Posted: January 17, 2014
												Broken Age exceeded all of my expectations. The artwork is beautiful and the world is wonderfully crafted with so much character and life. I've been a fan of adventure games since I was a kid but for about 10 years now it's been really hard to find quality adventure games that make you fall in love with the world and the characters. This is exactly the game that's been missing. The story is engaging and keeps you guessing until the end. The voice acting is excellent. There were numerous laugh out loud moments where my husband and I were in stitches. We chose to switch between the two stories regularly which kept us engaged in both worlds. Thank you Double Fine for delivering such an amazing game that pushes the boundaries for the genre with the stunning art and the depth of the story.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2015
												The game only took about 5 1/2 hours to beat and was frankly unsatisfying. The plot/game world made no sense and the comedy was weak. Art wise the game has been consistently bad, it looks like barely any effort was put in. There's a weeks worth of background art and a days worth of character design in there. The puzzles were needlessly long, requiring a fair bit of running around through the same 6 or so screens. This only inflated the game length rather than add difficulty or enjoyment. If they put the objects for each puzzle within one or two rooms then this game would be even shorter. It's not the difficulty of the puzzles that takes so long, it's having to go back and forth and jot things down on a bit of paper. The only reason it took me as long as it did to complete this game is because I went into act 2 expecting not to need any paper. If you went in fully prepared you could probably beat the game in under 5 hours (not skipping dialogue).The Book of Unwritten Tales series and Deponia are far superior. Wouldn't buy this game for more than £8 if I hadn't already paid as much as I did. Tis a shame I can not get a refund.

												tl;dr: If you really have to: Play it until Mog Chothra crashes and stop. Just stop. You will be left with many open questions, but you are spared the shere disappointment of the rest of the game.===========Episode 2Wow... disregard everything I said for episode 1, episode 2 is just abysmal in every way imaginable.Puzzles are different in being very poorly executed and some of them are just infuriating illogical. Add the necessity to switch between Vella and Shay for some solutions which have no connection at all, but "feel familiar" when solved. It's as if you suddenly introduce new mechanics mid game, no one's expecting..., oh right. There is a difference between difficult and arbitrary, which Double Fine didn't seem to grasp.So puzzles are a big no-no, what about all the open questions and mistery leaving you very hyped at the end of episode 1?Yeah, they are answered after 5min playtime and don't think there are twists like in episode 1 anywhere. You could just skip the rest of the game, because there is nothing important left to learn.Everything about this episode feels rushed and unpolished and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.I'm kind of happy I waited 5 months, so my expectations hit gorund level and my disappointment wasn't as big, but it's still big enough to update this review.Double Fine, we are done.===========Episode 1:I really would like to recommend this beautiful marvel, but there are so many problems attached to it.Imagine the Mona Lisa but with only one half of the smile and everything else missing. There is just a sticky note saying "coming soon". You can clearly see, this note has dust on it.Get this image? That's Broken Age for you. And "Broken" could not be more fitting.[this review may change if episode 2 comes out, but I do not expect this to happen in 2015]

												I saw so many negative reviews on this game, but I still gave it a chance because it looks beautiful and the voice cast is amazing! I have to say, this is one of my favorite games of all time. It is simple, but the art is stunningly beautiful and I adore the world, the characters, and the crazy storyline. number of helpful: 24 of 39 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												Broken Age is a game of two halves thanks to how development went and it really feels like it, as they completely changed how the game was from one act to another. Act 1 is all about setting up the story with a few puzzles here and there but nothing that will get in the way of enjoying the experience. Then you get to Act 2 and it feels like you're hitting a wall with puzzle after puzzle that will make you go back and forth, the game never makes it that apparent what you can or can't interact with either so sometimes you may need to pickle hunt. It can be frustrating and unintuitive as sometimes you will have to find something using one character to use with the other as if their minds are telepathically linked.It is unfortunate as the game did have a lot of promise in Act 1 with interesting characters, a story set up to make you wonder what is going on with this world, decent voice acting and writing but by the end because of the frustration I felt, act 2's story didn't save it and felt almost trapped behind the puzzles, the ending wasn't very satisfying either so I left the game feeling dejected. I cannot recommend this game, if you are all about the puzzles then you may well enjoy this but then you'd probably feel that act 1 was too easy and possibly boring for you. If you're more interesting in story, characters and the world then you could just end up feeling like I did.

												Keep in mind that I loved the first act of this game and the second part was pretty good too, but I can never ever recommend this game because of the conclusion. The way it ends is genuinely jarring and unsatisfying. It feels like I'm playing a game that's 2/3rds of the way completed, and considering how great the rest of the game is, the ending is genuinely insulting. It's not even visually impressive, it doesn't look like an ending in the same way the beginning looked like the beginning. It's not climactic, it's not engaging, and it's not good.Don't play Broken Age. You'll love it, but then it'll spit in your face for it.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
												Tim Schafer is a game creator that I knew little about until I started to search for an adventure game to play. Tim Schafer is known for creating Grim Fandango (I never played it), which is loved by many and to be honest, I wish I was around to play it. He is also known for other things I bet, I am planning on doing research later. I love adventure games, and usually have it at the top of my list for things to play, and those with amazing stories please even more. When I first saw Broken Age on VGX, I was imediately hooked just by the art style and concept of the story. I got my hands on the game 5 months later than I hoped, wishing I bought it right at the start. This game is absolutely amazing, and Double Fine does it's well known job of amazing wrting, and I found myself laughing and crying at many points throughout this game. At the start of the game however, I started to feel a bit bored after a while, and after I had that feeling, I am thrown right into the point where I am on the edge of my seat. It is sad to say that the game is only one act currently, and I found myself annoyed that I dont have a release date for act 2 yet.. Then again, I waited for act 1, and I got exactly what I wanted. Waiting for Act 2 may in fact be a pain just because I am so desperately waiting to jump back into the story of Shay and Vella, but whenever it comes out, I know it will be just as good as this part, if not better. This review is not the best one I know, but it really does not have to be to tell you that this game is beautiful and very entertaining. I honestly say get the game if you want to have an amazing adventure that has probably one of the greatest scripts and stories I have ever seen. Broken Age is amazing and creative, and showed me exactly why adventure games are amazing, and threw me back into the times where I did not have a chance to experience adventures at their core. 9.75/10 I would reccomend this game to anyone.

number of helpful: 133 of 244 people (55%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												Though Broken Age acts as a return to Double Fine’s earliest adventure game roots, it’s also their largest and most ambitious project in years. But if anything, the added scope and possibility that exploded out of their hugely successful Kickstarter has only amplified their talents as a developer, giving birth to what seems easily capable of becoming the game that defines them as a studio.But playing Broken Age, there’s never the sense that Double Fine has grown beyond the quirky, commercially unviable studio that I’ve loved for years. Broken Age as a game, is exceptionally simple and humble in its construction. It’s unmistakably a product of its creator: esoteric, humorous, and at times even a bit profound, but without the often rough mechanics and invisible cage of possibilities that shackled most of the studio’s prior games. It’s Double Fine in their purest, most unrestrained form, and if you’ve played anything the studio’s made I doubt I have to tell you how exciting that is.It’s somewhat precarious to attempt to discuss Broken Age’s plot, both for fear of spoilers and for the fact it’s only half finished, but its themes are so strong and its writing on point that it’s deserving of more than a minor conversation. It follows the dual stories of Vella and Shay, two people stuck in vastly different situations but united by their shared lack of freedom, forced to blindly conform to the traditions and expectations of those older than them, unable to even question “why?”.Shay is the sole human aboard a ship intended as humanity’s last chance at finding a new planet they can call home. Trapped in an endless isolation, he lives out his days following his computer mom’s orders, still treated as a child ignorant to anything outside his daily routine and sheltered existence.Vella in contrast is a member of a village whose traditions dictate the sacrifice of several young women to the towering Mog Chathra during their annual maiden feast, or otherwise doom them all to its wrath. Vella is the sole person brave enough to propose they fight the beast, but is shrugged off as a silly girl who doesn’t understand the gravity of the situation.These two plotlines fold into each other to form Broken Age’s main themes of rejecting the systematic lives their characters are placed in, and being brave enough to discover the world for themselves. It’s rebellion without anarchy; breaking out to find who you are, not out of distaste of the world, but a desire to make it better if only you’d be given the ability to think and act for yourself.You could label Broken Age a coming of age story (in fact it itself does), but it’s so much more sincere than I feel that commonly implies. Its characters are delightful and lively and often absurd, but also fully developed in how they fit within their world. They fully embody their roles and proclaim them so effectively that it felt like I knew the people I was talking to, as if they had somehow taken on a life outside of the game. Even characters you see in only a single scene or who are given but a few lines of dialogue have so much personality and heart in their interactions that they transcend their small part into the larger world of the game.Double Fine has always been a developer recognized for brilliant writing and characterization, but I’ve never felt as immersed in the worlds they created or as invested in their characters as with Broken Age. As bizarre as their circumstances become, I connected with Shay and Vella’s plight for freedom of their parental and societal shackles, and was as curious as them upon entering a new area and meeting its peculiar inhabitants.For all I know act two could be a complete disaster. It could cause Broken Age to go down as one of the most disappointing games in recent memory and probably cause even me to think twice before checking out anything Double Fine puts out in the future. But for now, it’s sublime, beautiful, expertly pinned, and not afraid to wear its heart on its sleeve. As a huge fan of all things Double Fine, I’m finding it hard not to readily declare this their best work yet, which I consider no small praise.Act II Update & ConclusionPerhaps I expected too much.It’s been more than a year since the first part of Double Fine’s Kickstarted nest egg first release, and since then the anticipation, unease, and in some cases legitimate anger have been steadily increasing to levels that beg the question just what this game means to people. It was one of the first hugely successful examples of using Kickstarter to fund games, as well as a callback to Double Fine’s earliest work and easily their biggest and most ambitious game in a long time (despite hav ing began as something far smaller). It was hard not to want to continuously give them the benefit of the doubt; to let them give it their all and assume Broken Age would come out the better for it however long it took. But for all the hype and impossible dreams of what Broken Age might be, we might have taken it too far. Or maybe Broken Age took it too far, and in my naive enthusiasm I went along with it. [...]Final WordI said at the end of my act one write-up that I could see Broken Age being the game that defines Double Fine. I still think that to be true, but unfortunately it isn’t as glamorous an image as I had first imagined it to be. Broken Age isn’t a bad game, nor do I regret playing it or wish to advise others not to. It’s impossible to ignore though just how uneven and weird the first and second act are. Broken Age seems to reflect a lot on its extended development and the detriment its model of funding and community feedback may have had on it. It began with an eagerness you couldn’t escape and the feeling that this couldn’t be anything but an amazing, and yet by the end it has lost a lot of its drive. It’s tired and drained, seeking to provide closure for those who have been waiting so long, but being unable to do much more.Sadly I've reached the character limit for Steam reviews. If you want to read my full thoughts on act II and Broken Age as a whole you can find them on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

Product received for free
												Very nice point-&-click. You get to play as two characters: a boy who lives in a spaceship with his overprotective computer parents, and a girl who lives in a village where girls are sacrificed to a beast every now and then to prevent it from destroying the village. But this broken age is doomed to become unbroken when each of them starts their own little rebellion. I absolutely loved the story. The puzzles become very difficult in the second act though, and some of them are randomly generated for each playthrough.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												Well this is rather pleasant. Broken Age isn’t a brash, jaw dropping, impossibly clever, superlative inducing spectacular. Instead it brings an old school charm. It seems not too much has changed in the 20 years since Tim Schafer last shipped a point and click adventure. The main difference is with the complexity of the puzzles. Broken Age is more story focused than puzzle focused with a simple single click interface replacing the verb system found in the old SCUMM games. But at the heart of this is Tim Schafer’s story, with colourful characters, imaginative settings and witty dialog. The story focuses across the two protagonists stuck in an absurdity that they are trying to escape from; one on a spaceship that controls their every action, the other in a fantasy land where they joyfully given as a sacrifice to a mysterious beast. Both of the settings are relatively small, but beautifully realised. Each story is largely independent with nothing like the item passing mechanic of Day of the Tentacle, meaning you can complete each at your own pace, swapping between the two characters at will. Everything comes together very nicely, from the writing, the excellent soundtrack and the beautiful story book art. There’s some excellent animation work as well and while a couple of lines fall flat, most of the voice work is very good.  There are a few minor issues, mainly with the interface. You can’t chose dialog options with the keyboard, the cursor is unnecessarily large and the inventory system is a bit awkward (I recombined rebinding right click to opening your inventory). There’s a larger issue if you were hoping for brain teasing puzzles, but if you were looking for a captivating adventure game your only real complain will probably be that Act 1 comes to an end a bit too soon.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												(It's hard to recommend/not recommend half a game. I'll update this when the full game is released.)Broken Age is definitely one of the more unique adventure games in recent years.To echo some of the other reviewers here, the game exudes charm. The art direction is exquisite and unique. Shafer's trademark humor is here, but it's understated. Below the humor there are weighty themes of independence and growing up, and I'm interested to see where it all goes (and not just because of the amazing ending!)Do not play this game for its puzzles. They are simplistic and not very satisfying to complete. (On the upside, this means the game avoids "adventure game logic--you will not be combining a string of objects in an illogical fashion). I hope Part II manages to make you feel clever, while at the same time keeping the logic. My other complaint is that I feel that at least so far, Shay and Vella aren't especially developed characters. Other than they want independence, we know very little about them. They're well-designed (with great voice acting), but they aren't fully realized yet. Part I is only around 3-4 hours, so this is somewhat understandable. And the ending paves the way for some...interesting...possibilities. Pro tip: give the wrong objects to people. You will often get amusing, unique answers. Also, map the right-click button to the inventory. The interface was obviously designed for tablets, and while it works on PCs, the default mappings should be different.As it stands, if you're interested in playing it, I would wait until the full game is released. I probably would've done that myself, but I wanted to continue to enjoy the (amazing) documentary as it releases.(Oh, and the music is VERY well done.)

number of helpful: 13 of 19 people (68%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												Broken Age is an old-school point-and-click adventure game funded through Kickstarter purely by nostalgia from fans that grew up with LucasArts games from the ‘90s along with Tim Schafer’s earlier works. For a very long time, Broken Age was Kickstarter’s poster-boy, all thanks to being the most funded project at the time. This meant that one small slip could potentially affect the way people perceive the risky-environment of Kickstarter projects in general. No wonder there was high pressure on Double Fine to deliver on their promises since they received almost $4 million in funding (which is almost nothing by today’s standards if it were funded by an actual publisher) in contrast to the $400,000 they were originally asking. The end result was split over two Acts, released approximately a year and half apart from each other.With that said, what Double Fine delivered in the end is a wonderful adventure game with an interesting plot concept: a teenager by the name of Shay who is a prisoner in his own spaceship trying to escape from being babysit by computers he refers to “Mom” and “Dad”; and Vella, daughter of a family of bakers in a village who tries to oppose taking part in a traditional sacrifice to Mog Chathra, a creature known for devouring worlds. Two teenagers living in two different worlds, yet facing almost similar problems, eventually collide with one another. Although the story starts agonisingly slow, it eventually builds up momentum after two or so hours in and keeps you invested until the totally unexpected, nonetheless remarkable, plot twist near the end of the first act which makes up for any pacing issues encountered. I really dig the concept Broken Age is trying to follow here.Additionally, compliments are to be given to the charming art-style. It is simply startling, albeit childish -- but that is its beauty, right? In fact, that is part of the story’s undertones. Sure, perhaps being an adult playing this might look silly, but from an artistic perspective it succeeds in capturing the aesthetics of a children’s storybook. It may not be what some people were expecting Broken Age to look like when the game was first pitched on Kickstarter, but I have no problems with it because Double Fine have done it very creatively. Likewise, while the humour might not be as memorable as in other comedy-oriented adventure games, Broken Age does not disappoint in this aspect either, all thanks to a couple of support characters such as the cutlery collective - the Spoon, the Fork and the Knife – whose dialogues and remarks never seize to be amusing. Throughout its duration, there are a handful of good chuckles to be had from time to time. Conceivably, I do not believe it was necessary for Double Fine to hire Hollywood actors as voice actors, but in the end they all did a solid job in most parts. Whilst there are minor moments where there might lack of emotion in the delivery of some of the lines, they do not break the immersion the game has to offer. And once again, Pete McConnell does a fantastic job on the soundtrack for this game, especially the three stellar tracks “The Lumberjack’s Cabin”, “Vella Wakes” and “Battle At Shellmound”. If you read up to this point, then surely you may be wondering why I gave a negative review for something which, based on my comments above, sounds like an amazing point-and-click adventure game? Well, here is why, and it does actually break my heart to say it but:Act 2 ruined it all.Pretty much everything that is established in Act 1 is thrown out the window. The things we, as players, are to believe judging by how the story unravels in Act 1 simply do not materialise in the second half. In fact, the whole concept seems detached in places in Act 2. As far as the story is concerned, it becomes uninteresting and seems to go almost nowhere. Any new revelation either turns out predictable or unimpressive. And this may be due to a few major flaws which simply killed Act 2.The most obvious crime committed here is the reuse of the same exact locations found in Act 1, with only Shay’s spaceship being “redecorated”. To me, one aspect of adventure games which sucks me in is the notion of exploration; finding new locations and meeting new interesting characters to advance the plot, aside from solving challenging puzzles. Desolately, that is not the case here. Simple as. In reality, what bothers me the most might not actually be the reuse of the same locations in the end, but rather all the fetching for items. In this part of the game, it did not click with me because it is a chore. But hold on a second, fetching for stuff has been in adventure games like this for decades? Yes, but the problem here is when you ultimately realise that most support characters are nothing more than “mechanical” characters. Paying close attention, almost none of them have any influence over nor take direct part in the story. They only exist there artificially for either Shay or Vella to retrieve a specific item from them to solve a certain puzzle. So this makes you stop investing time in caring for them, as characters. Also in regards to the puzzles, Act 1 is indeed a breeze for adventure veterans, so it is almost impossible to get stuck at any point – which in a way I do not think that is necessarily a bad thing at all. All puzzles, although pretty obvious, feel logical in Act 1. On the other hand, Act 2 bumps up the difficulty and takes some risks in being creative with some of the puzzles, but the end result is a mixed bag. Contrary to what other people say, I give Double Fine credit for the wiring puzzle in terms of creativity because it actually made you think (and no, it is not as hard as some people claim it to be – just time consuming). I only wish it was not as frequently used in the last quarter of the game and more intuitive, but stuff like the snake puzzle was badly implemented; waiting for a puzzle to solve itself? But yeah, most puzzles in Broken Age basically boil down to asking the right person for the right item and that is you more or less done. Sort of.Comparing the two acts, it feels like Act 2 was either rushed or made up while they were going along (as in it was not planned out at the same time with Act 1), or both. The charm and humour are still intact in the second half, but everything in terms of plot, characters, concept and some puzzles took a major hit by some bad design choices. Plus, just when you think Act 2 would redeem itself by the end, Broken Age ends in an anticlimax which raises more questions than providing all the answers. Simply put, the writing is poor in Act 2, and it seems like poor management could have been another factor here.In conclusion, Broken Age is a visually beautiful and well-crafted game where all the passion was clearly injected a lot more in the first act, but all its potential is completely ruined by its second act plagued by poor writing and some bad design choices which reduces it to no more than an adequate adventure game at best. Broken Age could have been the next big thing in this genre, and Act 1 is a valid gauge, but when modern adventure games like The Book of Unwritten Tales or even the more retro-y Blackwell series (as a whole) exist and provide a (subjectively) better and more fleshed out experience, then you know that something went wrong at some point in your game. Broken Age is still worth at least one shot thanks to its promising Act 1, so long as you lower your expectations in the next act. If so, then this still is a good starter for anyone new who wants to delve into point-and-click adventure games. Otherwise, for old adventure fanatics, I cannot really recommend it; easily skippable thanks to Act 2. To be honest, I could have also easily given this a neutral review if there were such a button on Steam.I am still looking forward to Double Fine’s next project, but what a bummer coming from Tim Schafer.

content:
Posted: January 2
												Broken Age is really like two games, one of them great, the other not that good at all.First, on the surface layer: BEAUTIFUL presentation, lovely (in act 1) charming characters, great voices, sfx, animations etc, all around, presentation wise it's great.At first glance and initial play, there is a lot to literally love there.So then, going deeper, the two games in gameplay and story:One, the first act, is a quite good classic (if by itself a bit short) adventure game modernized in some nice ways.It came off a bit easy in some aspects and only had two puzzles where i wasn't sure what to do next.(which is a good thing in my book regarding the not getting completely stuck/lost aspect)The puzzles in act 1 were overall for the most part easy and logical to grasp (again, besides two exceptions for me) and most of them were fun or lead to fun/nice/memorable story outcomes.The second act/later part of the game (which was initially also released way later) sadly is way worse though.In the second act the puzzles were changed to a completely "requires walkthrough constantly for sure" level and even with a walkthrough they didn't seem logical nor fun.It's like the game was suddenly made massively more "difficult" in all the wrong ways.Like "how many most not logical at all/most not intuitively discoverable things can we stuff in there at every corner?"That would still be much more tolerable to me if the story went on as great as in Act 1. Sadly it didn't =(Sadly, also the story aspect fell apart completely for me in the second act.There were way less fun and charming moments with characters there and the whole plot turned from could totally happen/ realistic/believable and very charming scenario to totally cheese and totally not relate-able to rage causing levels regarding how/why they let it sink there.I read some reviews stating one should best not play the second act and imagine for oneself how the story from the first act could end, well, obviously i didn't go with that recommendation since i wanted to play onwards after the great act 1 part and see where the story goes, but post playing act 2 i can see where they are coming from with those recommendations.I really liked the story and enjoyed the gameplay a good bit during act 1 and i feel like act 2 really tarnished that. If i wouldn't remind myself of Act 1 i would have to give this a way more negative review overall.So, overall i have a bit mixed feelings about it.On the up side, there are extremely charming, really lovely characters, art style, music and sound effects presented in the first act, the whole outset of the story is beautiful and i loved being in that world with those characters (and so charming presentation).I most loved the aspects that one could play the girl or the boy both with their different (seeming) eras, environments, back story etc. and playing through that portion was overall largely a joy._______________SPOILERS FROM HERE ON_______________Sadly the second act completely trashes that all. Basically initially it seems like storywise a few possible scenarios could have been the case. Like the boy or girl could be time traveling to meet the girl.The boy's Mom could be a computer only for real and not his actual Mom so it would pose the question if his parents long died or what. And the question why she/it imprisons him, why he was put on that mission alone. There was also the question (even touched upon briefly) whether the second "astronaut" could be an older version of the boy or a younger version of his father, again implying quite interesting story twists.Sadly, none of that all, what was unveiled with Act 2 storywise was basically a way worse and way less plausible and less interesting and less appealing turn of events /plot twists for pretty much every major character that really ruined any connection with the storyline to me completely.All aspects of how the two "eras"/worlds/characters were brought together felt forced, unrealistic and like complete nonsense. Hey, hooray, it was fake, more fake and most fake and what really went down was the least plausible way more idiotic setup.It went from some masterfully done great story portions in Act 1 to some super sloppy and bad plot overall in Act 2.The whole plotline of the boy was basically turned into complete made up nonsense in multiple ways, and each "unveil" making the plot worse than the previous._______________Major Spoilers below_______________Hey, his "Mom" and "Dad" whom he only saw on the computer screens initially and who there came off as both very computery and also totally not trustworth at all, as if they were imprisoning him with some dark motives, were then unveiled to actually be his real parents, just for some reason had not been around him in person for so long that he didn't remember them even being his parents or real humans at all.Ok, i get it, it plays on the point that many parents work so much that their kids don't see them much for a while, but it is just the lamest story twist option in this setup, where the initially presented setup was so much more interesting with so many more interesting possible outcomes.Then another plot twist, that the spaceships are not actually space ships and have never left earth.Downgrades the whole setup and story potential so much.Then with that also the unveil that they are all in the same era/planet/place.Another big story downgrade.Then that the "spaceships" from the outer shell look like monsters and are what's picking up the maidens.Then the twist who let's those monsters do that etc.With each plot twist, one by one, it got worse and worse and less and less plausible/likeable/connect-able.Like really, why did the story have to get worse by every 10 minutes in Act 2 until it was a complete dumpster fire? =(And as i said before, many of the puzzles in act 2 seemed so random, too that i feel like the chances for solving them without constant walkthrough usage are very low to non existent to most players, they were for me despite i played many adventures in my days.Some puzzles are also made in a way where they can't even be solved easily with a walthrough since some aspects are randomized, which is extra enraging when an annoying non onbvious, non logical and not fun puzzle after the other already forces one to play through with a walkthrough and then on top even with that one in between gets stuck at some points.Some of the puzzles in act 2 made me really really not enjoy playing the game at all anymore for a while and i only went on since i wanted to see the end of the story.Sadly, the ending, like most of the entire second act was not satisfying at all.I so wish the whole second act could be rewrittten completely, because i would so love to play through it in a version where the story could have progressed in a  form where it hadn't been turned to this trash later on.So, where does that leave us?Still a bit sad/upset about what happened there with act 2 and i wish it had storywise gone and played completely different.It's a rare case where i wish there could be a director's cut/revisit/remake of a game later on where the first part would be left mostly as it is and the second half completely redone with major changes in plot and gameplay.Still, i think after a while, i will play the act 1 parts again some time, because within those, there is some awesome stuff there.The first portion of the storyline was downright excellent in my eyes, there was so much wit and self and medium aware joy in those aspects making fun of games, hero and decision making or how they are presented as such in games or in the world and how we choose our own paths or not etc, some great stuff there.And for that all in Act 1 i give it a thumbs up =)I just have to get rid of the sour taste of act 2 and play act 1 again some time later to refresh those good memories of Act 1 =)

content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												It’s great to see that Double Fine’s Kickstarter wasn’t a complete flop.There was a lot of anger towards this game for various reasons of which I do actually understand. The kickstarter was launched asking for $400,000 and they ended up with $3.45 million. Yet they blew their money too quickly and ended up having to release a first act to try and raise funds for the second. Which a lot of people deemed the second act to be lazy and rushed. All of that aside, in my opinion Double Fine do great games. I’ve been following them for a while now and so far I haven’t been all that disappointed with anything that they’ve made that I have played. Despite their games always having a somewhat childlike feel to them, I always enjoy them.Sometimes I do wonder if this would have gotten so much hate if the game was released as normal with people being pretty unaware of the recent drama and goings on of Double Fine. If you were to buy this game without knowing anything about it, I think more people would enjoy it.This was kickstarted shortly after the “Amnesia Fortnight” events that Double Fine did, of which I loved. So I backed this since the beginning. From what feels like forever ago, I just never really bothered all that much actually watching or getting involved with it. It’s kind of been just a dusty book on the shelf until now. I finally got around to playing it and can say I think they did a really great job with it. I may actually go and watch the documentary now.The story is definitely interesting. Luckily by the time I played it the second act was already out. I can’t imagine myself being all that happy about having to wait quite a while for the next act. But that’s down to pure impatience. I wanted to know what was going on straight away. I was expecting something a little different when it came to the story, but it surprised me in a good way. The story comes together in ways I couldn’t predict. I think most people’s problem with the story is that a lot of act 1 is the set up. It asks all the questions, it gets you interested and it leaves you on a cliff hanger. After all that waiting, act 2 came out and honestly I can understand people’s disappointment. Most questions are straight up just answered. No real build up. The answers were somewhat brief, vague and honestly there are some holes in the story which made me wonder. I get the feeling most people yearned for more information or something much deeper then what it turned out to be. But I see this game again as almost child-like and light hearted. It honestly didn’t bother me all that much. I still enjoyed it and didn’t at all feel any sense of real disappointment concerning the plot. The art in the game is really nice. It’s smooth and wonderfully drawn. The audio is well done both music and voice acting wise. I can only assume they blew most of that budget getting Elijah Wood in. The puzzles are straight forward most of the time, which again I think rustled some jimmies. But I honestly enjoyed a little bit more simplicity. It helped the game flow a bit better for me. I could progress and find out what the fudge was going on (I can be impatient when it comes to plotlines). The main kind of puzzle at the end I found a lot of fun. As to where to find the solution is annoying, but deciphering what everything means was quite fun for me.  Usually I end up getting frustrated with point and click games (I think many people do) as it can sometimes be pretty easy to get stuck. Admittedly, I still got stuck on this a few times for a fair while but the puzzles and combinations are logical enough to not be stuck (and therefore annoyed) for very long. It’s also a nice feature to the game being able to switch between characters and take a break from what you were doing.The annoying part is the achievements (if you are even into achievements, I suppose). I personally insisted on 100%ing the game. It took me 18 hours and I have to say it was a little tedious. That may be just because I stayed up until 1am no-lifing and ended up quite tired and annoyed with it… but still. If you’re looking for an easy 100% it’s not all that easy. It’s do-able but you’ll need to be meticulous, complete it a few times over and be able to be quite fast about a complete play through to do it.All in all, I enjoyed this game. I thought it was great. Was also nice to see Pendleton Ward doing some voice work for Double Fine after the last Amnesia Fortnight. I hope to see more of that.Keep it up Double Fine!TL;DR : Despite all the recent Double Fine drama, it’s a great story,  it had good audio, visuals and puzzles. It has achievements that actually do feel an achievement to get and it just generally is another great game by Double Fine. I’d think any point and click or Double Fine fan would like this game. If you’re neither or those things, try it anyway. I still think there’s a chance you might enjoy it despite Double Fine’s games always having a slight childlike feel to them.

Don't get me wrong - the game is solid in terms of puzzles (though a little too easy for my taste) and mechanics, but 8 hours of total gameplay is just not worth 23 euros. Posted: January 14, 2014
												UGGGHHH! IT'S SO FREAKING GOOD!  AND SO FRUSTRATING NOW THAT IT'S OVER!  Episode 1 will last you about four hours, and who knows when the second half will come out. The only official word is "later this year", so I am expecting December 30. Episodic adventure games missing their deadlines is the worst thing ever.That said, this game made me remember what a good adventure game is actually like after playing a bunch of lesser efforts recently. The story is absolutely captivating, the puzzles are good if on the easy side, and the art style is this gorgeous "construction paper art project" sort of thing. You split your time evenly between two very different characters in very different settings, and each grabs you immediately and won't let go. Hilarious writing, characters, and voice acting too. The ending will make you slam your head on the desk because you will need to know RIGHT NOW what happens next, but instead the long wait begins.Buy it so we can discuss and commiserate.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2015
												If you are considering buying this game, you need to ask yourself: "do I like 90s adventure games?" If the answer is "no", don't bother: you won't like this one either. If the answer is "yes", Broken Age is most likely worth your time and money.The most important factors for a good point-and-click are here: great setting, great characters and superb writing. I laughed aloud countless times during my playthrough. Even the music and art style were spot on. However, you will most likely find yourself infuriated by some of the puzzles later on. If you're not the most patient individual in the world and a master of lateral thinking, get ready to look at walkthroughs. To me, consulting a walkthrough at least once or twice during a point-and-click is competely normal, but if you are the kind of person that considers it cheating or refuses to do so for some other reason, you're most likely going to get stuck multiple times during the later half of the game.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2015
												Broken Age started out extremely strong. Act One was phenomenal in almost every aspect, however, I feel like Act Two kind of dropped the ball.Graphics:The graphics throughout the entire game were amazingly colorful and bright. Everything was pleasant to look at and really helped to bring the game to life. Audio:The voice actors did a decent job with bringing out whatever emotion they could from the script. The music was complimentary to what ever was going on in the scene at the time and also helped to add to the excitement.Storyline:The storyline throughout Act One was extremely well done. It gave an in depth sense of what was going on and why, and you knew exactly why you were doing the things you were. However, once you got into Act Two, the storyline almost seemed non existent. The puzzles became increasingly hard, almost to the point of wanting to give up, with very little clues to go on. For a good portion of the final Act, I spent a lot of time looking through walkthroughs just to be able to move on. Even though I enjoyed this game for the most part, I have a hard time recommending this game, based on the fact that Act Two left too much to be desired. I have more questions at the end of Act Two, then I did when I started it. There are still too many loose ends that have not been tied up. The game itself had so much potential, and I think that is why there was so much disappointment at the end.

number of helpful: 21 of 35 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19, 2015
												Edit: Act 2 has been released a while now, but i can safely say I don't feel like going back to this game. It sounds as if I would have to play act 1 all over again just so I can understand stuff in act 2. And Act 2 doesn't sound worth it. So, yeah...The awkward moment where steam tells you when you purchased the game, rather than when you last played... X(I bought this game without any prior knowledge of the kickstarter origins of Broken Age, and I feel that this title supports my arguement for NEVER backing a game through kickstarter, unless you like throwing money at something which may never happen. There is always a risk when giving money to someone for something that doesn't exist, and I think a lot of people have unrealistic expectations, and unfortunately in this case, it was the people making the game that didn't plan and budget ahead.I bought this game in a steam sale not long after it was offically realised, which was the best choice at the time, as I had heard a bit about the game and was excited to play it myself. I played through act 1 and expected a few months wait for act 2, as this is the norm with most multi-part titles. How wrong I was. Over a year later, I am still waiting for act 2. I can't imagine how annoyed people must be from backing this game from the start! However, the signs for problems ahead were there from the beginning.Having only just bought the game, I started looking through sites to see if there was an expected release date for act 2, only to find an article which stated that the profits from act 1 meant they could go on and fund act 2. I was horrified! I had no idea that this game was not even funded for the second part. I had no idea that this game wasn't even supposed to be split into 2 acts in the first place. But I thought to myself, oh well, it might take a little bit longer but I can wait. Update after update, deadlines came and went for act 2 to be released. I think this is what really got to most people. The waiting wasn't the problem, it was the promises that were broken that made people upset and lose faith in Double Fine as a developer. How can you trust someone with your money if you don't believe they know what they are doing? If someone who has 30 years experience in the games industry can't budget for a full game, then we are all doomed! Unfortunately for us, its too late to take back our money or get back our trust. This is the true lesson to be learned from this experience: Research, research, research! If something looks too good to be true, then it probably is!I feel that some of the fault in my buying this game has to fall at Valve's door. The steam page for Broken Age is very misleading, as it gave me no indication at the time that this game is kickstarter funded and may never have been finished. And, even now, it is impossible to tell from the steam page that this game is not finished! This is why I have written this review, to give people the knowledge of the situation surrounding this game, so that someone else can make an informed choice over whether to purchase this game, I choice I didn't have.So, I guess you want to know a bit about the game, huh? Other reviews can tell you more, but the basics are: It's a point and click adventure that follows two very different main characters, with the option to switch between characters whenever you wish. Its a pretty looking game, with amazing voice-acting and simple puzzles.Is it worth almost £20? No. Act 1 took me about 3 hours (I got stuck for about 30 minutes because I'm bad at video game logic :P), with act 2, if and when it appears, to take another 5 hours. I'm honestly not sure I will play act 2. It has been so long since I played act 1 that I will have to replay it all from scratch. And really, there are SO many other games I could be playing, I may never experience this game as it was supposed to be played. My advice: Wait until both acts are out and grab it in a sale. As the second act is currently not out, I cannot recommend this game to anyone.A real shame.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												It has taken me a day to mull everything over, but I think I'm ready to put an opinion out there, so here it goes.I loved it. I will probably play it again as soon as I have time. The art was well done. The dialogue was genius (as expected). The voice acting was better than I could have hoped for. The story... the story was hands down the best adventure game story I have ever encountered. I spent a good chunk of time today just thinking and wondering about different parts of the story, what they mean, and what will happen in Act II. When a game's story gets me to actively engage it even when I'm not playing, it's a damn good story. I am sitting here wishing I had Act II in my hands already because I want to know what happens.Now, the reason why it took me a little while to say this:I don't consider myself a genius when it comes to adventure games. I expected to get at least 5 hours out of Act 1. When I finished it in under 3 hours, having exhausted every dialogue option available along the way, I felt as though the puzzle difficulty should have been higher or that there should have just been more puzzles. I was honestly a little irate that somebody like Tim Schafer would make the game so easy, considering what he has done in the past.I currently still wish the difficulty had been a little higher, but I've started to understand why it wasn't.  Point & click adventures are known for their DEVIOUS puzzle design. When you're only playing a game puzzle to puzzle and getting stumped at every single one, it is more satisfying to solve them, but that satisfaction comes at the cost of the storytelling (which is and definitely should be the main focus any P&C adventure game). The purpose of the puzzles, however, is not just to make a story interactive. The best designed puzzles give you little nuggets of the story while presenting an interactive, stimulating challenge. Not every puzzle in Broken Age did this, but a lot of them did. If this quality makes for less contrived, more logical and consequently easier puzzles, then so be it. A great example of this is the "use spoon with cereal" bit that, on the surface, seems overtly mundane. My advise, should you choose to play this game, is to think about why some seemingly mundane actions are there. Also, it think the game is very much meant to flip back-and-forth between the two stories, so I would recommend switching after every major "happening" you encounter. I'd also recommend starting with Shay's story.Thanks for reading, and I hope you choose to enjoy this fantastic game.

Posted: January 25, 2014
												Huge Tim Schafer fan. Monkey Island is by far my fav. point and click adventure game and overall love all his work.I got this game through the kickstarter which got me extremely excited when I heard he is making a new adventure game, especially since he has 100% full creative control, no publishers.. AWESOME!That being said, this is a good game... It's slightly below my expectations, I don't consider it to be AMAZING, however I do think it's fairly good.I've been following their documentary that covers the development of the game and since I also am a game developer I fully understand (and I was expecting) that they ran into financial and deadline problems. Especially for a point and click game where you have to basically build the engine yourself if you want anything decent, since it's an unpopular genre nowadays.The game has small problems here and there like various depth issues when it comes to certain animations, and also the game was dropping frames for me when I was using an item to interact with something. (Keep in mind that I'm playing this before it's officially out on steam, so they will probably fix these problems by then)All those problems don't affect the experience, however I don't feel like the experience comes anywhere close to Monkey Island or Grim Fandango. That's probably just me being nostalgic.. or playing too many games and being desensitized.But if you are a Tim Schafer fan or just a point and click adventure genre fan, this is worth getting. It's an old genre game with beautiful graphics. I say in the end, it's worth it.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												* Updated to contain Act 2 and represent the whole game *Overall I'm glad that I backed the game, it did take more time than they thought and it did came out in two parts but as a whole I feel that it was money well spent. Let's start with the good:The art is great, they have used this style very well. The soundtrack is amazing and also the dubbing with several celebrities (Elijah Wood, Jack Black, Wil Wheaton and others). The story is pretty interesting and I enjoyed revealing it bit by bit, playing some time as Shay and then as Vella, it's useful when you get stuck on a puzzle to switch to the second charater. As I hoped the second part took me longer to beat and overall Steam says that I played the game about 15 hours, I took my time, although the actual time should be a bit less it's still a nice amount, the average time to beat should be about 10.5 hours or so.And for the bad:I kinda hoped there would be a bit more to the story and somwhere in part 2 I could guess where it goes.Most of the puzzles where fine but there were a couple of kinda hard to guess puzzles that really took me time to figure out, one of which was a really bad choice in my opinion and I'm sure that many players got stuck in that place, it was kinda annoying and I decided to use a guide just for that one puzzle (still not sure if I'de get that one without it! they needed to add some kind of hint there, I was just clueless on what I needed to do next and wandered around the screens looking for a hint).Also some puzzles were a bit tiring (fetching things, going from one place to another and back again several times etc'), mostly on act 2.To sum it up, as I said I enjoyed the game overall, I'm happy that we got the game but indeed it could have been a bit better, the first part was shorter and easier but more interesting and fun to play. Still if you like adventure point and click games you should give this game a try, I thought it was worth the 15$ I paid for it, but you can get it on sale for much less (lowest so far was 6.24$).I hope Tim will be up to the task of creating another original P&C game in the future, we need more of those! :)

number of helpful: 12 of 18 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												The puzzles are probably a little too easy for point-and-click adventure game veterans - finished it in around 6 hours and I didn't attempt to rush through it. So if you're expecting a challenge, look elsewhere.In all other ways, it lives up to expectations as a Tim Schafer game. The setting is adorable without being outright twee. The dual PC/split POV narrative has promise and some really fantastic bits (can't say more here without spoilers). The writing is never as outright hilarious as, say, a Monkey Island game, but it does stay consistently amusing throughout.Also because of its pedigree, the gameplay is gratifyingly streamlined. As an example: in older games, getting from one side of the map to the other was a chore, consisting of watching your character amble along each screen. In this game, if you double click an in-room destination, the character will jog there. Double-click an exit and you warp to the next room immediately, bypassing the walk animation completely. This may be one reason the game is so much quicker to complete, but I'm a huge fan of the feature and others like it. Adventure games should be challenging, but never tedious.Is it worth full price? I received the game as a gift, so it's hard for me to say whether you will get $20 worth of fun out of it. But now that I'm hooked on the setting and story, I'll be picking up the rest of the game without a doubt.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												What can I say?  Tim Schafer has done it again.Broken Age is an enjoyable point-and-click adventure with the right mix of character dialog, puzzles, and humor.  This all leads into decent character development throughout the game, and sets up the ending of this First Act perfectly.  The dynamic of shifting between the stories of two characters worked well throughout the game.  The two stories were balanced in terms of content, and I really didn't favor one over the other.  While it's important to play and appreciate both stories you aren't forced to switch throughout most of the game.  This allows the player to enjoy each story and character independently, and not be arbitrarily ripped out of the experience.  I enjoyed being able to switch between the stories when I wanted to, without consequences.And the ending of this First Act?  I won't spoil it, but it's brilliantly executed and memorable.  It certainly makes me look forward to Act Two.  As far as which story to finish first, I will say that I finished Shay's story first and found the ending very profound.  It was truly an 'OMG' moment where the two stories merge, and suddenly everything makes sense and shocks you at the same time.  Please take your time and enjoy both stories before you get to the ending, as you'll appreciate the results.I highly recommend Broken Age to both fans of point-and-click adventures and first-timers.  Tim Schafer and Double Fine have delivered a high-quality experience that is well worth the money.

												This is a brilliant game. A great throwback to 90s lucasarts adventure games. The first half's puzzles are great but a little easy and the second half if perfect. I really wasn't sure how to solve some of them and was stumped for a while but when I figured them out I was relieved to find they all had logical reasons to them.That's just how an adventure should be. I know some people don't like the challenge but if you breeze through it without having to stop, go away and think outside the box then it's just an interactive cartoon. Wonderful characters, witty dialogue, gorgeous music and a delightful art style.I don't usually leave reviews but I really liked this and thought it an underrated delight.Thank you Double Fine!

content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												This game deserves to be played by absolutely everyone. If you grew up playing and loving the classic LucasArts and Sierra adventure games, this will be right up your alley. And if you didn't? Well, then you're in for a treat! The humour throughout is spot on, and I found myself smiling or laughing at nearly every turn and every conversation. The extraordinary Double Fine feeling eminates from beginning to end,  and the story will most likely captivate you and leave you guessing where it's going to head next.Broken age is yet enother example of the amazing and peerless work that Double Fine keeps producing, and it definitely gets close to the level of quality that they have produced in the past, including their own Psychonauts as well as games from their LucasArts days like Grim Fandango and Monkey Island. The puzzles in the game never reach the absurd levels that the old classics could achieve, but I did run into a handfull of headscratchers along the playthrough. The good part was the ability to switch between the two characters if I got stuck, or wanted a change of perspective in the story, very similar to the mechanic from Day of the Tentacle.Overall, I can't recommend this game enough, it is a masterpiece in the genre, and it's only half-done! I for one can not wait untill part 2 is ready. Judging from the absolutely amazing work Double Fine did on part 1, there's no chance in hell that part 2 will dissapoint. Mark my word.

number of helpful: 9 of 13 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2016
												I really wanted to like this game. I went into it having read mainly positive reviews and having grown up with point-and-click games. Unfortunately the game is let down tremendously by Act 2 and the poorly-explored story. The ending puzzles are also stupidly frustrating and artifically difficult - after many hours of getting nowhere I didn't bother to finish the game and just watched the ending on YouTube. I was glad I did because I would be annoyed if all my hard work resulted in it!This is quite a gentle, slow-paced game for the most part. While there are some timing puzzles that require you to be quick, overall everything takes a leisurely pace. This didn't bother me but some may find it too slow.Act 1 of the game is the only part of the game worth playing. You play as either Shay or Vella up to a certain point, and then switch to the character you didn't choose at the start to play through their story until the two stories align with each other. While Vella's story is more interesting, there are moments in Shay's that genuinely made me laugh. The NPCs are interesting and have some well-written dialogue and the environments are rich and colourful.Act 2 is very confined to the areas you can explore and doesn't tread much new ground. I was disappointed by this as I'd hoped that it would add more new areas or expand old ones - you barely get a glimpse of the final area which ws built up to be this large and menacing place. The puzzles spike in difficulty, with some being made artifically difficult and frustrating. The second part of the story is also rushed through at a tremendous pace and almost entirely through dialogue with the antagonist. It was interesting that the tone of the game became a lot darker,  but it was never fully realised. The execution is clunky.Overall this game was a big disappointment. If you want to play I would advise keeping a walkthrough handy and having a phone nearby to take photos of some puzzle elements that need to be memorised, but even then you're going to be frustrated.Pros:- Gorgeous art style and smooth animation- Writing that's actually quite funny in places- Act 1Cons:- The story attempts to be grand but falls flat- Very few areas to explore overall- Some puzzles require big leaps of logic or remembering a lot of information- Unsatisfying ending- Act 2

content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												After a bit of turmoil over their release structure (with the 'solution' being the two-part release), we now have the first half of Broken Age, and I must say, it was worth the wait. If you're a fan of the point-and-click adventure games of old (LucasArts games coming to mind immediately, as well as The Longest Journey), Broken Age is worth playing. The game doesn't have the length that some of the old ones had (assuming Act 2 is roughly the same length as Act 1), though that may be largely due to the puzzles being a little more logical than those in the older games were, so you spend less time aimlessly clicking on the environment and trying to use random items with each other in hopes of finding a solution, and more time enjoying the stylized art, amusing dialog, and interesting world.Is it a good game? Yes, perhaps even if the adventure genre isn't normally your cup of tea. Is it worth $25? That really depends on whether playing half of the game now and half of it "later this year" bothers you... chances are you'll have the opportunity to get it on sale before Act 2 is released, so that might be something to consider.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												so i just beat broken age.it took me roughly three hours to do so.i think i liked the game?  the voice casting and acting was excellent, and the story itself was pretty interesting. I switched back and forth between shay and vella after they reached major points in their respective stories, so for sure saw the ending coming from preeeettttyyy far off. theres a lot of good points but i also have like, i guess, some issues.  lets discuss.artistically this game is amazing. every area you go to is beautifully rendered and the characters actually have a nice highlight layer that respects lights located throughout the level, so even though its technically 2D they still feel like they navigate a 3D world in a way that is subtle and convincing.  all the characters had a great feel, and each area you went to had a clear artistic theme that worked well and created a good identity for the individual characters and the world itself.  Each village Vella visited had a great sense of fashion that reflected their purpose in the world, and in Shay’s case he just had a whole bunch of amazing everything friends to hang out with.  That being said there are a few places where i noticed the assets looks pixelated and improperly rezzed, but it was infrequent and it was never an object that was important to the story.the sounds design was great.  the music was very well done, and the variety of voice actors was pretty impressive and full of wonderful and recognizable people who really did an awesome job of selling their characters. The characters were also great. Shay’s friends were are hilarious and the way they interacted with him when on and off duty was entertaining.  The people in Vella’s world were also pretty interesting, although they all blindly love Mog Chothra which would get old if not for it being an integral part of the story, so i guess i don’t mind? It kinda bugged me that all the female characters in Shellmound were super ditzy and shallow though.  This could have been subverted by making one of the temple guards a dude, as their shallow nature ends up being a gag, but all the girls who were offered to mog chothra and the two temple guards kinda just blend together.the gameplay was pretty standard point and click stuff, and the puzzles themselves were rarely very challenging. to be fair i’ve played point and click adventures for like, my entire life as a gamer, so these things are kinda second nature to me. there were some design choices that were a little strange - like the snake. why is the snake there? it is a dead end and misleading. there was no reason to get past the snake, and as far as i coudl tell, no way to get past the snake. why is there a snake?  the story itself was pretty interesting, and how the two stories come together is pretty obvious, but i cant fault the game for not surprising me with it’s plot twists.  Shay’s story is interesting because it all happens in a very small scale - he explores the ship to do a thing.  Vella, on the other hand, goes on this big winding adventure around her world (but really only like 3 locations).  Her story seems like a race against time, while shay’s seems far more casual and meandering.overall though my biggest complaint is in the story.  it took me three hours to beat the game, and at the end of those three hours the story gets interesting.  the whole game is building up to this specific point (which again, is pretty easy to see coming if you like, you know, know how stories work) and when it finally happens the game ends. imagine, dear reader, that you are watching star wars, and just as luke gets on board the millenium falcon the credits roll.  Technically, yeah, you know luke is like off on an adventure, and leia needs to be rescued but NOPE. you’ll find out about it later.I know that tim put out an apology for making the game too long and how he wanted to release SOMETHING because its been what, 2 years since the kickstarter? and so the game was split in two parts so we can play half now and half later.  but to me, this felt like maybe 1/3? speaking from my other P&C adventure experience: telltale games released a new season of sam and max every 2 years. each contain 5 episodes that take roughly 3 hours on the first play through - about the same size and substance as part 1 of broken age. they also cost the same amount of money. for 5 episodes released every month, instead of 2 released i guess like 6 months apart? they haven’t really been clear on when more is coming.i know each studio has its own way of creating games and i’m not trying to say double fine should have made me more game, but i just feel like in 2 years and with 3 million dollars i was going to get something a little more substantial.broken age is pretty good. it didn’t blow me away, but i enjoyed playing it. i look forward to part 2, whenever that gets finished  but like, if i am being honest, i enjoyed it more for the art and acting than i did for the game parts. the old lucas arts adventure games were challenging and engaging and really shaped my sense of humor and love for adventurous stories. the dig and monkey island will be with me the rest of my life because they impacted me in a big way.  act 1 of broken age is not memorable or impactful in the same way.  so i’m looking forward to episode 2. because episode 1 is great, but pretty forgettable.

number of helpful: 10 of 15 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2016
												oh hell no.The art and voice acting and story of Act 1 were very good and enjoyable. Act 1 should be played. The Shay ending could have been designed *slightly* better visually to make it hit harder but the stories make sense and drive themselves. Act 2 was very very bad. I will now get into specifics so watch out: spoilers. Act 2 there are no new environments = bad. Many puzzles are tedious and require copious walking and cutscenes many times over = bad. The game requires you go get info from one protagonist's world to help to the other protagonist, although how this would work in-universe makes no sense because they aren't telepathic/have photographic memory. Every NPC serves only as a means to your end-- case in point sometimes NPCs who should be on your side and want the same things you do must be "tricked" into letting you take the wheel. In Act 1 the rebellion of the young protagonists made sense in the plot: Vella wants to live and Shay wants to not be helicopter parented. At the very end of Act 2, Vella and Shay both want to not die to the missle barrage and same with Alex and Shay's mom. But instead of just telling them the plan and getting them to cooperate, Shay and Vella have to distract them in order to get their plans into action. And the upshot of that "climactic" final plan is that they jettison their respective ships which were under attack (um... why didn't they just do that anyways?????). And why is Shay's mom completely freakin useless while a miraculously brave and resourceful teenager launches a nuke out a trash pipe to destroy an evil empire's death star? Why was so little "story capital" used in explaining the motivation for the evil empire, destroying the death star of the evil empire, and fleshing out what life was like inside the evil empire? This empire and its motivations were RESPONSIBLE FOR THE ENTIRE TIMELINE OF EVENTS THAT CONSIST THE PLOT-- why was it given the screentime of a side quest? The evil empire as revealed is an extremely one-dimensional "pure evil and creepy" antagonist that kicked the events into motion but does not deserve our attention as the main conflict in the story... which I guess is instead solving stupid puzzles? In Act 1 we knew what the story was about: it was about kids finding themselves and rebelling against the system. All the NPCs are focused on maintaining the status quo, and we outsmart them in order to do good. But in Act 2 we realize a great and horrible truth that should shatter the worldviews of everyone and wake up the sheeple. And it absolutely doesn't. All the NPCs are just sitting around having a grand old time and it just feels so helpless and stupid that we have to e.g. partially consume a cupcake so that an old man will frost the cupcake for us so that we can borrow his cane so that we can fence with some juvenile druids to get the robes they stole it's like HELLO THERE IS SUPPOSED TO BE SOME EUGENICS/GENOCIDE STUFF GOING ON! Act 2 *tells* us there is vague bad stuff going on when it should be *showing* us. That's my main issue. Being told there is evil stuff is not enough to make a game interesting-- besides, there is hardly any action in the game devoted to fighting the bad stuff. Why would anyone play this game instead of just watching a playthrough? Since the art, voice acting, story are the enjoyable bits, the only reason I could see is if the puzzles were satisfying to solve. I recognize it is a very hard balance to make a puzzle which is not too easy but also not just simply "anti-logic." And I grant there may have been a couple of actually satisfying puzzles in the game, but by and large in Act 2 I was so desparate for there to by any sort of hint of a plot payoff for the level of frustration that I faced. When none was forthcoming I resorted to partial walkthroughs in hopes to keep the pacing of the plot at tolerable levels. Act 2 made me think "this game is too long" and a game should never do that. When a point and click player goes from thinking "I need to outsmart this environment/situation" to "I need to outsmart the stupid twisted game developer" they break the fourth wall and the challenge isn't fun anymore.I have specific little gripes, like with specific puzzles or the fact that the final of very few times the music was given space to shine it was blaring repetively in the final scenes and overlapping with my musical hexipal. But there were some nice musical portions. In essense I would say this game was good to my eyes and ears but not to my brain.RockPaperShotgun explains the disappointment well: "Broken Age Act 2 is a poor game because of its terrible puzzles in repeated locations with little purpose. But the disappointment I felt playing it is so much more extreme because of its betrayal of everything it implied it would be about. Broken Age is, it turns out, not a game about the complexities of being a teenager, of the transition from childhood to adulthood, but in fact some dumb thing about funny looking birds and evil space aliens. And it’s this that most surprised and let me down." That's the key. Throughout Act 1 there was a thought that maybe this game was about something. Then Act 2 comes along and says "here forget about exploring characters and growth, knock over this banal punching bag (evil aliens, trust me they are evil) and let's just resolve the plot by having the two protagonists meet on terra firma and call the game done at that point." So probably don't play Broken Age, but if you do, stop after Act 1. Please.FINAL VERDICT: 1/2 of a cupcake out of 5 hexipals (1/2 because Act 1 was good but Act 2 was trash)

content:
Posted: June 1, 2015
												It took me a lot of stopping and starting to finish the first act of Broken Age. An interesting world with some fun moments, but overall a bit of a mediocre adventure game; one of the stories had pacing problems, and the other had serious structural and character motivation problems. Finally I managed to push through and was pleasantly surprised by the excellent ending to Act 1.It was on the strength of that ending (and a kind of masochistic pig-headedness) that I played through Act 2, which is a complete DISASTER. The puzzles are obtuse and nonsensical in the worst tradition of bad adventure games. The mechanism of switching back and forth between story lines to gain information is ridiculous in a story where the two characters cannot communicate (What, are they telepathic?). There's an entire elaborate multi-stage puzzle sequence where your progress can be completely reset by doing things in the wrong order. This wouldn't be so bad if we had a goal, or some sort of logical progression of steps to be following, but for much of the second act I honestly couldn't have explained to you what the characters were trying to accomplish or why what I was doing would in any way help. This culminates in a series of actions that every piece of information you have indicates will lead to your horrible and gruesome death, without actually gaining anything meaningful.A pointless, stupid, and frustrating experience. If you haven't bought this game already, for god's sake DON'T.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												TLDR (Analysis further down): In short, Broken Age Act 1 is a masterpiece, but it is very short. The short length could have meant ABSOLUTELY NOTHING and be absolutely doubly-fine... if not for cut-down tablet-style gameplay, where the most fun part of questing is absent. This means: "poking around and performing a lot of available actions to achieve an initially non-obvious goal (to get closer to bigger goal)" VS. "clicking around to find a SINGLE next action that will nudge the game to reveal next single action".So gameplay disappointed me a little. I was very surprised to see that I finished it in 3,5 hours, despite clicking on everything and trying to milk every line of dialogue and funny interaction.==The long version:==Any praises for this game could not be more spot on: the sophistication and delivery simply knocks out anyone who has ever seen an animated film, played a quest game or read a good story. In any aspect, this is an artistic triumph. Nevertheless, there are some nagging questions behind the excitement of discovery and heart-pounding plot realizations: namely, does Broken Age succeed as a game? Sadly, this is not so clear-cut.Every location is a stunning gallery of quirky characters and beautiful backgrounds. But each time, there are only one to four active objects on-screen, and only one way to solve the one puzzle that game feeds you at the moment. The gameplay is, sadly, as straight as an arrow and as bare as a plank. Even if you think and fantasize about how the objects may interact and what it could mean for the characters and NPCs, it ultimately boils down to trial-and-error, simply because there are so few options. Meaning, you are better off sticking everything into everything, because it will take less time than figuring out the answer. No matter how good the story and setup, the actual gameplay is to exhaust dialogue options in any order without a chance of failure, then combine two objects, then repeat. It may seem like a normal quest experience, but there are good reference points: content-wise, Broken Age Act 1 amounts to about 2 chapters of Curse of Monkey Island. Gameplay-wise, it is less than one (and one of the shortest at that). Curse of Monkey Island had six. Moreover, you can't perform various actions on objects or people, so every step is reduced to one try; one line to make a joke; one obstacle. Whereas classic LucasArts quests were, essentially, a search for a hidden action among the multitude of highly entertaining failures to act. You literally get less bang (trademark Schafer humor, which is still hilarious) for your buck.So in the end, you fly through very rich and insanely beautiful locations with no time to appreciate or explore them and make mistakes - like you're watching a cool animated show. The locations are packed with possibilities - but the only ones available are the ones you MUST utilize to move the plot along.The "length issue" is even more sad because of the 2nd part of Velle's quest. I say it this time from a perspective of a writer.****SPOILERS****The Meriloft section does nothing to the plot, and doesn't change the character in any way - it's just an interlude to get from Sugar Bunting to Shellmound. It's crazy good looking and ripe with plot possibilities (at the very least, the mystery of the cloud prophet/charlatan who (maybe?) duped these people into his religion). But inside Act 1, it doesn't mean anything at all. It's all the more obvious when you play both characters intermittently: I finished Shay's part (basically a single-part affair) while Velle was in Meriloft, and then he lay unconscious while Vella was getting through Merriloft and then got to actually move the plot in Shellmound. So it's 1 or 2-part vs 3-part (where the middle part is disposable). Again, Meriloft is rad - it's just sad that it doesn't matter much (maybe it will matter more in Act 2? still applies though).****END****Anyway, Broken Age still kicks♥♥♥♥♥and is gorgeous. I sincerely recommend it to EVERYONE, not only nostalgic quest players. This includes people who have kids. And maybe especially them. Kids will be super-grateful for this when they grow up. And for a reason.
