Posted: January 17, 2014
GET IT GET IT GET IT.If you're a fan of old-school point and click adventures, get it.If you're a fan of Double Fine and Tim Schafer, get it.If you think it looks kinda kooky, get it.If you've never played a point and click adventure, get it.If you wanna see some of the power of crowd-sourcing, get it.If you want to support the developers and NOT money-grabbing publishers like EA/Activision, get it.Graphics: A lovely combination of hand painted models and a 2.5D engine.  It looks deceptively cartoony, but if you look closely you can see how well they've managed to mesh the dimensions.Music: Creepy ambience and a fantastically subtle score.Voice Acting:  Elijah Wood, Jack Black, Pendleton Ward, Wil Wheton, Jennifer Hale... need I say more?Gameplay: Everything you'd expect from a point and click adventure; puzzles, dialogue quests, inventory management (that isn't done poorly), item combinations etc etc.Writing:  I don't think I can properly comment on this yet, but it contains Schafer's typical comedic aspects with a hell of a lot of creepy undertones.I've followed development of this game since it was announced on Kickstarter and I can happily say that with only a couple of hours play time, I already see it as money well spent.  Not only does it revive a 'dead' genre of gaming, it does it in a smooth manner that hopefully shouldn't be daunting to those that have never played a game like this.  Shay's opening sets up the story and teaches the player how to play these sorts of games flawlessly.  I find myself repeatedly clicking things "just in case I missed something", just like I used to do with Monkey Island.I'd love to have written a more concise review, but I am so full of feelings on this game right now that anything more will be unintelligible fangirling.

number of helpful: 11 of 17 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												I backed this game on Kickstarter, and I would have got my money's worth following its development even if the finished product wasn't particularly good. Fortunately that hasn't happened, and Act 1 of Broken Age is the most fun I've had playing a game designed by Tim Shafer since the last one I played! It's a beautiful game in every respect, the art and animation is wonderful, the music is of the highest standard, and the voice acting is excellent without exception. Really, as a demonstration of what a modern adventure game can be, there's no finer example. It's mildly amusing throughout, with a couple of laugh out loud moments. The puzzles aren't particularly challenging, although I did get modestly stumped a couple of times, having to come back the next day before the solution presented itself. Frankly, that's about my speed, but I still hope Act 2 is a little more challenging. Even if it isn't I would have had a great time. Overall a great success then, as far as I'm concerned. Like any good two-parter, the story ended on a suitable cliffhanger with some burning questions remaining unanswered, hopefully Double Fine don't take too long completing it.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												Having not played a point and click adventure since I was eight or so I found Broken Age to be quite enjoyable. The story is fairly entertaining and the puzzles fun.There is a marked difference between Act 1 and Act 2. The game is quite easy in Act 1 while Act 2 is much more difficult. While a game getting harder as you play is to be expected (otherwise where would the challenge be?), it is not a gradual progression. The game goes from being fun for all ages to overtly complicated at a moments notice.Though some of the puzzles can give you a migraine; if you muscle your way through this is an enjoyable little game. It hasn’t rekindled my eight year old love of the genre but it was an enjoyable game that reminded me of why I loved and hated that genre.While I wouldn’t advise purchasing this game at full price it is worth it in a bundle during a sale. My copy only cost $1.25 and at that price I certainly felt I received my money’s worth.

number of helpful: 11 of 17 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												Broken Age Act 1 is a beautiful adventure game where you follow two different people in storylines that feel quite different to each other. It's got an art style that feels quite unique, the voice acting is on the level of Shiny's Sacrifice - in other words high profile names doing their best quality voice acting giving their personas a very distinct character. The story is really well written and funny, and the world adds to that - there are also lots of hilarious things about both the environments and small side things happening.Shay's story is like a teenager stuck in a spaceship where the computer treats him like he was still three years old, and the environments are full of props to that effect. Also, lots of things seems to be vowen, knitted of crocheted, like the yarn buddies, the arms of the computer, the warping effect when travelling in space, the present, the weaver etc. It's also quite heavily lampshaded. The story does a good work of giving the feeling that you as a character are bored and need to find a way to get out of the grudge while still not boring you as the player. It also gives you a great feeling of wanting to be doing something to help others.Vella's story is the tale of a girl who is chosen as sacrifice to a monster to save the village, but who instead wants to fight the monster. The setting is such that nobody except her grandfather sees anything wrong with the sacrifice, instead seeing being sacrificed being a great honour, but you can see in it moments of despair about losing daughters or those daughters dying while still being an honourable sacrifice. The setting is more a renaissance faire with some fantastic elements to it, and a good lot of humourous dialogue.What is the game missing? Well, in the LucasArts games of old, you generally had tasks like Monkey Island's sword fighting puzzle, where you first had to do an item quest, then you had to do a collection of lines, to eventually beat the Sword Master. It felt like you were actually achieving something by solving it. There were also moments in the game where you got stuck for a while and had to search for a solution, trying to figure the puzzle out. In here, the solutions are always really close by the problem, and there is no procedure to figure out you need to go through to solve it. There was not a single puzzle that made me stop and actually think about how to solve it, everything was obvious from the outset. The good thing about it though is that there is no pixel hunting, no missing items far away and having to backtrack, no banging your head on the table in frustration of not being able to get past a point and eventually dropping the game in frustration.Despite those faults, the first act is storywise about as great as any point'n'click game has ever been, in looks, dialogue, humour and music it's spot on. The game throws a few screwballs at you, and I feel that depending on your game play order you will get a very different experience. If you play Shay's story first then Vella's story, you will suddenly get a shocking reveal that casts your actions in Shay's story in a very different light. If you play Vella's story first you will at the end of Shay's story get a different screwball where you at the end suddenly realise that an assumption you will probably make in her story's later part was dead on wrong, but not the shock of the reveal about your actions as Shay. If you switch characters at natural boundaries, and this is probably best done with playing Shay first, then switching when quest giver changes to Marek, and for Vella changing between Sugar Bunting and Merriloft, then Shay for the linear quests given by Marek, then Vella changing after escaping Merriloft, then play Shay to the end, then finally Vella to the end. The big picture of the story will be revealed way earlier, but it will not have any great reveals. It ends with a great cliffhanger that makes you really anticipate the second act.If you wonder about the inspirations for the story, Tim Schafer has pointed to 1948 story The Lottery by Shirley Jackson, with a spoiler warning if you read it.Over all, it's a very good and humorous story experience, if you're a lore fan you will probably really get into the game, but if you're looking for hard thinking nuts to consider, the puzzles of the first act will not give you full satisfaction, but I think you will have a hard time finding somebody that played the first act that is not eagerly anticipating the second act.A warning though: Don't view any let's plays of this game, or you will spoil it utterly.

number of helpful: 12 of 19 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												My review of Broken Age can be broken in two (pun!). First, the bad: This is a very simple game that puts up only a ghost of a challenge. What's worse is that unsolicited hints come in like crazy, treating the player like a kid. I'd compare the gameplay to some of Telltale Games' easier fare (Wallace & Gromit, Back to the Future), but with the hint system on. Secondly, the good; and there is a lot of that. This is a beautiful game. It's 2D, it animates like a flash game, but man is it the most gorgeous, eye-popping flash game out there. I've seen a lot of Lead Artist "Bagel" Stapley's work for Broken Age in documentaries, but seeing it so crisp and clear in the game does his talent justice. The animations are also very fluid and charming, despite the limited technology. In terms of story, it was also one hand or the other. The story of Shay, the boy protagonist, feels a bit dreary and uninspired - which may be unfair considering he was trying to escape a dreary and uninspiring situation. However, playing Vella, the female protagonist was a treat through and through. Great scenes, great characters, great situations. It's like the game saved most of the great bits for this half. Broken Age Part 1 also ends in an unexpected cliffhanger that still continues to have me wonder what happened and what's going to happen next. I can't wait to play Part 2, which is a good sign that I enjoyed the game despite the few issues I had.In short, this is a game for those who are really into story, and will forgive gameplay that is almost condescendingly easy. If that's you - it's definitely me - then I highly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2015
												I was one of the people who backed this game on Kickstarter years ago. I like point-and-click puzzle games for their stories, and Double Fine has done some other games that I've loved.Broken Age was... disappointing. The review would have been rather glowing if I'd written it when we were still waiting for the second act to be released. But with the release of the conclusion of the game, it feels... lazy? The first act introduces two interesting storylines with colorful, interesting landscapes (Or, sort-of landscapes) to explore. True to P&C adventure games, you meet all manner of interesting, quirky people, and get to ask them all manner of interesting, quirky questions.The second act offers... very little. For the most part you're revisiting the areas you saw before, but with the other character. Dialog options seem less varied and numerous, and puzzles begin to feel more like legwork than puzzles (Get X item that's on the opposite side of the game and bring it back to me).The ending feels sort of lackluster, but it may simply be that it's a letdown after the outright grueling back-and-forth grind of setting things up required for completing the final puzzle.

Posted: March 10, 2014
												++ Charming characters and amusing dialog, as expected from any Double Fine production+ Competent voice acting+ Not-bad story.  Not great, but good- Tumblr nose.  In fact, the only likeable thing about this game's art style are the backgrounds-- Extremely short;  Act 1 only took 4 hours to complete, and word has it there's only going to be an Act 2 after this.  Unless Double Fine really digs in and amps up the elements of what makes the adventure game genre great in the forthcoming Act 2, I wouldn't recommend this game.--- The most significant negative:  No challenge at all;  this adventure game has the easiest "puzzles" I've encountered in any point-and-click to date.  I'm not saying it should be Sierra-level difficult, but it's not unfair to expect a few good head-scratchers once in a while.  Alas, there were none.Verdict:  Not Schafer's best.  I know he can direct and produce a better game than this.  Play Psychonauts and Grim Fandango instead.P.S.:  If Act 2's development makes a 180 degree turn and ends up being awesome by not repeating Act 1's more egregious mistakes, I will happily eat my shoe and give credit where it's due.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												Tim Schafer and friends made another cool game. The Writing is Double-fine quality: Great writing with bits of humor thrown around. The Gameplay is what you come to expect from a point and click adventure game. click to walk around, Item Inventory to use for puzzles, etc. Nothing truly groundbreaking but compared to old 90s point and clicks like Day of the tentacle and Sam & max the interface is way better. It serves it's purpose well. Would say it feels better than the recent telltale games.The Puzzles have a sense of logic to them, they arn't Phoenix-Wright/Ghost Trick style Logic-Leaping but it isn't  "Fit round object into round slot" easy.The Voice acting is really well done. it is easily the highest quality part of the game. Nothing felt out of place and nothing got annoying to me.The Characters are great too, From the crazy cloud people to the Blind Guardians of the Dead Eye God. Even the Hipster lumberjack (now named Curtis) which was made fun of early in development is funny.The Soundtrack is great for what it does, but it's not something i would loop on my Music player when im not playing.The art style is beautiful. I Pressed the screenshot button alot to get some desktop wallpaper out of it.It's quite obvious that the ending part was slapped together quickly because it randomly became a two part series in development, But i can't wait for part 2. Don't want to spoil anything.I would recommend buying it. If you have a longing for a classic point and click adventure or want something like the Telltale Sam and Max Games i would get it. Though if your expecting something like the Walking dead or Wolf Among Us with ~~choices~~ and stuff like that don't get it.also, it got me to write a review thats more than two sentences, it's that good.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2016
												The good:- The characters and their banter was rather entertaining most of the time- Voice acting was great- The art is beautiful, albiet cartoonyThe Meh:- The soundtrack while enjoyable wasn't all that memmorable- Spending time backtracking through reused enviorments - Doesn't take itself seriously, which isn't a bad thing as a whole, but that doesn't make it all that gripping either.The bad:- Some rather forced/tedious puzzles    " Some required knowledge unknown to your present character that you gained when playing the other one    " Some didn't really make sense, and required a guide to finish (at least for me, though I doubt I'm alone in that)    " Some made me abuse print screenshot and paint to keep track of some reused puzzles that were 'randomized'- Reusing enviorments - No replay value, unless you crave achievements- Weak plot/setting - The ending/puzzle almost made me appreciate Mass Effect 3's endingOverall?It had tons of potential, and prior to the 2nd act, I would have recommended it in a heartbeat. Yet, the middle/late half othe game dragged most of the way until the so called 'ending' was the final nail in the coffin, destroying what love the 1st half had garnered. Don't purchase this game, even when it becomes cheap.The characters can't carry the weak plot, the art can't cover up the reused enviroments, and the gameplay is not only lackluster but it lacks replayability. It might be beautiful at first, but this candle will burn itself out rather quickly. Your time would be better spent elsewhere.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
												I have to say, I was pleasantly surprised at how much I enjoyed this game.  Well, actually, story with puzzles.  I liked that most puzzles were not too difficult, but enough to make it fun. (Remember the wiring!  That will make sense the first time you play and realize you paid no attention.)The story was deeper than I thought it would be and, happily, longer than I thought it would be.  Don't let the unusual art work deter you.  It is more sophisticated than it seems from the previews.  It fits well with the story and I enjoyed this.As for playability, I've played through once so this is from a one-time play-through perspective.  Let me put it this way, if you enjoy reading a story, setting it aside for awhile and then reading it again, you could replay and enjoy it. If, however, you are a person who reads a book once and never reads it again, you may not enjoy playing it again.  But I bet you enjoy playing it at least once. Though the story seems to be set, the fact that you are allowed to solve the problems in your own time, and some interaction is done differently, I think you could play it more than once.I definitely recommend it.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 3
												Recommended for:- people who love point-and-click adventures- younger gamers (it's "family friendly," as they say)- people who are willing to suffer a little to see some pretty, whimsical design- people who don't have too much pride to use a walkthrough at timesNot recommended for:- people who get frustrated or bored with long, tedious point-and-click puzzles- people who want to feel emotionally attached to the charactersOh man, there are so many good things about this game, and I really want to recommend it. :( The art is colorful, the settings are interesting, and the story is really cool. The character design is splendid. Actually the overall design of everything is splendid. The female protagonist is pretty awesome, and I think the story has some good messages. Some of the dialogue is really witty too, and all in all the game seems really well thought out. I like the story, too -- lots of good plot twists, interesting, unique.But... maybe it was too well thought out. It started out fun enough, though at times I had to wonder to myself "I feel like this game is meant for an age range of about 8 to 13???" (But it is marketed as "family friendly," so I shouldn't complain now.) By the second act, everything starts to feel extremely tedious. It took me forever just to get through the puzzles. It felt like I'd have to walk through a million rooms and do things *just right* just to get things to work. Whereas I didn't have to use any walkthroughs in the first half of the game, I kept getting so frustated at how slow things were in the second half that I resorted to them multiple times near the end. By the end of the game, I just wanted to be done.In addition, despite having a really cool story to begin with... the tedium somehow ruined it for me. I felt completey unattached to the characters. I liked the female protagonist well enough, she seemed really strong and daring and at least that gave her some kind of characterization. The other protagonist, well... if he'd fallen into a pit and died at some point I really couldn't have cared less. Which is sad, because his backstory is interesting enough and I feel like there could have been more... introspection there? Even a little?In all fairness, point-and-click adventures aren't really my thing, I guess. I hadn't played one in a long time and I wanted to try this game because of all the good reviews. But... I WAS SO BORED. I want to give other point-and-click games the benefit of the doubt, because I'm certain I've played some that aren't quite so tedious. If you're into this type of game, maybe you'll like Broken Age anyway -- after all, it does have a lot of cool elements in it. I just feel like they missed some things in the execution.Saving grace: It has tree jokes. And makes fun of hipsters, whom we all love to hate. Feels like there's some of that classic Monkey Island humor in there, too.So... time to make like a leaf and... no, never mind.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2016
A thoroughly enthralling experience from start to finishBroken Age tells the story of a girl and a boy, living very different lives, whose paths eventually converge in a rather unexpected way. Throughout the game, you have the option of switching between Vella (the girl) and Shay (the boy) at any time. The game plays out like any other point-n-click adventure game, with full voicing throughout. Puzzles comprise the typical adventure game obstacles, as well as a few teasers that require a bit of logic, thinking, or working out.The Good- Superbly high quality production (well, it did cost $9+ million to make[www.gamesindustry.biz])- Absolutely gorgeous artwork and graphics- Excellent music- Top-notch voicing (Elijah Wood plays the male lead, & Jack Black one of the characters you meet along the way)- Engaging gameplay & story- Humorous in bits throughout the game- Great writing- Switching between the 2 characters adds an added level of interest- Lots of beautiful environments to explore- Game world is detailed & immaculately conceivedThe Bad- No way to skip just one line of dialogue; skipping will cause the entire dialogue to end- Story is rather short- One of the puzzles is very tedious and involves trial & error until you get the correct configurationConclusionThis is a must-play if you consider yourself a fan of point-n-click adventure games. Broken Age's brilliantly crafted world is magical and highly immersive, and the story well plotted out with clear direction and goals. I grabbed this during sale at S$5, which I consider a more than worthy price to pay for such an epic and enjoyable experience.

number of helpful: 11 of 18 people (61%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												Lacking the charm, intelligence and writing of some of the better point-and-click games of the past decade, this seems to be a rather lackluster experience and one of the worse written games that came out of Tim Schafer’s production company.The bad:-A really lackluster story; and seeing how the story seems to be the game’s focus, this is saying a lot. A good setup for a story that starts out strong but turns out to be quite a mess in both character’s cases. Either lackluster or just completely stupid twists thrown in for good measure.-Completely simple puzzle solution that most people probably won’t even want to think about. Use everything with everything wins the day here; and even then it is just way too easy to advance.-Really bad, sometimes grotesque humor. Characters seem to try to be funny, but fail miserably most of the time. While some lines are worth a few chuckles, this does not come even close to some of the amazing writing and humor of other games of the genre like Sam and Max or the Monkey Island series.-Short. Very short.-Just really bland characters in general. Some of them can be entertaining, some of them even memorable, but most of the time you will just get thrown more and more characters onto your face without them having any sort of character development, interesting traits, stories, or anything else that would make them stand out.  The good:-If you like how point-and-clicks work, this is a fairly clean UI that works well.-Graphics are interesting, but obviously might not be for everyone’s taste. It has a unique art style though, and is visually interesting, so that should be noted.-Voice acting is mostly really good.-The atmosphere, especially at the beginning of the game, is really well presented. The game might make you feel uneasy, and even if it doesn’t, it presents its world very well at the start. Sadly, this somewhat falls off as the story progresses, and by the time you hit the end of Act 1, you will notice that the best part of the game was actually the beginning.In general, it is a game that is hard to recommend to anyone. Horrifyingly short, quite silly mess of a story, uninteresting characters for the most part and just a lack of anything great besides the interesting art style and good voice acting make this a game that only die-hard fans of the genre or Tim Schafer’s games should check out. The rest might want to wait for a sale or just skip it completely.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												I honestly can't understand why some people claim that "this isn't even a point&click adventure! it's dumbed down and made for tablets!" or "oh my god, WE paid 3 millions for a flash game!". I finished this today and here are some of my thoughts:- It looks gorgeous. I totally loved some of the hand painted sceneries. I can understand why it might not appeal to some people; however, if you don't like the style, that's no reason to qualify it as a "cheap looking flash game". Even if they have a childish vibe, the backgrounds and the characters are well polished. Moreover, I feel that they have a little more personality than the regular cartoonish or detailed fairytale-ish style of recent point&click adventures. But as I said, it's a matter of taste. Look at the screenshots and decide for yourself if it's your kind of game.- It is easier to play than most of the old school point&click adventures. If you're looking for pixel hunting, engineering puzzles and running around with 20 items in your inventory, this might not be your kind of game. I found it to my liking, since I'm not a fan of spending 2 hours on a puzzle or constant alt-tab-ing to check the walkthrough. They said the second part will feature harder puzzles, so you might want to wait for the reviews of the full game, if you're not sure it will be enough of a challenge for you.- The music and voice acting are great, and that means a lot. Most adventures released in the past few years have very bland, if not outrightly bad voice acting. Elijah Wood and Masasa Moyo did a great job voicing the main characters. I also enjoyed the performances of David Kaufman (as Marek) and Wil Wheaton (as the hipster lumberjack).- I didn't find it as funny as the old Lucas classics (Monkey Island, Day of the Tentacle), but it made me chuckle several times. It is definitely a charming game. - As I started to grow fond of the characters and feel warm and fuzzy inside, the first part was over. Yeah, I agree it's a little too short. Not 2.5-3 hours long, as some complained, more like 4 or so (it took me 5 hours to finish it). Still short. Ending the first part on a cliffhanger didn't help.So, tl;dr:DON'T buy this game if:- You're not a fan of point&click adventures;- You don't like this particular hand drawn style of graphics;- You like your puzzles ruthless with a touch of illogical;- You hate playing games in a seasons/episodes format.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												There are certain animated children's movies that strike an emotional chord, which compel adults to keep watching them over and over again.  This game manages to capture that emotional chord.  I'm sure kids will love it, but there's something special about the story that will draw in adults and make you feel something.The scenes are gorgeous, as is the music.  Controles are simple, and the puzzles are challenging enough without forcing you to figure out, say, how to connect your chicken to a pulley.  If you're a point and click puzzle adventure afficionato, this game will be easy.Reading some of the negative reviews, I'm surprised how much dislike there is for part two.  Personally, I really enjoyed getting to revisit locations as they change and watching the two main characters get to know each other indirectly.  The puzzles got harder in part two, but given how easy they are in part one, that's not a bad thing.  You get to see all the characters you've met earlier change, develope, and grow.In terms of plot, the one thing I wish would have been changed was part one.  I felt like there wasn't really time to establish Vella's character the way there was for Shay.  I had a very strong sense of who Shay was as a person in part one, but since Vella's story was so driven by her adversity to the obstacles around her, it wasn't really until part two that I began to get a sense of her personality beyond being willing to stand up for herself.  It would have been nice to have her do some small puzzle unconnected to the maiden's feast to define her personality to the player, before her adventure started.I'll admit also I bought this on sale, so I didn't mind so much that it was short.  (I took my time and it lasted about 14 hours.)  Never the less, I will definitly be replaying this game, just like I rewatch Toy Story and the Iron Giant.

number of helpful: 21 of 38 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2015
												Being one the people who got this game gifted after the second act came out, I think I can give it a look that isn't sullied by backer's disctontent. So let's go and try to do it.The game starts off great - you got 2 pretty different characters in rather different settings going on about their rather unusual daily lives. The world is bizzare, characters are colorful and voice acting is great, music score while nothing spectacular does compliment the tone of adventure very well, so it really drags you in for the first 1 or 2 hours. At that stage puzzles are almost trivial and you spend more time listening to dialog and exploring the world, rather than getting frustrated filling out charts and solving equasions, it feels like you playing a lighthearted interactive movie more than playing a game.After about 4 or so hours in, with a bit of twist at the end, 1st act of the game ends and unfortunately what follows it up is one big mess. Act 2 is pretty much a dissapointment in a variety of ways - you meet next to none new characters, 95% of the locations you will visit are rehashes of the old ones, the plot unravels itself but leaves holes and doesn't really give a satisfying ending to the story. One important thing to notice about second act is the difficulty of puzzles - it racks up in a big way, so much, you would be excused to think devs have tried making second act feel longer by making you spend majority of the time scratching your head. Main strengths of the game so far: characters, dialog, bizzare setting, fade out at this stage in favour of trying to figure out what's the trick behind another wiring puzzle. It really kills the mood of the whole story and leaves a sour taste in a mouth.At the end I feel troubled recommending this game, for even though I still managed to squeeze some fun out of it, I also didn't have to spend any money, which made me far less judgmental. Since it doesn't really doesn't have interesting satisfying puzzles, or at least a decent enough ending to the story, I urge you to purchase this product at your own discretion, for it can really get your hopes up only to crash them down and leave you feeling dissapointed.

												TL;DR: Supremely entertaining and gorgeousRichly-imagined and lovely worldbuilding, characters and story. Great twists, hilarious dialogue with brilliant voice-acting, funny and clever puzzles, so much charm and attention to detail, and looks and sounds absolutely beautiful with its painted imagery and orchestral score. In the game you get to switch freely between two likable young teenage protagonists in very different worlds, rebelling against a system imposed on them, and as the player advances their storylines they can begin to see the connections between them and use that to get them to help each other out.Vella has the 'honour' of being offered as a sacrificial maiden to appease a monster attacking her village, but she decides to fight back instead. Shay has grown up on his own on a spaceship programmed to serve his every need and coddle him, and decides he needs to break free and try to make a real difference.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												This game took me back. It's fortunate that I waited for both episodes to play, since the wait between them put so many people off. Now that it's one complete package I think it works fine. This is a good example of why episodic games can either work or fail. If episodic means you tire everyone out, it hurts your game. If it means everyone is thrilled by a cliffhanger by the new episode, it helps your game. I am recommending this now, but I think breaking it up hurt this game, and I think that is unfortunate. It's still a gem, and Double Fine has an opportunity to learn from their mistakes.

number of helpful: 59 of 112 people (53%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
												edit:This review was written long ago in the past, when only Act 1 (half of the game) was available & I didn't know when (or if) I will be able to play the rest of it. Act 1 was released on January 2014 and Act 2 just now (April 28, 2015), so as you can see it was a long wait for many people. I will rewrite this review as soon as I'll complete the second part of the game. :)----------Broken Age is a classical in nature point & click adventure game, that focuses mostly on the story, characters & dialogue. Puzzles themselves aren't challenging, although they are logical and support the narration nicely. Visuals are really charming - a distinct painted 2D art style. The setting (or settings, as there are two protagonists) is fresh and manages to grasp and keep the interest up.Too bad this is just Act 1, or in other words - it's half a game, and ends with a cliffhanger. Certain parts of the plot are explained by the end, but not nearly enough & the ending scene just made me want to immediately play Act 2, which is unfortunately unavailable at this point.The game itself is quite short. It took me 4h 20min to beat it and I certainly didn't rush it. I visited every location, talked with everyone about everything and tried to interact with every object.Even though I would prefer to play both Acts at once & not wait indefinitely for 2nd half of the game, I'm still recommending this game :) It's charming, intriguing and enjoyable, provided one likes story focused adventures.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
												This game is short, but so sweet that I'm glad there's to be an Act 2 some time later this year, or so I've heard (About the later this year thing, not about the act 2, that's been confirmed). I've seen some reviews that list this as a game they wouldn't recommend, and I think in some cases that may be because the game can be considered a bit too linear. Choosing different dialogue options won't throw you in a different direction like in some games, and for the most part you can figure out where you need to go and what you need to do next by exhausting every line of dialogue available to you. Before I bought the game, when I saw that there were different dialogue options available to the player, I wouldn't have thought that would be the case, but it didn't bother me, per se, and here's why.The game is beautifully rendered and a joy to look at, it has an air of whimsy and a tongue in cheek flavor that I couldn't get over. There were some jokes that would go right over kids' heads, which is probably for the best, but which didn't fail to get a laugh out of me.  You know, those kind of jokes. I always count those as a plus.Also, despite thinking a few times that I had the game pinned down, in other words thinking that I knew where it was going, I found with good humor that I was wrong. It managed to provide a twist that I didn't see coming, and for that I have to give it some more points. I finished the game in a few hours and I wish I had part 2 right now. I picked it up for 40 percent off (14.99) and I would say that it's worth more than that, counting the fact that there's more on the way and that I'm a sucker for a good story/twist.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2015
												With charming art and animation, together with stellar voice-acting, Broken Age is an enjoyable adventure.However, the combination of a somewhat lackluster story and puzzles that sometimes become quite head-scratching does deflate the experience a bit.Occasionally the story gets a bit interesting with the two protagonists' experiences mirroring each other. While never causing me to wipe tears of laughter from my eyes, Broken Age often made me smile.If you're looking to enjoy lovely visuals, well-written dialogue and excellent voice-acting, this is the point'n'click adventure for you. If you're looking for an engaging and thought-provoking story, I'm afraid this game simply doesn't offer that.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 16, 2015
												My impressions at length, if you're not sure why I reached this conclusion: http://xander77.livejournal.com/27144.htmlAlso, your steam playtime counts the time the game spent paused while alt-tabbing. I have in fact played through the game once, and it took about 7 hours of actual playtime. Part 1 was a nostalgic, traditional (charming) point and click adventure. Part 2 is very much not.The puzzles in part 1 were very much typical, nostalgic point-and-click adventure puzzles that could be solved by talking to everyone and clicking on everything. They were mostly logical, congruent with their setting, and solvable by understanding how the locale in which they are found works. The puzzles in part 2 are "puzzle game" puzzles for the sake of puzzles (does puzzle look like a word anymore?), in the tradition of Myst or (a better example) Puzzle Agent 2. They are arbitrary, have little to do with their surroundings, and interchangeable.The thing is - no one at Double Fine ever designed a "puzzle game" before and (consequently?) they are really really terrible at it. In (say) Puzzle Agent, you solve a puzzle by figuring it out logically (mathematically, whatever). In Broken Age act 2, you solve a puzzle by following instructions. The only difficulty you're facing is the fact that the instructions were written by a drooling retard, and you have to write them out and puzzle the meaning from the gibbering.(Also - almost everything in act 2 is also recycled from act 1, and the conclusion to the story makes absolutely no freaking sense.)I rather enjoyed the first act, though it was over in 2 hours or so (fairly complete exploration with no walkthrough). Act 2 had very little joy, and was mostly frustratingly obtuse. I would not recommend you purchase it. In fact, I really should have youtubed a playthrough of act 2 after completing act 1, even though I already had the game.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												Ok, so I finally finished the first act.  I'm a little slow on these games sometimes except for the most part, not this one.  I figured out all the puzzles in Shay's story pretty easily; it was only when I got to Vella's story that I started having trouble, and even then it was only one or two things that kinda didn't make sense to me (until after the fact).  The voice acting is mostly good, though I'm not fond of Vella's voice.  Everyone else feels like they fit very well, especially Shay's "Mom".  The graphics are kinda like what you'd imagine if someone had to painstakingly create each scene out of construction paper cut into various shapes.  It looks better than that, but it still has that feel to it.  The music is nice and fits very well; but unlike the Soundtrack to the Monkey Island games, few tunes make me really want to hear them again.Certain characters in the game really stand out though, and make me wish they had much more of a role to play (maybe they'll show up again in Act II?).  The humor is great and made me laugh out loud in a few parts, but again, if you compare it to Monkey Island, it doesn't hold up as well.  Otherwise there's lots of cleverness in the game, but clever doesn't mean funny in a lot of cases.I'm definitely glad I was a backer for this game, and I really look forward to Act II, and I'd say you should definitely buy this game if old school adventure games are a thing you're into.  It won't quite reach the same standards as the classics, but yet nothing else comes closer than this.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2014
												If you've ever heard of a game being Kickstarted, you can thank Broken Age for it. It was almost two years ago when Tim Schafer decided that he wanted to make another point-and-click adventure game, and he wanted the internet to fund it. Needless to say, it was a resounding success, and for a while all we wanted to talk about[thenexus.tv] was games on Kickstarter. The first half of Broken Age is out now, with the second half coming later this year.The game is split into two different stories, with two different protagonists: Vella on the left, and Shay on the right. Once you choose one of them, you start their story, but you can switch between them at any time. I used this once when I got frustrated with a puzzle I was having trouble with.Vella's story starts off in her village, which is made up entirely of bakers. Every generation they have the Maidens' Feast, where several young women are offered up to a big monster called Mog Chothra so it won't destroy the village. Needless to say, Vella is not thrilled about this and decides to fight back. Her adventure takes her to a couple of other villages, one that just had their Maidens' Feast, and another getting ready for its Maidens' Feast.Shay on the other hand lives a pretty boring life: he's been living on a spaceship his whole life, and the simulation missions the ship throws at him have gotten pretty boring because they were designed for a toddler. Eventually he breaks out of this rut and discovers a whole new part of the ship that he has never seen before, and some real missions to embark on.Visually the game is gorgeous. Everything looks hand painted, and in typical point-and-click fashion the camera is usually fixed, at most moving left or right as you move around the environment. There were a few places where I thought the textures looked low-resolution, but honestly it wouldn't have made much of a difference because of the art style.Mechanically it plays almost exactly like a point-and-click from the 90's. Or at least that's what I assume because I wasn't doing much video gaming in the 90's. All of the "puzzles" involved finding a specific item or combination of items to use in a particular way in a particular place to solve a problem. Most times it was pretty clear what needed to be done, and failing that just a little snooping around would uncover the solution. There was that one time though where the solution involved going back and forth through several areas to get different items, and I completely did not understand what I was supposed to do. Yeah, I looked up the solution to that one.One of my favorite things about Broken Age is the voice cast. Having people like Elijah Wood, Jennifer Hale, and Jack Black in the same game is delightful to my nerd brain. And Wil Wheaton playing a hipster lumberjack hiding from the talking trees was the best moment of my week.It took me just over four hours to complete Act 1, and they left us on quite the cliffhanger. It's definitely worth getting now, because Act 1 is a good length to finish in one or two sittings. This is one of the few games I have played that is appropriate for both adults and kids, so if you are a parent check it out. It's a little hard to name a good price because I have no idea how good Act 2 will be; if it keeps up the quality that Act 1 had, I would say that $20 is a good price.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2015
												I wish Steam had an option between positive and negative.  I didn't HATE this game...it had some things going for it like gorgeous animation, spot on voice acting, and a few times it genuinely made me laugh.  The ending of Part 1 was so fantastic and I utterly did not see coming.  But then in part two it wastes no time in bulldozing everything interesting about the first half and turning it into a very different much less interesting story. It almost felt like a betrayal. Nothing is really explained, there's plot holes big enough to fly a space ship through, and worst it doesn't even have much in the way of an ending rather then just stopping.  A good puzzle is the kind of thing that's challenging, but when you finally figure it out makes you go "oooooooh!".  These puzzles were not like that.  Some of the solutions were unbelievably obscure, even for a point and click adventure game.So while I can't say it's the worst thing I've ever played, based on all this it really just left me unsatisfied and wishing for it to have lived up to the potential the first half presented.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 7, 2015
												I can't recommend this game.Act 1 is short, fun, and whimsical. Its puzzles are easy, which allows you to explore the beautiful environments and meet all of the interesting characters without too many barriers in your way.Act 2, on the other hand, is just a frustrating mess. The entire act merely retreads the areas visted in Act 1, which removes the element of exploration that makes act 1 interesting. Worse yet, a lot of the puzzles are just ridiculous. Obvious solutions never work, and the actual solutions often make no sense in terms of why they would work or why the characters would try them. I've spent hours going through the levels clicking everything and trying to use my items on every object, and this is a common trend among players. For some puzzles, you have to go to the other character's perspective in order to find the solution, but the game never tells you when this is required, and it goes counter to everything you've done in act 1, so you might go through entire levels looking for answers that aren't there.After Double Fine spent over a year developing act 2, it's such a disappointment to see recycled environments and puzzles that are just badly designed and badly thought out. Perhaps those problems might be more forgivable if the quality of the story made up for it, but it doesn't. Despite the brilliant setup in act 1, neither of the two main characters undergo much if any character development in act 2. Instead, we're treated to a bad science fiction plot which tries to explain the superficial elements of the world, and yet still leaves many questions unanswered in the cliffhanger ending. The villains expose themselves as something out of a children's cartoon, and some of the dramatic reveals only make sense if you don't think too deeply about act 1.This game is a huge disappointment to me, and thinking about it still leaves a bitter taste in my mouth. If you want to see the interesting environments and the story that could have been, watch act 1 on youtube. If you must, watch act 2 on youtube as well. The game itself is absolutely not worth playing.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 7, 2015
												If you want to play half a game; by all means buy this game. I have been waiting forever for Act 2 of this game, and when it came I was disappointed beyond belief. This game was going so well, the storyline was perfect, there was good humor! Yet, when this final act of the game finally came out I wish it never did.Storyline:The storyline in Act 1 was perfect. It had the perfect setting with the perfect amount of humor. Act 2 completely obliterates all of what you know and love of the original setting and storyline (and not in a good way). To add to this; humor is less present and even when it is it is poor. The characters in Act 2 are so disconnected it isn't funny. I began to ask myself "Why can't I meantion this to that person?" questions. There are so many things any logical person would tell another if they were in Shay's or Vella's position; but they aren't options. It feels like most of the dialog was thrown together without anying logical thinking in Act 2.Puzzles:Act 1 took me quite a while to finish but Act 2 took  forever . Act 2's puzzles are more of a chore than an enjoyment. I tried for  three hours  to finish Act 2 without cheating; but it was inevitable. I finally looked up a guide and had to use it basically the rest of the way. Even after I got past my struggle; the puzzles were still basically impossible. Act 1 required no transfer of knowledge between characters or to write anything down. I loved Act 1's puzzles because I didn't have to write anything down; I could actually figure out the puzzles without a paper in an enjoyable and slightly difficult way. Act 2 you suddenly need to write things down. Act 2 you also have to take your knowledge of one character's environment to anothers: this is horrible! While other games have done it, Act 1 did not. This should not have been just thrown in like that for Act 2.Overall:I have lost all love for this game as a whole. I can never give this game a positive vote with the way Act 2 has been made. I loved this game so much when it was just Act 1; when it had a storyline, when it had humor, when it had puzzles, when it  was  a game, but Act 2 has sent it into the ground and made the last six to seven hours of the game a chore.

number of helpful: 8 of 13 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												I'm not sure that this game feels like a traditional point and click adventure to me. There is no really difficult puzzles, no pixel scanning with the cursor and no revisiting areas and dialog trees over and over again, causing that all familiar frustration that comes with most point and click adventures. I know from being a backer and watching the documentary that Tim Schafer wanted to avoid this type of frustration and he certainly has achieved it. At the expense of more difficult puzzles? Yes. But that's not a bad thing. I kind of do wish they were just slightly harder, but truly I am not that bothered at all.Instead, this game is smooth and fun to "play". It's like walking into a piece of art, not only visually but the music and voice acting are also brillant. I have seen a couple of comments where people have mentioned the Spoon character, which is just awesome. He reminds me of "Talky the Toaster" from Red Dwarf.The best bit about playing this game is that it takes you into another world from a collective (double fine) imagination, where you really want to see what happens next and how it all pans out. The story is really quite compelling. And just wow, that ending :) Vella's side of the story is the most artistic and fun to play, but to get the best from it play Shay's side first right to the end. Although, you can of course switch between the girl/boy side at any point and continue from where you left off. Just don't complete Vella's side before Shay's. At least for me, I'm certainly glad I did it in this order.It should take you around 4 hours to complete Act 1, not the two hours that many mention. I wonder if they have even played both sides yet? Or just followed the first guide that was released? At the very least they didn't take the time to explore the content and dialog. ALthough I did get stuck on the helmet puzzle for a bit (no spoilers!).To all those wondering about the cost of this game (£17.09 with 10% off pre-purchase) all I can say is.. How much does it cost you for a ticket to go watch a movie nowadays? £8-10 for 1.5 hours of entertainment? If Act 2 is another 4 hours long, you do the math. Overall, I really enjoyed it and couldn't put stop playing just for the story. Can't wait for Act 2!

content:
Posted: January 21
												Unfortunately, a good game was made bad by a terrible second half. I loved the game through the first act. The story kept itself interesting, there were some good twists, and I felt accomplished with each puzzle I solved. The beginning of the second act seemed good, but the further I got, the more awful it became. Terrible story progression, no good plot points, instantaneous "character development," and insane puzzles that are very obviously hard for the sake of adding difficulty, where I was not pleased with solving them, rather I felt like I wasted hours of my time trying to figure out illogical things that can be done in (literally) mere minutes. I was heartbroken to see such a good product turn sour when it was at its peak. It turned into a "try everything with everything" extravaganza where even doing that wouldn't get your solution sometimes. Think of it this way: there's an achievement for finishing the game in under an hour, and the poor implementation of puzzles stretched my game time to nearly 10 hours. It's exactly like having two games, with the first game being amazing, and the second one being bad enough to regret buying. Personally, I think the entire last quarter of the game should just be redone so that I can like this game. I really want to, but I can't.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												So I was slightly dismayed by the price point initially, especially with the reported length of ~4 hours, but I did not initially realize that this game is using an episodic structure. If you are at all familiar with Telltale's adventure game work over the past few years- Tales from Monkey Island, The Walking Dead, The Wolf Among Us, the Sam&Max games... so you're buying not only the game, but an unknown number of future acts in addition. Judging by history, you will probably get your money's worth by buying in on this.As for the game itself... initially I was expecting pretty much what I got; something silly, cute, and DEEPLY ♥♥♥♥ed up on a psychological level (as I fully expected and hoped for from something from the mind of Tim Schafer!). However... once I got to the end of the act and the plotlines were finally tied together, the "♥♥♥♥ed upped ness" reached a whole new wonderful level.If you have enjoyed ANYTHING in Tim Schafer's stable of products... Costume Quest, Brutal Legend, The Cave, Grim Fandango, Psychonauts, Full Throlttle, the first three Monkey Island games, Maniac Mansion or Day of the Tentacle...You will enjoy this game. And probably find in it a worthwhile purchase.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
												I have to say that playing Act I was fun and did remind me of the olde adventures of the past.  The artwork and music are both stunning and extremely well done, and the voice acting is pretty great with Elijah Wood, Jack Black and others making the game feel well put together.Unfortunately, Act II is repetitive, boring and frankly feels like a cheap rip-off of Act I.  The scenery is almost identical.  The wiring puzzles are a pain in the proverbial (so much so I resorted to checking walkthroughs online) and the whole thing feels smashed together into a big pile of useless goo.I, like many others dropped $35 or more on this as a backer. I am thoroughly disappointed with it.  The wait was way too long and I still would like to know how something this poor could blow away millions of investment from backers so easily.  I miss games like DOTT, and this certainly doesn't compare with those high standards at all.A true shame, really.  It could have been so much better if they'd changed the scenery (secret rooms in Mog, other locations for Shay for example) and thought outside the box about the puzzles, but so many are too complex or obscure, or simply too easy, to enjoy.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2015
												Almost one and a half year ago I praised this game for how interesting the setting was in Act 1: a boy trapped in a spaceship that doesent want him to be in danger, and a girl who haves to be sacrificed to a monster to save her village, but she's the only one who wants to fight that monster.In act one the story is so well driven, and the puzzles are fair and logical. Also most of the characters are very funny and interesting, but sadly very straight forward with little no backstory.Still, with such good premise, great art style and amazing plot twist at the end of Act 1, you expect that Act 2 would be a thrilling conclusion to this throwback to a different Point and Click era?Well, too ♥♥♥♥ing bad, because after one and a half year and 3.5 million dollars we got a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ending put togheter with spit and feces.The whole mistery around the plot made no sense, Shay's campain is all about finding some objects, that can really take 30 minutes at best (let's be honest, is way more fun to play with that guy then the other uninteresting character) and let's not mention that to complete some puzzles there's no logic: you're gonna need one clue from one of the two character to complete the other, thing is, they literally have no ways to contact with each others, not even telepaticly, and this is never explained through the whole game.The villian is just pathetic, same for his explanations, that have little no sense.This is just one angry fan talking about one and a half year of waiting and promises, and mostly expectation since this haves the work of Tim Shafer written all over it, the same person who created Psychonauts, Grim Fandango and Brutal Legends. I really had big hopes for this, now, I don't think anyone will trust any of his projects.

												This game as whole was a great experience, wonderful art direction, wonderful music, Alot of the puzzles were great, although some were difficult, but not impossible (plus every playthough changes a aspect of some specific puzzles in order to keep it difficult each time). The concept of two stories going at the same time was very well done, at first it felt very seperate, but as time goes by you notice that what you see in one side can help you with a puzzle in the other side, and I believe that was very clever. Story wise though, overall it could have been better, mostly for the ending, but it still was good, had a few good twists and it kept you thinking through out the game. Although from the looks of it alot of people did not seem to like the ending that much and thinks the game as a whole was horrible due to that. For me the journey is what matters and man that was a great journey. Plus it had a few cute ending credits pictures to get a good idea what happen after the game.Overall it was great and I recommend anyone to play it. As long as they don't care about the ending bieng a bit short in delivery.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												I don't usually write reviews but I just had to for Broken Age, mainly also because number of negative reviews here.In a short Broken Age is a "traditional" point and click adventure set in an interesting worlds. You controll two main charactes with possibility to switch between them any time, sometimes it is even necessary to find out a solution to puzzle in other character's "world". Main charactes are Vella, young girl which escapes her fate of a sacrifice for giant monster and Shay, a growing-up boy trying to escape his over-caring space ship. Plot is really interesting and I was hooked to see how will the two story lines cross or join.As for the puzzles, I have to say they are mostly fair. You are given an overall clear idea (or multiple goals) what has to be done and it is up to you to come up with the execution. Many people complain that some puzzles in Act II are unfair because you had to look for the answer with other character in his/hers world. I found it interesting and smart, requiring you to think outside of the box or pay attention to details. Kind of reminded me the old days of Day of the Tentacle.The art style and animation in game is beautiful, voice acting is excellent and dialogues are quite funny, I especially enjoyed Vella's interaction with "hipster" woodcutter. Not only because I like poop jokes :) What I didn't like so much is the harsh conclusion of the story. There was potential for Act III, it is shame that authors didn't extend the last part of the game to its own Act.

number of helpful: 13 of 23 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 30, 2014
												Okay, so I bought this game because I'm so very fond of point and click games, but I have to say this one was hyped up to be much more than it was. I loved so many things about this game. The beautiful graphics, the voice acting very good, and the soundtrack very nice. But for a point and click game, it left me with few things to click and explore, its so linear that its rather boring. The secondary characters are pretty flat and you aren't give enough interactions to care about anyone in the world, including the characters themeselves. The only character that actually had any depth was Vella, even the second MC, Shay was flat and boring. As for the puzzles themselves, they weren't challenging, and there was no real "challenge" to them really, Just find stuff and use it on the right person or place and oooh you've done it.I hate to be the nay-sayer among so many voices crying how good it is, but even from a story standpoint, if this act was supposed to get me interested in the characters and wanting to know more about their plights, this acts fell incredibly short. A real shame because I really really wanted to like this game and was hoping for a fresh and new game with all the beauty this game has.I can't say I hated this game, it wasn't annoying or gaudy in any way, it as just bland. Which is a real shame since the art is so rich and alive, I had been hoping for a story and a game with those things in equal measure.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2014
												Okay, so I bought this game because I'm so very fond of point and click games, but I have to say this one was hyped up to be much more than it was. I loved so many things about this game. The beautiful graphics, the voice acting very good, and the soundtrack very nice. But for a point and click game, it left me with few things to click and explore, its so linear that its rather boring. The secondary characters are pretty flat and you aren't give enough interactions to care about anyone in the world, including the characters themeselves. The only character that actually had any depth was Vella, even the second MC, Shay was flat and boring. As for the puzzles themselves, they weren't challenging, and there was no real "challenge" to them really, Just find stuff and use it on the right person or place and oooh you've done it.I hate to be the nay-sayer among so many voices crying how good it is, but even from a story standpoint, if this act was supposed to get me interested in the characters and wanting to know more about their plights, this acts fell incredibly short. A real shame because I really really wanted to like this game and was hoping for a fresh and new game with all the beauty this game has.I can't say I hated this game, it wasn't annoying or gaudy in any way, it as just bland. Which is a real shame since the art is so rich and alive, I had been hoping for a story and a game with those things in equal measure.

number of helpful: 13 of 23 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												I liked this game. I think? It's complicated, okay!Well, it isn't that I can't recommend this game. I would, to certain kinds of people and I know for sure that they are out there, it's just that I wouldn't to the majority out there. But let's get into this because as I said: It's complicated...Let's talk about the mechanics first. It's your standart Point'n'Click Adventure. Inventory system's a bit wonky but it does its job. Collect items, drag and drop, solve puzzles. That's about it. The only new and interesting thing - and the one that drew me to it in the first place - is that you switch between the two main protagonists and experience the world from their points of view. They didn't really do anything with it mechanic-wise until Part 2 though, so up until then it was only a gimmick really. But a nice one. I enjoyed switching between charakters every other puzzle and it helped to paint a better picture of the world and its story, in my opinion. Oh, story. In theory I should love this game. For me narrative is more key to a great experience than mechanics (a blend between the two being the "perfect game") which is why I enjoy games that do focus on it more than I do "skill-based" ones. Adventure games typically one of the genres that shine in that regard. And the story to Broken Age is interesting. Well, the ending of Part 1 that is and some of Part 2 up until its rather anticlimatic finish. All in all it's a story of coming-of-age, paralells and juxtapositions between the protagonists drawn rather well. All characters are likeable, the voice work is well done, the humour keeps your attention but nothing really stands out much.Looking at the other arts as well, the designs are great and so is the music, the animation does its job and all in all they work together well. But never before in my life have I found myself so physically tired while playing a game. Not frustrated, not bored, not overjoyed, not laughing - nothing. And that's a pitty because I like this game. It just does everything well but supposedly not well enough for me to really be enjoying it. And even when thinking back about the games I've played in my life this one will probably be forgotten somewhere down the line and to be honest, I'm kind of sad about it. Well, if you want to give it a try I can't NOT recommend it either. It's a bit pricey for the experience you get out of it, in my opinion, so if you ever catch it on sale and are curious about it, please, do help yourself. And I hope you'll be able to enjoy it more than I have.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												I was lured into purchasing this title because it promoted a throwback to old school point-and-click adventure games like Monkey Island. While indeed it is point-and click, it is by no means a throwback to those of yesteryear. The puzzles were beyond easy. I kept half expecting Dora the Explorer to pop up and ask me, " Do you see see the triangle?", with the preceding pause and eventual highlighting of the object. This was only enhanced by the art direction of the game. It is done very much in the style of Nick Jr. cartoons. But, I figured what the game was lacking in animation it would make up for in both storyline and mechanics. I was sadly disappointed. The storyline fit the art direction. Meaning, it would be entertaining for an audience of toddlers. And this same thread followed into the mechanics as well. Which Items could be interacted with were very obvious in the environment: oversized, brightly colored, etc, compared to the old LucasArts games that would take hours, days, or months to discover what needed to be done next to progress forward.  To sum things up, if you loved point-and-click titles, like The Secret of Monkey Island, THE DIG, and LOOM, you're better off replaying them. However, if you enjoyed those titles, and want a game for your toddler, than look no further.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												When Double Fine went to Kickstarter, it constantly reminded us of the past great adventure games like Grim Fandango and Day of The Tentacle to get people (including me) to contribute. So why is the "final" product NOTHING like these games? The graphical style alone has divided people but the rest of the game feels nothing like the old Lucas Arts adventures - the comedy is lacking, the puzzle quality is lacking, the colourful characters are lacking, the wacky art style is lacking ... it's just ... dull. And to realize how much money they blew on making this game when other Kickstarter games like Tesla Effect did much MUCH more with far less money, it makes you wonder what on earth happened. The free adventure game "Host Master" was a far better game than this and it didn't cost 3 million dollars to make. Not only is Broken Age proof that quality games are not made by a single "big" name but rather by talented teams, it's also proof that lots of funds can still leave you with only half a game with an indie feel and look that realistically barely even covers 10% of the amount they raised.Basically: big thumbs down.

number of helpful: 15 of 27 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2014
												The game is split in two parts, the boy's part and the girl's part. Both parts are too short, even though it's just the first half of the game. I finished it in 6 hours, and I'm sure you could do it in four.The boy part is very babyish. The puzzles at the beginning are extremely simple, which is of course intended, but still I think it would bore even a child of 12. Even when the boy meets the wolf (which actually looks more like a fox), things stay rater simple. The graphics on the screen of the "rescue machine" are horrible, this whole rescue thing doesn't feel real, but is very abstract and silly.The girl part is much better. I even actually like this part of the plot. There are some jokes (finally) and even some puzzles that aren't just trivial. (They aren't very hard either, but that's OK.) The part tastes a little too girlish for me, but that's just my opinion. I liked the two sentinels and the puking tree best.The graphics are quite nicely painted in general. This is even the case in the boy part of the plot (apart from the rescue machine's screen). The problem with the scenery in that part is that everything looks so baby-like, I can't help disliking it. In the girl part, I especially like the slow animation of plants in some screens, or the birds in the sky at the beach. When there is a closeup, however, graphics become very blurry. Also, apart from some smoke and a laser ray, there's almost no special effects.I like the fact that the music was played by a real orchestra. Unfortunately, it doesn't make much difference, because the game lacks of a recognisable theme. There is no opening sequence, no central score, so the music stays just in the background. The thing with background music is that it tends to get on your nerves after some time. I would have liked it better if there was one score that appeared in cutscenes, while the rest of the game would stick to ambient sound effects.The overall impression of the game is not very good. It's too short, babyish, girlish, unchallenging, uninspiring. I'm not sure if I am going to be willing to invest six more hours playing the second part when it's out.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												I bought this game during the summer sale, and it was well worth the VERY LOW price I paid.  Unfortunately, I cannot recommend it for the full retail price.  So why do I recommend this game, anyway?  Read on...First Impressions     The first thing you will notice are the well-scripted animations for each character.  The art style is quite appealing to the eyes, and fluidity between actions is definitely there.  The game is played by switching between the perspectives of a young man (Shay) and young girl (Vella); I started my playthrough as Vella and was instantly sold on the story.Game Structure     The game is split into two acts, and for me the first act was more story-driven, while the second act was very puzzle-driven.  As I mentioned, the story is pretty good and I always wanted to uncover more, but the climax and ending fell short of my expectations.  The second issue I have with the game are the puzzles, which I will explain in more detail...The Puzzles     Ah yes, the puzzles!  If you go and read discussions (SPOILERS IN THERE) you will find that many people are complaining that the puzzles for this game are way too hard to the point that they are "moon logic" puzzles.  I somewhat disagree.  During my first (and only) playthrough I found that the solutions to two particular puzzles were very farfetched and even said aloud to myself in both instances, "who would ever think to do that?".  Near the very end of the game is a third puzzle that is actually very complex and difficult to solve, but I ended up enjoying it since I had some pen and paper ready for notes.  This third puzzle alone easily took me about an hour to complete and is the puzzle that many people complain about.  In my opinion, some of the other puzzles were more confusing and tedious.  All-in-all, I liked the mix of puzzle difficulty and adventure, but I have to admit that I used a walkthrough on more than one occasion when I felt stuck (which is hard to do if you don't want to spoil the rest of the game).  So, if you are not super casual and have the patience to spend an hour or more on a single problem, then you will most likely enjoy this game.Recommendation     Now for the reason I cannot recommend it for the full retail price of $25: a very bad ending.  Everything up to the very end of the game answered enough questions to keep me thoroughly entertained.  However, once you complete the game you are left with a series of images on the credits screen that fill in the final bits of the story.  It helps explain what people ended up doing once the story has concluded, but it fails to answer many questions about the final scene of the game.  I had so many questions about the origins of Mog Chothra, the Plague Dam, Sugar Bunting's past (as Steel Bunting), and why the Volta's and Alex had to be tricked.  Also, the concluding scene never explains how the attack is abruptly stopped, why the whole operation had to play out for "as long as anyone remembers", and what happened to Vella's grandmother or why she was in Sugar Bunting.My Final Judgement     If you can buy this game on sale then it is probably worth it, even if the ending is not that great.  The game had enough charm and other positive qualities for me to recommend it, but I would not have bought it if I had to pay $25./Review

content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												I am not that good at point and click adventures yet I love the heck out of them... I usually have to find the answers to the puzzles on the net after the first few... with that said I found this game to NEED ALMOST NO SKILL AT ALL... the puzzles are so simple they give away the answers. I kept waiting for the tutorial to be over... but it never got any harder... there was nothing that took me more than 5 min to figure out and 90% of the game I did without even having to think out the puzzle since it was so obvious... The game IS beautiful and the story IS interesting but it’s so short it had me reading the Steam return policy to see if there was a time limit in which I could return the game because it was over that quick...Steam shows I have 3 hours in the game total and about an hour of that was the game on pause to make dinner... I see NOTHING about this game that says 3 MILLION dollars was put into it... I am very disappointed and feel ripped off. Maybe if the game was finished or maybe if it didn't COST $25 dollars? This is a $9.99 game at best... I mean you get 2 to 3 hours TOPS with BOTH story modes and there wasn't much else for side quest or exploration... such a letdown. I will be finishing it when the update comes out only since it’s free... if I could return it and NOT finish it later I would... I knew I should have just watched a let’s play instead of buying it but with all the RAVE reviews I thought "how could I possibly go wrong?" Well it did... To sum it up this "game" is WAY TOO SHORT & WAY TOO EASY to be a $25 dollar game... and it has almost ZERO replayability... I still to this day break out Monkey Island and give it a run though on my tablet every now and then... I just don't see it with this game... unless they wow me with chapter two... I really got to ask WHERE DID THE MONEY GO?

content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												A massive let down. It started out great in Act 1 but then takes a huge nose dive in Act 2. When the second Act came out, I expected more places to explore and better character development. Instead you just wander back and forth in the same areas, but as different characters, and whatever personality the two protagonist have in Act 1, is ignored in Act 2. For example, Shay has lived most of his life in a daycare prison ship, and he clearly wants out to experience something new. When he does get out, he basically goes "Sweet, I'm outside." and that's it. Any emotional response from the two characters is nonexistent in Act 2. The ending of the game is bland and unsatisfying. I expected something more on the emotional side, but it just sorta stops in its tracks. If there was a way to uninstall Act 2, I would. For those who bought the game, just stick to Act 1, and for those who don't, just watch a Let's Play of it and save your money.
