number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												Broken Age is a point-and-click adventure game, featuring two separate characters controlled by the player interchangeably. Vella and Shay, two teenagers living very different lives, find their worlds thrown into chaos as their fates are intertwined. GraphicsThe graphics in this game are gorgeous. Not in the “Wow that looks so real” sense, but the “Such a beautiful work of art” sense. Every visual asset in the game appears to be produced by hand, leading to a stunning experience. The nice thing about Broken Age, compared to some other point-and-click adventure games I have played, is the interaction points do not immediately stand out. You know how sometimes an object in a 2D game that is intended to move just looks different? This game does not do that.StorySo, Broken Age was originally released as just Act 1. Double Fine have since updated the game, and it now contains both Act 1 and Act 2. And I have to say, I almost liked it better when it was just Act 1. Act 1 was definitely focused on the character development, and fleshing out the game world. Act 2, on the other hand, was far more puzzle-orientated, and not what I was expecting after going through Act 1.Why I hated itCutting this review short here, as I have less to say about this game than normal. The puzzles, especially at the end, became very frustrating. I may not be that great at puzzles in general, but some of these just seemed entirely counter-intuitive. Final RecommendationIf you are a fan of the genre, this game is definitely a good one. If you are new to point-and-click adventures, this may not be the right place to start. It is a little… unique.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												I'm one of those who backed the game on Kickstarter three years ago and, being a long time Tim Schafer fan, with a substantial amount of money (and boy, does my now completely worn backer t-shirt look great!).I hate episodic gaming, so I was really disappointed when I came to know the game would be split in two chapters. I decided to wait until the whole game would be out, which resulted in a LONG wait. Eventually, the game came out and we played it. Was I happy with it? Well, yes and no... If you're wondering whether I recommend the game, the answer is yes. But don't expect the masterpiece that we were all waiting for, considering the names involved.The two chapters are so different in terms of story and gameplay that you cannot help but talk about them separately: you probably already heard up to the point of nausea of what everybody talked about. Of how more story-rich but incredibly easy the first part was, and how the puzzles were much harder in the second part where they forgot adding some story though. That's completely true, and depending on your inclination towards adventure games you'll most definitely like one of the two parts much more than the other. I personally prefer richer puzzles and so I enjoyed the second part more, gameplay-wise, but I totally agree that the first part was much more interesting in terms of scenarios, characters, dialogues and story. The second part seems to almost completely cast them aside, which is a pity.Anyway, since this is supposed to be a review on the game as a whole, let's focus instead on what unites the two parts. First of all, the UI: I don't think I ever hated the UI of a point'n'click adventure so much. It was so obviously conceived for touch interfaces that you cannot help but feel deprived of a much richer experience. There is just a single button for everything: no one was expecting the SCUMM verbs, but was a left/right click interface too much to ask for? This results in a much limited experience in terms of user interaction, as watching/using/talking/etc. are all done the same way, and the game decides what to do for you. Apart from that, I'm also not a fan of how the game looks: I guess the cardboard look&feel was specifically conceived like that, but it feels cheap, especially considering the budget. The music, while decent, is quite forgettable as well, which is a stab in the heart if we think Peter McConnel composed it.At this point you might be wondering: well, if all of this sucked so far, why are you recommending the game? Well, it's still a Tim Schafer game and it feels like it. Dialogues are (most of the times) funny, and, especially in the second part, puzzles are clever and rewarding. The music is often dull but pleasant and, while as explained I'm not a fan of the graphics, there is some art that is really good to look at (the clouds world, for instance).Just don't expect a masterpiece and you'll enjoy some 12-13 hours of your life.

												I'm challenged to write this review.  I would not recommend this game for, say, myself.  It is a bit tedious and repetitive, the puzzles are simple or random, and there's a lot of repetition.  The UI is a bit clunky too.  But it's a game I would recommend to people who yearn for King's Quest-type games.  The story is actually really good, or has the potential to be.  The acting is great, the voices are compelling and not annoying, the music is good too.  In fact, everything about this game is great, except that instead of giving me times when I might stop and think, it just encouraged me to click more faster.  It also suffers from typical parallel-story problems, in that one is dramatically more compelling than the other.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2015
												"Broken Age" is an adventure game that lets you dive into the adventures of Shay and Vella - two young people who live their lives without a connection to each other. Shay lives in his own, colourful spaceship run by his mother and Vella lives in a bakery town that prepares for the traditional "maidens feast". Unfortunately Vella is one of the maidens to be sacrificed to the hideous monster Mog Chotrha. But she is unwilling to bow down to senseless traditions while Shay is unwilling to play childish games practicly as a prisoner every day. But big events will offer them new perspectives and tasks...In "Broken Age" you pretty much solve puzzles the old school way (like in the classic LucasArts adventures or in "Simon the Sorcerer"): you talk to people in order to squeeze out information, you collect items, you explore environments and objects and you figure out specific patterns for puzzle solutions. And when I mean "old school way" then I also mean that the puzzles are far from easy. Sure, some are quite obvious but many others are very hard to figure out and some also demand perfect timing. This makes the game challenging and thanks to its length it will keep you entertained and occupied for a couple of hours (personally I needed about 16 to 17 hours in total). But prepare for a few frustrating moments as some puzzles demand you to think around a few corners to figure out a possible solution.The gameplay is easy - point and click. Also you can switch between Shay and Vella anytime (which reminded me of "Day of the Tentacle" where you switch between three people).But what about the story? Personally I think it's very fine. I dig the characters and the environments they're in. I just couldn't quite get the evil plan from the villains. I won't spoil it here but let's just say that I think this could all sound more logical.Also I really like that this game obviously spoofs cults and superstition, the ways people are made to believe stupid things in order to enrich a leader or to establish rituals that do nothing than silence one's conscience (and hurt others).There's a lot of humour in the game and it gave me a few good laughs wether it's due to absurd dialogues or to funny visuals and animations but the jokes never felt flat.I wanna say about the graphics that they are just beautiful to look at. Pure eye candy! This all looks like a hand-painted, colourful story book (only with moving, talking people). I enjoyed the visuals and also the animations to the end.The soundtrack is very likeable, too. I bought it as a DLC on Steam and don't regret it. Different but fitting tunes and styles give the game another awesome touch.The voices were very well selected, in my opinion. Elijah Wood voices Shay, Masasa Moyo (who I know best as Sarah from "Team America") voices Vella and both do a great job in giving these characters their personality. But the other voice actors and actresses are great as well.The most criticized part of "Broken Age" is the second act (of three). Many people complain that the story feels half-done or just not good enough. Personally, I don't quite get what the deal here is. I enjoyed the second act as I did the first one. What disappointed me was the ending that felt too sudden and short. In the end, can I recommend "Broken Age"? Absolutely.If you love solving puzzles and playing (old school) adventures then this is certainly for you. Give it a chance!In my opinion it's not the best adventure game ever but at least one of the best and most beautiful in the last few years.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
												Tim Schafer does it again in this point-and-click adventure game funded by fellow backers of Kickstarter. This game reminds me of the old Humongous Entertainment games I used to play as a child except intended for older audiences and the puzzles are very creative in this game. Both the themes of the characters you play as are similar in that they are "breaking" away from a tradition- a young man who has been treated like a child for most of his life wants to "break" away from his computer mother in order to prove he is old enough to handle himself while a young woman wants to "break" a custom in her village that has been done for years in order to prevent further villagers from sacrificing their lives.The artwork in this game is truly amazing. One of the most beautiful games I have ever played to date. The orchestrated music really fits the atmosphere this game delivers. Best of all, the dialogue is well written and funny to listen to. In fact, most of voice actors in this game are big name voice actors like Jennifer Hale, Richard Horvitz, Wil Wheaton, Elijah Wood, Jack Black, and even Pendleton Ward (creator of Adventure Time)!I really enjoyed Act I of this game and cannot wait for Act II!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
												'Broken Age' is a delightful, whimsical and funny adventure game from LucasArts alumnus, Tim Schafer. It features some of the most beautifully animated and visually unique graphics in adventure games I have seen to date. The puzzles are not particularly challenging, but creative enough to keep you entertained. This is particularly so for Act 1, and it's unfortunate that Act 2 fails to realize the game's full potential.The game was released in two parts, sadly almost a year apart. Act 1 features one of the more creative stories in PC adventure games. It is full of surprises and intrigue as we do not quite know how our two playable protagonists' storylines relate to each other -- if at all! The similarities and differences between the protagonists, in their upbringing and relationships with those around them, told through parallel gameplay make the introductions to these characters all the more enjoyable. Act 1 plays like a game about adolesence, rebellion, empowerment and curiosity that ends with a great cliffhanger, making you yearning for more of this "something (thematically) different".Now, in the time that it took for Double Fine Productions to churn out Act 2, one would expect them to produce something worthy to follow the (doubly?) fine first chapter. Sadly, no. Unlike Act 1, Act 2 feels like an average classic adventure game, in which you solve a long series of isolated puzzles to achieve a single objective -- and you get to do it for two characters! This may be more acceptable if it weren't for us visiting the same locations and interacting with the same characters again. Plus, the protagonists do not seem to be at a disadvantage despite being in wholly unfamiliar settings relative to their prior experience. Such wasted opportunities for adding a new layer of challenge to the gameplay!Act 2 does bring a few new twists. While these twists are interesting, they fail to enlighten or completely surprise me. In fact, these twists confuse me more, making me ask questions that I surprisingly find the characters not asking throughout Act 2. If questions are asked, they are asked by the wrong protagonist, as if the protagonists share a psychic connection through the player. The inconsistency in characterization and storytelling perspective make the gaming experience slightly jarring.Perhaps Act 2 will be more enjoyable if 'Broken Age' were not released in two parts. If so, perhaps the wonder, magic and intrigue of Act 1 would have spilled over to the second act, and I would not have felt the "been-there-done-that" effect as greatly. (Hmm, maybe that's why Tim Schafer recommended replaying Act 1 before playing Act 2?) Despite my criticism of Act 2, 'Broken Age' as a whole is a good game. It is one of the better adventure games out there; it is easy to pick up and enjoy, and I recommend this feel-good game. As long as you keep your expectations in check, you are unlikely to be disappointed by it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19
												DON'T BUY THIS GAME UNLESS IT IS BELOW $5Broken age is a game with a great set up with little to no pay-off. If the game had carried the awesome aspects of Act 1 into  Act 2 I wouldn't be so disappointed.First we can talk a bit about Act 1 before I highlight some issues with the overall game. Act 1 is a great level of storytelling, put into beautiful and creative environments. I honestly couldn't stop playing throughout Act 1 just to see what would happen next. Vella and shay's stories both had me wondering how they could possibly be connected and what this world was like. The puzzles were also creative and mostly made logical sense.Unfortunately as other reviews have said, this falls apart in Act 2. Act 2 feels rushed and unimaginative at best. Very few of the actual plot points are answered adequately, if they are answered at all. Most of them are answered in a very short dialogue with Marek, in which he vaguely hints about the reasons for their actions. This seems like Double Fine came up with the initial concept, then just slapped the first idea for an ending on it and called it a day. This however is only a minor flaw in comparsion to the puzzles within Act 2. The puzzles in Act 2 are riduculous, obtuse and lazy. It is almost impossible to solve the puzzles without having some sort of guide to show you what you need to do. Many puzzles in Act 2 give 0 hints on what you need to do and don't seem to have any reason behind them. I was only able to complete the game by using a guide and even then I thought they were frustrating and dumb. The puzzles also seem to go against or have no basis in the characters motivations. Often it doesn't seem like the characters have any reason or understanding of why they are doing these actions or the goal they are trying to accomplish. This just gets worse as you near the ending of the game.The last section of the game make no sense in terms of the plot or in the way you accomplish puzzles. You need to get both characters to do independant actions that they would seemingly have no actual reason to do. It doesn't help that part of these actions is distracting the competant characters so that your characters can complete the game. If the game had an actual ending that left the player satisfied rather then frustrated, this could have been a great game. Unfortunatly because of what seems like a phoned in ending it takes what could have been a 5 star game to 2 to 2.5. If you can get this game for really cheap and you are really into point and click adventure games, then its an alright buy. however, at the current full price of $27.99 CDN I can not recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 10
												This game is such an excellent example of what can be done with current tech for the timeless point and click genre. The visuals are bold, bright, and colorful, and I love how they achieved an illustrative effect for an interactive game. The voice acting is superb, and I loved hearing actors I love as hilarious characters. The story is so fun, it has funny and heavy moments, and they did a good job of executing a story with complex elements and character development. It was great to have such unique and brave male and female characters, with a story that touched on very 'human' elements. My only criticisms would be: (1) at times, the puzzles veer into being too simple or too abstract, which can make for a frustrating problem that limits player brainstorming (hate being forced to check online for hints, it suspends the story), and (2) the second part of the game loses a lot of its wonder and becomes a bit monotonous. It's still an excellent and enjoyable story and I have shared it with eager players. Those problems just feel a bit disappointing for an otherwise fantastic game. I would still recommend giving it a try, and the sale price is definitely worth it!Pros:-Fun story that is both funny and complex-Wonderfully interwoven experiences of the main characters-Great voice acting (hilarious cameos of well known actors)-Visuals are top-notch, love the color pallette -Part 1 puzzles are fun and intuitiveCons:-Story gets a bit slow in the second part-Part 2 puzzles sometimes get complexly abstract or lack intuitiveness

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
												Double Fine poses the question of what could adventure games have become if they were as popular now as they were back in the nineties, and they delivered what I consider one of the most memorable adventure games of recent years; while it comes short in comparison with adventure games of yore like Tales of Monkey Island and my personal favorite Grim Fandango, it still manages to communicate that sense of discovery of an unknown and charming world with mysteries, twists, puzzles, and of course a great sense of humor that adventure games are known for.While the story does fall short in act II when compared to what act I promised, it still is a good tale of coming of age, the puzzles are challenging but fair, and while I needed no hints or guides to complete them that doesn't mean that newcomers to the formula will have difficulties on the later half of the game, nevertheless that's also part of the charm of adventure games and the feeling of genius when you finally complete that puzzle that has been stumping you for the past half hour is what I miss the most on modern adventure games.The art style and animation are gorgeous, at each new scene I had to stop playing for a second and soak in all of it, and the places where the game goes are truly delightful, I've played other hand painted adventure games but none other comes close to the beauty of these environments.If you have finished the game I'd recommend watching the documentary series of its making on youtube, 


YouTube™ Video: Double Fine Adventure! EP01: "A Perfect Storm For Adventure" 

			Views: 141,400		

			http://adventure.doublefine.com/ Available on Blu-ray from Fangamer - https://www.fangamer.com/products/broken-age-special-edition-with-double-fine-adventure-documentary Available digitally on Steam,...		

 it's an amazing insight both into game development and the challenges the team faced while making the game which any aspiring game developer or game enthusiast should watch.Broken Age is an amazing game that both adventure game veterans and newcomers should experience.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												[Currently at the beginning of Act 2]This game has so many good things. The animation (which is what it truly is) is beautiful. I felt many times that I was watching something, rather than playing a game, because the actions were so fluid. The dialogue/voice acting is on point. Witty with a sprinkling of sarcasm, but definitely whimsical.The action/gameplay is a point-and-click, which appeals to me. It reminds me of the 90's computer games, but the setting and the styling make it seem fresher rather than retro-cool.The puzzles can be challenging, but not so much so that you rage-quit. Two things on my con list, and they're connected: Shay's story and the game as a whole seem too short. While I didn't finish in one long playthrough, it could easily be done (and in fact, one of the Steam achievement's is to finish the game in less than an hour). I'm not finished yet, but I can already tell that I'll be left wanting more.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												Broken Age was a fun point and click that had an interesting story with a suprise plot twist ending that left me wanting more. You have the option to play between two story lines, one of a boy named Shay and the other of a girl named Vella, both living in two very different worlds. Vella lives a life where young girls are sacraficed to a monster in order to keep their villages safe and Shay lives a life of solitude trapped in a space station he's grown up in all his life. I've played Act One so far and I can't wait to play Act Two when it comes out. For sure a recommended game. If you're still unsure of whether or not to buy it, I did a let's play on the game. Go to my videos and check out the first few episodes, hopefully it'll help give you a better idea if this is the kind of game for you.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												Experience on Linux so far:+ SolidThe game:As a huge fan of point-and-click adventures this game tickled my old school nerves in the most pleasant of ways possible. The artwork is wonderful, I wish they would have a replay button just to replay certain scenes for their artistic attributes alone. You play as two main characters (a boy and a girl) and you can switch storyline between them as you please.This is a nice way of getting away from the monotamy of the old-school point-and-clickers.Voice acting is a big part in PAC games these days and this game nails it. I recognize a few names, most notably would be Jack Black, but overall the dialogs and characters come to live both through the beautiful animations and the excellent voice acting.The game comes in two parts, the first part (out now) was outstanding, albeit short compared to even the mid 90's games in the genre. For the price I paid, yeah, maybe another two hours of gameplay, but I still think it was well worth it for maybe one of the best games in the genre ever.Score:5/5

content:
Posted: December 11, 2016
												I will review all my humble bundle games and see which is worth playing and which is not! Like a lot of people i buy H.B. games as a pack because i want some of the games, but not all. I will play for 5 minutes (or a litlle bit more) and give you my opinion on it. Sometimes the game will surprise me, sometimes it will be a total dissapointment. Just keep in mind this is my opinion only and is not an objective view of the game. You might actually like it!The review will be constructed into 5 parts:1. Game description (from what i've seen in the time i've played).2. Did i finish the game (YES/NO/Maybe in the future) and why.3. Pros/Cons.4. Final thoughts.5. RatingSo let's beggin...1. Game description:A point and click adventure game with a small twist. You play as 2 different characters and cand switch between them whenever you want. At first it is very simple but after a while it gets a little bit complicated and a little bit counterintuitive, but nothing  too complicated. Astonishing visuals, and although I am not a big fan of hand drawn games, this one did it beautifully. The environments and atmosphere are totally gorgeous , the music fits perfectly in, and the voice acting is beautiful. Thought I recognized some voices but only at the end credits did I realize that that was because  some major Hollywood actors voiced the characters.The story unfolds before you and is very well done.2. Did i finish the game? YESOnce in a while H.B. manages to surprise me. This game is one of those games. It caught me completlly offguard and I finished it all in one sitting. It has been a while since a game got me pinned to my screen for so long. I was not expecting this. 3. Pros/Cons.PROS:- Nice visuals- Funny - Great voice acting- Good storyCONS:- A few puzzles are counterintuitive  4. Final thoughts:I cannot recommend this game enough. Just  get it and buy it! You will be pleasantly surprised even if you are not a big fan of point and click adventure games.5. Rating9.5/10

content:
Posted: February 27, 2016
												In general this is a very fun easy-going game. I wouldn't necessarily classify it for children as some of the puzzles are challenging to solve, and there are some adult-themed jokes. However, there's not really any violence per se, nor profanity, etc. The game play is pretty simple click and interacting. Some of the puzzles while if you put some thought into them , they are solvable, a minority of solutions I think would be difficult to come across if only by chance. The storyline itself is very unique, and I love how the two worlds of Vella and Shay come together in an unexpected way. For the price it is actually very reasonable. I got about 10 hours of some very enjoyable time out of the game. I would say it might have some replay value but not much. But if I compare it to spending $10 on a movie ticket that entertains me for 2 hours, I would say I'm getting a deal out of this game. I definetly would purchase games like this from Double Fine, and hope they come out with similar games in the future. I already have their Hack in Slash was is humurous, but not as story rich.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												Like most things, whether you like this game or not is really just going to depend on who you are, what you like, and what you are willing to put up with.Personally, I was very disappointed with this game. The first act set up a really interesting story! And as much as I hate cliffhangers, I was totally on board for the second half of the game. Storywise, for me, it was like getting a wet dishrag for a christmas gift. The story goes completely tepid by the end, which is extra unfortunate because it made doing the ending puzzles that much more tedious. I can be totally into a tedious puzzle if I'm actually interested in the story outcome of the puzzle, but it really felt like a movie where all the actors stop acting and just start reading their lines from a prompter. By the end, I honestly didn't care what happened to any of the characters. Which is kind of really bad in a game that's essentially all story.Also, wrapping up a story in little sketches during the credits is just asinine. I used to love you, Double Fine, but I don't think I'll be buying your stuff anymore.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												Sadly a failure. While the game is both beautiful, funny and engaging, it fails in story and length,Act 1 proved to be well made and promised a longer and more complex act 2 that would wrap up the storyline. Sadly the game is rushed, many plot points are never resolved and the puzzles are less intuitive (although not very difficult or impossible, as some reviews will have you believe). The second act is also about the same length as the first, and almost no new environments or characters are introduced. In many ways I enjoyed Broken Age, but after waiting three years it really feels like a rushed disappointment. I wish I could give a good review, but I cannot in good faith do that. If you want to get it, buy it at a discount.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
												Even with a beautiful art style, animation, and voice acting, Broken Age turns into a dreadful game. The puzzles start out whimsical and somewhat charming, eventually becoming frustrating and downright asinine.  The gameplay relies heavily on backtracking, trial and error, and obtuse "logic".  You will be forced to run circuits throughout the same 6-8 scenes over and over and over again, deseperately seeking to stumble upon some absurd situation, or item-combining nightmare, for which no precendent was set.  This leaves you swinging blindly most of the time, just trying to trigger the next element to some puzzle that really has nothing to do with anything.Imagine, as a child, it is your birthday, and your parents throw a wonderful party; it's nicely decorated, and your friends show up in elaborate costumes; the presentation of it all is amazing.  It is not announced, but now it's time for party games; it's time to break the pinata!  ...because... well, you know you have to break a pinata.  ...but, you don't know where it is.  So you run back and forth across the various sections of the yard, and all throughout the house, looking for any sign of the pinata.  The clues to its whereabouts also probably involve calling random strangers in the phonebook until you discover someone who is also having their own birthday party.  You should probably get them find and take apart an old VCR though (hint: they don't own one; nobody does anymore), because ...WELL, JUST DO IT.  Then, with the VCR in pieces, which you know has something to do with the solution to something somewhere, it still doesn't make any sense.  Instead, you wander and cry for an hour before you finally stumble upon where the pinata is hidden.  Except, you have no implement to destroy the pinata, and are not tall enough to reach it. Then you realize that trading your aunt some string for a piece of gum, which you then place in the path of the Roomba that is vacuuming the house, will cause it to make a loud whining sound that causes someone outside at the party to trip and fall into the pinata, breaking it apart.  Except there are no treats inside, only tears -- tears of the fallen gods, who died out long ago after playing this game.There is some genuinely funny humor in places, but it is peppered in among cliches, and contrived circumstances built seemingly to make a joke.  The dialog and voice acting is otherwise top-notich, though the quality of Act 2 overall, especially in cutscenes, did not feel well-honed, giving it a sense that the project was rushed.  There are some good ideas in places, such as with sharing puzzle solutions between protagonists, but they are executed in such a frustrating way that makes playing the game an exercise in patience and tolerance.Perhaps all of the shortcomings of the puzzles and backtracking could be overlooked if the payout of the story delivered something surprising or exciting, but it never does.  The only twist in the game comes early in Act 1, and the rest of the narrative just leans on absurd puzzle situations without actually delivering an interesting overall story.  For as odd, and deeply imaginative as the setting and situations are, the story falls flat and doesn't deliver any incentive to see it through.  There is just no payout, and that's what makes this the most disappointing.  If you must play this, do it with a walkthrough at the ready.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
												Broken Age, when looked at as two seperate parts, starts out very promising and then starts to decline around the beginning of Act Two.Act One is short and sweet. It introduces the characters and world with a beautiful, handdrawn, storybook-like aesthetic. It presents enough plot elements to keep you interested and intriged enough to see the Act to its conclusion. It explores themes centered around coming of age and rebellion as well as the potential dangers associated with each. A number of interesting characters are introduced and it evokes a sense of Schafer's classic titles.Insert a year and a bit of waiting. Now take everything established in the first game and swap the characters. Very few new locations (usually single, one-off rooms), only a few new characters and a number of awkward puzzles to lengthen playtime. Also, the story goes a bit off the rails.The fundemental problem with Broken Age Act Two is that the more of its story it reveals, the more ridiculous it becomes. When you finally learn the antagonist's motivation for everything you realize it has almost nothing to do with the core themes presented in Act One. It's underwhelming in every regard.This would all be forgivable if the gameplay was worthwhile. While some of the puzzles are clever and funny, others are an exercise in tedium. The worst part is that some puzzles play by their own rules. For example, I had an idea of how to complete the knot untying puzzle before I presented the necessary items to complete it. Because I remembered a previous knot and requested instructions to untie it after I had all the items, the solution was no longer valid. The correct order was to have all the items first then present them to the NPC then look at the knot then go back to the NPC...... then do this two more times (at least there was a fast travel)...... Why did it have to be three times?Then the wiring/rewiring and final puzzle was a royal pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ If the order you had wasn't perfect for the final puzzle, you had to restart, rewire, reswitch, and reposition yourself until you got it right. If you made a single mistake you had to start from the very beginning.It also brings into question how two characters in seperate areas are able to reference things from the other's perspective. You could argue that Shay remembered the wiring pattern from looking at his mom's photograph, but how could he possibly know the wiring pattern for the bot that Vella fixed?Yes, "video game logic". I know. All-in-all I have mixed feelings about this game. As a complete package I would recommend a buy to Point-And-Click adventure fans but only when it goes on sale. As for the general consumer: avoid. If you want a better example of Schafer's work, play Monkey Island 1, 2, and 3, Full Throttle, Psychonauts or Grim Fandango. Despite its pretty design, Broken Age is hardly worth your money or time.

They must have whipped up Act 2 on their private yachts partially sinking (from the money weight) with a Piña Colada in one hand.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												The game itself has that broken age meaning , is it a full blown old adventure game ? no is it like one of those heavy graphics modern adventure games ? no Tim has decided to take the game in between making it the best of both eras , old and new.The game has great artwork , good characters and voice acting but limited adventuring , puzzles The story is pretty linear with no choices , i guess they were testing the waters with act 1. here is a short my takes on the game avoiding any spoilers.The good-gorgeous well designed game levels you can stand and look around and it will please the eye-decent story takes a while to understand whats going on -excellent characters and voice acting-amazing musicThe bad-no inventory or verbs to pick from like in old scumm adventure games just point and click-no branching paths :( -pixel hunting you will be clicking everywhere to find out what will interact-short game despite taking time to look around and talk to everyone game ended in about 4 hrs- no references to any other double fine games or old lucasarts aka not much hidden stuffdespite that the game is super fun for anyone to pick and play 8/10awaiting act 2 :D the damn stump requires disk 22 to play act 2 :D

content:
Posted: December 8, 2016
												A nice little point and click adventure with a great twist to the story that I had not expected.The puzzles are all really fun and solvable until you get to the 2nd act, where some puzzles become unnecessarily more difficult, to the point where it's just not enjoyable anymore. Story-wise I was really blown away by the 1st act: they did some things I had not seen before. The 2nd act was still good, but I felt like the ending was rushed, like they just wanted to have it finished quickly. They could have done a lot more with that!Overall I'd say it was still a great experience! I had a blast trying to use the spoon on every object and character: It has the funniest dialogue!

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
												As a long time fan I just had to play through a new Schafer game, even though the other negative reviews mostly confirmed that I wouldn’t find it too much fun. They were right. I don’t really understand what the target demographic here are. It’s silly in a childish sense, but also extremely time consuming with a lot of overly frustrating puzzles that no one except seasoned point and click players can withstand. Sure, the characters were mostly good - especially the supporting cast, and everything had great production values, from the graphics to the voice acting. But wow it was boring. The puzzles mimicked the worst from old school adventures, especially in the second act and the story that built up during the first act was mostly brutalized in the second one. But the biggest crime here was the ending. After putting in over twelve hours it seemed like a rushed joke on the poor kickstarter backers.There are so many great new point and click adventures out there and Broken Age can’t even hold up to the more lackluster ones. Absolutely not recommended.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2016
												Like a lot of reviews I read I have to go with a No way for this game.Part one was fun. There was one point where I looked up how to do a puzzle. The rest was easy or not to hard to work out and fun at the same time. I loved it and replayed it when part 2 came out.Part two was the flip side. It's like they said to them selfs "Part one was two easy and people completed it to fast. This time we will make it harder so it's more fun" and ended up killing it. One puzzle you have to look at a knote and try to tell a person a lot of clicking away what it looks like. If you get it wrong you have to go from the start with a NEW knote. There was also a LOT more swapping between both people and some parts that I just picked a random answer becorse there was no clear way to know what was right and once more if you picked wrong it's BACK to the start to do all over. I still have to end the game but each time I think it's time to do it I think back to how hard it became and move on to another more fun game.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												Wow. This game is a masterpiece. The art is beautiful and the subtle effects really emphasise the immersiveness of gameplay. The attentsion to animation also achieves the same. What made playing this game even more enjoyable was watching Double Fine Adventures, the documentry on the making of the game. Seeing the whole process of its development, the work put in by artists, programmers, producers, and others was awesome and especially enjoyable for someone such as myself wanting to enter the game industry. Please buy and watch it first before playing the majority of the game as it really increases your appreaciotion for not only this game, but the indie industry as a whole. The amount of hurdles and issues they overcame was impressive. As such, playing this game gave me an expirence unlike anything else I've played.Thank you Double Fine, Amazing game.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												tldr: Part two is not as funny, the puzzles are unintuitive and the game patronizes you. I don't plan to finish playing.I enjoyed the first part of this game. The art style was unique, the sountrack set the tone well and I thought the characters were mostly pretty interesting. I loved all the cameos, too. Jack Black, Pen Ward and Wil Wheaton are all in there and play appropriately funny roles. The puzzles weren't super difficult and relatively sparse, but I chose to reserve judgement until the second part came out. The story ended on a cliffhanger that made me pretty excited to find out what was going on. I was looking forward to part two.Upon starting part two, I'm instantly hit by the fact that they're done introducing interesting characters. I think so anyway. I got about halfway through part two, I think. The game continues and I'm not enjoying myself as much. It's like they told all the jokes in the first part and now they're trying to drag them out as long as the audience will listen. "Whatever", I thought, "I just want to finish the story!" Like a mantra, I chant this to myself every time some puzzle with an unintuitive solution comes up. There are a -lot- more this time around.I had to stop playing. Apparently they got the message that the puzzles were too easy because they managed to confuse the hell outta me. And then they do that thing that games do when you've messed up enough times that they begin to wonder whether or not you actually made it -through- second grade. They try to make it easier like "Hey, have you tried looking at all this stuff here? Cuz you know we put all this stuff here for you. No, not like that... Okay, well let me draw you a chart and put it up on the wall for you. That oughta help."That's not an exaggeration. That happens.So I'm not going to finish this game. It's frustrating and not as funny as part one. But the condescending attitude of a developer that feels the need to give unsolicited hints to someone struggling with a puzzle is too much for me. I'd rather stick with the trial-and-error that I was forced to do for nearly every other puzzle in part two.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2016
												I bought and played Broken Age after playing the remastered Day of the Tentacle. Whilst BA didn't quite scratch the itch I had for playing more of the same of DotT, I would still recommend BA. At the time of playing I did feel the puzzles were quite easy for much of the game, but towards the end the puzzles did become harder. I didn't become completely stuck at any point, and don't feel that there were really any 'random' or 'illogical' puzzles.The story and characters in broken age are quite pleasant, and some of the not-particularly-subtle adult puns and humour were well appreciated.I think that I would definitely recommend this game to anyone wanting to play a good point and click puzzle adventure. It is good quality.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												The early stages of the game made it feel like a kid's game. Until the wolf came along...What I liked about this:Great art, nice environments, great character designs, looks like a show from cartoon networkGreat voice acting (well it has to be, after all, it has big name actors behind it Elijah Wood, Jack Black, etc..)Some funny moments/dialogues (the yarn dolls, Jack Black's Harmn'y, Curtis)Interesing story, great pacing, unexpected plot twists (I like how it presents the plot from two interconnected perspectives)Most* puzzles can be solved with plain common sense - no nonsensical, convoluted, mind-numbing solutionsThe ability to switch between two characters and their storylines. e.g. playing through one character helps you solve a puzzle in the other character's storyWhat I didn't really like,Puzzle difficulty jumps from really easy kid's stuff (like eating ice cream) to something like a Sherlock-Holmes mystery. Although I try as much to complete a playthrough without  a guide, I had to do it more than a couple of times for this game. Like how was I to know that the snake would eventually faint after "hugging" me, wasn't it I who was supposed to faint?Lack of a guide or tutorial. The game directly throws you in with no instructions or guides of any sort. I guess its part of the puzzle solving to figure out how to work the game. Though this isn't much of a big deal to me since I've played alot of point-and-click games before but still having it would be nice.Not sure if this happens on all systems or if its something in the settings but sometimes the character seems to follow your mouse cursor around even if you haven't clicked on anything yet. It gets annoying at times when the character stands in front of an object you need to interact with.Overall it was a fun experience and a great game. Definitely worth its price even when its not on sale. :)

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 23, 2015
												As a huge Double Fine and Lucasarts fan I backed this game at one of the higher tiers, bought more merch along the way to support the extended development, and quite enjoyed Act 1.That said, now that the full game is here, I can't really recommend Broken Age, and I'm pretty disappointed with the game itself.I think the game suffers from a lack of a single cohesive world, two main characters that have no relationship, and what turns out to be a pretty ridiculous and silly plot (which would be fine in a comedy adventure, except it doesn't pay off the expectations that are built in the early parts of the game, i.e. it's a total let down). Many of the characters don't seem to have any purpose other than to be an artificial road block for puzzle business in the story line, and only a couple of characters I found to be memorable (often the characters that had the least screen time unfortunately). The second half of the game also spends the most of its time recycling the same environments and characters for the sake of some pretty tiresome puzzles. The timing puzzles are particularly irritating and don't communicate well visually. I worked through most of the second act without needing any hints, but eventually I hit a point where I just wanted to be done with the game and so I read the solutions. No regrets there.I really like the art in the game, but I think a different, more traditional adventure game art style may have helped get the game done sooner, and I would have rather played a game with worse art, that felt more polished, with more environments, better developed characters and more refined puzzles, than this game, which feels like made a lot of compromises simple because it was so damn time consuming to paint and animate.Finally though, I have to say that I don't feel ripped off and I still hope Double Fine can come back from the damage that Kickstarter and Early Access have done to their reputation in the past year or so. The documentary is great (particularly the first 10 or so episodes before development started getting into trouble) and was worth the price of entry alone, and it's clear that the people at Double Fine care a lot about what they do, but this project had  some fundamental problems right out of the gates and the result is a game that I can't put up alongside classics like DOTT or Full Throttle.

Posted: May 6, 2015
												The first act was pretty good even if the puzzles were for the most part incredibly simple. The second act is a complete let down however, as the story goes absolutely nowhere and the puzzles are frustrating and nonsensical. It is a real shame that the second chapter amounts to little more than two separate mostly meaningless fetch quests with minimal character development which destroys what made the two characters interesting in the first chapter.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
												Act 1 had so much potential (I actually thought it was amazing), but all of it was squandered in Act 2. Characters suddenly became 2-dimensional (especially the villains, who turned out to be laughably banal, unlike the mysterious stowaway we started with in the first Act) and so many plot points were left hanging at the end of the game that I stood up and screamed, "THAT'S IT?" at my screen like a crazy person. I think recommending this game will send the wrong message. It's not alright to end a game in the half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥way Broken Age ended, even if it started out like the dream adventure game everyone's been waiting for for 17 years. Double Fine should've just admitted that the 3,3+ million dollars they raised from Kickstarter was nowhere near enough to finish a complete game and split it into parts that can then be funded separately. I certainly wouldn't mind paying more for Act 2 if it didn't turn out to be the lazy, convoluted mess that was the Act 2 we received bundled with Act 1.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												I really liked the first half of this game. The art is awesome and the story was intriguing. The second part... left a lot to be desired. I didn't even care that it took so long to come out.  I went in excited to play the rest of the game. As I played the puzzles started to make no sense until the final part. I can't even begin to describe the frustration I felt in having my progress reset several times because I didn't figure out the magical correct sequence of events. Finally being so frustrated I just wanted this damn game to end I tried a walkthrough, following it to the tee I still managed to not get the order right and have all my progress reset. Nope. I'm done. I guess I'll never know how the game ends. I play games for fun and challenge. Not for frustration of esoteric puzzles and boring repetition. If you want a set of fun and beautifully created story puzzle games head over to Daedalic and skip this one.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												I haven't finished it yet but Act 2 is not very good at all so far. What the hell happened? The puzzles suck and involve a ton of backtracking through mostly recycled but slightly altered environments from Act I. It seems they took the criticism of Act 1 being 'too easy' too literally and decided to bring back the worst puzzles from the old point and clicks. Maybe it was supposed to be some kind of jab at the critics but all it did is make the game worse. So good job with that.I can only stand to listen to the same dialog so many times as I try every god damned combination to solve some inane puzzle. I can't play more than an hour at a time before getting bored. I can't really recommend the game like this. There are other much more fun adventure games available on Steam.As a backer this is super disappointing though not really surprising given how late and over budget this went. At least the art, voice acting, and documentary are good.

Posted: May 18, 2015
												Story is well done, but the game itself has no fluidity to it.The first half is incredibly easy and takes no time to really do. The second half is incredibly hard and takes quite a bit longer to do. The second half has certain puzzles that are just mind-boggling how you are supposed to think those things should happen, or you have to do them in such an order, that if you don't do it perfectly correctly, or forget one step, it resets you quite a ways back and doesn't just set you back one step...Not to mention, the budget was poorly handled in terms of game-length and voice actors, and how long it took the second half to actually come out...I was excited for this game, but it let me down in every fashion other than hearing specific voice-actors, and a decently written story (albeit a short one at that).

content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												Overall I think the game is great (on sale). After playing through it I was browsing some threads and saw all tha hate against Act II... and all I have to say to that is "quit whining already". Sure Act II was a bit more crazy than Act I, but it was still a fun point and click puzzle adventure. Some great lines, some nice writing, and decent reactionary events.I only got stumped once, on the boots puzzle, until I broke out pencil and paper and figured it out. I wasn't expecting to have to actually jot down notes, which caught me off guard. But, needing notes was nothing like say, Myst level note requirements! Broken Age was very casual in its execution, and a cute game.Anyhow, take it for what it is, fun little game, easily spend about 10 hours in it if you don't let Achievement OCD ruin it for you.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
												After a year of waiting time, the second act of Broken Age finally arrived! Unfortunately it has not been worth the wait in my eyes. These are the main reasons for me not to recommend:REASONS TO BUYAct 1:- Beautiful artwork- Gorgeous soundtrack- Superb voice cast - one of the best I've seen in a video game up to this point- Interesting characters and narrative focus on the "broken age" of two teenagersAct 2:- You get to know what happens after Act 1REASONS NOT TO BUYAct 1:- The puzzles are pretty boring- No one really listens to you (That may be part of the story though)Act 2:-The puzzles are difficult but annoyingly repetitive; obvious answers are often wrong; some puzzles can only be solved by randomly repeating steps in different order- No new places- Absurd story line that connects to the events of Act 1, but not to it's message Why would they replace the wolf by an Alien? This concept is not further explored in the ongoing game either.- Still nobody listens to you or is at least somewhat interested in other people. While there may be a narrative reason for doing so in Act 1, it makes all kinds of conversation flat and uninteresting in Act 2 (story wise at least - there are still some funny characters, such as the talking tree, whom I enjoyed talking with.)CONCLUSIONBuy in a Sale, to enjoy the overall atmosphere of Act 1. Don't waste your time with Act 2 though.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
												This game could have been so much more, but on the whole it falls a bit flat. The puzzles suffer from what is commonly called "adventure game logic," meaning they were horribly designed, and the solutions only make sense to an insane person. You will back-track a lot. Like, all the time. There are also only a handful of unique areas to the game, which makes the game feel repetitive. Additionally, there is no hint system to be found, so the game is best played in a relatively short time-frame.What I do like about the game is the humorous dialogues and the overall art style. The few unique environments present are colorful and vibrant, and the rough painted aesthetic is pleasing to me. Some of the dialogues are extremely repetitive, such as "I don't want to fork that" and other failed interaction lines, though on the whole I enjoyed a lot of the jokes.I am really close to recommending this game, because I did have fun and the game is very charming. However, I feel it is simply not worth the price it is being sold for currently. Unless you are a die-hard Double Fine fan, I would recommend waiting for a sale.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12
												I'd like to give this a "so so" rating, but I only see "Yes" and "No" buttons, so... I'll rate according to the sour taster after playing this.I loved the art (the character design is fantastic IMO), the music, and some of the history. Not so much the acting, which I think is hit or miss (to me, the spoon and knife are better characters than Elijah Wood's... whose acting I found wooden) The ending sucks, I think. It smells like "We ran out of money, that's it".I think the criticism towards the second act is fair, it doesn't make any sense to have Shay do some actions "interacting" with Vella, without each other knowing what the other is doing. Also, the first act feels like a modern game (and kind of easy), but you are never prepared for what's to come on the second act: "Here, there you have this non sensical contrived puzzles".I mean, when you already did the puzzles they may look like more logical, but YOU WILL HAVE TO TAKE NOTES (or at least take some pictures with your phone). You are never advised to do so. What the ♥♥♥♥, this is not 1989.I'm not against some challenging puzzles, and it's good to have some "Aha!" moments, but I think some of the last puzzles were far too contrived. Well, I don't know, play it if you want, but I expected something better.7/10 would use a guide.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
												I was worried that somewhere between Brutal Legend and managing an entire studio for Trenched, Tim Schafer had lost whatever "it" is necessary to write a clever, funny, adult adventure game. I was a ♥♥♥♥ing fool, because Broken Age shows Schafer and the entire Double Fine team are in top form. The art is beautiful, the music is enchanting, and the dialogue is witty and well-crafted. VO work is handled by a group of voice acting stars who push you into not just feeling for your character, but acting in a way that shows you feel what they'd feel. I'm halfway through the scheduled two acts, and I can already tell that my sole regret will be that this game won't last longer -- no matter how long it ends up being. So maybe this review sounds overblown. But if you've ever enjoyed a LucasArts adventure game, this should not be missed.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2015
												What an enormous disappointment.Act 1 was enjoyable though perhaps not as great as I had hoped. And I had read that Tim Schaffer, lead designer, had said that people should replay Act 1 before playing Act 2 so that you don't forget all the callbacks.And I did. What a terrible waste of time.Act 2 throws away so many story elements that made Act 1 intriguing. And so making me play Act 1 *again* and then tossed aside a bunch of the story felt like a complete betrayal. And the sad thing is that Act 2 retroactively makes Act 1 feel much worse... because all of the intriguing setups have terrible payoffs and therefore make the setups no longer enjoyable in retrospect.Act 2 is like the Matrix sequels. Matrix 2 didn't seem that horrible until Matrix 3 came out. If Matrix 3 had been amazing, people would remember Matrix 2 somewhat fondly. But since Matrix 3 was terrible, people simply wish The Matrix had never got a sequel at all.I guess this is my roundabout way of saying that I wish Broken Age didn't get made and I hadn't wasted my time playing it. This game is a big reason why I stopped using Kickstarter. Don't buy.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2016
												Disappointing game. The characters are very flat and uninteresting, the story is poorly written, the voice acting is emotionless. I mean, I didn't manage to care for my protagonists even by the end. Some of the NPCs were more interesting, and had more character to them, which is pretty bad.The overall plot is very weak, and it's never fully explained even in the obligatory Evil Boss Monologue. And it's not the suspenseful kind of unexplained, but the "wait, that does not make sense" kind, like the writers were too lazy to make up the proper background. Just like Shay's robot parents, who turn out to be his real, flesh and blood parents, and yet no longer interact with him directly. We even see a family picture showing this has been otherwise, yet Shay seems to be genuinely surprised to see that they are human. Why did they stop seeing him in person? Why doesn't he remember? There are no answers, and there is no narrative point to make. It's just random, like much of the plot.Other than that, many of the puzzles are more tedious than exciting, and the level design forces you to travel back and forth over an area, without any map or quick-travel feature. Again, tedious.Also, a whole unavoidable conversation back and forth elaborating on stool jokes. Not funny. At all. I actually cringed. And it was as much out of character for Vella as she has character.The only plus point is could say is that the robot puzzles in the last part of the game by utilizing different patterns was actually clever and inventive.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												A long boring slough through the worst game Double Fine's ever made.When I backed the kickstarter for this game,I wasn't expecting much in the way of innovation or ground breaking visuals. Hell,I'd have been fine with just a glorified Flash game as far as visuals were concerned. And on that,BA delivers,unfortunately. It really does look like a glorified Flash game.What I was really looking forward to was the humor and a fun story. With games like Psychonauts and Brutal Legend under their belts,I expected fun dialogue and insightful commentary. What I got was a cold read through and a bland story that basically rips off Destroy All Humans.Met Shay and Vella. These 2 robots are the lead characters. Voiced by Elijah Woods and Masasa Moyo. You should probably know who Elijah is and what he can do,but as far as Moyo goes,she played Candy in Arkham Origins where she at least did a decent job of voice acting. Here,they're both so boring,so bland,so completely without any passion or character,it's mind numbingly insane. Even the great Jack Black,well known for not holding back in any of his performances and voiced Eddie Riggs in Brutal Legend,is just so dull. It's like they had the joy sucked out of them. These are not amatuers and there's really no excuse for turning in performances this soul crushingly bland.Being saddled with these 2 lumps of blah would be bad enough,but the story is a forced march through cliches and twists so predictable they have no real turns at all. You'll pretty much guess the plot within seconds of the motivations of a character being questioned. And the whole thing could have been avoided had anyone in the cast shown an ounce of common sense. Not just the main characters,any one.The jokes are so bad,so devoid of any real humor. I didn't even register them AS jokes half the time until a character laughed. The whole thing is just boring and dull and most of my time sitting there playing was wishing the whole thing was over with and that there'd be some kind of pay off.And at the end of it all,there isn't. The heroes are the heroes and the villians are the villains and at the end of it all,everyone is friends. Good god. Just "hey,all's forgiven even though you tried to kill us several times." And this♥♥♥♥♥♥was from the same people who gave us Psychonauts! And Brutal Legend! Games with fun stories and relatable characters and funny dialogue. I just don't even wanna think about what this means for Double Fine.I'm just done. ♥♥♥♥ Tim,♥♥♥♥ Double Fine,♥♥♥♥ this game.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
												Yes, the art is great, the soundtrack is great, the story is great, but the actual gameplay itself wasn't very fun at all. This feels like it should have been a movie and not a videogame. You are almost always locked into one path. It didn't feel like an adventure at all- there's no real danger. Also it's very short. I definitely can't reccommend it until Act 2 comes out.1) The game doesn't explain itself. Especially in the Vella story, I got through all the puzzles by clicking on things in my inventory randomly. Also, at one point in the Vella story you come to a puzzle that can only be solved by an object from much earlier in the game that, at the time, you didn't actually need to have. I ended up having to go all the way back for it. Then there's also the part with the snake that blocks the path. There's no way to get past the snake. It's basically an invisible wall. But I didn't realize this, so I spent a good amount of time trying to get past the snake because I thought that that was how I was meant to progress.2) Yes, I get that there will be a second part, but even with all the wandering pointlessly and clicking randomly that I did, I still beat the game (both storylines) in 5 hours. Again, half of that time was spent wandering around between the beach and the woods. I beat the game the same day that I bought it.3) Maybe this game isn't supposed to work this way, but there's no way to lose the game. When you finally confront Mog Chothra at the end of Vella's story, you can stand on the beach as long as you want, and even when Mog Chothra finally grabs you, you just dangle in front of its closed mouth for a minute until Vella frees herself automatically or you do something. There is absolutely no pressure on you to do anything. Take your time.

												This is not a game. It's an interactive story. Don't expect to have to use any brain power to get through it. content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												A lot of people are complaining about the kickstarter, and how much money they made from it and I only half agree to this.First of, I think the game is great. Some people call it low budget assets, I call it beautifull artwork. It gives the game a certain vibe (no not the low budget vibe), a bit like it is hand drawn and animated paper. The puzzles are clever for most of the game and I only sometimes ran in to the run X on everything problem due to developers logic. The story is great and it is nice that you can play both characters stories at the same time. First I was afraid it would spoil the other story if I played them one at a time, but this was not the case and the end result was satisfying. It also played great on my Surface with touchscreen only so this is also a plus.Now on to the Kickstarter issues. These are mostly centered around 2 things: money and time.First the time issue: this game has been out for almost a year and there is still no part 2. I completely agree on this point that it is unacceptable. The game is currently fairly short, and I have no illusions that part 2 will be any longer. Due to this part two should have been out a half year ago at the latest. I agree that it feels that time is spent elsewhere while the Kickstarter made enough money to do this in a relatively short time.Then the money issue: people feel that not all the Kickstarter money is being spent on this game. Well, that might indeed be the case. Aside from the issue with the game not being finished yet, I don not agree with the comments that the game should have been different. The way I see it they have made what the Kickstarter promised and the rest of the money is profit. I don't think they should be obligated to spend it on this game, if they build another game from that money I'm not complaining. Should you buy this game? If the above video looks like it's your thing then yes. If it's on sale, then you really should.

number of helpful: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												Oh jeez. What happened between Act 1 and Act 2, Double Fine? I mean, aside from the year-long wait, of course.Act 2 was notably less enjoyable than Act 1. Where Act 1 felt whimsical, fresh, funny... Act 2 felt frustrating, obtuse, stale. Yes, sure, Act 1 had its fair share of problems. Shay's side in Act 1 was very monotonous, for example, but overall Act 1 was good. But Act 2 overall just... isn't. Act 2 introduces a lot more puzzles, except they're all extremely difficult and frustratingly obtuse. Some of the puzzles in Act 2 directly reference and are parallel to similar puzzles from Act 1. The only problem is, Act 2 launched OVER A YEAR LATER. By the time I played Act 2, I had forgotten everything I had done in Act 1, including prior puzzle knowledge.Without getting into spoiler territory, the ending and lead up felt very lukewarm. The big reveal kind of fell flat, and it was mostly in the way it was presented. There wasn't really a sense of accomplishment. The story as a whole basically gets swept under the rug in Act 2, after all these plot developments and hooks in Act 1. All the questions are pretty much just handwaved away, leaving even more questions and a bunch of plot holes. So... 3.3 million dollars and 3 years later for a 10 hour game, with a year in between the releases of Act 1 and 2... And it's honestly just not worth it. I actually feel bad not recommending this game, as I did enjoy it... mostly... But then I look at it as a whole and the disappointment sets in. Grab it on a sale, I guess. The writing is funny, the characters are great, the 2nd half of the game sucks and overall it's pretty meh. But you might get some enjoyment out of it anyway. I just wish Double Fine did better.Really, the big question is, where did the money go?

												Sweet jeesus, what the hell guys? This game is not worth the praise it's gotten just because it's, at best, ok. I don't really care for point and click games that much, but even I've played way better - what the hell have you guys been playing?YEAHYEAH the music is good, the art is neat in it's own way blahblahblah. The voice acting is decent (save for the ultra-mousey and annoying as hell Vella) but I expect that with the cast that's on it. 3 million dollars you accomplished that much - congratulations.First off, I wasn't expecting to beat this in about 5 hours, that's bad. I know it's in two acts, but we're sitting at 10 hours play time total? And I was lazy while playing it since I was bored by the "amazing" story.Revolutionary? By no means. I mean, how is this at all advancing or re-defining the genre? I get that there's not a lot of point-and-click titles, filled with crap like Anna and Gone Home... but if you think this game changes anything for the better, you just aren't familiar with the genre. At all. Maybe that's why everyone keeps gushing out the word "nostalgia" - as if boasting about rarely playing a genre makes you a better game reviewer. Honestly, you can get the Deponia series for cheap thru the frequent semi-annual sales on steam, and all three acts are good games on their OWN, you don't even need all three. They are filled with at least 10-12 hours *per chapter* and with more interesting and inventive puzzles and game mechanics. You know what else you get as opposed to this game? An interesting story, amusing dialogue, and much better characters. I cannot see anyone playing the Deponia series and coming out praising Broken Age. This is just very boring pretty fluff.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												(a recommendation written after completing the full game)+ Awesome graphics. Good choice of character models and I enjoyed the warm color palets and brushy textures.+ Great voice acting. Some dialogues and stereotypes are really enjoyable. It made me giggle, occasionally.+ Huggable technology never gets old. Neither do cranky old trees or talking spoons.+- Some of the more technical puzzles can get a little bit repetitive or frustrating, but I liked figuring out the patterns quite a bit nevertheless. Hell, I worked myself through the Myst series, this was a less then a cakewalk in comparison.+- Story is fun and somewhat original (not going to spoil anything here), but not every element has gotten enough attention to be explained in a satisfying way. Could have done with a little more elaboration towards the end of the game.- The adventure puzzles are often too simple though. There’s always too little objects or set piece details to interact with or even just look and comment at to really get into that old school adventuring feel. - A wider variation of locations would have been welcome as well. I didn’t get the feeling I have seen enough of this world; I had been stuck in interiors for the most of the time instead, especially towards the end. While I very much enjoyed my time inside I was kinda hoping to see a bit more of the outside world nevertheless. Compare this game to Grim Fandango, Sam & Max Hit The Road or even Monkey Island 1 & 2 and you’ll know what I mean.In conclusion: YES, this game was well worth the wait for me. I’m never in a rush to play a game with so many old games still unfinished, so I didn’t mind the delay all that much. I don’t regret backing it up and I would recommend it to any adventure game lover out there. If above points or the way this backer project has went down don’t bother you too much, buy it. And don’t forget to put a pen and paper on your desk while playing.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
												Where do I begin, I'd like to start by saying, I would, without a second thought, recommend this game to anyone that loves stories, beautifully inspiring artistic graphics, and both fun, humorous and at times mind wrenching puzzle click based games.ACT1 of Broken Age is, to put it bluntly, a work of art. It has humor, soul, depth, absolutely breath taking graphics and a story line that is as rewarding to follow through as any top selling novels out there! What sets this game apart from others, is not only the story line, the graphics, but its ability to skip from purely hilarious story telling to dark almost brutal and thought provoking moments. Act 1's story is purely amazing. It's a duel story game where you can switch from playing as Vella, a young girl who refuses her fate as a sacrificial meal to a horrifying creature, or as Shay, a young, over sensitive and  somewhat lonely cosmonaut who may very well be the last human alive. The story line and script in general is jam packed with hilarious references and pure comedy gold that had me giggling all the way through...but there was more. What caught me off-guard with Broken Age was how deep the story would go into topics of loneliness, self-discovery and sacrifice too. From a game-play standpoint I loved the duel story-line modes because you could be playing as Vella and get stuck on a puzzle needing a little timeout, you could instantly jump into Shay's world and continue the other story line for a fresh perspective on the other puzzles later on.No amount of words or compliments can actually describe how beautiful this game is, it's like your all time favorite comic book or coloring book come to life on the pages right before your eyes as the story is being told. The worlds are massive, creative, inspiring, and the experience of playing as either Vella or Shay is memorable to say the least.Now the much awaited review on Act2... let me start off by saying that the universe you find yourself hurled into in Act2 (which picks off right after the insane cliffhanger of Act1) is as beautiful and inspiring as Act1! Everything you loved graphically is right there, only it'll take you twice as long to get through it all than before, so more eye candy and heart warming moments to enjoy! New characters, crazy puzzles, and the most unexpected story line yet!The main difference in Act2 is that, the universe is the same..I know, i said difference, that's because you expect to explore more beautiful worlds, only you sort of backtrack to all the places you've already been to as you meet new characters and the story yet again develops into this fantastic tale of inspiring goodness! While I would have loved for an opportunity to explore even more cities and places, I was more than happy with how things went because the characters kept me on my toes and interested the whole time!The puzzles in Act 2 are at times super super super hard, and by super hard I mean Grrrrrr!!!!! hard!!!! Almost to the point of leaving me with a strange feeling that someone didn't think a particular puzzle through all the way, and some took far too long to complete, but overall I can't complain, the experience gained by solving them and playing Act 2, as well as all the fun I had, just made up for every moment of frustration! Act 2 wraps up the beautiful story and I can only say this was a gaming adventure I'll truly cherish! To all my friends and those reading this trying to make up their minds, trust me, this game is truly worth it if you're into this genre! If you have any questions leave a comment or add me to chat I would be more than happy to help you further!

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												Don't believe the naysayers, this is an excellent, fully voiced and animated AAA adventure with a special sense of humor that lasted me 14 hours.Like Peter Molyneux's "Godus", Tim Schafer's "Broken Age" gets dissed by a lot fo fans who supported it on Kickstarter. As with Godus, I set out with the expectation to find out if its detractors are right, or if the game is being unjustly treated. I didn't like Godus, but Broken Age delivers all that I want. Note that I never played the unfinished game.All puzzles are logical and have the clues needed to solve them available at all times, though they can be difficult to find or to figure out. Perservere! I got stuck 3 times and in hindsight wish I had perservered, I was never far from making the final connection that would have let me figure it out myself. It definitely has that old-school adventure feeling.You get to control two characters, Shay and Vella, who are separate at first, but in act 2 you have to learn to coordinate their knowledge in order to progress. The way the initially separate storylines have been intertwined is quite original!Conclusion: I'd say I disagree with pretty much every criticism of this game that I've read so far, except that the ending would've been more awesome if the events hinted at via the vignettes set into the credits were fleshed out more.
