number of helpful: 33 of 65 people (51%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												This is a review for the final game. There are two ways you can look at Broken Age. One, is to see it as just the product it is upon final release. The other, is to see it as the experiment in Adventure gaming that it was. I'll be looking at it both of these ways, separately.As a piece of gaming SoftwareBroken Age is low on bugs, fluid and fast. The art style is interesting, and the voice acting holds up well. While there are a few hiccups and inevitable bugs, Broken Age is a polished-feeling product in the end, that feels very solid.Being an adventure game, one of the biggest parts of the title will be the story. The story is strong for the first half of the game, though through the second half it has issues maintaining tension once it resolves some of the lingering questions introduced in Act 1. For story reasons my recommended play order is Shay, Vella,  Vella, Shay, until you reach the finale.Unfortunately the problem with having a free switching mechanic when it comes to narrative is losing control of pacing. By letting the player choose to jump in an out at any time, you do let them escape a puzzle to rest for a bit when they are stuck, but you lose any semblance of control over story pacing for the majority of large arcs unless you design around it. This is particularly evident in Act 2, where depending on who you choose, something is immediately revealed, or held off as a surprise much later. In my opinion, the latter was much better executed.Finally, as a adventure game, the last part is the gameplay and puzzles. The game plays as a very simplified point and click adventure title. With no on-screen highlighting of items, selectable actions, and limited inventory, it is up to players to investigate and locate nearly every object they need. This is not Monkey Island, where two pages of items and 50 things to interact with could baffle you for a time. In this regard, it is fine, though finding a balance is difficult and quite often, solutions seem rather obvious because your inventory at the time is never larger than 5 items on average. This is compounded by a few puzzles that felt padding. Some will require a piece of paper to take notes perhaps, or screenshots, but there are a few that simply require a few attempts before you will solve them, and being required to shuffle to the information and back to the problem, feels lengthy.Conclusions?As a product, I would give Broken Age a recommendation, with caveats. It's solid, it's pretty, and it's silly. But it's not going to make you feel terribly clever too often, and the story is good, but loses control of it's pacing. A worthwhile addition to the library, but not the crown gem of the genre.As a project and experiment?Broken Age is a resounding success, period. Double Fine delivered on every promise of their Kickstarter campaign in spades, providing a game much larger and longer in scope than most could have hoped for, and with a very high production value. This was done using their own funds, and by giving up all their profits from Act 1. The engine and mechanics all work great, and the product fantastically proved that Adventure gaming is not dead at all. There is plenty of potential for other games like this to take off, and for Double Fine to be one of those making them. If you feel their vision grew too big or the game tried for too much, that is your right. But the promise was only ever for a Tim Shafer Adventure Game and a documentary of how it was made, and backers received exactly that. Double Fine never went back and asked for more money. Instead of doing that when faced with the project failing, or proceeding, they used their own resources and IP to double down on the project to finish it, funneling company funds from all other sales into this. In the end, it may make them some money over the long term, but until completion it was most certainly a labor of love.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
Act 2 is way better than Act 1First of all: don't watch a single episode of Double Fine Adventure! before playing this! I've read in the forums that I could watch up to episode 14 before playing Act 1, but I got some minor and medium spoilers.Well, Broken Age is a game designed by Tim Schafer, known for some adventure games like Day of the Tentacle, Full Throttle, and Grim Fandango. The game was funded on KickStarter with about $ 3.5 million when they had pledged only for $ 400k. The whole production process is involved in a lot of controversy, and I won't get into details here. The only important thing to point out is that Broken Age is divided in two Acts (the second Act also has a shorter "finale" which some people call Act 3), and that Act 1 was rushed out for financial reasons, and I think it affected its quality.Anyway, I'll list the most distinguised aspects of the game (good or bad) below:👍 The story is solid, well-woven and not something I'll forget anytime soon.👍 Different from a lot of games known for their awesome plot twists, Broken Age's plot isn't obvious. There were a lot of jaw-dropping moments for me, which are always nice.👍 I can see this game appealing to a very broad age range (despite what other people say). Of course, it won't reach all audiences, but it's not age-related, even though it's a "coming-of-age" story.👍 Most of the puzzles are really smart and just hard enough to give you that little frustration that makes puzzles interesting, but not too hard that makes you rage-quit (I beat the game without any help, btw). This applies especially to Act 2. You definitely get those eureka moments.👍 The level of the hints the game provides you is also spot on (again, mostly on Act 2).👍 Characters are interesing, fun to interact with and talk to, and have very distinguished personalities.👍 Voice-acting is really good, which brings even more life into the game.👍 There's a lot of extra additions to the game that really brings flavor into it. There are many things you can try out that will result in unique reactions, even if they don't help you advance in the game (a lot of them don't even provide hints). And that's a lot of work that really makes a considerable difference in your gameplay experience.👍 Graphics are stunningly beautiful--just take a look at the screenshots. Very good hand-drawn art.👍 BGM is also memorable. I even caught myself humming one or two songs when I wasn't playing the game.± While it's a good game, there's a lot of unexplored potential. I know you can only ask so much and that's not a bad thing per se, but it makes you wish you had more.± Playing with two different characters is a really nice aspect of the game. But I wish the game would explore that a bit more, making me go back and forth between stories more often (I beat Vella's Act 1 not switching even once to Shay). On Act 2, you'll need to switch between characters a few times, but they're still rare occasions.± I've played the whole game bug-free on my PC, but some people report a few bugs, especially in other platforms, so I thought it was worth mentioning it here.👎 A few of the puzzles were illogical (like the two characters sharing information via the player's mind -- in other words, for example, Vella learns something, you as the player learns that as well and have to use that information to help Shay, even though there's no way Shay could've known that), but those were excepetions to the rule.👎 Act 1 was way too easy. It was more like a story than an adventure game. More like a prelude, even. It made me question the quality of the game while I was going through it, but as soon as it ended, everything changed for me (for the better, of course).Basically, if you're an old-time adventure game fan, don't take critics on Act 2 too seriously. If you can handle some frustration of not immediately knowing the answer to a puzzle (and resist the temptation to look up the answer somewhere), then you'll enjoy this game, especially act 2.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
												I had been sitting on Broken Age since it was released, however I didn't want to play it until all the episodes had been released (two). Finally earlier this year the second episode finally came out. Broken Age is a point-and-click game. The game features two characters, each located in different worlds. You can switch between the two characters at any time you want at the click of a button, other than this; the characters don’t have any real interaction. It has all the usual adventurey type things such as an inventory and very good dialog options. The game looks absolutely gorgeous, animations are all done brilliantly too. Music and voice acting is all top notch.As with most point and click games, you have to have some nicely put together puzzles, and Broken Age certainly delivers, they aren't so hard that you are stuck for hours trying to work it out, but they aren't so easy that you can do it without thinking. I won't spoil anything with regards to the story, but it is beautifully written, and the characters are some of the most likable I have ever encountered in a video game.This is one of those games you just have to have in your library, its fun and worth the time and adventure. Don't let other reviews discourage you from a good time!If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												Overall I recommend everyone pick this up if you are fan of puzzle games. It contains a high amount of polish and should give you a good 10 hours or so of gameplay. There are some flaws, but I found it to a challenging and fun experience. I think it works well to play it in small periods and take breaks so you do not get too frustrated. Pros:Graphics: Beautiful hand painted game. Each area and character looks distinct. Since they are all painted, the game will probably still look good years from now. Sound: Fully orchestrated score and high quality voice acting. The personality of the charcters come alive through their dialogue. The investments and time they spent on the music and voice acting really pays off, especially with the main characters. Gameplay: Game is point and click and functions with a vareity of controller options including touch screen. The standard game play is to travel to different areas and solve puzzles to further the game's plot. The puzzles start off fairly easy and progress in difficulty towards the end of the game. Most are fairly fun and can be solved by following established mechanics or using information from items/characters. A few near the end can frustate you, but even then the game tries to give you hints for these. So if you get annoyed, take a break and clear your head. There are some fun chemistry puzzles and ones that use SAT question like logic and even one that involve tree jokes. Near the end, I needed to take pictures of some of the clues, so have your phone or paper handy. Story: The story is fairly straightfoward and a bit flawed, but the characters and dialogue really shine. Vella is one of the best female protagonist I have seen in a game for a long time. Shay shows some nice growth throughout the game and brings a nice opposing view to the world compared to Vella. All the side characters are are fun to talk to and will make you laugh. In fact every side character feels unique and memorable. Some highlights for me include the tree , the space weaver, and vella's family. Cons:Gameplay: The puzzles are interesting, and the game tries to give you hints, but it can be inconsistent about it. One of the aspects I did not like is that its not always obvious when you cannot yet complete a task/puzzle. Some puzzles require other ones to be completed first before you can solve them. The game is not great in explaining this always, so you can feel like stuck and frustrated when trying to solve a puzzle when you simply need some item from another puzzle first. So dont focus too much on anyone puzzle, try switching characters and tasks from time to time. Some puzzles are great at giving you hints and even teleporting you where you need to go if you mess up, but others seem to only clue you in once. Stacking had a nice hint system that might be helpful in this game. I think several big site reviews are frustrated by the boot, knot, and wire puzzles. The wire one is probably the most challenging though the game does try to give you some hints. Graphics: There not many new areas in Act 2. Most of the places you visited in Act 1 you will see again in Act 2, but through a differing perspective. There are a few new places, but do not expect a lot of new art. All of the characters have new dialogue at least.Story: The story does not feel entirely complete. On the surface it works and is satisfying enough, but the game definitely leaves a lot of questions about the world and its history. The characters go through their arcs and complete their goals, but there is a lot left for the player to fill in.  It definitely feels like changes were made or story was cut for the sake of time/money. The final puzzle is fun to solve, but from a story perspective, it feels like the motivations could have been better explained.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												This game is very good, but not as good as Grim Fandango.Broken Age is a point and click adventure game by Tim Schafer, about two teenagers who live two seemingly different lives.  First there is a girl who has been chosen to be sacrificed to a monster but decides to fight back.  Second, is a boy who has been raised on a spaceship by an overprotective super computer, but now he wants more excitement in his life.The art style and environments are gorgeous and Imaginative, the characters you interact with are colorful and memorable, and the humor is well written.  The story, while not as good as some of Tim’s past work, is a pretty decent story with some interesting twists and turns along the way. And while I do believe the game’s ending does leave some questions unanswered, I personally found it satisfying.My personal problem with the game was that some of the puzzles felt a bit too cryptic. I felt like I was forced to find the solutions online, and after finding the solutions, it made me wonder how any normal person would figure them out without having to resort to a walkthrough.  It would have been helpful if the game had a hint button like they had in the Monkey Island special edition.  Despite this, it didn’t really ruin the experience for me.If you in the mood for a nice, charming, adventure game then I would recommend checking it out.  It may not be perfect, but is still an experience worth having.I give this game a 7.7/10.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												Great first act, not quite as good second act, terrible ending (imo).Really becomes apparent that they ran out of money.First act is gorgeous and well written, a lot of fun to play.  The art style is amazing and the high quality voiceovers contribute greatly to the game.  The second act starts to fall apart as they reuse nearly all assets and locations from the first act, and resort to simple item swapping puzzles (fetch quests, effectively) across multiple characters and NPCs to stretch the length (seemingly).  The end of the second act, if you can even call it that, is about 5 minutes long and consists of several scenes of exposition and a fairly poorly explained 'ending', where you get little to no actual information about what is going on, just a brief explanation and then credits.The villain provides little to no motivation outside from one sentence as to why he is doing what he is doing, and even then, never explains at all why he has chosen the specific path he took to complete his action.  He exists almost solely as diabolus ex machina for the plot.  His motivation is unclear until the very end, and even then it seems completely weakly written.Save your $ unless this becomes extremely cheap.  There is no real pay-off at the end, you spend a lot of time getting excited about a few things that you never end up seeing and that never get explained, only to get a really short throwaway ending that exists solely to tie up one or two plot threads while leaving many, many others dangling.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												Coming from Double Fine, I admit I really, really wanted to like this game. And some parts are very easy to like - the gorgeous graphics and talented voice cast was always its strongest selling point. "Broken Age" sets up an interesting premise for Act I, which is then completely squandered in Act II, making the rest of the game's shortcomings all the more apparent. The writing and dialogue is disappointingly banal, the plotting is threadbare and as the game progresses the puzzles become increasingly clunky, illogical and repetitive. That may sound a bit harsh–don't get me wrong, "Broken Age" is not an entirely bad game–but it doesn't have much going for it beneath its lush visuals and it certainly did not fulfil my lofty expectations.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												I was one of the intial Kickstarter backers who helped it reach that magical 3.3 million funding bux.I had high hopes for this game after remembering Grim Fandango and recently replaying a lot of adventure games myself, as well as new the new ones.First I must say, for 3.3 million, I expected a lot more. The game when I played it had glitchy animations, graphics and overall felt rushed and unfinished. I can't even remember the music, or the voices. The level of polish and attention to detail I expected from the creator(s) of Grim Fandango just wasn't there. I can still recall Manny Calavera's voice, Glottis, the festival theme, the little jingles, and the rest of the strong characters in that game. That game made an impact on me which lasts to this day. Somewhere along the line, something got lost. Regarding the gameplay, the puzzles were a bit on the easy side, but at least they were a bit more straight forward and logical than some of the puzzles in Grim Fandango (The Petrified forest driving sequence almost broke the experience for me in comparison). Still, I was not pleased when I saw that this was it. I expected more.So for the price you are seeing, I will not recommend this game, and since it is only half the game still, I don't think I will ever recommend the game based on the fact that I was promised a full game and the developers backed off from that.

I say little because with a story this simple and slow gameplay, it'd be painful if it lasts 12 or 13 hours.All in all I'll give this an 8.5/10.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												(this review isn't completely done yet, buuut it still might help you)Since the release of Act 2, some reviewers have written about Broken Age being a point&click heaven, while others seem to hate almost everything about it. I don't think it's perfect, but neither do I see a sharp decline in quality if compared to Act 1. Let me tell you why I think so (spoiler-free, of course):Act 1 has absolutely funny dialogue, bizarre characters and a twist at the end that once left me hungry for more, but it lacked clever puzzles. True, Act 2 doesn't have as many surprises when it comes to the story and yes, most areas you'll visit have already been established before, but its dialogue and its characters is still absurdly funny, and its puzzle design is absolutely great and much more challenging. Of course, the solutions to some puzzles are so creative that you might silently shout "How the hell should I have known that?" but COME ON, Monkey Island 2 wasn't all nicely logical either, and I'm not going to start talking about the puzzles from the Runaway series ;)I understand why critics might be disappointed in what Broken Age has turned out to be, but that is not because Broken Age would be a bad game - on the contrary, you feel the love that Double Fine have poured into it, and it's still one of the best adventures I've played in the last decade. Critics are polarised because people got too hyped. It happens.I think you will like Broken Age if... + you like the old LucasArts adventures or adventures in general + you enjoy the Schaferian sense of humour + you liked the other DoubleFine games for its dialogue, story, characters or artstyle (especially Psychonauts or Brütal Legend) + you haven't played Act 1 before and therefore are open to perceiving it as a whole game, not two separate partsI probably wouldn't recommend it if... - you love your adventure game puzzles completely rational - you hate revisiting old places - you're impatient when solving puzzles - you're expecting a five-act-blockbuster with a life-changing story

number of helpful: 11 of 22 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												My first introduction to Adventure games was way back (perhaps not as far back as some), to the days of "Day of the Tentacle". This led to a lifelong enjoyment of Point-and-Click Adventure Games, including King's Quest, Full Throttle, Grim Fandango, Deponia, Whispered World, etc. This game piqued my interest early, and I was VERY happy to back the project.As a Kickstarter backer, this game has met and exceeded my expectations. It's a well-developed throwback to the Adventure games of yesteryear and has a good amount of heart. The humor is on-target in almost all cases, and never groan-inducing. The animation is WONDERFUL, and the world is detailed and has a very Double Fine feel while still feeling fresh and new. There are a few spots where it feels as though the animation is not as fluid as others, but it doesn't interfere with the enjoyment.As for the gameplay, the puzzles aren't terribly hard, and make a good amount of sense if you take a moment to think. This is the game's strongest ally; many adventure games rely on randomly assembling/using objects to progress the plot. This does an excellent job of helping you through puzzles through clever dialogue writing and timeliness. No more carrying around 10 useless items for the duration of the game HOPING that one will be useful.This is easily one of my most favorite games of the year so far, and no Adventure fan's library will be complete without it. Bravo, Double Fine!

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												It's pretty if you like the art style, not a massive fan of it myself but you can see how people would find it beautiful. Everything is a bit sparse, very few things to interact with.Puzzles are absurdly simple, there's a couple of odd leaps of logic as per standard but since you have such a tiny inventory and so few things to interact with it's hard to get stuck.  Given this was backed on the love of oldschool adventure gamers, this should've been way more of a focus.  Also for people who are used to exploring rooms you'll find a lot of dialog is out of place - your character is suddenly asking around about things they've not yet heard of.The two stories are charming but shallow, old adventure games were marketed at kids but the complexity of them was what made them stick.  This has none.It's hard to picture how DoTT had a budget of 600k, while they only managed half a game with a tiny fraction of the depth, with 3.3millionIn Act 2: Puzzles go from barely existing to frustratingly vague, random and even glitched to impossibility.  They don't even make sense, the two characters need to share knowledge on several occasions through the player, there is no possible way each could get the solutions the other needs to find out for them.  For one of them there is NO way to find out the answer, you have to just rely on the fact it's not the other 3 options and the game has given you a fourth out of the blue. A lot of the fail states are mind numbingly boring to reset - do it enough times and the game will actually step in and cut out some of the steps so it's not like they weren't aware the puzzles kinda sucked.I'm sort of imagining this is the backlash from everyone complaining act 1 was too easy, but there's a thing called balance and this is both of the worst ends of the spectrum.Story wraps up in record time - but still makes no sense - and then the finale is forced and anticlimactic, dialogue is much shorter, much less witty, character development is nil.  Revelations that should be earth-shattering and psyche-breaking are shrugged off in seconds. The ending not only doesn't make sense, it doesn't even solve anything.All in all if this were a quirky bargain bin game then sure pick it up, play for a bit and then forget. As a story it's a mess that clearly wasn't planned in advance. As a promised hark back to the old school games of yore, it's a nail in their coffin. This is not the game we backed.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												How could you go wrong with a game comming from Double Fine studio?  It's amazing in every aspect! Where should i start? The virusals.. the musical score.. the voice acting.. Just the very first scene of Vella waking up under a tree sets the tone for the rest of the adventure. It's enchanting. It's like watching your very first cartoons with children's eyes. There are quite enough puzzle, mostly very easy, but the adventure focusses more on the dialogues which you souldn't miss a single line as they are so well written and acted. Elijah Wood, Jack Black, Will Wheaton, ... even Pendleton Ward is in it :)  For the french speaking person i am not very much used to recognize english actors by their voice, i was surprised and pleased to recognize them in the game! The subtitles are very well translated, by the way. Really, it praises quality ... over quantity, which is the game's only downside. The game is very short (typical for point'n'click adventure games) and Act2 isn't even released yet, but it will be soon and for free. I just can't wait for it. Thanks Tim Schafer and Double Fine production. I knew from the start my money was on the right horse.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												Broken Age is a beautifuly crafted point & click adventure that challenges you to use a long lost tool vital to all human beings; logic. The absolutely stunning hand painted art style accompanied by whimsical and inspiring orchestrated music easily sets this game apart from many other adventure games within it's genre. Without a doubt, I would recommend this game to anyone who has the ability to think for themselves, and are yearning for a challenging game that won't hold your hand throughout the play-though.I also feel that I have to address the negative reviews that are slowly encroaching upon this wonderful game's reputation.A: I would have to agree that the second act is slightly lacking in the overwhelming epiphany department, in terms of the awe struck feeling it leaves you with at the end of act one, however, that shouldn't warrant people throwing the entire project under the proverbial bus as a result.B: As I previously stated in the introduction to my review, this game heavily relies on the players ability to utilize their personal logic and problem solving skills throughout the duration of the game. If you read the negative reviews, you will encounter a plethora of individuals complaining about the difficulty of particular puzzles, with which they defeated the purpose of the game by selling their own intelect short and merely looked up the answers. Once again, this game will not hold your hand, and assumes that YOU the player, actually has the ability to think for yourself via deduction and analysis of your surroundings.  C: Many gamers within the playerbase of this project constantly complain about plot holes and "unexplained" circumstances of intuition between Vella and Shay, as well as their overall importance to the Thrush. Within the second act, it's my personal opinion that players were too busy looking for things to hate about it, rather than actually paying any bit of noteable attention to conversational clues; albeit rather vague, but clues nevertheless. Tim Schafer himself has even explained some of these things within a post on the DoubleFine Forums, which you can read for yourself on this link: http://www.doublefine.com/forums/viewthread/16964/P25/#385125 -- 6 posts down.In conclusion,  everything is up to the player to decide, if you actually have the capacity to decide for yourself.

number of helpful: 8 of 16 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												This review is in regards to Act 1, since Act 2 is not available yet.Personally, I gladly recommend Broken Age, but I'm going to say right now that it's DEFINITELY not something that will fit everyone's gaming tastes. It's a point-and-click adventure, of course, but a very simple one; sometimes the only difficulty that arose was from temporarily looking over an item that needs to be used. I'm not sure if it's even possible to truly fail this game, to be honest. The game is short, simple enough if you pay attention, and doesn't particularly fall prey to the Sierra Logic issues that sometimes come with point-and-click games (Sierra games were infamous in particular for occasionally having puzzles with solutions that were so absurd, they didn't make sense). If you're looking for a complex puzzle game or something involving some combat, then you should look elsewhere.I recommend this game mostly on the merit of the story, music, and art style. If you've ever played Double Fine games before (Psychonauts comes to mind), then you'll have an idea of what sort of tone this game's story has. I enjoyed the characters and settings, short as everything was, and I'm glad I played it. I wish there had been more to do at least in some of the interactions, but considering this is part 1 of a 2-part game, I'm not going to hold it against the game.What this review basically comes down to is if you can like a game mostly for the story and style, then this may be good to look into. If you want a challenging sort of gameplay experience, though? It's probably not worth your time.

number of helpful: 16 of 32 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												For those of you expecting a return to the old-school point 'n click adventure games, you won't find it here. It's the genre reimagined for these modern times. This means the UI is optimised for tablets. No menu's, only one interaction prompt and drag & drop inventory. The level of interactivity is very poor as well, only essential objects can be highlighted. All really unintuïtive, so it'll take some time getting used to. Once and if you get over these modernisations the game will present itself as a charming adventure game. The artstyle is amazing, voice-acting superb and the music hits all the right notes. Though very enjoyable there's no crude humor like you'd expect from Tim Shafer, the whole thing seems rather harmless compared to the old days. Part 1 will only take about 3-4 hours to complete, because the puzzles aren't hard. You'll breeze through it, but at least that keeps the pacing going. It sets up part 2 to have some intruiging plot development and I'm excited to see where they take it.Pick it up if you havn't yet, this is one adventure you don't want to miss out on.

number of helpful: 11 of 22 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												A tenuous reccomendation from me. If you've played any adventure games in the last 10 years or so, Broken Age wont surprise you in any way. What is available in Act 1 is very well produced, and there are more than a few interesting spots to explore, but overall the worlds feel rather empty. There aren't a lot of random things to click on that aren't a part of the story, which is one of my favorite parts of any adventure game. You can try to combine some of the items to humerous effect, but that's pretty much it. It's a very straightforward and linear experience, and characters vanish as soon as they are no longer useful. It feels rushed storywise, which is insanity considering how long it's been since we all put down money on the Kickstarter. Of course, a story's beginning without its end is almost useless, so I can't be too hard on it right now. In any case, it is worth a playthrough, but I'm not sure that $25 is the right price, even with another half of the game yet to be released.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												Choose your Character - Vella or Shay...Both Character's reflect the Age Old "Perfect World Setting with Sinister Undertone" story, told brilliantly by the team at Double Fine. The Humour and Cleverness which Schafer and his team are synonymous for does not fail to disappoint, once again. The Art style is really what sets it apart from their previous games, this coupled with brilliant voice acting makes this a well backed game from my wallet (although the requirement for a… well, B-List Hollywood talent WOODn’t he be these days?…. wasn’t required – but HEY waddaya-gonna-do-with-the-extra-backerayola-cash-lol) and of course Schafer had to bring along his old buddy from Brütal Legend, which probably didn't cost him as much :)Without ruining the ending, the melding of both worlds - once both chacters are completed - is quite a nice touch and makes me hold on tightly for the next Act. Whilst it so far hasn't made as great of an initial impression to me personally as Cockroach Inks 'The Dream Machine', I would still rate (this Act at least) a quite capable 3.5/5 Stars. Let’s just hope the release of the Acts aren’t dragged out as much as those from the aforementioned Cockroach Ink team (but one could make reference to the funding comparisons between developers but one would not dare :).

												I'm having mixed feelings about this game. I played Act 1 about a year ago and I waited patiently for Act 2 to come. The ending of first act left me with so many questions, I had a bunch of theories going on in my head and was super excited to see if I got it. Well, turns out I didn't. Kinda like that, but on a smaller scale.I recommended this game wholeheartedly after act 1, and made several people buy it just cause my enthusiasm was all over the place. Now I'm a bit disappointed. Don't get me wrong, it IS a good adventure game, the characters are funny pretty much all the time and you'll get your lols and you'll scratch your head at some puzzles. The art is amazing too. And the voice acting. But in the end, most of us adventure games lovers want a good story. Something unpredictable that will make you go "aaaah!! ohhh!" not "oh, mmm okaaay". And let's not forget the ending, which was abrupt and I kinda wanted a bit more closure instead of dem credits rollin' and me hatin'. I will recommend this game because it's a good one all things considered. It's just not as good as I had imagined. So probably if you don't get your hopes up you'll enjoy it more. But buy it on sale maybe?

The puzzles are straightforward and prioritize progress over complexity-- not to the extent of something like Valiant Hearts, but just simple enough to never keep you bogged down.However, Act 2 is a disappointment. number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
												I can't say how much I recommend this game. This game is literally the reason I got into gaming (I saw the NPR piece about it and I knew I had to get my hands on something that lovely). Story:The first half is fantastic story. In the documentary they pointed out that things really kick up once Merrick shows up and that's definitely true. You don't really know what is going on or who to trust. Then you have the end of the first half and the beginning of the second half. The big mysteries in the first half are pretty quickly filled in within the second half but personally I loved the ways they were revealed (for one my husband was watching over my shoulder and exclaimed in surprise) and that the focus of the game was then executing specific tasks, rather than hunting for clues. I also really liked the ending; it reminded me strongly of the ending of Transistor with it's understated approach and use of the credits. Overall the story was just suspenseful/unnerving enough without being something I wouldn't recommend to younger players and fantastically winsome and memorable. Character Balance/Development:In the first half Vella's world is more flat than Shay's. She's less clearly motivated and the objects she carries don't result in really any clever dialogue at all (as far as clicking on them in inventory, offering them to everyone, etc). Shay's world on the other hand was amazingly rich. The spoon and knife I didn't really discover until my second play through and they alone make his entire world more charming. In the second half that's much more balanced. While Shay still has more interesting tasks since he isn't trapped as much in one locale, Vella picks up the knife and a fork and some new characters show up in her locale (along with an old one I was really hoping we hadn't seen the end of!) that give her more engagement. Shay has more of the "I don't think we can use that that way" lines in the second half. Shay is in my opinion more rounded and makes more sense than Vella. We don't get a good sense of Vella without really digging into one or two lines; otherwise she comes off as needlessly and oddly intense. But they are both very winning and you feel a vested interest in them. One thing character wise that bugged me in the second half was the fact that one character stands around on a beach and you can't really talk to him. His big issue is pretty easily solved and then he's just there for most of the game. If you try to talk to him you get the auto "Never mind!" line and have to walk away. That seemed really pointless. Puzzles: They are definitely uneven but not unduly so. The first half of the game they are realizing things are not as they seem. The second half they are trying to cope with certain big revelations and new realities. It makes sense that other things are suddenly harder as well. I have NO idea why people hate the second half so much. The puzzles are clever but not so obscure that you would never get them (I found the knot puzzle easy while I would miss certain more obvious items, like how to get the shell). Most of the time if one side got old I would switch and play the other and suddenly things would make sense to me. So I felt like it played very smoothly. You need to diagram some things out but please, that's point and click standard. If you don't see that as the sign of a good game then don't play point and click. I also didn't understand the claims some have made about not having a hint system. When your character tells you "Maybe I should look for X" how is that NOT a hint? Same with your character asking another repeatedly if thing X will cause reaction Y. I like all others would have liked more new territory, but again, that's point and click standard to have one environment you really scrub over again and again. If it had all been released at once it would have been less striking. I know there's more I could say here but these were the reasons I got into the game and these are the only things that really matter to me. It's a gorgeous game that is incredibly addicting and charming. If this appeals to you at all, buy it! It's well worth every cent!

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												Broken Age is a beautiful game, and it's first Act is a wonderful introduction to the old-school adventure genre for a new generation. The story is intriguing, and the puzzles intuitive and fun ... in Act 1.Unfortunatley, everything seems to start falling apart in Act 2. Massive plot holes are introduced to the story, and the puzzles become convoluted and frustrating. I can't imagine ever solving the final puzzle without consulting a guide - something I never had to do in Act 1, or for any other part of Act 2. But the puzzles in Act 2 are everything that was wrong with adventure games in the 1990s. Double-fine paid too much attention to the hardcore player's feedback about Act 1's puzzles being easy and ramped up difficulty (i.e. moon logic) enough to kill the enjoyment for all the other players in Act 2.The characters and world are still engaging, but everything else in Act 2 is a massive let down compared to the first Act of the game. I tenatively recommend the game if you can catch it on sale, just because Act 1 is so flawless and enjoyable, but Double-Fine dropped so many balls with Act 2 that it is a tragedy.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
												After having played this game through twice, I think I can safely say that it, for the most part, does justice to classic adventure games. Though the puzzles (with some exceptions, but I will get to those in a second) are really very easy, the game itself is extremely enjoyable; this is mostly due to the fully realized characters, the fantastic setting (which does start to dry out with the second part), and great humor and conversation.That said, the second part saw a pretty large detour from the first. It starts off on a relatively weak note, with astonishingly stupid plot twists (such as that of Shay's family) and long lists of tasks that the player has to do. Though a dedicated player will get past this section without pause, it provides very little motivation to keep going. In Vella's case, for instance, your first task (with the zero-gravity re-enabled) involves more timing than it does any intelligence. After this sort of "introduction" to Part 2, you are immediately hit with the aforementioned long lists of tasks. At this point, your primary goal in Part 2 is to wander the countryside and click on everything. You are stopped every now and again for a bout of puzzle-solving, but it feels very much like the puzzles are mixed throughout a game of wandering aimlessly. Even the puzzles of Part 2 are of varying quality. There are some that take legitimate thinking and reward you with a great deal of satisfaction, but there are others that involve screwing around with wires on the back of a robot (I am aware that the solution is hidden in the setting, but it was really very obscure). More than that, however, a number of the puzzles require you to get solutions from the other protagonist's story. This is irritating, but only because there is never any indication that this is the case. This can lead to some serious jumps in logic, as seen in many early adventure games.The setting, on the other hand, is absolutely fantastic. I won't say much about the setting, because figuring out more about it is probably the thing Broken Age does best.Is Broken Age worth your time and money? Yes, I would say that it is. Broken Age is a fun, lighthearted adventure game with less tedium than a number of classics; I recommend this to anyone interested in adventure games.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2016
												I'm having a really hard time deciding whether or not to recommend Broken Age.On the one hand, I absolutely loved the art style, the soundtrack, the characters and the world. All top notch. The hand-painted art is consistently amazing, even breathtaking at times. The game runs and flows very smoothly with slick cuts between scenes. The ending of Act I left me in awe of what had just happened and hungry for more. Definitely a page-turner of a game.Yet the game is unfortunately a victim of annoying, unintuitive and, at times, very frustrating "adventure game logic." The puzzles were mostly OK, but a few too many didn't quite work. Trying to use all your items on all environmental points of interest gets old fast. Some puzzles require solutions that aren't mentioned or taught to the player before (easy stuff like combining items, but in a specific and seemingly arbitrary order, and less obvious things that I won't spoil here.And the difficulty ramps up to 11 really fast near the end. It came out of nowhere, getting in the way of my enjoyment and destroying the pacing and flow of the experience. Lots of repetition if you fail to do exactly what the game expects, and it's not even clear why you're doing things. Is the player just supposed to do something because the game permits it, not because it's an obvious way forward?Maybe I just had a particularly bad time. I think I'll recommend this game in the end anyway. After all, walkthroughs exist (THANK GOD) to remove some of the frustration. I would never have finished it without looking up a few solutions. Don't be afraid to use one, and you may really like this game, as I did. Just expect some frustrating design, especially if you're not an avid point-and-click adventure game player.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2016
												As one of the backers fromtye original Kickstarter campaign, I ought to be really cross and take my annoyance out on the game in this review. But I won't, for the simple reason that it was never a factor to begin with. Even as I was finding the game my then computer was in no shape to run it, so had it been released sooner I still wouldn't have been able to enjoy it before now. Therefore, this will be a more objective look, removed from the drama.The first thing I wanna say is just how nice it is to have a point and click adventure that I can control with my wireless 360 controller. I know that's odd but the way it's set up using the mouse to drag by default is just awkward; I know you can change it but I got so used to the controller it felt nice. In a way, the game feels optimized for controllers, especially when you factor in that ludicrous 1 hour achievement - but more on that later.Visually and audibly the game is wonderful. I love the seemingly hand drawn art style, although I can't actually say if it is or merely simulating it. The voice acting is great and the music was always fitting and pleasant. I'm not sure the game NEEDED to have top o' the line voices actors like Elijah Wood, but their talent adds to the presentation.The gameplay is... It's a Point & Click adventure game, you would expect nothing more than inventory management and some puzzles of various natures. Instead we get a couple of really awkward timing/reflex puzzles and one that is completely awful due to two things: solutions being unique per run and needless trial & error. There's another that some people feel is in the same vein but that just takes a little imagination for the interpretations to make sense. By and large, though, the puzzles are actually fairly clever and all have logical solutions. Even if one DOES kinda make you wish you had a notepad.I'm giving this a recommended because I really did enjoy the game and felt I got my money's worth out of that initial crowdfunding attempt. A couple of bad puzzles just mean I'd take it down to 4 stars instead of 5 on my Backloggery. Incidentally, about that achievement... Who the hell puts a "beat the game lightning fast" objective for a point and click. That's like telling someone to finish a visual novel in an hour; it's DOABLE, but there's absolutely no enjoyment anywhere to be found. Unlike a VA, though, there's little room for error here. I actually got it, but it made me put off wanting to replay it for a while.

number of helpful: 11 of 22 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												My first introduction to Adventure games was way back (perhaps not as far back as some), to the days of "Day of the Tentacle". This led to a lifelong enjoyment of Point-and-Click Adventure Games, including King's Quest, Full Throttle, Grim Fandango, Deponia, Whispered World, etc. This game piqued my interest early, and I was VERY happy to back the project.As a Kickstarter backer, this game has met and exceeded my expectations. It's a well-developed throwback to the Adventure games of yesteryear and has a good amount of heart. The humor is on-target in almost all cases, and never groan-inducing. The animation is WONDERFUL, and the world is detailed and has a very Double Fine feel while still feeling fresh and new. There are a few spots where it feels as though the animation is not as fluid as others, but it doesn't interfere with the enjoyment.As for the gameplay, the puzzles aren't terribly hard, and make a good amount of sense if you take a moment to think. This is the game's strongest ally; many adventure games rely on randomly assembling/using objects to progress the plot. This does an excellent job of helping you through puzzles through clever dialogue writing and timeliness. No more carrying around 10 useless items for the duration of the game HOPING that one will be useful.This is easily one of my most favorite games of the year so far, and no Adventure fan's library will be complete without it. Bravo, Double Fine!

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
												If you are the type of person that loves games for their story, then this game will be worth the price tag. Some people have given this game negative reviews not because the game is bad, but because the price wasn't right for them. Yes, the game can be completed over a single weekend and yes, the price is steep, but it's been nearly a year now and I still think about the storyline of this game. It has more charm and personality than Deponia (which is saying a lot) and gives an immense amount of feels despite the small package it comes in.At the very least, keep in mind that Part 2 of this game is coming out very soon and will be patched in for free. Maybe you'll want to wait until then to buy it, but if you wait, please keep away from any forums, videos, or comments talking about it. You may get spoiled on one of the game's most incredible moments.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												I was one of the original kickstarter backers for this game back in March of 2012.  As I expected to happen, over the course of these 22 months my anticipation for this game steadily grew, ever so much more as its appetite was fed a diet of documentary episodes, game and art design updates, and an engaging dialogue with the reinventers of Adventure.  My fear was that this ravenous anticipation of mine would spawn an equally monstrous set of expectations that no game could hope to live up to; never have my tribulations been so firmly laid to rest.Irrespective of which story, Shay's or Vella's, you start out with, you are immediately drawn into a beatifully imagined and fantastical world filled with well developed characters following a meticulously laid out story.  I would often find myself having to briefly pause in my play of the game when the humor left me laughing too hard to continue for several moments.  The most enjoyable moment of the entire game was how the ending of the first Act caught me completely by surprise and desperate to continue.  This very satisfied backer's only real disappointment is the delay in continuing my exploration of the world and story.  Double Fine did an excellent job resurrecting a nearly extinct genre and I am very much looking forward to finishing the game when Act II comes out.

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												I missed the boat on the Kickstarter though I did end up preordering the game on the site, it was clearly the right decision.Broken Age is already an amazing game, not only is it Double Fine's best game I think its one of the best adventure games ever and its only the first half. The sheer amount of creativity is astounding and it really goes to show how shallow and lifeless AAA games are right now. The atmosphere is great and so is the writing, which is darkly humorous in its own unique way. The voice-acting is pretty great too. The puzzles are logical and not convulted, I never had to use a FAQ once, which is pretty damn good for an adventure game and I love the genre.One could easily criticize Double Fine for blowing their budget, and I even did, but its pretty clear that the money was put to great use and this is a truly a labor of love. I really do recommend this game and its a great thing that it is so good because it proves that despite the inherent risks crowd-funding like Kickstarter can really work to make great games that would otherwise never exist if the money is given to the teams that can make it happen.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												Coming from Double Fine, I admit I really, really wanted to like this game. And some parts are very easy to like - the gorgeous graphics and talented voice cast was always its strongest selling point. "Broken Age" sets up an interesting premise for Act I, which is then completely squandered in Act II, making the rest of the game's shortcomings all the more apparent. The writing and dialogue is disappointingly banal, the plotting is threadbare and as the game progresses the puzzles become increasingly clunky, illogical and repetitive. That may sound a bit harsh–don't get me wrong, "Broken Age" is not an entirely bad game–but it doesn't have much going for it beneath its lush visuals and it certainly did not fulfil my lofty expectations.

number of helpful: 10 of 20 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												Choose your Character - Vella or Shay...Both Character's reflect the Age Old "Perfect World Setting with Sinister Undertone" story, told brilliantly by the team at Double Fine. The Humour and Cleverness which Schafer and his team are synonymous for does not fail to disappoint, once again. The Art style is really what sets it apart from their previous games, this coupled with brilliant voice acting makes this a well backed game from my wallet (although the requirement for a… well, B-List Hollywood talent WOODn’t he be these days?…. wasn’t required – but HEY waddaya-gonna-do-with-the-extra-backerayola-cash-lol) and of course Schafer had to bring along his old buddy from Brütal Legend, which probably didn't cost him as much :)Without ruining the ending, the melding of both worlds - once both chacters are completed - is quite a nice touch and makes me hold on tightly for the next Act. Whilst it so far hasn't made as great of an initial impression to me personally as Cockroach Inks 'The Dream Machine', I would still rate (this Act at least) a quite capable 3.5/5 Stars. Let’s just hope the release of the Acts aren’t dragged out as much as those from the aforementioned Cockroach Ink team (but one could make reference to the funding comparisons between developers but one would not dare :).

number of helpful: 26 of 52 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												I'm sorry, please forgive me.  I'm co-responsible for this dullness: I was among those who kickstarted this (so I got early access and already have it).We gave Double Fine over 8 times more money than they had asked for.  Yet somehow it turned out it still wasn't enough for them: they went over schedule, needed some extra funding, made some cuts and are releasing it in parts.  But the worst is......it is just as insignificant, inconsistent  and boring as Monkey Island and Grim Fandango were fabulous, great and funny.  What happened?By far it doesn't look like the same Schafer we knew and loved.  Pity, pity, pity: mine and everyone else's hopes were so high.  We really believed he coud give us another gem, but it seems time has had it's toll and he's spent.  So sad.Please Tim, making things strange and weird does not make them interesting.  Oddness that has no motive and ends nowhere can titillate curiosity for a short time, but ends up being only boring and irritating.We still love you and many of us are longing for great adventure games.  We would love to get more of those from you.I'm sure you can still be a great team-leader and motivator, but maybe you should pass the creative leadership to some other artist who still has something innovative and interesting to say.   PLEASE!    Thank you.

												Loved it! Act 1 is short. But wow is it sweet.People complained that the puzzles were too easy in Act 1, so DF made them get progressively harder in Act 2, until they reach the level of a "classic" adventure -- which was just about right for me.What an amazing and beautiful experience this game is from start to finish. number of helpful: 8 of 16 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												This review is in regards to Act 1, since Act 2 is not available yet.Personally, I gladly recommend Broken Age, but I'm going to say right now that it's DEFINITELY not something that will fit everyone's gaming tastes. It's a point-and-click adventure, of course, but a very simple one; sometimes the only difficulty that arose was from temporarily looking over an item that needs to be used. I'm not sure if it's even possible to truly fail this game, to be honest. The game is short, simple enough if you pay attention, and doesn't particularly fall prey to the Sierra Logic issues that sometimes come with point-and-click games (Sierra games were infamous in particular for occasionally having puzzles with solutions that were so absurd, they didn't make sense). If you're looking for a complex puzzle game or something involving some combat, then you should look elsewhere.I recommend this game mostly on the merit of the story, music, and art style. If you've ever played Double Fine games before (Psychonauts comes to mind), then you'll have an idea of what sort of tone this game's story has. I enjoyed the characters and settings, short as everything was, and I'm glad I played it. I wish there had been more to do at least in some of the interactions, but considering this is part 1 of a 2-part game, I'm not going to hold it against the game.What this review basically comes down to is if you can like a game mostly for the story and style, then this may be good to look into. If you want a challenging sort of gameplay experience, though? It's probably not worth your time.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												Just finished Broken Age, and I have mixed feelings about it.As a backer, and a game developer, I'm still a little miffed that Double Fine couldn't finish the game on the $3+million they got off kickstarter.  Contrary to what you hear, it IS actually possible to set a budget for a game and stick to it... even a creative, art-driven game like this one.Part of me kept thinking while playing, what game were they planning on making if they had only gotten the $400k or whatever they originally set out to get?  And, is this game WORTH $3 million?But as I played and got caught up in the story, I started asking different questions.   Is the game worth the $25 I pledged?  Is the world a happier place with this game in it, even unfinished?I think the answer to both those questions is Yes.  It's a little bit simpler/easier than I remember the classic P&C adventures being.  But in every other way it's as good or suprerior.  The writing and voice acting are great.  The art is beautiful.  And the story is interesting.  I won't give anything away.. but I really liked the "ending" to this Act.Now I'm just keeping my fingers crossed that Double Fine can keep it together and manage their budget enough to actually finish the whole game.

content:

												Very short. A few hours. Only has first act. May not be worth the purchase, yet. The story is shaping up to be interesting once complete. The cliffhanger of Act I certainly has me chomping at the bit for Act II.Decent voice acting and writing. Has the whimsy, but not the wit of certain old school adventure games such as Monkey Islands. Though the lack of wit is a result of the story and characters being somewhat serious. (at least in comparison to the slapstick antics of Guybrush Threepwood Mighty Pirate) Contains a good bit of dramatic irony as well.The art style may be the best part. It's wonderful to look at. With the fanciful interesting character design we can expect from Doublefine.There are big names lending their voices, but it never felt like anyone but the character's themselves where talking.Due to not being the complete story. I would not recommend this game. Know what you are purchasing so you don't regret the purchase. I'm happy with my purchase but I have a soft spot for adventure games.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												I kinda loved this game. Given that now, if you come to this game, you might know it's history, you might know the negative reation behind the time and money it took to make it, or, and this bit would be wonderful- You could have no idea at all. The people with an idea, or any involvement in funding the kickstarter, might have a bitterness attached to some proceedings, but they're too blinded to see the truth. The people with no idea? You may well be in for a very awesome treat.One thing people don't get about kickstarter is that you ask for what the minimum amount you need is. If you got 100% funding, would it be able to be the game you want to make, completely? No, but you'd be able to have the story told. You might have to have less staff, it might take longer, the graphics probably wouldn't be as good, the story wouldn't be as long, and you might have to trim the number of locations down.In an ideal world, you'd ask for 3 million, you'd get 3 million, and the game would be exactly what you wanted it to be. However, people see that it got so much more than it was asking for and were thinking 'great, it'll be here sooner, be graphically superior, and with the ability to pay so many staff and so much electricty costs, they'll be done in no time!' Only that's not how it works.3 Years ago we got a glimpse of a game, and now it's complete. you ask any game creators out there, and that is an a-typical story, only we got a glimpse sooner than most of them would give, because that's how they needed to get their funding. I think, if people expanded their thinking on that, there might not have been so much anger towards this game.On the game, however, it is a funny, engaging game, filled with everything I've come to expect from Double Fine and point-n-click games. I recommended it to anyone who fits into that venn diagram!

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												To start, I just want to give a brief overview: Part 1 was brilliant, charming, and in my opinion, alone worth playing through for the purchase of this game, albeit not at full price. Part 2 did not deliver in regards to puzzles, and has had mixed reactions to the story (which I'm personally neutral on, I can't bring myself to dislike it, but the ending is by no means satisfying either).I think I speak for the majority of players when it comes to one thing, at least:Part 2 was not fun. It is as simple as that. After over a year of waiting upon completing part 1, I'll damit, the story could have been fleshed out more, but ultimately that is a minor complaint when it comes to repetitive and convoluted puzzle design that gets in the way of the more logical, more straightforward, but simultaneously still-difficult puzzles that really provided a sense of achievement when you completed them instead of giving you a sigh of relief to finally be done - just to move on to that same laborious struggle.That said, I believe this story is meritable if not for its puzzles, then for its artstyle and, in some part, story. This game is gorgeous from start to finish, in an artstyle that truly matches up to the very nature of the game and is pleasing simply to be walking through. That said, that is the only point that gets by without flaws, in my opinion. The music, whilst excellent, I found to be far too repetitive, although this likely comes from the fact that the puzzles in part 2 forced me to associate them with the unpleasant experience, which is really a pity.On to the story. I will avoid any spoilers but I will say that I have seen complaints that the story does not continue with part 1's themes of teenage struggle. This, at least, I disagree with. Part 1 heavily showed through Shay's story the struggle of dealing with overprotective and overbearing parents, and Vella's shows dealing with living and dealing with life outside of parental influence (and to a more minor degree, dealing with parents' beliefs  and their contrast to her view of the world). Part 2, on the other hand, shows the point of view of their respective families, moreso, and allows for a less one-sided view on the issues. I feel like if not for this, the story may have had the opportunity to flesh out more interestingly, but thematically was essential to take players out of their comfort zone when it comes to understanding both sides of an issue that directly affects what I believe to be the majority of players. Some plot points were not fleshed out, but I personally feel that that would have pulled attention away from the themes of teenage struggle we otherwise have.Broken Age, for me, has sated my hunger for adventure games and kept me engaged in a story that remains focused and rooted in its themes. Whilst as a story, it is weak, and for the second half the puzzles are tedious and disappointing, a beautiful artstyle paired with a thematically focused narrative means Broken Age, for me, reamins worth playing.It's no masterpiece, like I hoped that it could be, but it does just enough to make it worth playing through.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												My Review - This is a very descriptive review and states only what is correct and true. If you don't like reading why would you be in the review section..Alright, first off, ignore everyone else's review for this moment when you are reading my review, this is for the people who are interested in buying this game seeing as it is one of the most anticipated novel games last year. This review could also be for the people who had known about Act One and just found out about the Second Act being processed with the first. I did my best not to spoil anything when I typed this review, solely because it's up to the Viewer to decide which is wrong and which is right but there are some SPOILERS to be had.First off, this game consist of differential momentum in terms of environment, character, plot, and structural themes. This is what makes this game specifically unique than other novel games, this comes from my experience of playing at least 113 novel games for the past five years of experiencing different approaches in terms of genuine plot line that goes from you excited in the beginning, curious in the middle and satisfied at the end. Second, i shall list the pros and cons that truly defines this game as a whole review that will sum up your decision whether to like it or not.Pros - (1.) Genuine Characters (protagonists Shay and Vella are uniquely made through their origins and how they collaborate with each other and other characters), (2.) the plot line is not straight forward to players but that's part of the excitement and curiosity! (two different characters, as the player get closer to the plot, the closer both protagonist collide both their worlds), (3.) Dedicated aspects of the game, including well made environments that sets the atmosphere for the character as well as the player, (4.) Compelling, Mesmerizing and Humorous detailed puzzles, these are the eccentric part of the game, all made perfectly; easy for players who doesnt like puzzles and confusing for players who loves puzzles (does that even make sense!? I guess not but we'll go with it anyways!). (5.) The interaction between both the protagonist worlds are much more in Act Two which is rather impressing and needed because they switched. Cons - Now this part is what i hate to do while doing a review unless the game i'm reviewing is extremely horrid, since we're at the Cons of things, let me just say, these statements are to CORRECT the cons, not to directly tell you it's true. (1.) The fact that lot's of players who played Act One of Broken Age, built themselves from a eerie, curious, mysterious and unexpected adventure to a disastrous plot twist really sets it off for me as well but not quite, it is due to the fact that the creator wanted to give the players a taste of how a family succumbs to lies and betrayal as well as being utterly ignorant to which things are real and virtual. I didn't like how it ended but it wasn't that bad giving players reasons to say it was trash or garbage. When we put logic to these kind of games, it shows nothing but plot holes and disappointment. These games aren't suppose to be played like that. I was kinda relieved that the mother wasn't the antagonist because she was sweet, and she gave you that feeling of being 'cared about'. What i hated was that the father's plot line had no recognition as to why he had revealed his truest potential. (2.) The Grandmother having part as an antagonist had no surprises but gave no player interest because she reveals herself for at least four seconds and never gave the player another debut from her. (3.) Puzzles are straight forward, and need a keen eye for it, players need to actually think about things around you like every part of a scene are truly needed for a upcoming puzzle. (4.) I hated that they showed no scene for the reuniting of the character's family, it should've revealed the after math of both worlds being in peace which would of been a more satisfying ending but i could live with the one they gave.Now bear with me through this long review because my conclusion should give you the right edge to decide whether it's worth playing or not.As much as i was 50/50 on the Second Act, building yourself from the first Act is what makes it a lovable and memorable game, because a much as i gave away things that aren't right, I loved every single bit of it, because of it's unique characters from beginning to end. My conclusion- You should really try this game, it's lovable, it's exciting, it's genuinely awesome and humorous at that! My rating is 9.7/10 with it's truest form, no lies and no deceit, this game made me love my parents and it should do the same to you! Thank You for Reading my awfully long review, remember, it all comes down to your personal opinion!

content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												Just finished Broken Age, and I have mixed feelings about it.As a backer, and a game developer, I'm still a little miffed that Double Fine couldn't finish the game on the $3+million they got off kickstarter.  Contrary to what you hear, it IS actually possible to set a budget for a game and stick to it... even a creative, art-driven game like this one.Part of me kept thinking while playing, what game were they planning on making if they had only gotten the $400k or whatever they originally set out to get?  And, is this game WORTH $3 million?But as I played and got caught up in the story, I started asking different questions.   Is the game worth the $25 I pledged?  Is the world a happier place with this game in it, even unfinished?I think the answer to both those questions is Yes.  It's a little bit simpler/easier than I remember the classic P&C adventures being.  But in every other way it's as good or suprerior.  The writing and voice acting are great.  The art is beautiful.  And the story is interesting.  I won't give anything away.. but I really liked the "ending" to this Act.Now I'm just keeping my fingers crossed that Double Fine can keep it together and manage their budget enough to actually finish the whole game.

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18
												Well, at least the game is honest in it's name: yeah, it's broken.No spoilers:- There are less unique locations in this game than rooms in a flat. And just to be sure that they are even less unique, first you visit half of them with a character and half with the other, and then you visit them again switching the two characters.- Having few locations means that the designers have very few places for you to interact. This translate in "traverse 10 screens to speak with someone, then traverse back the same 10 screens to get a new quest to get an object to solve the first, then traverse 4 of the same screen as before plus other 2 to find an object..." and so on and on and on. You spend 99% of the time going back and forth and across the same screens, thousands of time.- The game is ridicolously cheesy, childish and boring.- The riddles are mostly so easy a child could beat them, apart from few that are really hard to solve. And, finally, there are some totally illogic where you have to use totally disjointed information to solve them.Then, the story is amizingly ridicolous and plenty of holes. And for a plot which is less than 100 words long, it's an accomplishment in itself :-DSpoilers:- You meet a guy dressed as a wolf, secretly hiding in a dark part of the ship you have lived on for years. So, an hiding guy dressed like a wolf...and he's the bad wolf of the game. It's so plainly obvious and phoned, that you get surprised that some designer has even thought it would have been a surprise for someone.Not to add that the main character never ever doubt about the entire thing. I mean, you discover a wolf-masked guy who's be hidden in the basement of your house, why shouldn't you think it's strange, uh?- Yeah, the guy has lived for years in the basement of the ship, alone, sleeping on a mattress on the floor. For what? Well, waiting for the hormons of the male protagonist to kick in so that he (the protagonist) could choose by instinct the best chick around. Lol.- The male protagonist spent all his time alone on the ship. All those years. With a couple of AIs. Knowing that he is the last of his species.Then at the end of chapter one...know what? The two AIs are his parents. I mean, they are not AI, they are human beings!!! His father has spent years outside the ship fixing it, and his mother piloting the...nothing, the ships needs no piloting, she spent year sitting. Not only the idiotic children never recognize his parents (the "AIs" are actually their real faces), but the parent never ever noticed it :-DAnd so on, and on...and on...I've seriously never ever played a more terrible, annoying, slow, and broken game like this. And I'm not recommending this just because it is from Double Fine, I don't care, the game is ridicoulos anyway,
