number of helpful: 10 of 20 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												I can see why people like this game. The art is really pretty, the music is really pretty, the characters are done well enough and are memorable.Well now with the good out of the way, we can get on to the bad. Yes as everyone else has said, you're buying half a game at this point, with no end in sight because Double Fine couldn't manage a hot dog stand. The gameplay itself is nothing really to write home about as its all fairly easy. That could be overlooked with all the positives, if it weren't for the aforementioned no conclusion in sight. Hell even the "half a game" thing could be at least mitigated slightly if the half that we do have took longer than 3 hours tops to play.I want to recommend this game, I really do, but until that second half is actually out and not just a promise I say stay away from this game.ACT 2 EDIT:Well, I finally got off my♥♥♥♥♥and played Act 2, how long it took me should tell you how hyped I was after having to wait over a year. While that fact shouldn't matter to those buying the full game now, you will no doubt notice some contrasts between the two halves. While the first half was quite easy, the second half is brutal at times. Pulling up a guide in the Steam overlay is at times REQUIRED due to how unintuitive the puzzles are sometimes. One such puzzle is almost literally a rorshach test, except its not open to interpretation. You have to get the correct interpretation, then give step by step directions in language that also sounds like it was pulled from a rorshach test. You COULD fiddle with it for an hour as you try to use just the right language, or, you could just look it up online because you ain't got time for that♥♥♥♥♥♥ Another such puzzle prevents you from so much as looking up the solution online, as you're forced to either gain clairvoyance or just guess at something for an hour. Many noted that in Act 1, you could play either side of the story all the way through with roughly zero need to switch back and forth. Double Fine apparently saw this as a flaw to be corrected, because now you are forced to switch back and forth at times. No, you will not know when those times are. Yes, it is infuriating as you once again are required to have clairvoyance. Yes, you will just look it up on a guide. Gameplay for the second Act can be summed up as "tedious". In any video game puzzle, completing it should make you feel smart. Like you did your work and gathered the clues, or you were able to follow a logical progression to the end, possibly even having some sort of epiphany. When completing the puzzles here, you just feel like you got lucky. The story in the second half is still alright to good, but it does contain some moments where you'll think that the writers were "just pulling that out of their♥♥♥♥♥quot;. Aside from that, the ending is fairly unsatisfactory, with the feeling that there is a lot more that needs to be tied up. Normally that would have me hoping for a sequel, but we all know that Double Fine has never made a sequel. And after this, no one will ever give Tim Schafer money again for a project. Speaking of money, let's get this out of the way. For a game with a 3.3 MILLION DOLLAR BUDGET, at no point do you feel the 3.3 million dollars and years of work that went into this. At its "best", the game only feels good. Nothing truly shines about this game. Yes the art is pretty, but its not 3.3 million pretty. Yes the music is nice, but none of it really wows you. The writing is good and has some twists, but it won't win any awards. The voice acting is good and they got some big names, but its surprisingly...dull? Actually, that might be the single aspect of this game that most reflects upon it as a whole. The voice acting is good, never bad exactly, but very few characters ever show strong emotions. Huge revelations are treated with minor surprise and then brushed off. Life changing events are also quickly brushed off. And that seems to be the theme of Broken Age on a meta level, doing good but never truly shining. I don't recommend this game because there just isn't enough noteworthy about it, aside from all the external drama. If you really need to get it, get it on sale, play it once, then forget about it just like the rest of the world has.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												I kinda loved this game. Given that now, if you come to this game, you might know it's history, you might know the negative reation behind the time and money it took to make it, or, and this bit would be wonderful- You could have no idea at all. The people with an idea, or any involvement in funding the kickstarter, might have a bitterness attached to some proceedings, but they're too blinded to see the truth. The people with no idea? You may well be in for a very awesome treat.One thing people don't get about kickstarter is that you ask for what the minimum amount you need is. If you got 100% funding, would it be able to be the game you want to make, completely? No, but you'd be able to have the story told. You might have to have less staff, it might take longer, the graphics probably wouldn't be as good, the story wouldn't be as long, and you might have to trim the number of locations down.In an ideal world, you'd ask for 3 million, you'd get 3 million, and the game would be exactly what you wanted it to be. However, people see that it got so much more than it was asking for and were thinking 'great, it'll be here sooner, be graphically superior, and with the ability to pay so many staff and so much electricty costs, they'll be done in no time!' Only that's not how it works.3 Years ago we got a glimpse of a game, and now it's complete. you ask any game creators out there, and that is an a-typical story, only we got a glimpse sooner than most of them would give, because that's how they needed to get their funding. I think, if people expanded their thinking on that, there might not have been so much anger towards this game.On the game, however, it is a funny, engaging game, filled with everything I've come to expect from Double Fine and point-n-click games. I recommended it to anyone who fits into that venn diagram!

It is as simple as that. After over a year of waiting upon completing part 1, I'll damit, the story could have been fleshed out more, but ultimately that is a minor complaint when it comes to repetitive and convoluted puzzle design that gets in the way of the more logical, more straightforward, but simultaneously still-difficult puzzles that really provided a sense of achievement when you completed them instead of giving you a sigh of relief to finally be done - just to move on to that same laborious struggle.That said, I believe this story is meritable if not for its puzzles, then for its artstyle and, in some part, story. I will avoid any spoilers but I will say that I have seen complaints that the story does not continue with part 1's themes of teenage struggle. This, at least, I disagree with. Part 1 heavily showed through Shay's story the struggle of dealing with overprotective and overbearing parents, and Vella's shows dealing with living and dealing with life outside of parental influence (and to a more minor degree, dealing with parents' beliefs  and their contrast to her view of the world). Part 2, on the other hand, shows the point of view of their respective families, moreso, and allows for a less one-sided view on the issues. I feel like if not for this, the story may have had the opportunity to flesh out more interestingly, but thematically was essential to take players out of their comfort zone when it comes to understanding both sides of an issue that directly affects what I believe to be the majority of players. Some plot points were not fleshed out, but I personally feel that that would have pulled attention away from the themes of teenage struggle we otherwise have.Broken Age, for me, has sated my hunger for adventure games and kept me engaged in a story that remains focused and rooted in its themes. Whilst as a story, it is weak, and for the second half the puzzles are tedious and disappointing, a beautiful artstyle paired with a thematically focused narrative means Broken Age, for me, reamins worth playing.It's no masterpiece, like I hoped that it could be, but it does just enough to make it worth playing through.

												This might be the Double Fine game we were waiting for since Brutal Legend - even if it took more time, than we anticipated. Kickstarter money wasted not in vain.Tim Shaffer once again proves that he indeed can deliver a great game only if he has a somewhat decent funding. This is indeed what everyone hoped for - a great, unique yet old-school-style P'n'C adventure, with a touching story, rich with unexpected plot turns, and all of that is enhanced with awesome voice acting and beautiful score.It is great. You should play it.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												Act 2 is out and the game is finished. Finally.The game is still charming, the art is still great and the voice acting is still superb.But it's a frustrating mess. Honestly, I got fed up with it one hour into the second act. The story's slow and predictable progress simply gave me no incentive to trudge through the sheer tedium of solving the puzzles. The puzzles in act 1 weren't great and have been a major point of critique from the start. You'd expect Double Fine to do a better job in act 2.Instead, puzzle solutions are unintuitive to the point of being arcane. And when they are obvious, they are tedious. I gave up when I had to solve a certain knot-related problem. The solution becomes obvious quickly. But so does the realization that it involves mind-numbingly slow backtracking across several screens (ALL recycled from act 1) over and over again until a certain permutation of choices is made. If this is any indication for the remainder of the puzzles, then I'd rather watch a Let's Play. I don't know how the story ends and frankly I don't care anymore. Which is a shame, because it looked so promising. This is not a bad game. But it's still a disappointment and simply not worth its price. I expected more.

number of helpful: 12 of 24 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												I thought that Broken Age was a fun adventure game. Was it a masterpiece? No. Did it live up to the amount of hype and money put into development? I think not. But putting all the preconceptions about Tim Schafer and the delay of the 2nd part aside, and approaching it simply as a game, I enjoyed it and thought it was worth the sticker price that I backed it for.I didn't have any issues with the amount of backtracking in Act 2, although the some of the puzzles in Act 2 can be frustrating at times and poorly designed. Mainly a certain knot puzzle that is very difficult, or at least annoying, to parse, and the final puzzle resets itself when you leave a room, which can be hair-pulling.The plot does have some plot holes, and ridiculous aspects, especially in Act 2. While they do stretch the limits of the imagination, they are not impossible to believe, especially since the universe the game is set in is a little bonkers and cartoonish.Overall, the game was fun, and saying otherwise is really a stretch. It wasn't a classic or a masterpiece, but it was good enough to pull its own weight. The question of whether it lived up to the amount of money put into it is another story. I don't really think it did, since there have been some very competent and funny adventure games made by indies on a shoestring budget. Most of the money from the Kickstarter really went into keeping the studio afloat and paying for star power rather than towards making an impressive game. That isn't to say that the game doesn't look nice - it definitely does. And even if the game didn't live up to the hype, it's definitely something that is "worth playing".

Posted: January 19, 2014
												Overhyped from the beginning, this game had a lot to live up to.Unfortunately, while it's charming in some aspects I also found it rather dull in many others. The characters don't have a lot of personality and the game just fails to create a strong emotional connection with the player. Also, as expected, the gameplay is very simple and not challenging.Inititally scheduled to be released as one game it was split into two parts when the developers ran out of money. That was very damaging to this game and it ends just when it starts to become a bit more interesting. Despite what was claimed in the original kickstarter video, adventure games are not dead, they never were. It's a genre that is thriving with many innovative titles. Compared to those Broken Age is not the worst but it's also far from the best.Overall an ok game but I recommend waiting until part 2 is released as hopefully that might fix some of the game's problems.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												I can wholeheartedly recommend this game. It's gorgeous, it has a nice story beginning to end, the characters are likeable, and the music and voice acting is excellent.I'm pretty okay at adventure games, but not the best. I've played quite some (among my favourite are Day of the Tentacle, Sam & Max Hit the Road, Machinarium and Book of Unwritten Tales), and I'm familiar with the general way of how adventure game puzzles are structured. The puzzles ranged from simple to challenging, but I never found them dull or illogical. I reached for a walkthrough once, and when I read the solution to that puzzle, I immediately realized where I had forgotten to connect the dots. I had disregarded some comment by one of the characters as irrelevant and forgotten about it, but it turned out to be relevant after all.  That's something that happens to me a lot more in adventure games, and I'm fine with that. Never have I thought "Well how was I supposed to come up with that?". As is common in adventure games, sometimes you do think "Why can't I just solve it this way? That would be way easier!" or "Surely that other character has the necessary qualifications to solve this issue for me". But obviously, if it were way easier, or you would let someone else fix things for you, you wouldn't have a puzzle to solve, now would you? :).There are some puzzles where Vella or Shay will give a hint when you do it wrong a few times. Sometimes I thought they were a bit soon with that, I would have preferred to muddle along a bit more without any hints.The characters often have funny things to say, and I've laughed out loud on many occasions. I have properly enjoyed myself playing the game, and I found the end satisfying. Sometimes a game is very nice while you play, but they botch up something at the end that leaves you unsatisfied even though you enjoyed it right up to the end. Luckily, this is not the case here. Oh, on that subject: the pictures surrounding the ending credits give a sort of epilogue to the story, so even if you usually click through the credits, you might not want to do that for this game.It runs fine on my Linux machine, which is nice, because I only boot Windows for games that don't run or don't run well natively on Linux. But I could use my preferred OS just fine.I could only find one problem with the game, related to clicking on objects in a scene. It turns out I need a lot of explanation to make clear what the problem is; so here goes.When you try to use an object from your inventory on an object in the scene, the object in the scene is highlighted. However, when you simply hover your cursor on an object in the scene, it's not highlighted. The cursor does indicate you can click, but the thing you're clicking on is not indicated. This can get confusing when you're trying to determine if something is clickable or not; whether it's background or a usable object. Say there's a person in the scene, and a space ship control panel next to that person. When I hover over the control panel, the cursor indicates I can click. But when I click, it becomes clear I've chosen to interact with the person. This can be confusing: is it indeed the case I can't click the control panel, or was I clicking too close to the person? After several clicks which initiate talking to the person, I'm concluding the control panel is part of the background scene. This can be annoying, because knowing what you can interact with is very important in a point-and-click adventure. Note that there is no pixel hunting in this game; it's not as bad as that. Everything you can interact with has a decent size, it's just that not everything that has a decent size can be interacted with :).I'm surprised by the amount of negative publicity around this game. These negative reviews are the main reason for me to write this review, because I think they paint a wrong picture of the game and might put off people who would love the game. So I'll admit I might be somewhat biased in my review, although I'm really doing my best not to be. But I feel a lot of the negativity and bashing is also not because of the actual game itself but because of other things surrounding it. People seem to be actively looking for things to fault the game for because there is something else they don't like for some reason or the other. Whether that be consciously or unconsciously.This game might not be your thing, and that's okay. But I find it very hard to find fault with the quality of this game. If you think this could be your thing, don't be disheartened by the negative reviews. It would be such a shame if you decided not to buy this game because of those, and missed out on the great joy you would have had playing it!

content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												You'll either hate it or love it - as such, it's a game about duality and how seemingly unrelated paths through crazy circumstances lead to one point.While I was not a backer for the original Kickstarter campaign (I didn't start backing games on that site until last year), I did follow their journey through the DoubleFine Adventure via epsidoes released every so often on YouTube, and let me tell you - it's a whole other experience watching a game being made, and THEN playing it. In short: it was an intimate experience, and I have much better understanding as a gamer about how the other side of the coin operates.I played Broken Age all the way through in one sitting - due to the anticipation from fans, I felt it was most appropriate to play it that way since serveral people complained about the "broken" experience where they whizzed through Act 1, then waited, waited, waited, got impatient, then brute-forced Act 2. If your experience was like that, I'm sorry you feel hatred towards this game, but your particular experience casued your particular reaction. The game, while it may feel unevenly paced, is still an enjoyable game in what many modern gamers consider to be "A dying genre". Adventure games are here to stay, as long as people play them, classics, remakes, or modern ones, it makes no difference.The art direction is great, the music is excellent, the animation (while not Disney calibur), fits the artwork appropriately and tolerable. The mechanics are as-expected for a Point-and-Click adventure, along with controller support (if that's your thing). The story is interesting enough to keep you moving ahead, even if some puzzles are frustrating until you look up hints or draw a diagram on a post-it or two (like I did for that Hexpals wiring puzzle) - it only makes you more satisfied once you finish. Depending on your first playthrough, you may or may not want to do it again to snag all of the achievements (for you Perfectionists/Completionists/Achievement Hunters out there).Overall, if you love the magic of Double Fine games, if you love Adventure games, if you like games that try to do something different and pray somebody will appreciate it, play this game. Whether you come to love it or hate it, at least acknowledge the money, the hard work, and most of all, the love that Tim Schafer and friends put into the game.It's worth the experience.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												this is a 50-50. I enjoyed it overall. I was torn between a thumbs up or thumbs down on this. In the end I went thumbs down partially because it is over-rated and just average. The game doesn't bring anything new to the table, nor does it "hearken back to the days of yore" or whatever. If you are excited about the optional 8-bit mode, this game is for you! This is a gaming hipsters dream.There really isn't too much gameplay, most of your time is spent watching the story unfold because you clicked on one of the handful of things you could click on.The hardest puzzle in the game was figuring out the UI. The minimalist design is initially very confusing. (probably very intuitive on a touchscreen device) This isn't a bad game, and you wouldn't hate yourself for playing it. I like the idea of being able to switch between the two stories, but it would have made more sense if there was a point in switching between them. When I discovered you could switch, I assumed I would somehow find clues for one story inside the other story or something.Had I not read how short the game was, I probably wouldn't have bothered finishing. It wasn't until the end that I was actually intrigued.According to the IGN rating, this game "ushered in a new age of point-and-click" that is absolutely false. if you're wanting a point-and-click adventure that takes the genre to a new level, play The Walking Dead, another game from Telltale.

number of helpful: 11 of 23 people (48%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												Broken Age is a story-driven experience in the same vein as sleeper hit Gone Home, which delves into the world of a pre-op mtf transgender named Shay facing oppression from his cisgendered parents, who are robots and therefore cannot understand the fluidity of gender. It also has a second story involving a bisexual otherkin named Vella and her growing relationship with a lumberjack who over time learns to check his white male privilege. Jack Black also makes a cameo as a religious zealot who the player has to take down in order to stop their culture-shaming. An overall heart-warming story that should not be missed.

number of helpful: 9 of 19 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												Very beautifully crafted point and click adventure game. Fantastic art style, great and dedicated music score, interesting world and story, great voice acting. Some chuckles here and there thrown in for good measure. To people worried if Double Fine delivered, I say, yes, they did, it's pretty worthwhile experience.Can't wait for second act! I mean, act 1 is a complete experience, if maybe on the shorter side, but it definitely leaves you craving for more. And, sort of.. for what it is now, even though I said "worthwhile", I can't shake the feeling it should cost less xD But the purchase does contain the second act once it comes out, it's just not released yet, so be aware of that. I have to say though that I am dissapointed with the puzzle side. Exploration, wonder, amusement, enjoynment of vistas and music and story etc - that is there, but having to think? Not really. Puzzles take an obvious backseat compared to the other mentioned elements. There are not that many things to do and not that many items at your disposal to do it and to me it was always pretty obvious what to do next and how to do it, can't fathom why they are actually making it even more obvious with hints from other characters. I think Telltale's Sam & Max series hit the puzzle difficulty nail better (avoiding the frustration of unfair puzzles of yore but not being too obvious, either).There is no question if it is a game or not like you might question something like To The Moon, as the gameplay/puzzles are above being just nominal, but I kind of expected more from them. Nonetheless, I did enjoy the ride and I heartily recommend it to others. With the caveat that to get the fullest out of its price range we'll really need to get the rest of it :3

content:
Posted: July 31, 2015
												What a gem of a game. It exudes charm, humor, and lightness in only the way Tim Schafer and crew know how to do it. And it's so wonderful to see a point and click adventure game like this, in this day and age, harkening back to Schafer's older, most respected works. On top of that the art is brilliant, the voice acting top notch, the script clever and hilarious, and so many fun little easter eggs all over the place. I spent a good portion of the game just talking to everyone and combining every kind of item just to hear the knee-jerk responses. Double Fine are some of the best comic writers in the entertainment biz, games or otherwise.The only downsides are those typical of point and click games. Some objects really do blend in with the background too well, you'll do lots of backtracking, various puzzles need to be solved in very specific order, etc. I must admit I did have to use a guide later in the game as some of the puzzle solutions were just not obvious enough after lots of back and forth trying out many different things. I can't really fault the developers for this, as I think these sorts of games do need to have some tougher puzzles, not everything can be elementary. Certainly nowhere near as perplexing and complicated as some of Machinarium's puzzles.I can't recommend it enough!!

number of helpful: 9 of 19 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												I backed the game in the initial Kickstarter and I completed Part One a while ago, but I just replayed it in order to refresh my memory for Part Two, which I've played for a couple hours. After a slight letdown at the release of Part One due to the easiness of the game, I'm really happy to see the difficulty ramp up in Part Two, and I also discovered that I really enjoyed playing through Part One again to find some of the jokes and details I had missed the first time around.I find the art absolutely beautiful, the dialogue witty and well-written (first time in a while I've laughed out loud at a game), and it's all accompanied by an excellent soundtrack (I'm definitely a sucker for games with good music). The story is interesting and compelling, especially once you start delving into Part Two, and I'm having lots of fun trying to guess where it's going to end up.Overall, I'm happy with the product Tim and the Double Fine team came out with - it's a very high quality point and click adventure and I'm having a blast playing through it!One thing I wish was included in the game is an in-game hint system for the more frustrating puzzles though.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												I loved every minute of this game. However, it's far too short and pretty much incomplete. I won't go ballistic about the injustice of how the community invested a♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of money into a kickstarter and only got a small part of what was promised to them; I didn't participate in that kickstarter and I only recently bought it, about a month before the release of Act II, so I can't really comment on that. If I had to grade it as a standalone game, I certainly wouldn't recommend it; it being an incomplete experience. But considering how the second installation is right around the corner, and how intensely I enjoyed the two meager hours of gameplay this first miniature installation had to offer, I will recommend it heartily anyway.As a caveat though, I have to say it's probably not for everyone. It's not incredibly thought-provoking, nor is it a particularly thrilling gameplay experience. It's just a charming adventure game that some might write off as childish and lackluster. And while I'd disagree with such a negative judgement, I can understand why some would think of it as such.I loved it. Will you? I honestly don't know, but one can hope.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2015
												A wonderful point and click adventure game.Puzzles:The first act is to easy puzzle wise, but the second act fixes that a lot. Multi-layered puzzles that actually makes you think, still not as hard as old-school adventure games, but much better than the first act, where each solution had only one step. I find the solutions to puzzles to be more in the "Aha! That makes sense" column than in the "WTF!" column.Story:The game has great characters and a good story. I wish the game was longer at the end, so it would flesh out the bad guys more. Maybe even more scenes/puzzles in the city. Art:When the art was first revealed, I wasnt really sure about. Truth be told, I expected the art style to be closer to Full Throttle or Day of the Tentacle, but it grew on me and now I really like it. I can't imagine that it would look some other wayReally?:This is a hint for the second act, so if you do not want to read it, stop. Half the fun is finding out on your own. Though there are some players that don't like it. In the second act, you can get hints about puzzles from the other character's point of view. The characters dont interact, but you can switch between the characters and notice some details in Veila's part which help you solve a puzzle in Shay's part. It really comes out of the blue and you basically have to figure it own on your own. This didn't frustrate me or anything, but I can understand that some gamers are annoyed by this. I don't know, maybe it's the mileage of playing adventure games.If you want to play a great adventure game, buy it. This game made me laugh and lately adventure games don't really try to do that or they just think they're funny (Deponia).Plus, watch the credits, there is some nice art there ;)

Posted: January 11, 2016
												Broken Age represents the return of the classic “point-and-click” adventure game; it promised to feature the same wit, humor, and odd-ball puzzles that made games like The Secret of Monkey Island and Day of the Tentacle such timeless classics. I grew up during the hey-day of the point-and-click computer games and still have a box filled with floppy discs for games such as Monkey Island, Monkey Island 2 and Day of the Tentacle. My sense of humor was shaped by the comedy that Tim Schafer and Ron Gilbert wrote into their games.Now, after a controversial development, Broken Age arrives in full on the PlayStation Vita making one thing absurdly clear: it makes good on everything it promised. It is an adventure game that is as deep and rich as any I’ve ever played.2015-04-27-043646Broken Age tells the story of two young adults with one thing in common; they’re unhappy with their lot in life. Shay is a young man who has spent his life aboard a spaceship and has had his every need catered to by an overly mothering computer. The only excitement in his day is when he embarks on scripted expeditions to “rescue” creatures in peril. Day after day his life trudges on the same, and day after day he goes through the same charade – wishing each time there was something more.Vella is a young woman who lives in a village of bakers. Every 14 years the village offers up the best maidens in town as an offering to a horrible monster that ravages their land. Despite having such an honor bestowed upon her, Vella wonders why the people of her village cower in fear rather than fight the beast. She has chosen not to be a sacrifice; she has chosen for something better in life.2015-04-21-161855Shay and Vella are both unhappy with where their lives are going, but they also question what is real in the world around them. More than anything, what they really want, is to peer behind the curtain and discover the truth.The story in Broken Age is a deep and philosophical one that ironically doesn’t take itself too seriously. Shay lives on a spaceship where his companions are all knitted out of yarn, while Vella comes from a place where young women compete to be eaten by a monster. It’s the juxtaposition of these conflicting ideas that brings an elevated sense of humor to the story…Wow, that was deep. What I’m trying to say is that despite the underlying story, the surface is full of wild and wacky elements that are not only fun but hilariously funny. Often times this humor is derived from our two naïve heroes entering strange, new situations. Shay is a bit of a bumbling hero, much in the vain of Guybrush Threepwood from Monkey Island, while Vella is a headstrong go-getter with only one thing on her mind. Their dry comments in the oddest of situations would frequently make me laugh out loud, sometimes uncontrollably.And it’s good to have a sense of humor when playing a puzzle game like this. The puzzles presented in Broken Age feel very familiar and fresh at the same time. They’re the same twisted puzzles I grew up with where clues hide in plain sight and the answer is often more absurd than you’d think. Sometimes these puzzles get solved in a matter of minutes while other times you may have to think about them for a few hours.2015-04-23-0805262015-04-21-194850The game is broken up into two acts. Act I introduces us to our two protagonists and allows us to guide them on a new adventure. You can play as either Shay or Vella and switch between them at any time. The puzzles are challenging with a number of “A-ha!” moments, but it goes by rather quickly.Act II starts with you having to deal with the consequences of your earlier actions. Shay and Vella want to peer behind the curtain, but what do they do once they have? The second act is much longer than the first and the puzzles get more intense. In total it took me around 13 hours to complete the entire game.The interface for the game was designed with a PC in mind, and while it does make the transition to a controller fairly well, it still feels a bit awkward at times since you use the thumb sticks to move an on-screen cursor and interact with the environment. A nice feature is that the right stick will automatically snap to “clickable” objects so you don’t have to scan the entire room for something to click. It works decent enough, but it’s still not very precise. However, the PS Vita does have an advantage over the PS4 version – you can use the touchscreen to select items in the game. It works amazingly well and really speeds things up.2015-04-25-083347Visually, the game is absolutely stunning. The 2-D art style retains the feeling of the pixilated adventure games of old but adds a brilliant layer that creates a hand-drawn look to the game. The characters have a bold and unique style to them and the environmental art is all top notch. Everything runs smoothly with the performance never being a problem.Likewise, the voice acting is superb. With notable talents such as Elijah Wood, Jack Black, and Wil Wheaton (whom I didn’t even recognize until the credits rolled), the characters are all given a great sense of depth and humor. And as good as the acting is, the musical score is even better. It’s composition is grand in ambition at times befitting the heroes’ journey, but it can also be tender and intimate. It’s by far one of my favorite game scores to come out in a long time.2015-04-23-074403As great as Broken Age is, it’s not perfect. I often had trouble with the audio late in the game where the characters would speak but audio would be delayed for several seconds (or get drowned out by other noises). It’s a problem that happened in isolated areas but it was persistent. It also appears to be a Vita issue as the same problem would not occur on the PS4. I also had problems with the game crashing occasionally which seemed to go hand-in-hand with the Vita losing a connection to PSN.Any other issues I could point to would be nit-picking. It would be nice if there were more areas to explore, and it would be cool if the world felt a little bigger. Some characters get criminally underused while others get a bit too much screen time. In the end, I found it clever how the story would weave back into itself and reuse a lot of the same locations.Broken Age is a masterpiece. It manages to capture everything that made point-and-click adventure games great in the first place. It is the perfect blend of interesting characters, wacky humor, and head-scratching puzzles that constantly have you wanting more, and represents everything that made these games so wonderful to play.REVIEW OVERVIEWPresentation	5/5Gameplay	5/5Lasting Appeal	4.5/5Execution	5/5SUMMARYBroken Age promised to be a return to the classic point-and-click adventure games from yesteryear and manages to succeed on that promise in every way. It's a game filled with brilliantly absurd puzzles wrapped around a beautiful story that's told with wit and humor. It is both laugh out loud funny and head banging frustration. Broken Age manages to blend all these elements into a wonderfully charming game that should not be missed.4.9/5

number of helpful: 7 of 15 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												So, there it is. Broken Age is finally out. I haven't touched it before tonight (bought it sometime last year during a sale) and waited patiently for it to be ready for a full-on, one-session playthrough. The question is: Was it worth the wait?The (spoiler-free) answer to that is: Yes it was, if you have been patient and didn't raise your expectations too high.Now, something to say right away - Broken Age is not the adventure to end all adventures. It has its strengths and weaknesses. But what makes assessing them hard is that they switch around. In Act 1, the story was very strong and somewhat mysterious while the puzzles were mostly fairly easy. In Act 2, the story lost a lot of its pull (in my opinion) but the puzzles became more complex and challenging, some of them just the right amount to be satisfying, some pushing it a little (or well) into the realm of the frustrating.But I will not blame Double Fine for experimenting with some of the concepts behind puzzles. The fewer developers keep recycling the same concept, content and game over and over, the better, so I can admit I was satisfied with that part of the game even though I eventually had to look up a hint or two.The story left a somewhat bitter aftertaste, though. It's not that it's bad overall - The presentation is brilliant, the setup stellar (particularly Shay's Act 1 was great) and the cast of experienced and skilled (voice) actors add to it, as do the beatiful soundtrack and catching visuals. And the writing also doesn't leave a lot to be desired: It's witty, but not too over-the-top and just the right amount of educational to be played by all ages.It does, however, suffer from what I would call the "Mass Effect 3" effect: By the end, it seems like nobody really knew what to do with it, so it was just wrapped up in whatever way they could. It's not as bad as Mass Effect 3 but I found the conclusion unsatisfying and the last few scenes made me wonder where the good writing with its surprises and twists had gone and why I was now watching a B movie.I know that doesn't sound like a hearty recommendation but that doesn't mean you shouldn't pick it up. Broken Age is still a great adventure; it just isn't without faults, just like the story of its development. Be aware, though, that you are probably only going to get one playthrough of 8-10 hours out of it (maybe another some years later). But during a sale, this is a good pick.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												I've only played a few hours into Broken Age, but I'm not sure I'll ever fire it up again.Although the art style is respectable, the dialog is stilted, silly, and repetative. It's quite childish, but not in a way I think children would enjoy. The girl's story was somewhat engaging, but the boys side just failed to capture my imagination. Perhaps it was having to repeat the same 'quest' and dialog options multiple times. I get it, I'm supposed to feel like the boy who is bored out of his mind by endless repetition. Mission accomplished. Even when things started to pick up, the boy's lack of concern (or even moment of pause) that something has changed was too much for me to handle.Again, I didn't really get too deep into the game, so maybe it picks up a little later, but I also found the gameplay completely lacking. The objects you need to find are basically handed to you, and what you need to do with them is painfully obvious for an adventure game. They really only serve as a means of advancing the plot.In a word, I found Broken Age to be: boring.

												Broken Age is a game that focuses on two protagonists, Shay and Vella. They're very different but it turns out they're important to one another's story. Broken Age is their story and about how the two of them change things.This game is very creative. Not only is it really pretty but the characters are so much fun and the puzzles are unique. It also features some famous voice actors like Elijah Wood and Jack Black. The only major issue is the very end. It felt rushed but it doesn't really ruin the game completely. Yes, it's a bit disappointing but that doesn't really make me feel like I wasted my time. I still enjoyed myself and the game is replayable.If you're a fan of adventure games, then I highly recommend this.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												Just finished the complete game, including my 3rd play through the first "Act", and I have to say I definitely felt I got a $10 million experience—Double Fine put in the time, effort, and funds, and it paid off. Beautiful artwork, fun & interesting characters, quirky settings, and the layers within layers of "twists" in the plot were fun even though they were pretty obvious [to me]. With the full game in perspective, the "half" formerly known as "Act I" feels more like a prologue; it teaches you the interface, introduces the characters, setting, and plot, and it isn't until you reach "Act II" that the game really seems to begin. The game wouldn't work at all without the first act, but its value doesn't really become clear until you reach the second.Having recently played through some "classic" adventure games (e.g.: Monkey Island 1 & 2), I am grateful for the advancements of modern gaming & interface (thank goodness verbs are gone!) design, while still challenged by some of the puzzles and sometimes-tiny-and-obscure clues. In my opinion, Double Fine is taking adventure games in the right direction and, with all the time & effort they've invested in the engine, I look forward to seeing more adventure games from them in coming years.

number of helpful: 7 of 15 people (47%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												Broken Age is an adventure game by Double Fine that was initially funded via Kickstarter in 2012. Now in 2015, the game is finally fully released! But the question is: does it deliver?The story describes the coming of age of a boy (Shay) and girl (Vella). You get to play with both characters by alternating their storylines, which are interwoven in a clever way. After a certain point, alternating between characters becomes essential for progressing in the game. I found the story compelling and it motivated me to keep playing the game.The puzzles in the game use the classic object manipulation and character interaction staples from the adventure game genre, which are executed in a appropriate and traditional way. Unfortunately, some puzzles do suffer from being too easy or having an unclear context. A bit more polish here and there would have definitely made all puzzles great. Overall, I enjoyed solving the puzzles.From a visual perspective, Broken age has a unique and nice art style, which is definitely a selling point. Animations are crisp and the world feels very much alive thanks to a quirky cast of characters with great voice actors. The ambience the game breathes is great and it is an enjoyable environment to walk around in.The soundtrack is also very enjoyable and it always suited the mood for the story.In conclusion, from the perspective of an adventure game player, Broken Age might feel underwhelming, since it never tries to go beyond the classic adventure game mold. What remains is a charming game that any gamer with an open mind can appreciate, given its sense of adventure and positive spirit.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2016
												This game has great visuals, genuine humor, and stellar voice acting, but puzzles can be unintuitive and dialogue regrettably stitched together.Watching the trailer, you can see and hear the pros I listed. A great cast and imaginative art make this game worth playing. What you can't see from the trailer are the cons I've pointed out.As others have pointed out, the second act of this game has a sharp difficulty spike. A good portion of my play through was simply being stuck in the second act, not actually playing the game. All in all, I had to look at hints 3 times to progress in the second act (not at all in the first). If you don't mind using a guide, this game will likely be great for you. If having to toggle between two characters to get answers to puzzles bothers you (immersion breaking because characters use knowledge they otherwise wouldn't have) then this game is definitely NOT for you.Other than the difficulty in the second act, I wasn't entirely pleased with how the dialogue flowed together. The lines by themselves were not the problem, but following one line of thought and then having to jarringly switch over to another to get a hint or key to a puzzle really bothered me.For me, I liked the game, but I would have preferred to watch someone else play it (stitching together the dialogue best they could) or for this to be a short movie.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
												I don't not-recommend this as a hard No. I might very likely recommend it to someone I thought would enjoy it, albeit with reservations. *SPOILERS*Weeellllll, I just finished playing Broken Age. Hmm. First off, it's so beautiful. SO beautiful. I can see why I paid full-price for it after knowing hardly anything and watching the trailer. The game is just as beautiful as the trailer looks, with a whole lot of tiresome monotony thrown in. Broken Age is split into two acts. Act One has fairly simple puzzles which follow the fun story. Vella and Shay, the two main characters, each inhabit their own world with no knowledge of the other (but you know that's gonna change). Playing either character is possible at any time. In Act Two, Vella and Shay switch worlds, and while each world is expanded on and new characters introduced, the puzzles became so tedious and not-obvoius, I found myself walking around the same places over and over. The puzzles were tough in a way that didn't feel very stimulating, or creative, or challenging. Just sort of a shiny cute laborious thing to sludge through, with the help of walkthroughs that I very quickly turned to. I really want to make this sound more positive than I am, but I think the best part of the game for me was finishing, haha. Being done brought a feeling of satisfaction and relief that the game itself mostly hadn't. I did find Vella and Shay both to be interesting characters, largely because they're their own people and don't align so much with gender stereotypes. That said, a lot of other characters are pretty cliche and boring. Like, there are some married parents in Act Two, and the mom's main activity seems to be worrying about her kid, while the dad is gettin' all scientific with the PH balance of a mud puddle and patching holes in a spaceship. I recommend buying Broken Age on sale, taking lots of screenshots, enjoying Elijah Wood's voice (as Shay), turning to walkthroughs as wanted, and maybe having the snacks you like best nearby. Because this game, like any, is a whole lot better with some nice ridged chips and a towel to wipe the grease.

												This has been one of the most enjoyable games I've played all year. It's aurally and visually beautiful, and the puzzles are challenging, especially in the second half. number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
												Broken Age was the very first project I backed on Kickstarter. As such, it will always have a special place in my heart. It also revived my interest in adventure games, which I didn't think possible in my old, jaded age, but it's a consequence of the game that will stay with me long after the game itself is finished, which is an impressive feat.The first act is a love song to 2D adventure games. There are tropes that play out like you'd expect and others turned totally upside down. It's fun and light-hearted and whimsical. You won't find another voice cast including the likes of Jack Black and Wil Wheaton in an adventure game any time soon. It's funny, and at times, poignant.Sadly, the second half doesn't follow nearly as strongly. The puzzles are more obtuse. The writing is more matter-of-fact, and a lot of the situations, artwork, and even puzzles get heavily re-used. In some cases this allows for a creative twist on things, but in others it stinks of laziness. Personally I think the issue is that the success of the Kickstarter and Act I gave Double Fine some room to maneuver, so they got distracted: they made several new games such as Massive Chalice and remastered some old adventure titles in between the releases of the acts. The second act feels like it's a necessary conclusion to the story, but one that they rushed through creating rather than taking the time and care needed to make it something truely memorable.My other complaint is with the achievements. Most of the time I feel that achievements are neutral - you would've done the requirement for it anyway - or positive because they force you to play the game in a new or interesting or challenging way. But here the achievements are almost all neutral or negative - actively detracting from the experience. First, they were only included for Act I after Act II was released, which forces another run through just to get credit for things already completed. Furthermore, some of the achievements require you to get something right on the first try. For me, this is the worst kind of achievement because it discourages experimentation and encourages relying on guides. It's exacerbated by the fact that there is no chapter select, despite the natural break point in the middle and the forums shouting for some kind of way to jump into Act II when it came out.Finally, there is a speed run achievement. Simply put: it has no place here. An adventure game is the not the kind of game where you want to skip all the cutscenes and dialogue and use a guide for all the puzzles. That's like purposefully ignoring all the best parts. It's stupid. Some people have theorized it's only there because Xbox Live requires games to have leaderboards. It's just speculation, but if it's true it's awful reasoning and it's fustrating that they kept it included in the desktop version, where there are no leaderboards. And to top it off, because of the included manual save feature the speed run is not even challenging, since you can just save when you only complete a section in the optimal time. So it's an achievement that is a worthless chore requiring no skill that forces you to skip past the best parts of the game. I can't imagine what they were thinking.Broken Age has some beautiful moments and engrossing puzzles set in a unique world. It can't carry the magic all the way through, but it doesn't have to for it to be a game worth playing.

This is an adventure game for the 21st century.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
												Broken Age was the very first project I backed on Kickstarter. As such, it will always have a special place in my heart. It also revived my interest in adventure games, which I didn't think possible in my old, jaded age, but it's a consequence of the game that will stay with me long after the game itself is finished, which is an impressive feat.The first act is a love song to 2D adventure games. There are tropes that play out like you'd expect and others turned totally upside down. It's fun and light-hearted and whimsical. You won't find another voice cast including the likes of Jack Black and Wil Wheaton in an adventure game any time soon. It's funny, and at times, poignant.Sadly, the second half doesn't follow nearly as strongly. The puzzles are more obtuse. The writing is more matter-of-fact, and a lot of the situations, artwork, and even puzzles get heavily re-used. In some cases this allows for a creative twist on things, but in others it stinks of laziness. Personally I think the issue is that the success of the Kickstarter and Act I gave Double Fine some room to maneuver, so they got distracted: they made several new games such as Massive Chalice and remastered some old adventure titles in between the releases of the acts. The second act feels like it's a necessary conclusion to the story, but one that they rushed through creating rather than taking the time and care needed to make it something truely memorable.My other complaint is with the achievements. Most of the time I feel that achievements are neutral - you would've done the requirement for it anyway - or positive because they force you to play the game in a new or interesting or challenging way. But here the achievements are almost all neutral or negative - actively detracting from the experience. First, they were only included for Act I after Act II was released, which forces another run through just to get credit for things already completed. Furthermore, some of the achievements require you to get something right on the first try. For me, this is the worst kind of achievement because it discourages experimentation and encourages relying on guides. It's exacerbated by the fact that there is no chapter select, despite the natural break point in the middle and the forums shouting for some kind of way to jump into Act II when it came out.Finally, there is a speed run achievement. Simply put: it has no place here. An adventure game is the not the kind of game where you want to skip all the cutscenes and dialogue and use a guide for all the puzzles. That's like purposefully ignoring all the best parts. It's stupid. Some people have theorized it's only there because Xbox Live requires games to have leaderboards. It's just speculation, but if it's true it's awful reasoning and it's fustrating that they kept it included in the desktop version, where there are no leaderboards. And to top it off, because of the included manual save feature the speed run is not even challenging, since you can just save when you only complete a section in the optimal time. So it's an achievement that is a worthless chore requiring no skill that forces you to skip past the best parts of the game. I can't imagine what they were thinking.Broken Age has some beautiful moments and engrossing puzzles set in a unique world. It can't carry the magic all the way through, but it doesn't have to for it to be a game worth playing.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												Tim Schafer is known for his quirky brand of the Monkey Island adventure game. For those new to the genre of point and click adventure games, you explore and solve puzzles within a highly stylized environment as action and narrative gradually unfolds. Understandably, there are both strong and weak points to this style. Since the genre has been around for three decades, the weaknesses have integrated themselves into the appeal of the game. There is an audience who enjoys having ten unique items in a sack and endlessly manipulating them to unravel the story. Other games, such as Telltale's Walking Dead and The Wolf Among Us, estimate the majority of the greater potential audience dislikes this style of Trial and Error, and streamlines the experience. Thus, I will cut right to the chase, Broken Age is consciously archaec. If you have played Monkey Island, The Longest Journey, or Grim Fandago, you know exactly what to expect, since you have played this game before. The story unfolds along an intriguing ark, you obtain and interact with ten items in a sack, appealing humor and characters are involved, and the overall experience is entertaining, moving, and of high quality. If you are new to the genre, and are open minded toward it. Broken Age is one of the Top Grade titles of its class. Tim Schafer himself is a product of the Steven Speilberg, Disney-Pixar, Nintendo craze of the 80's and 90's, and his work is a luminous reflection of his influences. Schafer does have a few off-beat conventions in his style, which you would not expect from a Disney or Nintendo show, but his games deviate only a couple of steps from first base. Did I enjoy Broken Age? Yes, I was entertained and moved. Is it a classic of the overall genre? As much as Grim Fandago or Monkey Island is in my mind. Would I recommend it to someone else? If you like Tim Schafer's product, then yes, if you have not enjoyed his Adventure Games in the past, there will be nothing here to dissuade you from your prior bias. If you haven't played an adventure game before and you like the Speilberg-Disney-Pixar-Nintendo product, Broken Age is a good place to start and you will have a great time. There's no shame in following a walkthrough.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												With Telltale leading the effort in evolving the point & click adventure genre, it can’t be easy for other aspiring developers to catch up. In Double Fine’s Broken Age the first act is a bit of a strange case. The sound design is solid, with the voice acting delivered by several big movie actors. The soundtrack is also fantastic. The art style is clearly thought out, feels unique and works well with the story. The gameplay and puzzles feel streamlined. And yet, it just doesn’t feel like fun. It’s half the time downright boring. Both the story and the gameplay refused to interest me throughout much of this first act.The two seemingly unrelated stories of Shay and Vella both start off very slow and frankly feel a little dull. The current life that Shay wants to break out of is boring and meaningless to him. This is projected well on to the player, who will feel the exact same. But the player’s feeling doesn’t let go once Shay starts on his big adventure. In fact, it still feels unmotivated and dull all the way towards the last ten minutes of the campaign. Only then does it pick up some speed, right before it abruptly ends with a tedious cliffhanger. Vella’s story is better and at least feels more focused.Broken Age’s first act isn’t a bad piece of work. There’s just too little of it. It’s a slow game, but a short one at the same time. Most of the puzzles feel devoid of any real cerebral challenge, and consistently remains on a level that a child can master. But more seasoned veterans of the adventure genre - which likely includes most of the people who backed the Kickstarter campaign - will be disappointed by what Double Fine are offering. The game isn’t bad by any means; it looks beautiful and the last few seconds of Vella’s story really makes me interested in what will happen next. But so far I can’t recommend Broken Age to any seasoned adventurers, with this two hour unoriginal and uninspired first act. Telltale has grown this genre so much. Why are you treading backwards, Double Fine?

												I loved it!  I've enjoyed several other classic point-and-clicks: Monkey Island I and II, Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis, Day of the Tentacle, and Full Throttle, and I think this one makes a fresh and interesting contribution to that library.  The art and music direction is fantastic, the voice acting is great, and the humor is done well.  Minor things bothered me in the final puzzle sequence (mostly the music), but overall I liked the game a great deal.  The puzzles in Act I are fairly easy, so most of my enjoyment came from watching the story unfold and interacting with the characters.  In Act II the difficulty increases a bit, which I appreciated.  Online walkthroughs are easy to find, but of course I recommend playing without them as much as possible if you actually want to enjoy hitting those "Aha!" moments when you solve particularly challenging puzzles.The "Double Fine Adventure" documentary series online is also fun to watch if you're interested in the blood, sweat, tears, and laughter that goes into video game production.9/10

content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												Broken Age has the same charm that I've come to expect from Schafer's games, like Psychonauts, Costume Quest and Stacking.  The characters are interesting though admittedly one-dimensional (just like most point and click adventure games) and the conversations are mostly quite entertaining.  I think the voice acting is superb as well, especially with the two main characters and the Computer ("Mom").  The animation and visuals prove that a game does not need super high def SSAO bloom TressFX etc etc to set the atmosphere of a game in the right direction.  The overall aesthetic (visuals, music, ambience) elicit zero complaints from me. Unfortunately, the same cannot be said of the gameplay.  I'm not sure what I was expecting, but I found the item hunting a bit tiring at times.  I wish there was a way to speed up conversations, as I generally read much faster than people speak (pressing space will skip the entire conversation, not just the current dialogue with subtitles) and though there are some areas where your character can run, most of the time you walk at a very slow clip.  I'm glad that there isn't much hand holding, but when certain areas open up, it can be a bit annoying to walk back and forth between screens looking for an item I missed. Still, it's not like I did not enjoy the gameplay at all.  I think the clever dialogue (and even off hand remarks as I look at items or walk past characters) cracked me up, and that makes a ton of difference in adventure games.  I had an idea of where the story was heading at first, but now I'm not so sure.  All I know is that Act 2 cannot come soon enough.

												Let's get the quibbles out of the way first: It's not immediately apparent why Vella needs to do what she does when she gets to Shellmound, and the occasional lack of variety in "I can't use these things together" messages is jarring when considering the great variety on other occasions.That said, Broken Age is a fine throwback to the era of the adventure game. content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												At this point, I might as well proclaim my undying love to Tim Schafer. It seems every title I've touched with him behind the director's chair reminds me why I love video games.Apparently 16 years since his last point-and-click adventure game, Grim Fandango, and the man still knows how to work it. I mean it's not like he wasn't doing anything, with Psychonauts and Brutal Legends druid-plowing themselves into my favorite's list, but point-and-clicks are very different from your normal genre. Practically visual novels; if the story or context doesn't hook you, there's nothing to go back for it aside from meager puzzles.Luckly Broken Age hooks you from the start with both, and beautiful artwork to boot. Shay and Vella's story is nothing new, something we've seen or read plently times before, but Tim Schafer's spin leaves it refreshing. For example, Shay's situation is entirely understandable, where he puts a mental barrier between him and the "Computer" who is taking care of him. Although never brought up by Shay or the game itself, it's likely only programmed to take care of him - it isn't true love and concern. Yet all it takes is some lovely voice-work provided by the ever awesome Jennifer Hale and a small story toward Shay, and I can't help but feel sad for "Computer". Damn you, Shay, just call her "Mom" for once.Contrary to what I'm saying above, the game is light-hearted. Vella's story about sacrificing maidens is not as grim as you'd imagine it to be. No blood or gore, just a small glimpse of a body as it's devoured by a giant species of monster called a Mog. Yet that's part of its charm. Combined with its watercolor artwork and peaceful soundtrack, it's as if I'm reading a children's storybook. Then you eventually come across someone whose name is shortened to Ch't.... heh-heh.All and all, I am very looking forward to Act 2. Having started Shay's story first, I thought I had an idea of where his story ended when I was nearing the end of Vella's. The end of Act 1 practically told me "Nope," punched me in the face, and jumped off a cliff. I'd pay again in order for it to come sooner, but like everyone else, I'll have to wait for the free update... whenever that is.C'mon, Tim. Don't do this to me, man. I needs it. I needs it now~

content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												Having now played both Act 1 and Act 2, I feel the need to completely edit and amend my earlier review:This is an interesting concept for a game. You start out with the option to choose between two characters, and you can jump back and forth between their separate stories at will. The hand-painted character designs, locations, and background art are completely unique and absolutely beautiful.  I would recommend playing through for the visuals alone. I also really dig the musical score and the voice acting. In general, the production values are incredibly high.For the most part, the puzzles in Act 1 are easy.  If I was stumped it was either because I was over-analyzing the situation, or it was because I failed to pick up an item earlier in the game and needed to backtrack.In Act 2, many of the puzzles are still intuitive, but there are some that are more complicated or frustrating than they need to be, and there are others that require information and clues found in the other character's storyline. You will *need* to switch back and forth between playing as Shay and playing as Vella at regular intervals, and you will need to pay careful attention to every item description, detail shot, and offhand dialogue comment.  Throughout the game there is a fair bit of comedy, more so in Shay's story than Vella's.  Make sure to talk to everyone, examine everything, and to use each object with every other object/person in order to get all the flavour dialogue.  The spoon and knife are particularly amusing.I had initially disliked the plot of Act 1 because it felt very misogynistic, and even now I am still slightly bothered by Vella's story. I think what the writers were going for was to show current women's struggles (limited options, needing to prove their inherent worth to the world, needing to sometimes be overly-aggressive to make their voices heard, having a cultural obligation to put the needs of others above their own, etc.) within the context of a familiar sci-fi/fantasy plot device (virgin sacrifice). Unfortunately, the way the writing was handled made it seem like just another case of lazy violence against women, and made her and everyone else around her look petty and cruel. I think they could have explored the same issues in a less offensive manner and been more successful; however, after playing through the entire Meriloft section in Act 2, I have restored faith that the intentions of Act 1 were indeed positive, even if the execution was flawed.Shay's story, on the other hand, is wryly humorous, immediately relatable, and culturally relevant. We understand over-protective helicopter parents, we commiserate with his teenage desire to be grown up and take risks, and we are sympathetic to his need to take on responsibility and do something important and heroic with his life. The issue is that juxtaposed against one another, the stories of Act 1, at least on the surface, come across as "white boy who feels entitled to more control" vs. "female PoC who just wants the right to live," rather than "kids who want autonomy," whether that's what the writers intended or not, and it at once both highlights and re-enforces cultural inequalities. Act 2 does a better overall job with the writing; the main characters are more well-rounded and developed, the side characters are deeper, there is a greater sense of balance and equality, the plot hook is more compelling, and within the first five minutes they threw some major twists in I wasn't anticipating. At the same time, they also introduced plot holes you can drive a bus through, and they don't answer any of the meaningful questions they raise. I expected with the amount of time and resources at their disposal they could have created a coherent well-thought-out conclusion, but it felt rushed, unsatisfying, and nonsensical.Act 2 also gets mixed marks in other categories:I liked that Vella and Shay get to learn about each other's backgrounds, but for the most part you spend your time backtracking through the same exact screens you saw in Act 1. (Navigating around each location can be a bit of a slog, but double-clicking will expedite your characters' movements.)Also, while I like the idea of achievements, it took some of the joy out of playing when I saw they were for things like "do this really long and onerous sequence in one shot" or "pick the right answer on the first try instead of exploring the other dialogue options" or "speed run this not-very-fun game in an hour." Those kinds of achievements don't lend themselves to an adventure game.I'm not sure what to rate the complete game, honestly. As a point-and-click puzzle-adventure, it's adequate, with a couple of frustrating puzzles overshadowing the otherwise decent gameplay. As an art piece, it's production values, acting, and music are beautiful. As a story, many of the individual concepts and characters are great, but the overarching plot is full of holes and uses a passe trope for its macguffin, and it also dodges answering any of the meaty questions it raises. As a piece of social commentary, it sends mixed signals. As a comedy, it has several moments of brilliance and a few cringe-worthy duds. As a game that crowd-sourced more than 8x the needed funds and then took 3 years to complete, I was hoping for better. I guess that now leaves it somewhere in the 5.5-6/10 range. I would not pay the full $25 for it.

Posted: July 27, 2015
												A very unique style of game, with very deep storytelling. The game is a story and puzzle game. Think of games like myst where you go from area to area gathering tools and items to unlock the next part of the puzzle/story, The game levels are technically linear but they have a very open feel to them. There are many achievements to be had, giving some limited replayability. Some achievements you only get one shot at and if you didn't have a manual save, you would need to start the game over. Most puzzles are well designed, but a few are near impossible to figure out without a guide.  The visuals are amazing works of art. The voice acting and environmental audio is top notch. Overall this game is a great break from traditional styles of games. If you like adventure genre video games with good story telling, you will not be disappointed.Negatives:Once chance to attain some achievements without a manual savePoor guidance for some puzzlesLimited replayability for achievements onlyPostives: The few puzzles encountered are well designedExcellent graphics and environmental detailIn depth storytellingTop notch voice acting and environmental audioGraphics: 10/10Sound: 10/10 Story: 9/10 (some story elements do not make sense)Gameplay: 7/10 (lack of puzzle guidance and replayability)Overall:9/10

content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												Having now played both Act 1 and Act 2, I feel the need to completely edit and amend my earlier review:This is an interesting concept for a game. You start out with the option to choose between two characters, and you can jump back and forth between their separate stories at will. The hand-painted character designs, locations, and background art are completely unique and absolutely beautiful.  I would recommend playing through for the visuals alone. I also really dig the musical score and the voice acting. In general, the production values are incredibly high.For the most part, the puzzles in Act 1 are easy.  If I was stumped it was either because I was over-analyzing the situation, or it was because I failed to pick up an item earlier in the game and needed to backtrack.In Act 2, many of the puzzles are still intuitive, but there are some that are more complicated or frustrating than they need to be, and there are others that require information and clues found in the other character's storyline. You will *need* to switch back and forth between playing as Shay and playing as Vella at regular intervals, and you will need to pay careful attention to every item description, detail shot, and offhand dialogue comment.  Throughout the game there is a fair bit of comedy, more so in Shay's story than Vella's.  Make sure to talk to everyone, examine everything, and to use each object with every other object/person in order to get all the flavour dialogue.  The spoon and knife are particularly amusing.I had initially disliked the plot of Act 1 because it felt very misogynistic, and even now I am still slightly bothered by Vella's story. I think what the writers were going for was to show current women's struggles (limited options, needing to prove their inherent worth to the world, needing to sometimes be overly-aggressive to make their voices heard, having a cultural obligation to put the needs of others above their own, etc.) within the context of a familiar sci-fi/fantasy plot device (virgin sacrifice). Unfortunately, the way the writing was handled made it seem like just another case of lazy violence against women, and made her and everyone else around her look petty and cruel. I think they could have explored the same issues in a less offensive manner and been more successful; however, after playing through the entire Meriloft section in Act 2, I have restored faith that the intentions of Act 1 were indeed positive, even if the execution was flawed.Shay's story, on the other hand, is wryly humorous, immediately relatable, and culturally relevant. We understand over-protective helicopter parents, we commiserate with his teenage desire to be grown up and take risks, and we are sympathetic to his need to take on responsibility and do something important and heroic with his life. The issue is that juxtaposed against one another, the stories of Act 1, at least on the surface, come across as "white boy who feels entitled to more control" vs. "female PoC who just wants the right to live," rather than "kids who want autonomy," whether that's what the writers intended or not, and it at once both highlights and re-enforces cultural inequalities. Act 2 does a better overall job with the writing; the main characters are more well-rounded and developed, the side characters are deeper, there is a greater sense of balance and equality, the plot hook is more compelling, and within the first five minutes they threw some major twists in I wasn't anticipating. At the same time, they also introduced plot holes you can drive a bus through, and they don't answer any of the meaningful questions they raise. I expected with the amount of time and resources at their disposal they could have created a coherent well-thought-out conclusion, but it felt rushed, unsatisfying, and nonsensical.Act 2 also gets mixed marks in other categories:I liked that Vella and Shay get to learn about each other's backgrounds, but for the most part you spend your time backtracking through the same exact screens you saw in Act 1. (Navigating around each location can be a bit of a slog, but double-clicking will expedite your characters' movements.)Also, while I like the idea of achievements, it took some of the joy out of playing when I saw they were for things like "do this really long and onerous sequence in one shot" or "pick the right answer on the first try instead of exploring the other dialogue options" or "speed run this not-very-fun game in an hour." Those kinds of achievements don't lend themselves to an adventure game.I'm not sure what to rate the complete game, honestly. As a point-and-click puzzle-adventure, it's adequate, with a couple of frustrating puzzles overshadowing the otherwise decent gameplay. As an art piece, it's production values, acting, and music are beautiful. As a story, many of the individual concepts and characters are great, but the overarching plot is full of holes and uses a passe trope for its macguffin, and it also dodges answering any of the meaty questions it raises. As a piece of social commentary, it sends mixed signals. As a comedy, it has several moments of brilliance and a few cringe-worthy duds. As a game that crowd-sourced more than 8x the needed funds and then took 3 years to complete, I was hoping for better. I guess that now leaves it somewhere in the 5.5-6/10 range. I would not pay the full $25 for it.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												I was in the middle of a 10 pages review when I accidentally kicked the power cord and the computer turned off. So I'll make this brief.Yes, I recommend it. Buy the game.Strong point: story. Very clever and surprising. Broken Age ditched all those verbs from the first adventure games. I think that's actually an advance, these things always felt hacky, sometimes there were redundant verbs and you never knew exactly what to do, do I USE a door or OPEN it? Eventually the verbs shrunk to less actions, like full throttle's intuitive wheel. But it was still questionable, what does HAND means I'll do? punch? pick it up? OK, I am glad we got over that but the fact is that more options than simply clicking gives more dimensions to the puzzles and Broken Age feels easy and linear in the puzzle department. Maybe there's a sweet spot between plain click and verbs that makes sense.I may be swimming against the stream here but I don't like the voice acting. It's not bad acting though, I think they don't know how to deliver Tim Shafer's very dry humor writing, everything sounds like a children's cartoon and it's not as funny as it could be.UPDATE FOR EPISODE 2:Everything I said before still holds but I want to make an extra comment on the voice acting. I HATE VELLA'S VOICE. Most of the voices are pretty bad, missing the jokes and all, but serviceable, except hers goes the extra mile and makes me hate the parts of the game I have to play as her. It's like they wrote all of Vella's lines in a book and had someone read it to children as bedtime story, recorded it, and called it voice acting. It's bad. Really, really bad.I still like the story. It got a little messy and confusing near the end though (still better than several classic adventure games). There were some clever puzzles. I laughed on occasion. Besides my dislike for the voice acting (and hatred for Vella's voice in particular) it's a good adventure game.
