number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												My husband and I decided to play this game together. We took turns; he controlled Shay and I controlled Vella, and I would have to say that this worked out beautifully. I would recommend other couples try this, or perhaps parents with children (not super young children because it gets a bit scary at times).  You can switch back and forth between the two characters at any time, and when you finish one character’s story it automatically jumps to the other character. We enjoyed the game itself. The artwork and voice acting were amazing. The puzzles were pretty doable for the most part. There was only one time we were both stuck, but there were a few times one of us was stuck and the other was able to jump in with suggestions. This made our experience all the more enjoyable. We also really liked being able to discuss our theories about how the two characters were going to intersect, and the surprise ending of part one made us glad we shared our theories because we were pretty far off the mark and it was nice to share the revelation with other person present. All in all, I would recommend Broken Age as a game for anyone who likes adventure games or point and click games, or for anyone who loves a good story, but I would doubly recommend you play it with another person. It’s definitely a game that is better when shared.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
												Absolutely fantastic game! Where to begin?1. First and foremost, this game is an awesome deconstruction of unrecognized privilege. I've never come across a game more directly attempting to reach gamers and improve them as human beings. All games published henceforth ought to take a page out of this game's socio/political playbook. I could go on about the instances of this, but there's an outstanding article that pretty much blows it out of the water here: http://www.geekquality.com/broken-age/2. The art. Ho boy the art in this game. It has the unique Tim Schafer magic of Day of the Tentacle and Full Throttle, but with an elegance that is totally unparralleled in any game I've played to date. Some of the scenes in this game beg you to stop advancing in the game for a while and just ENJOY the beauty. 5/5 stars here.3. The voiceover and script for the game is phenomenal. All the corny, cherished humor of adventure games from Ye Olden Tymes with A-listers reading.Amazing work, Double Fine. Please keep turning out more titles like this one!

content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												I didn't back this game during the kickstarter and I didn't play it until it was fully released. I intentionally kept myself in the dark to not create expectations and not to spoil myself fun of discovering the game on my own.Wow this game looks good. The art style is gorgeous, music is great. It is obvious that a lot of work went into presentation. Animation for each conversation seems to be hand-crafted, so if you have an eye for details you will find many things to enjoy. Sadly the other parts of the game aren't that interesting. Puzzles are occasionally fun but nothing groundbreaking. In the later stages of the game, when it attempts to provide more challenging puzzles BA falls into a trap of being quite abstract. You will do some things, which really don't make sense within the context of the story. Story itself is enjoyable but disjointed and not particularly convincing. Still it was good enough to keep me interested for the duration of the game. There are some intriguing ideas but overall it is a very silly tale.I think it is good game but not a brilliant one. If you are looking for something on the level of the Longest Journey, Siberia or Grim Fandango... well, play those. Broken Age is a weaker kind of p&c - the puzzles stop you from progressing the story, rather than being a way of developing plot and characters.I don't think Broken Age will reopen doors to point&click adventures. It runs into too many problems the old games did and beside presentation it doesn't bring anything new. But if you crave for a new point&click, it is a fun adventure!

												Broken Age is an Adventure, which is mostly thought for kids, but it makes a lot of fun for older ones too.The Game is build up simple, funny and sometimes kind of tricky.You Play the two charakters, one in a kind of an space ship, the boy shay, the other in a little village, the girl vella.Its very exciting to watch their own world and their own problems, which sometimes have some great supprises for you.Vella, whos always in dangour and mets allong her way many very stupid People. She seems to has a lot more intellect, than the other and thats often difficult to handle for her, while Shay is allone on this Big Space Ship with the KI playing his Father and his mother. He´s always searching for an real Adventure, without having any real knowledge, about what hes really doing.To come to a conclusion I think Broken Age is a very funny and Great Adveture, just for the first part, which is really nice to play and makes a good difference to the games you normally play instead. It´s really worth it

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												I didn't back this game during the kickstarter and I didn't play it until it was fully released. I intentionally kept myself in the dark to not create expectations and not to spoil myself fun of discovering the game on my own.Wow this game looks good. The art style is gorgeous, music is great. It is obvious that a lot of work went into presentation. Animation for each conversation seems to be hand-crafted, so if you have an eye for details you will find many things to enjoy. Sadly the other parts of the game aren't that interesting. Puzzles are occasionally fun but nothing groundbreaking. In the later stages of the game, when it attempts to provide more challenging puzzles BA falls into a trap of being quite abstract. You will do some things, which really don't make sense within the context of the story. Story itself is enjoyable but disjointed and not particularly convincing. Still it was good enough to keep me interested for the duration of the game. There are some intriguing ideas but overall it is a very silly tale.I think it is good game but not a brilliant one. If you are looking for something on the level of the Longest Journey, Siberia or Grim Fandango... well, play those. Broken Age is a weaker kind of p&c - the puzzles stop you from progressing the story, rather than being a way of developing plot and characters.I don't think Broken Age will reopen doors to point&click adventures. It runs into too many problems the old games did and beside presentation it doesn't bring anything new. But if you crave for a new point&click, it is a fun adventure!

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												I was in the middle of a 10 pages review when I accidentally kicked the power cord and the computer turned off. So I'll make this brief.Yes, I recommend it. Buy the game.Strong point: story. Very clever and surprising. Broken Age ditched all those verbs from the first adventure games. I think that's actually an advance, these things always felt hacky, sometimes there were redundant verbs and you never knew exactly what to do, do I USE a door or OPEN it? Eventually the verbs shrunk to less actions, like full throttle's intuitive wheel. But it was still questionable, what does HAND means I'll do? punch? pick it up? OK, I am glad we got over that but the fact is that more options than simply clicking gives more dimensions to the puzzles and Broken Age feels easy and linear in the puzzle department. Maybe there's a sweet spot between plain click and verbs that makes sense.I may be swimming against the stream here but I don't like the voice acting. It's not bad acting though, I think they don't know how to deliver Tim Shafer's very dry humor writing, everything sounds like a children's cartoon and it's not as funny as it could be.UPDATE FOR EPISODE 2:Everything I said before still holds but I want to make an extra comment on the voice acting. I HATE VELLA'S VOICE. Most of the voices are pretty bad, missing the jokes and all, but serviceable, except hers goes the extra mile and makes me hate the parts of the game I have to play as her. It's like they wrote all of Vella's lines in a book and had someone read it to children as bedtime story, recorded it, and called it voice acting. It's bad. Really, really bad.I still like the story. It got a little messy and confusing near the end though (still better than several classic adventure games). There were some clever puzzles. I laughed on occasion. Besides my dislike for the voice acting (and hatred for Vella's voice in particular) it's a good adventure game.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 20, 2015
												I really enjoyed Act 1 for this game. The puzzles weren't too difficult, but not overly simple either. I loved the story line, and how you could play and switch between two characters at a time. It's absolutely beautiful and a very entertaining game; once I started playing I didn't finish until I had completed it.Unfortunately, Act 2 was not the same. When I first saw that Act 2 was finally coming out, I was extremely excited. I had been looking forward to seeing the conclusion after so long, sadly though it was not nearly as good as the first act was in some aspects.The art style was just as good, if not better. A very beautiful game. The story line got incrediably interesting, with some twists I didn't expect. The most important aspect, though, are the puzzles which was the biggest downfall of this act. They were overly ridiculous, things you wouldn't ever even remotely expect and were absolutely absurd in their logic. Without a walkthrough (which I never had to use in the first act) I would not have been able to complete this game. I was shocked at how much different this game was, and I could feel that the developers may have rushed it, or completely concentrated in other areas that weren't the mechanics of the game itself.All in all, I really enjoyed the first half of this game, not so much the second half. I'm giving this a thumbs up solely based on the story line, art style, and Act 1 as far as the game mechanics go. Please read other reviews and get more input before deciding to spend $25 on this game. Act 1 was definitely worth the money, Act 2 was not.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
												While I loved games like Grim Fandango and Monkey Island,  I have to say this game combines great story telling, heartwarming animation, user-experience and puzzle design in way that simply surpasses the former greats.I seem to have a different opinion than many, and that is likely due to the fact that I played Act 1&2 together.  Waiting several months and then playing in mostly the same settings I suppose could be disappointing, but if played together actually makes the game feel seamless and natural, and in fact the story is as well thought-out as it is whimsical. I think the same is true with puzzle difficulty: the puzzles progressively get harder over the course of Act 1&2, which makes sense.  Yes, there are times when I got stuck, but that just made figuring them out satisfying. I think one or two puzzles required a pencil and paper (or memorization) in Act 2, which crossed the line for some people.  I would say: 1. the puzzles make sense (enough for an adventure game), and 2. the game is liberal with clues, and 3. no puzzles "require" help online.  Kudos to the developers and all involved.  I think there are many stories left to be told in this universe, and I hope we get to see them someday.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												OK - Just finished the game and here are my thoughts:What I loved:+ Writing, voice acting and some jokes are clever.+ Variety of weirdly thought out characters such as a talking spoon.+ Plot is clevery written+ Graphics are charming and in 2D.What I didn't like:- There are not much of areas to explore. It felt compact.- While the plot is clevery written, it still does not capture what made classic adventure game stories interesting. There isn't much to get interested in the two main characters (Shay and Vella). We are simply solving their life problems.- Very simplistic point-and-click game. Clicking on an object will automatically trigger whatever the progammer wanted it to be. Sometimes the character would comment on it, sometimes will try to "activate it" and sometimes will take it. I'd prefer it if it reused the verb technique, like in Curse of Monkey Island (Look at, Use/Pickup, Talk/Eat).- The puzzles at the end of the game were frustrating and confusing.Verdict: It is a return to classic adventure games alright but I don't see it surpassing my favourite classics (Full Throttle, Monkey Island, Grim Fandango, Sam and Max). However, it is still a recommended game for all those who still want Adventure Games. It is better than whatever Telltale is doing with Game of Thrones, that I can tell ya.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												Just pass on this. Seriously, it isn't worth the time.If you were excited like I was that Tim Schafer would be making a game the same calibur as Grim Fandango, this is not it. Instead, go buy Deponia: The Complete Journey and enjoy the game that Broken Age should have been.Here's the long version:Tim Schafer wrote and directed Grim Fandango, which I believe is the best point and click adventure game of all time. I say that with confidence as I've played a huge amount of adventure games (ags anyone?). Schafer, as it turns out, is a horrible project lead. Broken Age was kickstarted for over 3 million dollars which gave players Act 1. Act 1 took me about  2 hours to complete, and was fine. Just fine, it was not a game that should have taken 3 million dollars to complete and other studios have done more with much, much less. After the game released, Double Fine announced they had enough money to complete the project and deliver the abysmal Act 2.But not everybody really cares about the politics of the game, so here's some extra stuff for the passionate adventure gamer:The "good":Might as well start here as there is so little.Act 1 was okay. The puzzles were fair and made sense, and it did create this idea of some dark story beneath the kid friendly veil. Had Double Fine continued immediately from this point and used their 3 mil to make the entire game, I think it would have been fantastic.The bad:While the puzzles in act 1 were fair and made sense, they were very easy. It just didn't take a lot to get through it, leading to the very short 2 hour runtime. Act 1 soaked up all 3 million dollars and was only 2 hours long. As previously mentioned, Act 1's story was pretty good and gave the sense that there was something much darker in the story than we got from the frilly and colorful aesthetics. For example, at the end Vella's arc: The sacrifices are eaten by Mog Chothra and we are pretty much led to believe that they're dead. This is proved wrong in act 2, where we find that they're a-ok inside a prison cell in Mog Chothra, which is also a spaceship for some reason.The worst part about the game is act 2. Following the story from act 1, act 2 feels like it was written long after act 1 ended and they never really knew where they were going with the story. In fact, I found this on wikipedia: "In October 2014, producer Greg Rice announced that Schafer had finished writing Act 2 and the game's finale.". But the game released on January 28 of the same year. So after 3 million dollars, and a moderately successful release, Tim Schafer didn't even know how the game would end. And that should tell you all you need to know about how funky act 2 feels. I won't even bring up the awful wire puzzle later in the game. Others have, and everybody hates it.So there you have it, it took 3 million dollars to make a mediocre, 2 hour adventure game with a cliffhanger, and the sales from that (probably not 3 million btw) paid for an awful act 2.Just... just go play Deponia.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												Broken Age is a love letter to the classic adventure game by a classic developer, and it shows. If that's your bag, you'll enjoy this beautiful and quirky game. If you don't like adventure style games, your not gonna like it.When it's strong, it's incredible. The dialogue and characters are memorable, the setting is unique, the duel story lines that criss-cross through two colliding worlds are legitimately interesting. When the worlds do collide, the different view points are interesting. 99% of the puzzles will make you think without being unsolvable. Here's a tip: flipping back and forth between the pair is essential to solve some of the later puzzles, and some hints apply to multiple puzzles.When it's weak, it's still palatable. There are sections and background I would have loved to see more of, and a few parts that feel rushed. There are a few points where it suffers from 'clickitus', where you end up trying to use everything you have everywhere and with everyone to progress forward. While most of these appears obvious in hindsight, there are two cases where I was stupefied by the puzzle logic.From my experience, I'd say it has around a 8 to 12 hour play time if you don't seek out any hints online, about 4 to 6 if your the type who just can't resist looking up hints when you get stuck. The inventory and controls are good, and the art is amazing.TL;DR version: 8/10.

There are sections and background I would have loved to see more of, and a few parts that feel rushed. There are a few points where it suffers from 'clickitus', where you end up trying to use everything you have everywhere and with everyone to progress forward. While most of these appears obvious in hindsight, there are two cases where I was stupefied by the puzzle logic.From my experience, I'd say it has around a 8 to 12 hour play time if you don't seek out any hints online, about 4 to 6 if your the type who just can't resist looking up hints when you get stuck. The inventory and controls are good, and the art is amazing.TL;DR version: 8/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2015
												I've been following Tim Schafer since the first time I played Psychonauts, and I am always interested in his stuff.  So I picked this game up as soon as I heard it existed.When I played the first chapter of Broken Age, it seemed like it was setting up a lot of thematic elements and mysteries for the second part.  We've got two young people on the cusp of adulthood, questioning the way things have always been, being lied to their whole lives...  There are many different forces and people influencing the way they see the world, and they're finally breaking away and beginning to question those things.In an attempt to avoid spoiling much...  The second act kind of drops the ball on all those ideas.  It takes the thematic elements and makes them literal, and introduces concepts out of nowhere to explain preexisting plots and wrap up the story.  The puzzles also seemed less cohesive in this act.Like, I'd recommend it -- but it wasn't a religious video gaming experience or anything.SPOILERS FOLLOWMy biggest beef with this game is that there are all these unfortunate, sexist subtextual narratives that stem from a minigame in the first act: Shay has some kind of outrageous intuitive "mateworthy" radar that makes him, I don't know, uniquely capable of selecting the most appropriate women for procreating???  And then Malik or Malichi or whatever his name is in the second act is straight up implying that all the women sacrificed in the feast aren't MERELY BEING CAPTURED/DEVOURED, no, they are being used to provide genetic material to the super human race -- and then either exhausting their bodies to the point of death, or literally just being killed in the process of extracting the aforementioned genetic material.I cannot believe the epilogue implied everyone was supposed to have made peace after the end of the game.  Like, how else was anyone meant to interpret that?

content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												A beautiful point-and-click adventure game with imaginative locales, witty dialogue, and an engaging coming-of-age story of two youths whose paths collide in an astonishing cliffhanger for Act I of this game.The game is a visual marvel, and is further brought to life with top-notch voice acting. The puzzles are relatively easy, but will still require some more tinkering than say The Walking Dead. If you find yourself stumped with one character's path, you have the freedom of switching to the other, but it is recommended to finish Shay's story first before Vella's. While the game it has it's humourous moments, there is dark undercurrent, coupled with a gender critique that gives it a depth beyond merely being cute.All told, expect to complete Act I in roughly three hours, but with the richness of its atmosphere and detail, you may want to revisit the game to appreciate the interactions of its wonderful universe.

content:

												A wonderful homage to the traditional point-and-click adventure, yet in every way a modern game worthy of recognition in its own right.  The graphics are stunning, the voicework and music surreal, and the puzzles engaging.  A backer of the project myself, I have watched hours of film documenting the trials and tribulations the games' creators have gone through and yet none of that is a spoiler for this truly remarkable creation.  Hats off to Tim and the entire team at Double Fine Productions.  I strongly recommend this game to any fan of the genre, but more than that, to any person interested in discovering what gaming can be like when you put a story and some heart into it.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												This game is fun and charming! The musical soundtrack is fantastic (Melbourne Symphony Orchestra!), the art style is appealing.The interesting story element of this game is - you play as two different people from two totally different universes, and you wonder how on earth they can fit together and make one cohesive story.  It's a fun device.  It gives some Day-of-the-Tentacle-like freedom to switch around and try another character when you get stuck.The controls are quite simple, and to me this is a good thing.  There are no verbs to select from, you can either left click on a thing/person to interact with it, and you can drag things from your inventory onto things/people, and that's it - no trying "use thing, nope, push thing, nope, look at thing, nope, talk to thing, nope, pull thing...ah-ha!".  The interactable things on the screen have a large clickable area, and the cursor changes to a big ball-thing, so there is no pixel hunting - just run your mouse around once quickly, you find everything interactable very easily.The puzzles gradually get more difficult, and Act 2 has some particularly good brain teasers.  Now that both acts are released, the game length feels just right.This game is also suitable for children.Oh, and don't pay attention to all the downvotes on these reviews, I think they're mostly from some sad internet hate group who got upset about a joke Tim Schafer made, so this is how they get their revenge.  Pretty sad way to spend time eh?

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												Just got through act one as yesterday. I am a backer for the game and absolutely loved all the old lucas arts point and click adventure games. With that being said, I have not had enough time on my hands to watch many of the episodes they have posted on the documentry. However, I watched enough to have an idea of what the game was going to be like. As I played through my first thoughts were really how unique this game was as compared to some of the older games (i.e the monkey islands, day of the tentacle, etc...) in terms of the art work, the interactions between characters and items and everything seemed very thought out. But there is deffinetly a relatable feel to this game cooresponding with the older ones. I can tell by playing act one that alot of heart went in to this game and that for me was enough for five stars.However, there is much more than heart visible in this game so far. The moderetly challenging(with harder ones to come in following acts according to doublefine) puzzles give the game the classical point and click feel. However I found when trying to use items with multiple people, there would be unique and different dialoge for pretty much every person! This for me was a huge shift in the right direction! It adds that subtlety to the gameplay that I feel will be vital for the survival of future point and click adventure games. And if that was not enough for you, the plot(so far) is absolutely genious, in my opinion one of Tim Schafer's best! The twists and turns really bring you along for the ride, and you never feel bored or left out. So with the bar being set with the release of act one, I hope that the rest of the game can live up to the expectations. I hope to see more challenging puzzles, and can't wait to see how the story will develop. I hope and expect to see the rest of the game will leave me jaw dropped just as act one did! And to the all staff of doublefine on board with this project - Great job guys! This one really blew me away!!! I can't wait to see what adventures await our two protagonist in the story! This one, so far, is truly a stroke of genius! Keep up the fantastic work!!!!

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												Broken Age is the game that launched a thousand Kickstarters... well, not really as Kickstarter existed 3 years prior to but I digress.  The original Double Fine Adventure arguably brought Kickstarter into the mainstream light.  After suffering a series of delays and controversial pre-production images that questioned the infamous "3.3 million dollar" funding, how does the final product hold up?Very well.  Broken Age is a game of unrequited vision: a product designed by visionaries for a very specific audience.  The title of the game represents  adolescents, the titular "Broken Age" being the lives of the two protagonists who are caught in the pains of growing up.  Vella was groomed to be sacrificed to a monster and Shay lives his life aboard a ship run by a coddling AI.  Through a series of events the two characters break free from routine and challenge their place in life.  The result is a game that looks like a Little Golden Book and contains writing that's both light hearted and darkly comedic.People expecting a puzzle heavy logic adventure like the classic LucasArts days will be disappointed.  There's little challenge here and nothing is really taxing on the mind.  But like Telltale's recent titles, Broken Age's strength lies in its presentation.  It is all style, little substance, but the style is more than entertaining to make up for its shortcomings.  This is only part 1 of the game and runs 3 to 3 1/2 hours but the cliffhanger ending was enough to grab me for the second part instantly.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2015
												I've been following Tim Schafer since the first time I played Psychonauts, and I am always interested in his stuff.  So I picked this game up as soon as I heard it existed.When I played the first chapter of Broken Age, it seemed like it was setting up a lot of thematic elements and mysteries for the second part.  We've got two young people on the cusp of adulthood, questioning the way things have always been, being lied to their whole lives...  There are many different forces and people influencing the way they see the world, and they're finally breaking away and beginning to question those things.In an attempt to avoid spoiling much...  The second act kind of drops the ball on all those ideas.  It takes the thematic elements and makes them literal, and introduces concepts out of nowhere to explain preexisting plots and wrap up the story.  The puzzles also seemed less cohesive in this act.Like, I'd recommend it -- but it wasn't a religious video gaming experience or anything.SPOILERS FOLLOWMy biggest beef with this game is that there are all these unfortunate, sexist subtextual narratives that stem from a minigame in the first act: Shay has some kind of outrageous intuitive "mateworthy" radar that makes him, I don't know, uniquely capable of selecting the most appropriate women for procreating???  And then Malik or Malichi or whatever his name is in the second act is straight up implying that all the women sacrificed in the feast aren't MERELY BEING CAPTURED/DEVOURED, no, they are being used to provide genetic material to the super human race -- and then either exhausting their bodies to the point of death, or literally just being killed in the process of extracting the aforementioned genetic material.I cannot believe the epilogue implied everyone was supposed to have made peace after the end of the game.  Like, how else was anyone meant to interpret that?

content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												I've had mixed feelings for this game when the first part came out. I didn't like the "coming of age" story concept (not my issues anymore), I didn't like the setting (childish fantasy-world), the dialogue wasn't all that witty/funny, and the puzzles were simplistic. HOWEVER, as the hours trickled by, I slowly came to like that game. It was the little details that reminded me of Tim Schafer's previous games.Then came the awesome end of Act I, and then Act II is pure awesomeness. The puzzles were multi-layered and fun, the characters were developed some more, and the game felt like it should have been like this from the start. So ultimately, I had a great time.I would also like to praise the custom interface for all the different puzzles - this was done really well, much better than in many of the old adventure games, where this was always the biggest problem (fighting the monster in Grim Fandango or racing in Full Throttle).

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												I wanted to like Broken Age, I really did. The first half of the game, released all the way back in January 2014, is absolutely incredible. Sure, the puzzles were a tad easy at times, but I'd rather have that than the ridiculously obtuse "adventure game logic" based puzzles that the genre had been plagued with. For me at least, point and click adventure games have always been about telling a story. And the story of Broken Age Act I was absolutely brimming with promise. It took on universal coming of age themes in a clever, lighthearted way, with a quirky cast of characters and a healthy dose of humor to round out the mix.Unfortunately, it was too good to last. Act II, released in April 2015, fell short in almost every area Act I had previously succeeded in. The art and music remained as good as ever, but the story became a cliche ridden mess that abandoned many of the first act's thematic elements in favor of a much simpler resolution. The puzzle quality took a massive hit as well. Adventure game logic is back in full force here, locking the (increasingly disappointing) story progression behind a gauntlet of infuriating mind-twisters. I'm not terribly good at adventure games, so I often find myself having to consult walkthroughs even for well designed ones. However, I can tell when my inability to solve a puzzle is due to my own shortcomings (as was the case with much of Gemini Rue, for example), and when the puzzle itself is just plain stupid (as was the case with Broken Age Act II).I've seen a lot of stories, across many mediums, that fall short of their original promise in the later acts. However, Broken Age takes that to an absolutely mind-boggling level. It went from one of the best games I'd ever played to one of the worst just past the halfway point. If you're curious about the premise, picking it up on sale might be worth it just for the amazing first act. However, under no circumstances should you pay full price for what is ultimately a huge letdown.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												Broken Age mixes a wonderful story of two perfect strangers chosen to fulfill a great destiny with beautiful hand-painted aesthetics to create one of the best graphic adventures of all time.Divided in two acts (one which came out February 2014, the other April 2015) you control both characters in different environments, having the ability to switch between them at any given time. Sometimes, the actions from one affect the other, which makes some of the puzzles hard and compelling.The story itself is amazing, one the best I've ever seen. Combining sci-fi with fantasy, finally creating one of the best atmospheres you could imagine for this kind of game.Totally recommended.___________________________________Original reviewPosted: 20 Feb, 2014 @ 7:38pm"Broken Age's only flaw is being episodic. Well, not even a flaw. I mean, I just want to play the rest of it NOW!Hand painted graphics, wonderful performance, perfect gameplay, compelling story, and top-notch voice acting. What else do you want in a videogame?A prime example of how Double Fine excels at videogame making, and how a really good graphic adventure is done. I can't wait for the rest of it to get released!If you like having cliffhangers and enjoy the wait, you should get it now, if not then wait for the rest of the episodes and then get it. It's a superb graphic adventure, and a magnificent piece of art in every sense, in graphics, story, screenwriting, voice acting and gameplay mechanics."

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												Broken Age is a modern adventure game with throwbacks to the past and - at least for me - an ideal fusion of both worlds. Background: I'm not a backer, so the game didn't have to live up to a specific promise for me. I used to play adventure games back in the 90ies. I waited until Act 2 was out, before I started playing Act 1&2.There's so much to love. The art style is amazing, charming, well thought out and manages to create a whole real world, partly made out of yarn. Yay! The character design and animations are great. The puzzles in Act 1 are easy enough to welcome newcomers to the genre and quickly ramp up in Act 2 to provide a real challenge and with that a real feeling of accomplishment upon solving them. There are always hints to be found. The writing is brightly witty. The voice acting is top of the line. The "plot twist" at the end of Act 1 genuinely surprised me and had me uttering "what the f..." maybe 10+ times out loud in a row. Well done.I really liked the transition into Act 2: the character reveals, the expansion of the world and the fact that you had to solve puzzles with things introduced in Act 1. I felt even more at home in Act 2: switching between the characters felt like switching between the characters in Zak McKracken, constructing the tree joke reminded me of the Monkey Island swordmaster insults. I didn't miss the verb interface at all.The only complaint I have is, that you can't load straight from a running game, you have to save+exit to the main menu first. That's it.I'd strongly recommend Broken Age to everyone interested in puzzles, art or humor. It's a monument for what can be achieved with love, talent and dedication.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
												Y'know, Act 1 is extremely enjoyable with a lot of great world building and character development. It sets itself apart as a story with how much of it you do not expect and the kinds of interactions. Vella's character is a necessary one for modern story telling in gaming, often going almost over the top with how independently driven she is. In her torn pink dress and over sized cloud shoes, she's perfectly iconic. And a girl with a back ground that on a few occasions implies that her (because of family and community) only skill is baking, that is so incredible to have still be the most warrior like character in the whole game.And don't get me wrong, Act 2 was fun and adventurous in the same way, (Shay finally connecting with actual people for the first time in his life and getting to know his family and doing some good, that was great) but I couldn't get through this damn thing without a walk through. SEVERAL walk throughs. Several text anD VIDEO WALK THROUGHS. It was difficult in places that did not need to be difficult. The difficulty in telling a talking tree a joke was set to high. I finished Act 1 in about four hours and Act 2 took twice that.WHY DID THE WIRE PUZZLES HAVE TO BE RANDOMIZED. IT TOOK FIVE GOOGLE SEARCHES TO FIND THAT OUT. IT WAS A PUZZLE ON ITS OWN, GOOD LORD.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
												People complained that the first act was too easy. Now they complain that the second act is too hard, There is no pleasing some people. Complaints that the puzzle in the second act can not be solved without random trial and error are largely false. Being observant (like you are supposed to be in these types of games) is enough to deduce the puzzles. However, you will need to switch between Shay and Vella. If you are stuck on one puzzle, change character and move on. Clues for Shay can be found in Vella's story and clues for Vella can be found in Shay's story.All in all this is a fun, funny, challenging game which is visually stunning and has a great story.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
												The first act of Broken Age is very amazing. A AAA level quality of animation, funny jokes, amazing voice acting, and the most important aspect, the Story, was full of explorations, mysteries, and imagination. You'll keep wondering what happen, why it happen, and what will happen.The second act however, is not as good as the first act. IMO, it's just lazy. You'll just re-exploring the places that you have explored in Act I, and for an adventure game, re-exploring is not fun. Though it still have the same quality of animation, jokes, and voice acting. The story is also a bit lacking, the great thing about act I, is that it makes player keep asking question throughout the game. Unfortunately, in Act II, the important mysteries already solved in the beginning of the game, and the remaining mysteries are remain unsolved until the end.But still, with all the disappointing elements in Act II, Broken Age is still an amazing game. The animation, jokes, and storytelling are something that should not be missed. Just think of it as a great game and it's not-so-good sequel compiled as one.

You won't be totally gobsmacked or anything, but they're nice to look at.Sounds are fun too, the poppy soundtrack and voice acting is spot on.Story is interesting so far, we will have to see when Act 2 comes out.Unfortunately, as pretty as this game is, I can't recommend it just yet, as it's basically half a game for way too steep a price.tldr; Game Quality 8/10Value for Money 1/10 (Regular Price)

												I really wanted to recommend this game. The writing is great, the general idea is inventive, and it just feels genuine. That said, I cannot recommend this game due to the puzzles. Now, I may be a dolt, but usually after I trudge my way through a puzzle that should not be as difficult as I made it, I understand this and say "Wow I can't believe I didn't see that." This game doesn't give you that feeling on more than just a few occasions. Complexity and difficulty are good things, but incoherence is not and I would guess that even the smartest puzzle people spent hours with trial and error at certain points or used a guide. It's sad to see this in a game that might otherwise shine, and what would have been a memorable story with likeable characters becomes obscurred by drawn-out frustration and hindering gameplay.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												Short Answer:  This game isn't so much "bad" as it is disappointing.  Starts amazingly strong in Act 1, but clearly something went wrong during Act 2's development.  Only buy this game if it's on sale for a maximum of $10.  I'd wait for $7 or $8.Long Answer:  Act 1 was great, amazing even.  The art is wonderful, the story is compelling, the voice acting is great, and the puzzles are interesting.  The game allows you to switch between the apparently-unrelated stories of protagonists Vella and Shay and both have their own mysteries to explore, and puzzles to solve.  The puzzles in Act 1 are great too!  The majority of the puzzles aren't too difficult to solve without help, or too easy to be interesting.  There are a few that aren't as great, but most are pretty good.  The story leaves you feeling like you've completed something, while also leaving you with a cliff-hanger that will bring you back for Act 2Act 2 fails in most of these respects miserably.  The art and voice acting are still up to par, but the rest was disappointing.  The puzzles are mostly impossible-to-guess non sequiturs, which can't even be solved by clicking on everything with everything else like you did in the old adventure game days.  In fact, quite a lot of the puzzles can only be solved by telepathy.  By which I mean Shay and Vella must have a telepathic link because information only available in Vella's story is needed to progress through Shay's, and vice versa.  The rest of the puzzles can only be solved by internet walkthroughs because the logic is so insane.  The story makes about as much sense as the puzzles, and is never really finished by the end of the game.  Act 2 is so out of sync with Act 1 that I can only guess it was either made by totally different people, or something horrible happened during its development.I'd still buy this game just because Act 1 is so strong.  But I'd recommend only getting it at a really deep discount.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												Broken Age is without a doubt one of the best point'n'clicks of the last few years. As I mostly liked it, let's focus on what's wrong with it.I'm not a fan of the character design. Those faces, noses especially.There are some sloppily cropped parts of the foreground - artifacts are visible against the backgrounds.Some animations are lacking.There's a lot of backtracking and after the first act you've pretty much seen all areas the game lets you explore. For the rest of the game you'll be walking around them again and again, just with the characters swapped.There are some inconsistencies in the story.The game feels rushed, especially the ending.If they could've just taken the quality from the best parts of the game and keep it throughout the whole thing, Broken Age would not only be one of the best point'n'clicks of the last few years, as mentioned before, but also one of the best adventure games ever created.Overall, objectively 8/10.

I enjoyed it a lot and think this game might be a future classic.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												(Disclosure: I was an early backer, and patiently waited through the delays and whatnot because these things take time and that's fine by me, so this review - I hope - isn't based on the Kickstarter campaign or the game delivery, just the content and gameplay). I wish I could recommend this game but I really can't at this point. Act 1 was fairly well executed, if simple and relatively short, and it set up a lot of potentially interesting events in Act 2. The overall idea of two playable characters in parallel but interconnected story lines is interesting as well, as is the world they occupy. It's not a "classic" point and click. It's a more modern take on the genre - high quality art, more snazz, quality audio and voice acting - and clearly shows where the money raised has been spent.Sadly, there are some minor gameplay issues and major plot and puzzle issues that make playing through the game difficult once you get into the 2nd Act.   Gameplay:  - You can't skip through lines of dialogue like in most adventure games today; you can only skip the entire "cut scene," which is a pain when the puzzles are designed with some repetition necessary (e.g. trial and error)- Primordia for example, had a map system to help you quickly navigate the various areas of the game that you'd already been to; Broken Age lacked this Plot and Puzzle: - There are some major plot gaps that remain unexplained / unresolved. Here are a few:*  Why didn't Shay's parent look anything like the "bad" Lorunians? *  How come it took Shay and his folks 14 years to get to Sugar Bunting, but in Act 2 it took everyone (even Alex's much older ship) like 10 minutes to get back to Loruna?? *  If Vella's grandmother was responsible for Steel Bunting turning into Sugar Bunting, was she also responsible for Shellmound and Meriloft turning soft? How?! *  I doubt there will be a sequel, so what happens now that everyone is stranded just outside Loruna? The "bad guys" aren't even necessarily dead, so what happens next? Nothing is resolved satisfactorily, it's not even a cliffhanger! - Even if you've not played point-and-click games before, you'll find Act 1 puzzles reasonably straightforward. Act 2 puzzles on the other hand suddenly become mindboggling and tedious - not challenging or clever or layered or any other word that indicates an increase in difficulty or complexity, as you'd hope for and even expect in an adventure game. There - The puzzles in Act 2 advance the plot tangentially, relying on some tedious and repetitive puzzling based on characters -  Hexipals  - that are largely unimportant to the main plotline. The  wiring  puzzles aren't even applied cleverly, relying on Vella and Shay to  magically learn what the solution is through the observations of the player.  That's ridiculous, and I've played the Monkey Island games. The result is that the player gets frustrated, sucked out of an already problematic story, and left to engage in trial and error puzzles that are situationally unrealistic. So? Doublefine have done a reasonably good job here, but have created a form of storybook point and click adventure game with a thin and curtailed moral/philosophical veneer, a plot with holes that become increasingly difficult to ignore, an ending that screams budget/time constraints and a sense that this game could have been a lot to a few rather than a little to many.  Don't buy this game.  Go and spend your money on some of the classic Lucasarts games, or better yet, on modern developers like Wadjet Eye or Daedelic, who are carrying the torch of adventure gaming in a way that I imagine (and hope) Schafer would be proud of. While not as charming, their games are polished, narrative-driven, clever and importantly, labours of love. If Broken Age was half as fun as Stacked, I'd gladly recommend it, but it isn't even. Shame really. Sorry Doublefine.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												This game was a piece of art and was very beautiful to play. The gameplay itself was simple point-and-click but numerous puzzles were rather tedious and challenging. I enjoyed the story and even though many have pointed out Act II was a let down in comparison to Act I, I do still believe it was engaging till the end. Sure Act II did fall in terms of quality of story and perhaps, the puzzles were more meticulous and repetitive than Act I, but i still remained immersed in the world of the characters.Characters had quirkiness and unique personalities, adding humour and warmth to the feel of the game (especially the adorable robots, such as Gary and the Hexipals/gals!). Only drawback was the repetitiveness and tediousness of a few puzzles and the ending wasn’t completely satisfying hence the captivating story was underdeveloped. Although overall, I would recommend this game, especially if you’re a fan of beautifully designed graphics, light-hearted but thought-provoking gameplay and an interesting story. Full price may be a bit steep but if on sale, it is worth the buy.Rating~Gameplay: 7/10Story: 7/10Graphics: 9/10Characters: 9/10

content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
 DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine Broken Age is an adventure game developed by the wonderful people behind Stacking, Brutal Legend, Costume Quest, and Grim Fandango: Remastered. Double Fine Producitons once again hits the nail again with their cleverly designed and well thought out gameBroken Age is a point-and-click adventure game where you play two young people from different cultures and places experience their own adventures until secrets are revealed that bring them closer together. Broken Age follows traditional point-and-click adventure games where basically you have to click everywhere until you happen to find something that continues the storyThe story is very well written, although the ending does end abruptly and must of dissapointed a lot of people, I cannot blame them, the ending felt too rushed to satisfy me as an ending. The voice acting is really good, some well known actors and actresses lend thier voices to the game, such as Elijah Wood (from the Lord of the Rings Trilogy) and many othersThe game's graphics are really cute and well designed as well as the music is really well done which reminds me of Disney classics. Broken Age has good things but has bad things, the game overall is very good however the bad things are the puzzles, the puzzles are not that bad but the last few puzzles are so confusing it took me roughly 45 minutes-1 hour to solve some of the puzzles...Overall, Broken Age is a wonderful point-and-click adventure game which you will enjoy the fantastic graphics, story and music, even though the game does have some of its flaws RECOMMENDED :)

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												I was leery of buying Broken Age.I was one of the people who didn't know Kickstarter existed when the Double Fine Adventure got kicked off, and cursed myself for my inability to donate at a later date.  But then I heard about Tim Schafer's "Oops, I accidentally made the game too big out of excitement" and the resulting decision to release the game in two parts.I was leery of buying such a Broken Age, broken into pieces.  But I bought it anyway because I believed in the man behind the Age.And I was right to do so.I will only touch upon the beauty of the designs and the watercolor style artwork.  How it transforms the world into a living, breathing, stylistic entity that adds to the gravity and majesty of the game.  You can see that just from the advertising previews.I will only offhandedly mention the beautiful music, and how it aids in captivating the strange and enchanting art, holding your attention and increasing your desire to see what's over on the next screen.I will speak about the voice cast.  About how Curtis (Wil Wheaton) just made my day, and Shay's (Elijah Wood) desperately struggling morality trying to escape it's infancy made me really, really care.  About how the entire cast is Grade-A and there is not a sour note amongst them I could even try to harp upon.I will talk about the length of Part 1.  It is short... but it is just right.  There was no filler in it, and it felt like Shay's story was shorter than Vella's, but neither side of the adventure had any spam in it.  No filler to make you sigh in boredom of somethign that should not be there.  Every bit of the game was something to be important, either in setting the tone or setting of the characters or the world.  Nothing too much, and it delivers you to...The Twist.There is a reason that Tim Schafer chose to end Part 1 right where he did, because there is no better spot to end Part 1.  The Twist changed my entire perspective on EVERYTHING.  And I will have to play the game again in reverse order to make sure I understand it this time for it's true self.  Just like Fight Club, you have to see it at least twice to really get it.And the time from now until the release of Part 2...  Let that Twist stew in your gut.  let it capture your imagination and leave you asking, How and Why.  All in preparation for Part 2.Part 1 was just the closing of the First Act in terms of the laws of writing.  The Second and Third Act are yet to come.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												Broken Age is absolutley FANTASTIC.  Its so good in fact that I would rank it as my second favorite thing Tim Schafer has ever done behind Psychonauts, THAT is no small feat.  It has all the hallmarks of Schafer's greatest works: amazing cast of characters, perfect exceptional voice acting, challenging and hilarious puzzles/gameplay, excellent Peter McConnell soundtrack, incredibly written script, its all here and its awesome.  The real star of the show, though, is its story; the story here may be simple but its one of the best and most original plots I've EVER heard in a video game, built around 2 seperate plot threads that seem completely unrelated until a few plot twists mid-way through.  This two-story structure also plays into the gameplay, where you switch between the two main characters in order to complete the grander whole of the game.  There are also a few streamlined features that help speed up some traditions of the point-and-click genre that have long needed an overhaul.That said, as is the case with ALL point-and-click adventures, it has a few niggling problems.  For the record any PAC game that has time-based puzzles never fails to frustrate me; there are times where you will be on the correct train of thought for solving a problem, but still fail because you didnt click in the right timing.  This doesnt sound like a big deal, but when you do fail this can cause you to try seeking other ways of completing the puzzle and waste a ton of time in the process.  There are other logic issues with some of the puzzles, but overall I think the difficulty was perfect for this genre, and overall I only needed to get help under 10 times in a lengthy adventure.All in all if you are a fan of Double Fine, Schafer, or a point-and-click fan in general you absolutely MUST play Broken Age.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												I have had this game in my library for quite a while, but for various reasons I set Broken Age aside for another time. With the release of the Double Fine Adventure on Steam it was time to properly play the game.The art, animation, music and voice acting are all really great. This certainly meets my expectations of what a modern adventure game should look and sound like. The user interface is nice and minimal, as one would expect from a modern game. I quite liked the writing too. Some of the characters are very funny, and there is plenty to laugh at. The main plot points had unfortunately already been spoilt to me by careless reviewers. Fortunately the story itself is actully quite a lot better than some reviews would have you believe. I don't have any problems with the ending myself. Everything is tied up neatly in the end credits.The puzzles are perhaps the weak point of Broken Age and were certaily a source of frustration for me. I was stuck at a few points in the game and had to look at walkthoughs to progress. Looking back I think I could have solved most of them myself if I had picked up on all the hints or not overlooked an item here or there. The python comes to mind. I was also not a fan of some of the puzzles later in the game that required memorizing things or writing them down. I prefer the game to do any note keeping for me. Also, I would have liked to see more interaction between Shay and Vella. The final set of puzzles would have made more sense if the two protagonists had been in communication with eachother or if there was  an exchange of items or influence on eachothers environments.But was Broken Age worse than the classic adventure games that inspired it? Are its leaps of logic so much more outlandish than Monkey Island or Day of the Tentacle? I personally think not. I played the old Lucasarts games back when they came out, and it's easy to overlook their problems though the rose tinted glasses of nostaligia. For me, Broken Age rekindled some of those fond gaming memories and I had fun playing this game through to the end.So in summary:+ Art, animation, music, voice acting, writing, humor, plot- Some of the puzzles, not enough interaction between the main charactersRecommendation: Very much worth the price, even more so when at a discountBeing able to watch the making of the game in between gaming sessions was quite enlightening. I strongly recommend you watch the documentary too if you buy this game.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
												Ok first the technical stuff: AMD Phenom 4 Cores 2.7 GHz, 6GB of DDR2 ram, radeon hd 7970 3GB.GNU/Linux fedora rawhide with the radeon open source driver (Yeay!)In 2560x1600 the game cannot run smoothly (all game are calibrated for 1920x1080 nowadays...). There is something which seems weird with the resolution/fullscreen  on gnu/Linux. Anyway, I played it "not fullscreen", and it was fine.I would have felt the game a bit too empty for the full price (I got it cheaper thanks to sales). I think they used the kickstarter money to ramp up the first iteration of their game engine for the next games. Basically, we can expect a much more dense and rich act2 and follow up games. Nevertheless, I think it's hard to make a rich point-and-click game with real voices, coz tons of phrases to record, and creating interesting and rich puzzles with that many original graphics, well... tons of more work due to the combinations.On the overall I liked the journeys offered by this game from all perspectives, namely graphics, sound and music and most of the puzzles. Personally, this "dual" journey is quite new and refreshing for me.Again from a technical/legal point of view, they should use an open source game engine (protected with a GNU Lesser GPL license) and build their game on it (maybe they used the scumvm engine!).

												Aesthetically brilliant, with a charming story told through witty and defined characters. number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2014
												Broken Age makes me excited for adventure games again.Intuitive puzzles, clever and funny dialogue, and all brought to life with incredible graphics which make the game look more like a living cartoon than a game, Broken Age is easily one of the best modern adventure games out there.You play the game alternating between two lead characters, each with his and her own unique situation from which they're anxious to escape. I won't spoil anything here - I'll just say that both characters have an interesting story, and you won't be bored with either or them. Control is simple adventure game stuff, so if you've ever played a point-and-click game (or even if you haven't) you won't have any difficulty here.My only complaint so far is that when you get a game series off to such a good start, the wait between episodes is going to be tough. What's here now though is worth your time and money, and I highly recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												Broken Age is an amazing point and click experience, reminescent of Steven Spielburg's The Dig in a light-hearted setting. The art stlye and some of its antics remind me of Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker,The story touches on various enlightened understandings about life, and its quite meta; of itself and reality in general. There's quite a few gags and clever lines, and one in particular (a Terminator reference of all things) made me tear up and laugh at the same time.It doesn't really go very far with the story, it doesn't aim to be the most riveting and jaw dropping storytelling experience ever. Still, its a perfect example of when the games medium does story telling well. Broken Age never goes overboard, but there's a lot to ponder about the philosophical meaning of different elements throughout. Its kind of light or deep as you want it to go, I think.Its a little hard to review a game that's just a storyline with some secondary interactive elements without spoiling anything. I'll just say, the sound and voice acting are flawless throughout. The story is captivating as anything you'll find  in modern media. It has a good length. Its difficult to figure out what to do at a few parts, but its not ever bad enough to actually warrant using a game guide. The character swapping mechanic sees some token use to aid advancement, but I think over-use of that feature might make gameplay too novel.If you like games like Monkey Island, The Dig, or just a good, mild storyline, I'd definitely recommend Broken Age.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												Broken Age is absolutley FANTASTIC.  Its so good in fact that I would rank it as my second favorite thing Tim Schafer has ever done behind Psychonauts, THAT is no small feat.  It has all the hallmarks of Schafer's greatest works: amazing cast of characters, perfect exceptional voice acting, challenging and hilarious puzzles/gameplay, excellent Peter McConnell soundtrack, incredibly written script, its all here and its awesome.  The real star of the show, though, is its story; the story here may be simple but its one of the best and most original plots I've EVER heard in a video game, built around 2 seperate plot threads that seem completely unrelated until a few plot twists mid-way through.  This two-story structure also plays into the gameplay, where you switch between the two main characters in order to complete the grander whole of the game.  There are also a few streamlined features that help speed up some traditions of the point-and-click genre that have long needed an overhaul.That said, as is the case with ALL point-and-click adventures, it has a few niggling problems.  For the record any PAC game that has time-based puzzles never fails to frustrate me; there are times where you will be on the correct train of thought for solving a problem, but still fail because you didnt click in the right timing.  This doesnt sound like a big deal, but when you do fail this can cause you to try seeking other ways of completing the puzzle and waste a ton of time in the process.  There are other logic issues with some of the puzzles, but overall I think the difficulty was perfect for this genre, and overall I only needed to get help under 10 times in a lengthy adventure.All in all if you are a fan of Double Fine, Schafer, or a point-and-click fan in general you absolutely MUST play Broken Age.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												I have had this game in my library for quite a while, but for various reasons I set Broken Age aside for another time. With the release of the Double Fine Adventure on Steam it was time to properly play the game.The art, animation, music and voice acting are all really great. This certainly meets my expectations of what a modern adventure game should look and sound like. The user interface is nice and minimal, as one would expect from a modern game. I quite liked the writing too. Some of the characters are very funny, and there is plenty to laugh at. The main plot points had unfortunately already been spoilt to me by careless reviewers. Fortunately the story itself is actully quite a lot better than some reviews would have you believe. I don't have any problems with the ending myself. Everything is tied up neatly in the end credits.The puzzles are perhaps the weak point of Broken Age and were certaily a source of frustration for me. I was stuck at a few points in the game and had to look at walkthoughs to progress. Looking back I think I could have solved most of them myself if I had picked up on all the hints or not overlooked an item here or there. The python comes to mind. I was also not a fan of some of the puzzles later in the game that required memorizing things or writing them down. I prefer the game to do any note keeping for me. Also, I would have liked to see more interaction between Shay and Vella. The final set of puzzles would have made more sense if the two protagonists had been in communication with eachother or if there was  an exchange of items or influence on eachothers environments.But was Broken Age worse than the classic adventure games that inspired it? Are its leaps of logic so much more outlandish than Monkey Island or Day of the Tentacle? I personally think not. I played the old Lucasarts games back when they came out, and it's easy to overlook their problems though the rose tinted glasses of nostaligia. For me, Broken Age rekindled some of those fond gaming memories and I had fun playing this game through to the end.So in summary:+ Art, animation, music, voice acting, writing, humor, plot- Some of the puzzles, not enough interaction between the main charactersRecommendation: Very much worth the price, even more so when at a discountBeing able to watch the making of the game in between gaming sessions was quite enlightening. I strongly recommend you watch the documentary too if you buy this game.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												Broken Age provided an approximation of the Lucas Arts games from yesteryear, but only that.The high points broght me back to a time of simpler graphics and collecting items to combine together in silly ways. The dialog is spot on while remaining light, overall. I enjoyed the art style while it remained unusual throughout. The functionality both with mouse and controller work out well. All the voicing is done well, though I feel that Jack Black was an underused voice in the game.The two main parts of a point and click are the puzzles and the story.The puzzles are a mixed bag. Some of them were quite straight forward and logical in the "adventure game logic" that you would expect. Others might involve a clever use of the environment that isn't quite as obvious. But then, there are those that are generally just try until you get it right. I'm very much not a fan of puzzles that the only real way to solve them is to try to solve them enough times to find the information to essentially use a solution that is written in the game. I don't feel like I actually thought through that; I feel I just threw things at a wall until I could use a written solution. And the worst (though there is only one) is a puzzle solved by waiting. That is the worst.The story is again a mixed bag. The end of act 1 was definitely a high point with a twist I at least didn't see coming. Unfotunately, there is enough other things that don't exactly get well explained to leave you with a good sense of closure. The ending I find frustratingly vague (said as someone who actually likes endings to not always be perfectly wrapped up - this ending more felt like you just solved the puzzle with the grandest music so the game is over).In the end, though, I am glad to have played it and would love for there to be more point and click games of this level being made though possibly with a better structure to the game budget so it can end as high as it started.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
Really great game! Wholeheartedly recommended.9,5/10+ fun point-and-click adventure, challenging but fair puzzles+ beautiful artwork/design+ minimalist facial expressions with maximum effect (in comparison: Dreamfall Chapters, a current story rich 3D game that I also love is disappointing me in its somewhat limited mimic range. Broke Age however delighted me with how tiny changes in the 2D characters make a huge difference. Maybe I'm projecting though...)+you can switch between the two characters (almost) whenever you like+ lovely, funny, quirky characters+ great voice acting (I started it in German which I enjoyed too, and switched over once I learned that Wil Wheaton does one of the voices)(only only the high-pitched voices of the knitted friends could get annoying after a while)+ two worlds, each beautiful and interesting and quirky in their own way+ great plot twist; story gets even more intriguing afterwards+ THE NAV SCARF! THE HEXAPALS!! :D (some of many adorable side characters)+ THE TALKING CUTLERY with hilarious personalities and comments when used with other items- (a MINOR problem) you can't always run (only when your starting point is in the very distance), so... lots of walking. Yeah I'm pretty sure that was my only drawback in the game. ^^ It was very nearly perfect! :)

												Broken Age provided an approximation of the Lucas Arts games from yesteryear, but only that.The high points broght me back to a time of simpler graphics and collecting items to combine together in silly ways. The dialog is spot on while remaining light, overall. I enjoyed the art style while it remained unusual throughout. The functionality both with mouse and controller work out well. All the voicing is done well, though I feel that Jack Black was an underused voice in the game.The two main parts of a point and click are the puzzles and the story.The puzzles are a mixed bag. Some of them were quite straight forward and logical in the "adventure game logic" that you would expect. Others might involve a clever use of the environment that isn't quite as obvious. But then, there are those that are generally just try until you get it right. I'm very much not a fan of puzzles that the only real way to solve them is to try to solve them enough times to find the information to essentially use a solution that is written in the game. I don't feel like I actually thought through that; I feel I just threw things at a wall until I could use a written solution. And the worst (though there is only one) is a puzzle solved by waiting. That is the worst.The story is again a mixed bag. The end of act 1 was definitely a high point with a twist I at least didn't see coming. Unfotunately, there is enough other things that don't exactly get well explained to leave you with a good sense of closure. The ending I find frustratingly vague (said as someone who actually likes endings to not always be perfectly wrapped up - this ending more felt like you just solved the puzzle with the grandest music so the game is over).In the end, though, I am glad to have played it and would love for there to be more point and click games of this level being made though possibly with a better structure to the game budget so it can end as high as it started.

Really great game! Wholeheartedly recommended.9,5/10+ fun point-and-click adventure, challenging but fair puzzles+ beautiful artwork/design+ minimalist facial expressions with maximum effect (in comparison: Dreamfall Chapters, a current story rich 3D game that I also love is disappointing me in its somewhat limited mimic range. Broke Age however delighted me with how tiny changes in the 2D characters make a huge difference. Maybe I'm projecting though...)+you can switch between the two characters (almost) whenever you like+ lovely, funny, quirky characters+ great voice acting (I started it in German which I enjoyed too, and switched over once I learned that Wil Wheaton does one of the voices)(only only the high-pitched voices of the knitted friends could get annoying after a while)+ two worlds, each beautiful and interesting and quirky in their own way+ great plot twist; story gets even more intriguing afterwards+ THE NAV SCARF! THE HEXAPALS!! :D (some of many adorable side characters)+ THE TALKING CUTLERY with hilarious personalities and comments when used with other items- (a MINOR problem) you can't always run (only when your starting point is in the very distance), so... lots of walking. Yeah I'm pretty sure that was my only drawback in the game. ^^ It was very nearly perfect! :)

												This game isn't flawless. I'll get the cons out of the way first:-The game suffers from one of my pet peeves in point and click games, the character "magically" knows which items it can or can't interact with and which items will save a purpouse later on. if you can click on something and pick it up, your character's not gonna dare part with it until it eventually needs to use it for something.-There is a part in the second half of the game where the two characters need to perform actions based on the other characters' knowledge, even though there is no interaction between them. You can write this off as them acting on instinct or guessing, but... It probably could've been written better.Pros:-Y'know, I could honestly care less about this game's gameplay faults because at it's core, it's a story. You're here for the plot, for the characters, and for the worldbuilding. And it excels at those. It's a truly good story, which is occasionaly paused when you hit a puzzle that you have a hard time solving.-There are also stuff I liked about the gameplay, but as I said, this game should be played mostly for the story it tells and the world it takes place in.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												Full review: http://www.cublikefoot.com/review/broken-age-act-1-game-review/This is a review of ACT 1 of Broken Age, act 2 is currently unreleased.Broken Age - Act 1, an excellent point-and-click adventure. This is coming from someone who usually avoids the genre. I don't know how, but Double Fine somehow kept me entertained whilst playing their latest adventure. I despise point-and-click games, but this, this was a treat.Broken Age's existence is entirely due to the success of Double Fine's "Double Fine Adventure" Kickstarter, which in my opinion, is the reason why Kickstarter is so popular today. The game's credits list all of the backers, all of them. It took quite some time for all of those credits to roll.The game employs a colorful, stylized world, all in 2D. The art is fantastic, retaining that signature Double Fine feel to it. The music was also great, combining well with the game's overall style.The game's story however, is what I enjoyed most. The story is what probably kept me playing. Normally, I wouldn't even play a point-and-click game, and if I did, then I'd quit it within say.. 30 minutes? With Broken Age however, I never felt bored and the puzzles didn't keep me stumped as long as I would have expected from a game in the genre. Actually, I would have preferred the puzzles to be a bit harder. Most of them were rather straight-forward and easily solved. I may have gotten stumped once or twice, but I felt like they could have been a lot more challenging while retaining my attention.The story is broken into two parts: Shay's and Vella's adventures. Two entirely different characters that the player can switch to and from at any given moment. I found myself going through with Shay's quest first, rather than Vella's. I enjoyed Shay's story more than Vella's, but I played through the whole game wanting to know if the stories connected somehow, possibly one of the reasons why I found this game so enjoyable. The constant desire to see how the stories connect, or if they do at all.Voice acting in the game is incredible, well, aside from one character. It felt like Vella's voice was... off. It just sounded out of place. That may just be me, but it constantly bugged me throughout her journey. All of the other voice acting is simply amazing, no complaints there.All good things said, Broken Age does not bring anything new to the table. This may be disappointing for some, but I certainly overlooked this fault purely out of interest for the game's story. Although I may dislike point-and-click games, I've played quite a few of them in my time, and Broken Age doesn't seem to differ from them, aside from the art style. Broken Age was actually much easier than a few of the point-and-click game's I've played, because, as I said, the puzzles are rather straight-forward.There are many reasons for me to recommend Broken Age. I urge you to try it out for yourself. I certainly can't wait for the next act in the series.
