number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
												Act 1:The first hour of the game is pretty terrible, as there are no puzzles and hardly any user interaction, you are basically clicking your way through a cartoon and not a good one, as there is a ton of repetition. It does get better later on as the game opens up and you are allowed to run around on your own, but it still never quite captures what made the classical LucasArts adventure great.In terms of interface it feels disappointing and like a step backward for the genre. You don't have a dialogue-skip button and can only skip full cutscenes, that makes it far to easy to skip over important content. And the lack of a dedicated view-action means you aren't allowed to inspect the environment properly. There isn't a hotspot-highlight button either. All of that have been standard parts of most modern point&click games.Graphically the game is ok, but just barely so. The sprites all look really flat and cheaply animated (i.e. what you expect from Flash animation) and the backgrounds show some ugly pixelation when the camera zooms in. On the plus side the game does a lot of camera motion to keep things interesting and it has quite a few custom animation.All that said, I did start having fun with the game before the end. As once the game opens up and you get a little more familiar with the characters and the overall situation it starts to feel more like a proper point&click game. If they can improve a little on that this might turn on into a really good adventure game. But compared to all the stuff Daedalic has put out this just doesn't really look all that impressive and as a callback to the classic days it kind of fails, as it feels to watered down and artsy for it's own good. It's still good enough to recommend it, just don't expect a worthy successor to the LucasArts adventures.Act 2:Continues exactly where the first one left off. There are no updates to the interface, graphics or anything. Puzzles are this time a little harder then before, but not in a good way. There is a lot of walking forward and backward through scenes and it can be easy to miss a critical clue. The game is also filled with time based puzzles and puzzles that require correct setup or else they reset, this leads to a lot of repetition and frustration due to the lack of proper dialogue skip. Good inventory based puzzles don't really exist and the game doesn't really do much with the character switching either. You can play each character almost completely separate from the other and outside the very last sequence they never interact.As far as setting is concerned, act 2 reuses most locations from act 1 with some small changes. There is very little new happening here and the story reveal feels pretty "meh", as it doesn't really open up any new areas or anything. The whole mythology of that world feels pretty underdeveloped and not really explained enough. The ending feels like there would be an Act 3 to follow that plugs those holes, but there isn't one.Overall this isn't a horrible adventure by any means and it has it's moments, but it's pretty mediocre and certainly not up to classical LucasArts quality and with all the simplification going on in the interface it feels like they weren't even trying to get there.On the positive side: The game runs flawlessly on Linux with Open Source ATI drivers.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												Review for Act 1While playing video games growing up I've come to realize that the best games always seem to have something very specific in common; something that allows you get wrapped up in and immersed in a different world to escape reality for a short time and get lost in the beauty of it; and that would be that they all have a great story. A story first above all else; above crazy graphics, above gameplay, and even above music, etc.  A story that lets you become a part of it.There are so many games these days that seem to forget that you should always start with that good story first, with fully realized worlds and the characters that inhabit them. And the games that do realize what should come first, usually turn out to be amazing works of art; games that draw you in and never let go, and have a lasting impression.And Broken Age is an excellent example of this. The story is at the heart of the experience and you can feel it.And even though this game might seem very simplistic in nature (given its gameplay style), it truly is just as satisfying to play as it would be to play a huge, multi-million dollar, RPG production made by a first-party studio by hundreds of people. But I think that's what makes this game so special: that it can be as great as it is even though it was made by just a handful of dedicated people who truly care about what they’re creating and why they’re creating it.Double Fine has shown that you can have an exciting adventure that whisks you away to worlds full of challenges, laughter, and even emotionally-engaging moments, in the form of a point-and-click adventure that’s very accessible and easy to pick up and play. And the impact you feel at the end of Act 1 is an immensive one, that really gets you thinking. It was surprising to find out how much I cared about what happened to the two main characters and how they impacted the worlds around them.I would definitely recommend this game to people who enjoy a great story, even if the gameplay style isn’t normally what they might be in to. You just might be surprised with how much you’ll enjoy it.I absolutely cannot wait until Act II! I cannot wait to go back into Shay's and Vella's worlds to finally get some answers to some burning questions! And I have a feeling it's going to be a very satisfying conclusion regardless of how it ends.:)Congrats again to Double Fine for some amazing work so far!

I was also disappointed in how the part on the spaceship ended just when it started to get interesting, not to mention how towards the end of the game you meet a man in cryo stasis and you get that ah-ha moment and you feel the plot is tying up only to get a completely out of nowhere plot twist that breaks those tied ends and raises further questions.Still, I enjoyed playing the game and bought it at a significant discount while it was on sale, and for what I paid for it, I'd recommend it. if you can get it for a good price, it won't last long, but it was fun to look at and play while it lasted.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4, 2016
												Broken Age is  a point and click adventure game by Double Fine, and more importantly, the last work of Tim Schafer, creator of such classics as Day of the Tentacle or Grim Fandango. It was funded via Kickstarter, a lot of people wanted to see a new adventure game that matched the clasics in quality, story and gameplay wise. Did it succeed? Not quite. But I would still recommend it to any fan of the genre. A lot of people were dissapointed by the game, mostly because it wasn't complete when it came out. The first part is excellent. The art style, every location, the pacing, the characters and dialogs are golden, and I couldn't stop playing until I hit the ending point. If anything, it might be a bit too easy, but it was really enjoyable, and left with quite a cliffhanger.The second half... it's not that good. It recycles every location and practically every character in the previous half, it introduces a few puzzles that become tedious to figure out, specially contrasting with the easy ones from the first half, and it becomes QUITE CLEAR that they put a lot more of thought in the enigmas presented during the first half than in the resolutions in the second: There's quite a few plot holes, glaring ones. It was quite the dissapointment, specially taking into account that the second half took 2 YEARS to come out. Still, do I recommend the game? Yes. Even with the flawed second half, it's still an incredibly charming tale, full of funny and endearing characters, and I quite enjoyed the ride, even when at the end it left me with a bit of dissapointment over what could've been if the second part matched the first one. Still, having played it once the entire game was already out, the clash didn't hurt me as much as if I had to wait for it, so that's a plus.In conclusion, if you like point and click adventure games, you gotta try it out, just be aware that it doesn't end as good as it starts. If you're on the fence about it, wait until it goes on sale.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												EDIT: I can no longer justify leaving this as a positive review. The game has gone un-finished for far too long. This isn't a multiplayer game adding new features, this is a narrative driven point n' click adventure, meaning there is nothing remotely complete in this product you are purchasing. On top of that the half that is playable is incredibly easy (which an Adventure game shouldn't be) & short. Broken Age is clearly not worth the money.I will leave my original review below intact. Just treat it as a review for half a game...Original review at the time of beating the "First Act":Broken Age aka Double Fine Adventure is finally here in all it's pointy and clicky glory! Is it that return to the good old days of PC gaming that everyone hoped for? Or does it fall short of its high expectations?.............psst, this is a Double Fine game, it will probably be amazing.            With Broken Age, Double Fine pretty much put Kickstarter on the map for indie developers, making it the go to platform to help make their dreams come true. The original idea for the project was small. Tim Schafer hadn't released a point and click adventure since 1998, and this was the genre that started his career. No big publishers wanted to fund these kind of games anymore, so he turned to us, his fans, to see if we wanted it or not. Our response was clear as the initial goal was to raise $400,000 and the Kickstarter ended at a total of $3,336,371...and that is just the total from the initial funding. Despite the incredible success Double Fine saw from public funding, there were some concerns that made news during development, the main one being that the project had become too big and they required more funding to complete it. Tim Schafer later announced that Broken Age would be split up into two acts and would take the funds from people who purchase the game and use that to develop Act II. This is why I am writing this review. This is a unique situation where how well this game does financially after release will have a huge impact on the second half of the game. This review is my way of trying to help out Double Fine to get a bigger audience so that this fantastic game gets the finale it deserves. Even if one person reads this and because of me decides to purchase the game, I will be happy. So now that you know how super important this is to me, I'll try actually talking about the game itself. :)            In Broken Age you play as the two teenagers Shay and Vella, as they are separately trying to make a major change in their lives. Shay lives in a spaceship with his loving AI parents where his every need is taken care of, though they still treat him like a child, due to their limited programming. Whereas Vella is about to be sacrificed to a giant monster as is tradition in her home town....one of these lives sounds worse than the other. Much like Day Of The Tentacle, you can swap back and fourth between the two protagonists at any moment and experience the two incredibly contrasting stories in any form you like. The gameplay is very similar to the classic point and clicks you remember, even bringing back the traditional crosshair rather than a hand or simple mouse cursor which are both more common nowadays. The big difference for gameplay is that you click and drag items in your inventory onto other objects rather than clicking to activate the item, then clicking on the object you wish to interact with. This may seems like a very small change but it instantly felt much better than the traditional method, greatly improving the overall flow of the game which I could feel was very important for Double Fine.            The main parts of any traditional point and click game are the story and puzzles. The puzzles in Broken Age may be the weakest part for some players, as this was expected to be a return to the olden days, the puzzles in Broken Age are overall pretty easy. I was never stuck for six hours straight, pulling my hair out over what I needed to do next. To be honest though, that's a good thing. Puzzles are still an important part of Broken Age, and it still feels like an adventure game, but I feel like Double Fine wanted everyone to be able to experience the wonderful story, characters, and environments they worked so hard to create, rather than have half their players be stuck because they don't know what to do with a bottle of root beer. The puzzles aren't bad, they are still very smart in how they are used, and they compliment, rather than hinder the flow of the story, which is truly what makes this game an absolute gem.            The stories of Vella and Shay are both incredible, and filled with mystery. The reason I finished this game so quickly is because I needed to see what happened to them, and I needed answers as to why these kids are both in these crazy situations. Double Fine has always been masters at creating fantastic yet unique stories, characters, and environments and this game is no different. With the help of backers, they were able to create and bring together these extremely contrasting environments and characters and somehow make them feel like they all belong together. I never questioned that in the same game I was talking to a hipster lumberjack in the forest, I also had a futuristic talking spoon in space. As you can tell from the last sentence, Double Fine brings another of their staples to Broken Age which is comedy. Though it doesn't have as strong of a presence as some of their previous games, most likely due to the somewhat serious tone, I was still laughing quite a bit, and it definitely helped that they had incredible voice talent to take advantage of including Wil Wheaton, Elijah Wood, Jack Black, and more.            Originally when I saw the art style for Broken Age, I have to be honest, I really did not care for it. It seemed too strange, and it didn't say "old school point and click" to me. However that all changed when I started playing the game. The art really does compliment the style of the story and the feel of the game. Seeing it come alive and be animated really proved me wrong and what was once ugly to me is now an absolute visual beauty.            Overall Broken Age so far is an absolutely amazing game, filled with wonder, charm, and childlike fun, something that has been mostly lost on modern video games. It's a must play for anyone that was obsessed with the point and clicks from long ago and an excellent starting point for those who are interested in the genre. The story, characters, environments, art, and dialog all mix together and makes for truly a Double Fine Adventure. Please support Double Fine with this masterpiece so that we get the incredible finale it deserves.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
												Act 1:The first hour of the game is pretty terrible, as there are no puzzles and hardly any user interaction, you are basically clicking your way through a cartoon and not a good one, as there is a ton of repetition. It does get better later on as the game opens up and you are allowed to run around on your own, but it still never quite captures what made the classical LucasArts adventure great.In terms of interface it feels disappointing and like a step backward for the genre. You don't have a dialogue-skip button and can only skip full cutscenes, that makes it far to easy to skip over important content. And the lack of a dedicated view-action means you aren't allowed to inspect the environment properly. There isn't a hotspot-highlight button either. All of that have been standard parts of most modern point&click games.Graphically the game is ok, but just barely so. The sprites all look really flat and cheaply animated (i.e. what you expect from Flash animation) and the backgrounds show some ugly pixelation when the camera zooms in. On the plus side the game does a lot of camera motion to keep things interesting and it has quite a few custom animation.All that said, I did start having fun with the game before the end. As once the game opens up and you get a little more familiar with the characters and the overall situation it starts to feel more like a proper point&click game. If they can improve a little on that this might turn on into a really good adventure game. But compared to all the stuff Daedalic has put out this just doesn't really look all that impressive and as a callback to the classic days it kind of fails, as it feels to watered down and artsy for it's own good. It's still good enough to recommend it, just don't expect a worthy successor to the LucasArts adventures.Act 2:Continues exactly where the first one left off. There are no updates to the interface, graphics or anything. Puzzles are this time a little harder then before, but not in a good way. There is a lot of walking forward and backward through scenes and it can be easy to miss a critical clue. The game is also filled with time based puzzles and puzzles that require correct setup or else they reset, this leads to a lot of repetition and frustration due to the lack of proper dialogue skip. Good inventory based puzzles don't really exist and the game doesn't really do much with the character switching either. You can play each character almost completely separate from the other and outside the very last sequence they never interact.As far as setting is concerned, act 2 reuses most locations from act 1 with some small changes. There is very little new happening here and the story reveal feels pretty "meh", as it doesn't really open up any new areas or anything. The whole mythology of that world feels pretty underdeveloped and not really explained enough. The ending feels like there would be an Act 3 to follow that plugs those holes, but there isn't one.Overall this isn't a horrible adventure by any means and it has it's moments, but it's pretty mediocre and certainly not up to classical LucasArts quality and with all the simplification going on in the interface it feels like they weren't even trying to get there.On the positive side: The game runs flawlessly on Linux with Open Source ATI drivers.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												Review for Act 1While playing video games growing up I've come to realize that the best games always seem to have something very specific in common; something that allows you get wrapped up in and immersed in a different world to escape reality for a short time and get lost in the beauty of it; and that would be that they all have a great story. A story first above all else; above crazy graphics, above gameplay, and even above music, etc.  A story that lets you become a part of it.There are so many games these days that seem to forget that you should always start with that good story first, with fully realized worlds and the characters that inhabit them. And the games that do realize what should come first, usually turn out to be amazing works of art; games that draw you in and never let go, and have a lasting impression.And Broken Age is an excellent example of this. The story is at the heart of the experience and you can feel it.And even though this game might seem very simplistic in nature (given its gameplay style), it truly is just as satisfying to play as it would be to play a huge, multi-million dollar, RPG production made by a first-party studio by hundreds of people. But I think that's what makes this game so special: that it can be as great as it is even though it was made by just a handful of dedicated people who truly care about what they’re creating and why they’re creating it.Double Fine has shown that you can have an exciting adventure that whisks you away to worlds full of challenges, laughter, and even emotionally-engaging moments, in the form of a point-and-click adventure that’s very accessible and easy to pick up and play. And the impact you feel at the end of Act 1 is an immensive one, that really gets you thinking. It was surprising to find out how much I cared about what happened to the two main characters and how they impacted the worlds around them.I would definitely recommend this game to people who enjoy a great story, even if the gameplay style isn’t normally what they might be in to. You just might be surprised with how much you’ll enjoy it.I absolutely cannot wait until Act II! I cannot wait to go back into Shay's and Vella's worlds to finally get some answers to some burning questions! And I have a feeling it's going to be a very satisfying conclusion regardless of how it ends.:)Congrats again to Double Fine for some amazing work so far!

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												NOTE: For review with screenshots, please visit http://microfloppy.net/2015/06/13/broken-age-2/Today, Kickstarter has been used by a number of different developers to crowdfund their games. I would like to say that Broken Age was the game that started this trend (which, by the way, I am very happy to see). Tim Schafer, the co-developer of Day of the Tentacle and developer of Grim Fandango, asked for $400k to make a small game as well as a documentary about the development process. He got waaaaay more and started to make a full-length point-and-click adventure game.This was in February 2012. As scope increased, so did the development time and the game took a long time to get done. Double Fine also ran out of money and decided to split Broken Age in two acts in order to make some money whilst developing the last part of the game. I was one of the backers and I worried immensely about the future of the game. In the end I was happy to see a full game released. But how was the results?First of all, the graphics are beautiful. I love the hand-painted feeling in the game and the imaginative scenes that we get to explore. Everything is just gorgeous. The music goes hand-in-hand with the graphics and the result is a very smooth and calming ambience.The theme of the game is growing up and taking control of your life. Our main protagonists are Vella and Shay:Vella is a young woman who has been selected to be sacrificed to the beast that regularly visit her village, threatening to kill everyone if it doesn’t get young maidens.Shay is a young man who stuck on a spaceship where the ship’s mother does everything to keep him safe and out of harm’s way.Neither of them have any control of their lives and they desperately want to break out of their situation.Broken Age is divided into two acts which were released months apart, and the difference in gameplay is very distinct between the two acts. In both acts, you will solve puzzles in order to advance the story. After the first act Double Fine Productions were criticised for not making the puzzles difficult enough. They were easy, story-based and required very few steps to solve.In the second act, Double Fine had listened to their fan base and upped the difficulty of the puzzles. The second part of the game has more classic adventure game puzzles with some far-fetched solutions. I had to bring out pen and paper and take notes to solve some of them, and I must say I enjoy this difficulty level much more than the first part.Unfortunately, you can’t please everyone. With act 2 released, now the critique was that the game was too difficult and that the puzzles were not fun anymore.Either way, if you love beautiful graphics and a nice story I would definitely recommend Broken Age. Just be warned that there may be some difficult puzzles waiting ahead. If you instead want difficult puzzles you will need to play for an hour or so before you will have your challenge.I am very happy that I backed this game when it was released on Kickstarter because I truly believe it has made a difference in the gaming industry. However, if I were to recommend just one point-and-click game to you, I would have to recommend Deponia instead.The documentary is very worth seeing so if you have the time and are curious about how to make a computer game: check it out on YouTube!6/10 grabbin’ garys

content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												I really enjoyed my playthrough of Broken Age. A lot of games nowadays have trouble holding my attention for extended periods of time unless I've already previously invested a lot of time in them. However, when I picked up Broken Age, I fell in love with it right away. It's visual art style as well as its voice talent brought me in, and I stayed for the comical yet engaging storytelling. The characters are also likeable, not two-dimensional but rather have depth to them which adds to the immersion that the game tries to present, especially the game's two protagonists, Shay and Vella. The puzzles did not feel like a chore: they felt challenging yet fair, and when completed, made me feel good about solving them, rather then feeling as though I had lifted a burden off of my shoulders like other games. The puzzles started off simple and later on grew in scale, encompassing (at some points) both of the game's protagnists to solve puzzles, which was an interesting game mechanic in itself. Would definetely recommend, especially to those who have yet to try point and click adventure games.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												There are so many things to say about this game. So let me break it down.1. Gameplay - Obviously, it's point and click. You can't exactly right click on everything. It's all done via point and clicking (or dragging your mouse) to move the charcter along the screen. All puzzles and item combination is done by simply dragging an object over a set piece/another object. There's not much to say besides that. It's point and click. If you don't know what that is then go away.2. Graphics - This... THIS is how you do graphics. Forget being ultra real, brown, and close to real life as possible. Broken Age chooses a different style and its style is beautifully hand painted characters and environments. Yes. Painted. Imagine you're looking at A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte. Now imagine it as a video game. That's this game. The world is absolutely beautiful to look at, and it never really feels like you're controlling characters in a map. It seriously feels like you're playing with a movable painting. It's so badass!3. Presentation - Broken Age's art style, humor, and challenging puzzles are all exceptional. The first act starts out strong, and  ends on a high note. The characters are all lively in their personalities with some good humor to back up the few. The voice acting is superb, although there were rare occassions where it felt like the actors might have delivered their lines a little short. For the most part they do their job exceptionally well and bring the characters to life. Hell, a knife and spoon have more on screen chemistry than most leading roles in AAA games. That's saying something. The puzzles can make you scratch your head a few times which is exactly what we need from these sorts of games. It's clear that a lot of heart went into making this project a reality. I can't imagine what this game would have been without it's 3 million dollar kickstarter backing. Or in the hands of some moron publisher who ruins everything.Overall - Broken age is a solid point and click adventure title with a new spin on how point and click adventure title games control. Albeit many will find it to be something similar to controls used for a tablet, but I would argue it's more for cutting out the use of right click. One button controls inspecting, combining, and using an object in your inventory. I beat the first act in about 5 hours. While that may be a tad short, I'm hoping the second half is just a teeny bit longer and harder. I still had a fun adventure exploring Shay's and Vella's worlds. I'm definitely glad I backed this project during the Kickstarter phase. If I had to give this game a score, it'd be along the lines of a 8.5/10. Do pick this one up. It's very special.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												First, I am a backer. Which means: for every positive review I am considered a fanboy, for every negative review I just did not understand what I was backing.That sad: a funny old-style adventure was promised. They got 10 times the money they asked for. They needed an enormous amount of time to deliver the game, were other companies that got way less money delivered real gems. Well, that would all be ok if the result was a gem too. It is not, sadly.While the graphic style appeals to me and the voice acting is superb, the story starts very interesting in act 1 just to succumb to complete meaninglessness. Every "Oh, what's that?"-moment in the first act was deeply disappointing explained in act 2.The puzzles did not get harder, just much more painful to solve which much trial and error and revisiting the same locations over and over.The game ended for me after ~10 hours of playtime with a real bad written ending. This game only achieved one thing for me: never buy a game again where Tim Schaefer is involved. He betrayed the trust of his backer and his legitimacy as a story writer. He finished writing the story after more than 3 years according to his own words. 3 years for that short story with so few good ideas? Wow.I can recommend the game if you want to enjoy the graphic style and voice acting. I also recommend to stop at the second time the characters start over on a split screen. Your expectations of a good story unfolding will be disappointed and you will see already often visited screens over and over again to solve some really boring puzzles. It's just sad....

content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												Finally, fiiiiiiinally I finished the game Broken Ages. It's a cute, silly, point-and-click game where a couple of brats are in undesirable situations and so are trying to change it. Player gets to play 2 different sides, capable of switching sides whenever desired to. One side involves a boy named Shay living a futuristic and OVERLY-PROTECTIVE environment. The other side involves a girl named Vella living a primitive?/modern? setting where she is a giant monster's sacrifice, but Vella is trying to kill the monster instead and free all the villages from it's terror. I started playing the game last year and it only had Act 1. Act 2 came out last April. But, I heard there were changes to Act 1, so I really can't say too much due to memory and the fact I refuse to play the game at the beginning again. The game is semi-decent to play once, but that is pretty much it. Art style was a nice painting style. It has it's funny moments, a lot of puns. Very bad puns. I like puns, but I know most people would just turn off the game due to how bad the puns were. Puzzles......I vaguely remember going through Act 1 without cheating, however in Act 2 I ABUSED the walkthrough! I try my best to figure out solutions. Playing the Ace Attorney and Professor Layton series taught me not so be so reliant since the best part IS solving a puzzle. But this flippen game has me stumped on the very first puzzle in Act 2 on Vella's part. Trial and error is the best method when it comes to these kinds of games. Part 2 was evil. It has specific directions in solving a lot of it's puzzles. I now hate cereal. For now. Until I forget that stupid puzzle.  OverallGameplay: Simple, puzzles are sometimes VERY annoyingArt: clay/painting-like decent Story: silly and decent, bit repetitive on dialogue. Wouldn't hurt to play it once, but not the second time.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
												The voice acting, soundtrack, initial storyline, overall themes, and artwork were appealing and intrguing.  I enjoyed playing as two vastly different, yet strong character leads.  The parallel, and at times, converging storylines were well written and kept me looking forward to the puzzles  and character interactions with NPCs.  Most of the voices that you hear will be familiar and it was fun going through the IMDB cast of voice actors, when I knew I'd heard that voice before.  Although most of the puzzles were logical or just took a little thought and tinkering, I did find myself perusing a walkthrough on occasion.  About halfway through the game you'll find the there are points were the storyline drags because you're going back and forth between the same scenes.  These two drawbacks are common enough with point-and-click adventure games that it didn't deter me from pushing through those sections.  I enjoyed most of my time with this game but would recommend getting it wihle it's on sale.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												NOTE: For review with screenshots, please visit http://microfloppy.net/2015/06/13/broken-age-2/Today, Kickstarter has been used by a number of different developers to crowdfund their games. I would like to say that Broken Age was the game that started this trend (which, by the way, I am very happy to see). Tim Schafer, the co-developer of Day of the Tentacle and developer of Grim Fandango, asked for $400k to make a small game as well as a documentary about the development process. He got waaaaay more and started to make a full-length point-and-click adventure game.This was in February 2012. As scope increased, so did the development time and the game took a long time to get done. Double Fine also ran out of money and decided to split Broken Age in two acts in order to make some money whilst developing the last part of the game. I was one of the backers and I worried immensely about the future of the game. In the end I was happy to see a full game released. But how was the results?First of all, the graphics are beautiful. I love the hand-painted feeling in the game and the imaginative scenes that we get to explore. Everything is just gorgeous. The music goes hand-in-hand with the graphics and the result is a very smooth and calming ambience.The theme of the game is growing up and taking control of your life. Our main protagonists are Vella and Shay:Vella is a young woman who has been selected to be sacrificed to the beast that regularly visit her village, threatening to kill everyone if it doesn’t get young maidens.Shay is a young man who stuck on a spaceship where the ship’s mother does everything to keep him safe and out of harm’s way.Neither of them have any control of their lives and they desperately want to break out of their situation.Broken Age is divided into two acts which were released months apart, and the difference in gameplay is very distinct between the two acts. In both acts, you will solve puzzles in order to advance the story. After the first act Double Fine Productions were criticised for not making the puzzles difficult enough. They were easy, story-based and required very few steps to solve.In the second act, Double Fine had listened to their fan base and upped the difficulty of the puzzles. The second part of the game has more classic adventure game puzzles with some far-fetched solutions. I had to bring out pen and paper and take notes to solve some of them, and I must say I enjoy this difficulty level much more than the first part.Unfortunately, you can’t please everyone. With act 2 released, now the critique was that the game was too difficult and that the puzzles were not fun anymore.Either way, if you love beautiful graphics and a nice story I would definitely recommend Broken Age. Just be warned that there may be some difficult puzzles waiting ahead. If you instead want difficult puzzles you will need to play for an hour or so before you will have your challenge.I am very happy that I backed this game when it was released on Kickstarter because I truly believe it has made a difference in the gaming industry. However, if I were to recommend just one point-and-click game to you, I would have to recommend Deponia instead.The documentary is very worth seeing so if you have the time and are curious about how to make a computer game: check it out on YouTube!6/10 grabbin’ garys

The voice acting is also brilliant, including some big names.There are some things I wasn't asa impressed with. The story is better in act 1 but I found the puzzles too easy. In act 2 the story gets a bit weird and seems a bit forced, but the puzzles are a lot better and some had me stumped for a while, which was nice.It's definitely worth the price and it's definitely worth a play. I had been in a gaming rut, with nothing new really exciting me. Playing Broken Age got me excited about games again, you can tell a lot of passion went into making it and it's really just a nice game to play.

												There's no way I would ever have finished this without hints/guides.  I've never been great at adventure games, and some of the puzzles here (especially the ones where you have to get hints from the alternate character's environments) border on cruel. This second act is made up almost entirely of recycled environments and characters from the first act, but it works for the most part.  There's some more humor, and a lot more plot development, and a final sequence that would have taken forever without hints, but overall it made up an enjoyable story with a good ending.  Nothing on the Grim Fandango level, but not a bad throwback adventure experience.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2015
												Broken Age is a fun but uneven, oddly paced, hit-or-miss affair. I will still recommend it on the merit is that it tries very hard to do the adventure game genre justice with the unique telling of a story with two separate characters. It also plays with a dream-like aesthetic that is often soft and cuddly that makes up for any faults I found with it. The puzzles also try to recapture the spirit of LucasArts days puzzle solving with some good logical puzzles included, it is a fairly fun experience overall. Storywise, this one probably wouldn't win any awards, it's lackluster in back story and a lot of the characters' dialogue comes across pretty chill. All the characters are very charming, and I think my favourites are still the hexipals, they're just so cute! Honestly funny moments are too few and far between. Tim Schafer's dialogue and story writing skills unfortunately weren't on full display here, and I grew to miss the wit that usually was to be found in his work.Some players will find the puzzles too easy in the first act and too challenging in the second act. I personally found myself stuck a few times in the second act, but some friendly hints along the way got me back on track. The logical puzzles are good and they required me to have the pen and paper handy, something I really enjoy doing when solving puzzles. What I truly appreciated about Broken Age was that Tim tried telling the story in a format that was something different, where the player is the unseen link between two physically separated characters. Some puzzles are solved with both characters seeing clues that aid the opposite character, all without them speaking or saying anything. I wish this idea could have been taken further.For those who enjoy a good adventure game will certainly enjoy this title and still be pleased by the art, puzzle design and the Schafer style storytelling. Also, with a soft and cuddly aesthetic, it's hard to be displeased with the final product.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												After watching the documentary, I get that a lot of blood, sweat and tears went into making this game.  Unfortunately, part 2 does not deliver on what part 1 set up.  I totally empathize with what they went through, but I have to be honest here.  I was extremely let down by this  game.I feel like we got the outline of an interesting story.  The two main character's worlds are explained fairly well.  Unfortunately the antagonist's isnt, and instead is simply summarized through dialog...and even then it's still not explained very well.  Imagine if a character is on a journey to a destination, and when they finally get there, the only thing you get to see is an exterior shot and nothing else.  That pretty much sums it up.  There were some major, "Hey!  What about the so and so's trapped in the you know where?" type of plotholes that were never resolved.   There's also an extremely frame-breaking puzzle mechanic introduced in part 2.  Characters A and B are completely separated with no way to communicate.  Yet Character A has puzzles with solutions that only Character B has information about.  So when Character B looks at an inventory item, you have to use information about that item so Character A can solve the puzzle.  I was literally stumped for a couple of hours because I didn't think Tim would actually break that kind of rule.  It made absolutely zero sense in the story so why should it be possible?  When I finally gave in and used walkthrough to find an answer, I literally put the game away for a few months.  I was suddenly disinterested because it's cheating the story just to make the puzzle harder.  Anyways, after I finished watching the documentary, I decided to start over and finish Broken Age.  I was even more excited now that I got a glimpse at how it was made!   Maybe I was wrong.  Maybe that was just one puzzle that was bad.  Well, it turns out several puzzles break the narrative.  The end of this game has two characters coordinating an attack who aren't in communication at all!  Seriously!  It felt like I was playing an old Sierra puzzle game called Gobliiins.  Get these characters in the right places and push the buttons and pull the levers to continue.  Couldn't Tim just put some sort of communication device in the story that allowed them to communicate in some fashion?  I think it would have led to better story telling as our characters actually got to know each other.I'm even more disappointed after seeing so many likeable people put a lot of time and energy into this and to come up with something that feels 77% complete.  The art and the music are superb.  The voice acting is top notch.  Unfortunately the part two's puzzle felt like busy work (seriously, once I demonstrate I get the gist of it, I shouldn't have to go through all the steps over and over again) and felt like they focussed more energy on making puzzles harder and less time developing the story.  So I cannot recommend this game at full price.  I'd definitely wait for it to go on sale.  I never thought I'd say that about a Tim Schafer game...

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												Just finished playing "Broken Age"  (Act 1) and I'm just... wow!Feels like playing those epic and classic adventure games back in the days (Monkey Island 2 and 3, Maniac Mansion 2) but with jaw-dropping hand-painted high-resolution graphics and a marvellous music-score.It brings back the best of point-and-click adventure games to our "modern" age, while retaining their essence (I'm very glad, for instance, that they didn't go the 3D route).The story is good and intriguing, the setting is excellent, the puzzles are just right (neither too obvious nor too hard).This game will become a classic, and I think it's a must-play game.Definitely a recommend! Looking forward to "Act 2".

I'd recomend this game either on sale or with a coupon at most to get the time per dollar value but over all an amazing game to play!

Pros+ witty humor.+ well developed plot and twist(s.)+ a vast, lovable (and not so lovable) cast of characters.+ gorgeous hand painted visuals.+ every single detail of the game tying into the ending.+ Grabbin' Gary.Cons (very few)- very rough looking backgrounds when cutscenes and close-up dialogue are taking place.- some repetitive lines when inspecting something more than once or twice.- I picked this up for about 1/4 of the normal price during a weekend sale, if you're interested in the game, I'd put it on your wishlist and wait for it to go on sale. I love the game but I think the regular price is a little high.first review I've ever done :')

content:

												Old point and click nostalgia and Double Fine's classic brand of humor.  If you have played any of the classic LucasArts games (i.e. Maniac Mansion, Day of the Tentacle, Monkey Island) then you owe it to yourself to play this game.  The gameplay has been very dumbed down (as in, clicking on something and it acts as 'pick up', 'look at', 'eat', etc.) but the story and gorgeous art style is well worth it.  I disagree with the asking price (I was a Kickstarter backer so I have it at a discount) but on a sale this should be a must buy.  9/10

content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												Broken Age is beautiful, charming, clever, brave, and funny. It brings great twists to classic concepts like "stuck in space" and "human sacrifice to ancient gods" thanks to witty writing and unique, delightful visuals. Each character is instantly lovable thanks to great voice acting and perfect design/animation. The first half of the game is, in many ways, much superior to the second in terms of pacing and seamlessly teaching the player how to solve interesting puzzles, while the second half sometimes drags due to illogical and difficult solutions, but overall the story and art (not to mention the exciting reveals) make this a terrific game worth owning and playing more than once.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												Broken Age is the story of two kids trying to change their lives. Vella is about to be sacrificed to save her town while Shay is wandering through space doing the same missions every day. The story starts off pretty simple and you can start with either character. In fact one of the interesting things about the game is that you can switch between the storylines at any time. This is your average point and click adventure. You walk around looking for items to complete a puzzle to get to the next location. Some of the puzzles are easy to figure out, while others will have you thinking for a while. Then there are the puzzles that you accidentally find the missing part to complete that one puzzle you have been on for about an hour.The graphics are nice, nothing next gen which adds to the game subtle charm. Each location has its own unique design and color scheme. The music is well done. Nothing overbearing or too generic. The voice acting is also well done with interesting conversations. Like many games, there are always a few characters with some extremely cheesy dialog. If you are a Double Fine games lover, this is definitely a good game to pick up. The whole time playing it, it felt like I was playing the old point and click game “The Dig”. This game is nowhere as long or as hard but was just as enjoyable.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2016
												This game can be broken into two parts:Before the Hexipal Wiring puzzle, and After.The game before the Hexipal Wiring puzzle is beautiful. Polished, crisp, lovely. Interesting puzzles and wonderful dialogue, beautiful art style, just a pleasure to sit and relax and enjoy with.Once you get to the Hexipal Wiring puzzle, quietly close the game, uninstall, and watch a lets play for the rest. Do not put yourself through that nightmare of an unsolveable puzzle that, if walkthroughs are any indication, you must repeat several times more. It is not a puzzle you can do with a guide. It is not a puzzle you can do with intelligence. It is pure tediousness, plain and simple, and sucks the joy out of the game.I do not recommend this game because that is how game-stoppingly difficult this puzzle is.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4, 2016
												Broken Age is  a point and click adventure game by Double Fine, and more importantly, the last work of Tim Schafer, creator of such classics as Day of the Tentacle or Grim Fandango. It was funded via Kickstarter, a lot of people wanted to see a new adventure game that matched the clasics in quality, story and gameplay wise. Did it succeed? Not quite. But I would still recommend it to any fan of the genre. A lot of people were dissapointed by the game, mostly because it wasn't complete when it came out. The first part is excellent. The art style, every location, the pacing, the characters and dialogs are golden, and I couldn't stop playing until I hit the ending point. If anything, it might be a bit too easy, but it was really enjoyable, and left with quite a cliffhanger.The second half... it's not that good. It recycles every location and practically every character in the previous half, it introduces a few puzzles that become tedious to figure out, specially contrasting with the easy ones from the first half, and it becomes QUITE CLEAR that they put a lot more of thought in the enigmas presented during the first half than in the resolutions in the second: There's quite a few plot holes, glaring ones. It was quite the dissapointment, specially taking into account that the second half took 2 YEARS to come out. Still, do I recommend the game? Yes. Even with the flawed second half, it's still an incredibly charming tale, full of funny and endearing characters, and I quite enjoyed the ride, even when at the end it left me with a bit of dissapointment over what could've been if the second part matched the first one. Still, having played it once the entire game was already out, the clash didn't hurt me as much as if I had to wait for it, so that's a plus.In conclusion, if you like point and click adventure games, you gotta try it out, just be aware that it doesn't end as good as it starts. If you're on the fence about it, wait until it goes on sale.

Posted: March 14, 2016
												Broken Age, lets see, what can I say about Broken Age.......  Well it didn't suck.  It wasn't great either.  It was slightly above average if you ask me, so maybe a 6 or a 7 out of 10.  I enjoyed the story, and I wasn't turned off by the ending like so many of the nay sayers.  What I really didn't like about this game is the wire puzzle.  I was able to do it, and I only have average intelligence, but still the way the game approached solving this puzzle made it tedious and down right frustrating at times.  It should have been implemented better.  I do recommend this game, but the wire puzzle might make your eyes bleed, you have been warned.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												Broken Age is the game that essentially started the kickstarter craze.  They wanted $400,000 to make their game idea a reality.  What they got was over $3,300,000.  With their new budget they started making a 'larger' and 'better' game.  Double Fine then went way beyond budget and had to break the game into two parts.  The backers, such as myself get both parts (once completed) while anyone who buys act 1 is simply funding act 2.  As of this review they have made enough money to make the second act.  This review is about part 1.Broken Age is about 2 hours long.  It is an old school point and click adventure game where you play as two characters in very different worlds.  The humor in the game is what you would expect from Tim S. and Double Fine.  The game is very creative and beautiful.  The game runs smoothly and I didn't experience any bugs.  The puzzles in the game are laughably easy though.  Aestheticly and humorously entertaining the gameplay itself is just to simple.I would recommend this game for it's imaginitive design and it's humor.  I have to not recommend this game though, knowing the whole story of development, because it is just to short and to easy to feel anything more than a simple flash game someone could hammer out in a few weeks and toss up on newgrounds for free.  I feel that I did get what was promised, a game and a movie of how it is being developed.  When you weigh the time of development and the money spent on it, compared with what the final product became, I have to say that you should buy this game as cheaply as possible.  I hope Double Fine learns to manage their money better from here on out.  If you are looking for a unique set piece and story that is short and has simple gameplay mechanics that you don't have to put much mental thought into then this game is just perfect for you...for the next two hours.Update:Act 2 is finally finished and just as simple and short as act 1. The game even has an achievement for beating it in under one hour. Gee, thanks Tim.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												Very cute with memorable characters and a well-composed plot.  The adventure gameplay is quite nice, although you won't find any puzzles that are too ingenious in here.  There is a nice variety though, and only one puzzle I felt was unfair (getting the snake, it was the only "puzzle" I had to look up, and I didn't feel bad about it after I had done so.)  I suppose the game reminds me a bit of Loom, but it is a much more satisfying and complete experience than that game, which felt to me a bit like a demo for a game that could have been.  I would imagine everyone would enjoy this.  I hope there is a sequel which will let us explore in the land beyond the plague dam, and learn a bit more about that culture.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25, 2016
												By reading the reviews I expected the game to start really sucking during the second half, but that didn't happen at all. I thought the second half was just as lovely as the first and both together create two halves of a great story.While it is true that there seems to be a missing third arc, the game does fine without it. You understand the underlying plot just fine without having to actual see the bad guys get taken down. It completes the personal stories of the two main characters and that feels fine.Personally I loved the spaceship and was intrigued constantly by everything about it. The design and concept behind the whole thing is just amazing and the game was fun just to get to explore that thing.All in all I loved this game, and I think everyone is being way too hard on it. People complain about the difficulty of puzzles in the second half, but if you're a Adventure game regular you won't have too much trouble. (Granted there is a robot wiring puzzle which is confusing as all hell and even when you understand it you basically HAVE to write things down on a physical piece of paper to complete it which is reeeaaal old school.) I can understand why people who hate it for that.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2016
												I hesitate to recommend this game. It is a big disappointment for me after the huge Kickstarter campaign and the big names behind it. The production quality is immense; top of the line (and famous) voice actors, professionally recorded soundtrack, beautiful artwork and a perfect user interface. But really, that's all it has going for it. The game feels so incredibly empty, it's depressing. The story is nonsensical, the characters are boring, the humour is lacking and some of the puzzles are rather badly designed. At the end of the day, it is a solid game, but it could have been so much more.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 7, 2016
												The game is beautiful, but also ugly...The first thing you will notice about this game, whether you're playing it or looking at screenshots and footage, is the undeniable beauty this game exudes. This beauty is found in everything, from the distinct art style that is both shocking and comforting, to the humourously written script that kept me chuckling and shocked by it's delightful twists and turns. The gameplay is engaging and rewarding through the adbundant player interactions and the logical puzzles... of the first Act. The second Act though I'm not so sure.I couldn't help but feel cheated by the second Act's puzzles. The first Act provides the player with just enough information to suggest the plan of attack for solving it, but not so much that you feel that your hand is being held through it. I didn't mind progressing, at I perceived to be a slow pace, during the first Act because I didn't feel I was being cheated by the puzzle's logic. I felt that if I was "stuck" for long enough the game gave a subtle enough nudge in the right direction for me to get their on my "own". On the other hand, the second Act felt punishing in some ways because the same level of information feedback was not provided to the player. Instead it felt like I was either left flopping around frustrated because I wanted to keep enjoying the bountiful world before me, to the point where I was simply employing a process of elimination for "solving" the puzzle, leaving me feeling cheap and unaccomplished.In summary, this is a wonderful game. I will reccommend it to all as I feel it certainly has a lot to offer, a wide range of different players. The artists within you will love the colourful, but psychotic world before you. The logician within you will enjoy MOST of the puzzles and adventurous players will enjoy an unfamiliar experience that I'm confident, the majority of modern gamers haven't experienced before; the point-and-click adventure game. If you do heed my suggestions, beware of some puzzles that will leave you broken.

Posted: September 14, 2015
												If you enjoy story centric games with basic puzzles, then this is definitely the game for you. If you want something a little more action packed... why are you looking at a click-adventure game?I absolutely loved the first half of this game. The story is fresh as hell, the characters are amazing (who doesn't love a girl with 'tude because the world's gone mad fight the big bad things in the world?) and the art is pretty damn awesome.The second half was not as great. I've heard some complain that the second half was terrible, that its fallen from its previous story, but personally it seemed like the second half had different goals. I mean, sure I would have loved to tackle the same kind of social issues and stuff in a story, but the second half was more: aaaaand so this is how the situation is going to be resolved. Not great, not bad.Imma give this game 8 7's out of 10! [7][7][7][7][7][7][7][7][X][X]

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
												I really wish Steam reviews had a 'mixed' button....Ok. Broken Age is... mostly solid, as a fun quirky throwback to old style adventure games. Nice art, ok Voice Acting, some fairly decent puzzles. It's short in theory, but your first playthrough should take a fair bit of time as you explore the world and try to work out the logic behind some of the puzzles. If you're into classic point and click adventure games, I do have to recommend this.However, Act 2 was ultimately somewhat disappointing to me, for a few reasons. The story's resolution, whilst there, is cut somewhat short and a few key plot points are left either unresolved, or barely touched upon. Alongside that however, is a completely illogical final sequence, where the player's end goal is not clearly explained to them, the puzzle requirements are irritating and time consuming rather than rewarding intellect, and where the plot closes out without a resolution on the underlying conflict.It has its virtues. I recommend investigating it if you're curious. But ultimately, the game did not justify the hype, or the Kickstarter. It will be remembered for kicking off the indie kickstarter boom more than as a game in its own right. Which I feel is a shame given the talent that act one displayed. Double Fine needed a stronger brief with this game, and I feel that ultimately they wavered and improvised the end.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2015
												Yet another Double Fine masterpiece: a fantastic story and setting with equally excellent voice acting and visuals and great dialogue. The gameplay is the classic point and click adventure style where you have to talk to people, find and combine items in a particular order to advance the plot by resolving various situations the game presents you with. There is a twist here where there are two characters whose stories are linked and run in parallel, both coming from very different backgrounds and you can switch between the two, also enabling you to find hints to solve one's puzzles in the other's world (although how they exchange information is never clearly explained there are some hints in some of the implied actions). The characters are great although Vella (the girl in the story) is overwhelmingly stronger out of the two. You travel from scenic location to scenic location while solving a deep mystery in a world that is a mix of fantasy and a degree of modernism without being directly contemporary. There's a minority of people complaining about some obtuse puzzles and backtracking but I did not find anything here that is any worse than other great classics of the genre (I've played almost all of them) and although a hint system would have been nice, the puzzles are generally feasible. Seriously though, do not let the minority of complainers (less than a third of the 2000+ reviews on Steam) whose reviews somehow got voted as most helpful thanks to people never seeing and voting for the positive reviews in the other tabs distract you from this great adventure game, it is something to be experienced.

number of helpful: 8 of 18 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												I always thought that I started gaming while playing the platforming genre like Mario and Sonic the Hedgehog being one of my favorite series of all time. As I thought about it for a minute, I remember I used to play a certain type of game even earlier than that. It involved using the mouse to click on parts of the environment to move your character, interact with it and solve puzzles. I never knew the name of the genre until a few years later when it peaked my curiosity enough to Google it. The genre was appropriately called 'Point and Click adventure games'.So why it was so hard for me to pinpoint the genre? Well, gaming between now and then exploded in a ton of different genres, which further splintered into a variety of subgenres. Between all this chaotic explosion of genres, one got caught in the crossfire and badly wounded to the point it almost got killed, yes you know what genre I am talking about.After more than a decade after that incident, the folks at Double Fine used their powers of necromancy to  Kickstart the Heart  of the genre back to life. They had to tap into the power of hundreds and thousands of souls to make it happen. Ok, I am very dramatic here but it kinda works doesn't it! The crowd funded Kickstarter campaign was a huge success, not only they greatly exceeded the funds to make their original vision of the game possible, but they kept on breaking all kinds of Kickstarter records in the process. The additional capital went further into making the game we all deserved but never asked for...or something like that.So how is the game? Double Fine crafted a beautiful imaginative world with colorful characters while some carrying surprisingly muted intentions. It tells a story about a boy and a girl from two entirely different environments, yet facing the exact same problem: being captive in one's fate, as they both try to defy the fate placed upon themselves. The world looks hand-drawn and reminds me of the story books I used to gross over as a child with the smallest of details carrying the biggest impressions. What is brilliant is how Double Fine lays down such a mature tale through the light hearted visuals and very simplistic and pleasing audio cues.As someone who played a lot of adventure games when he was a kid, but sadly gone out of touch with it - because of lack of such games out in the market. I got stuck in a couple of  puzzles, some of them took more than hour for me to figure it out!  I took about 6 hours or so to finish the first act. Your milage may vary depending on how good you are at solving the puzzles.If I had a gripe with this game, it is how much you are limited in solving the puzzles: I wish the game was a bit more open to clever to players out there. At times I felt I had the tools to handle a situation in an alternate way, but the game never really responded to such ideas. I know the game is playing it to it's well documented traditions, but I wish the game explored a bit further out the boundaries of this genre like this without taking away it's heart.For the asking price of 25$, it might put off a lot of people off considering the short ride they are getting. The ride may be short, but it is a much more memorable. They could have easily went the road most other games take by stretching the length with filler content, but they didn't. Not a single time in the game I felt it was wasted, it is even more true for games of this class as any sort of filler content will distract it further from it's puzzle solving elements. So what are you waiting for? Hop in the Double Fine express for a beautiful journey that you won't be forgetting anytime soon!

content:
Posted: November 14, 2015
												This is a delightful point-and-click adventure. Its strengths are story, superb art and animation, top-notch voice acting, and lush original music. The puzzles are more of a mixed bag: some really great ones, but also a few that don't make much sense and may prove frustrating with a lot of going back and forth.But, if you like point-and-click adventures, you are sure to enjoy this one. I recommend it. The tone is family-friendly (with a few sly jokes) and endearing. It may remind you in this respect of Machinarium and Botanicula, though voice acting and plenty of dialog really beef up the production.So, what's up with all these bizarrely negative reviews? This game had a lot of hype, and was poorly managed along the way (it was originally released in two "acts" and took a total of three years to make), which led to some inflated expectations about and misdirected anger towards the final product. Some people seemed to expect this to be the greatest point-and-click adventure of all time, and when it didn't turn out that way, slammed the game.Jut ignore all that noise: it's not the best point-and-click adventure of all time, but definitely worth your time and money. The game absolutely deserves a "thumbs up," even if it has frustrating moments.I also suspect that some of the negative reviews come from people who just don't appreciate the genre: point-and-click adventuring has always been based on 1) thinking logically, and when that fails 2) trying to use every object on every other object, and finally 3) going: d'oh, why didn't I think of that! If you don't enjoy this kind of gameplay, this is not the game that will convert you. It adheres to all the conventions of the genre, just with exceptionally high production values.Finally, I'd like to thank the developers for supporting Linux!

content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												A really great point-and-click adventure game! Especially if you like Tim Schafer's flavor of characters and silly humor. In terms of puzzles and difficulty, the first half of the game is a little bit easy and (depending on your experience with adventure game puzzles) perhaps even a little boring in a few places, but the writing and characters are still excellent.The second half of the game takes the puzzle difficulty up a notch! Some have complained that Double Fine overcorrected in the second half and made the puzzles too difficult, but I could not disagree more. The puzzles can be very difficult, and if you're not consulting a guide/walkthrough, you will definitely get stumped on a couple of occasions. Maybe if you're coddled by modern games and aren't used to the experience of not knowing what to do next, then you will find this frustrating or annoying, but back in the golden days of adventure games this was to be expected and was even desired! The great thing about Broken Age, though, is that even though you sometimes get stumped in terms of how to accomplish an objective, you always pretty much know what your next objectives are, and it's just a matter of fiddling with the environment and keenly observing your surroundings until you ultimately have an AH HA moment. It's sometimes slow to come, but it will come.The genius of the puzzles in the second half is that they essentially come in two types: 1) Pure logic puzzles where, if you have heard the pertinent information in dialogue or seen it displayed somewhere, then simple logic and deduction gets you the answer you need; or 2) Intuitive puzzles that require you to think more laterally or metaphorically, and yet make enough sense that you can figure it out without consulting a guide. All you need to solve the most difficult puzzles in this game is a bit of lateral thinking, some patience, and excellent observation skils. (You won't be making any fake mustaches out of cat hair taped to a fence, if ye olde adventure gamers catch my drift.)When the first half was released early, it seemed short and easy. As a full game, though, there is an upward-sloping curve to the difficulty that starts them at easy and raises them to very challenging.Above all though, in this game, as in all Double Fine games, there is a unique and inimitible purity to the good-natured and good-humored characters and jokes and universe that just makes you happy. I'll take that over face stabbing any day.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												This game is beautiful. I was lucky enough to be a backer of this game, allowing me to follow its creation to the point and as it continues in the future. I have been an avid fan of point-and-click/adventure games for a long time now and am a huge fan of Tim Schafer's games and writing. First of all, it is interesting to point out that you play as two characters in separate, parallel stories, a boy named Shay on a spaceship and a girl named Vella in a village. It is very unique and provides an interesting twist to the genre that I personally haven't seen before. At any time you can switch between the characters using the inventory menu at the bottom of the screen and pick up right where you left off with that character. I'm interested to see if there is a link between the two and when it will appear. It is a very interesting mechanic and I can't wait to see what DoubleFine continues to do with it.I have to say that everything in this game just... works. The art is done in a very interesting and eye-catching style, and it is a major draw of the game. In any point-and-click, the art is extremely important since you will do a lot of exploring. It is also important to make sure that it is clear what is in the foreground vs. what is in the background as well as make the distinction of what is just part of the backdrop and what you can interact with. The game does a terrific job of all of this. I have enjoyed exploring Shay's ship and Vella's home immensely. I think my favorite moment, in terms of the art, were the different birds you see flying during one of Vella's segments. The art style and direction is incredible.Complementing the art and story is the music. The music rises at parts and is more subdued at others, matching the mood. Some points will feel slightly darker while others will feel slightly more silly or intense. For every situation, there is a perfectly appropriate piece. They've also successfully avoided one of the pitfalls that can occur with a point-and-click: the music loop. If you spend too long on many games of this genre, the music loops can can become very annoying very quickly. However, if the music looped, I didn't notice it, which is a great thing to see in a game such as this. I have to say that little piece when you first start the game and see Shay and Vella back-to-back in different worlds has to be my favorite piece thus far. I am extremely glad I got the soundtrack with my backing.The voice acting thus far has been pretty spot on and terrific. I am thoroughly enjoying listening to these actors speak and find them to be believable, which can be tough to pull off. I often find myself listening to them in situations and thinking, yeah, I would be apprehensive also or that I would be just as confused as them given the situation they are in. The voice actors do a great job.The puzzles are as you would expect. Challenging enough that you don't breeze through them, but intuitive enough that you can figure them out if you put in a little effort and time exploring and putting the pieces together in your mind. They don't reach the point of frustration, at least not for me, which is just where it needs to be. Again, the art helps a lot in this department as well by showing you what you can pick up or interact with and making it clear what various different objects are.Finally, the crux of the genre, the writing of the story and dialogue. When Tim Schafer writes a story, you know it's going to be good. It's going to be one of the few games that can make you laugh out loud with how funny it is. This game is no exception. Throughout most of my time playing, I was smiling and, on more than a few occasions, I belted out laughing. Mr. Schafer has not lost it. He is still up with the best of them in terms of writing and I enjoyed going through every possible dialogue choice just to see what silly, or even insightful, things would be said next.Overall, I am quite pleased with what I have seen and am quite glad that I chose to back this game when I did. I have a good amount of trust in DoubleFine and believe they know what they are doing. I can't wait to see where this game goes in the future. Good luck to them in producing the rest!

content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												Don't expect Broken Age to be similar to Lucasarts great games, with weird characters and hilarious jokes everywhere.Don't expect Broken Age to be a very deep point and click with difficult puzzles.Do expect Broken Age to be as soft as its wonderful, pastel-colored world. The humor is there, but it's chuckles and light touches, instead of being a in-your-face laughing out loud thing. The game has a deeper goal than simply making you laugh, so it toned down the humorDo expect Broken Age to tell you a story instead of stumping you on puzzles. Puzzles are easy, but  that serve to make the story and the exploration more enjoyable.If you go without theses assumptions, you will discover a charming game, in a wonderful world, that is begging for you to explore it more. It's a story more than a game, and I love it for that. Unfortunately, this is only Act 1, and it ends on a cliffhanger that is hinting at a very surprising Act 2...Can't wait to know the end of that story :)

content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
												Normally I hate Adventure games. Really, I despise them. I'm not into FPS either, I'm your good ol' gamer who enjoys the classics, Dwarf Fortress and all that. However, this game really peaked my interest. I personally love the idea of online begging via Kickstarter, and followed this game to the finish line. Although I never actually gave money, I reccomended this game to everyone I knew, to the point that they called me the "Broken Record." However, I never bought it. There was always some DLC that I needed or some other thing that got placed right above this. I finally bought the game about a month ago and played it in one or two sittings.Playing this game is a life experience. It's the equivalent of getting a good grade on a test, while riding a motorcycle backwards, while going off a jump into a mound of bouncy balls. I can't stress how visually appealling this game is... It's the equivalent of... I think you get the point.I really have to hand it to Tim Schafer and his team, they really knocked it out of the park with this. I also admire that they took the risk of a media backlash to create best (and only) adventure game I will play. When I finished the game I started counting the days until Act II came out, but now that it's delayed to Q1 2015, I can only imagine what the game will play like.
