number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
Act 2 update posted April 28, 2015I replayed Act 1 and went on to beat Act 2. Everything I already said about Act 1 stays true in Act 2. Act 2 is about another 8 hours if you take the time to talk to everyone and try to do every combo of item with person/thing you can. The puzzles are a little more difficult which is good, but at the end of the game figuring out exactly what to do can be a little annoying what with the multiple possibilities of the "wire puzzle".The answers to what is going on are basically answered, but not to the depth I (and I'm sure many others) would have preferred, especially given the implications of what it meant. If you're worried about a cliffhanger, there isn't one; it just feels like there could (and hopefully will) be more to the story when you beat it. Sequel perhaps? There easily could be one.Overall I did enjoy this Act 2 and I feel it was very well done. One of the more memorable point n' click adventure games in a long time.Posted Jan 29, 2014As of this writing only Act 1 is available but boy did I have a good time! Act 1 is only about 4 hours if you take your time, but what is there is so superb you're not likely to mind. The story is so well put together with truly excellent dialog voiced by professionals. If you didn't already know, this is a point and click adventure game with 2 main characters that have their own unique and separate, but ultimately converging, story. One story is of Shay, a lonely boy who is on a spaceship with only his AI "mother" and "father" for company, while all he gets to do is play boring child-like games. The other story is Vella who is in a pre-industrial civilization and must prepare for the Maiden's Feast. I can't say more without spoilers.You may notice a lot of people complaining about the puzzles. What they are actually saying is that the puzzles in this game are all logical and usually have a clear goal given to you. Because of this the puzzles aren't convoluted and illogical like in so many adventure games prior. My only complaint is that the puzzles here aren't complicated at all, but this is only the first act and I expect they will get more challenging in Act 2.I can't say much about the characters you will meet or places you will go without spoilers, so I'll just say that the people you meet and interact with are all imaginative and well done, no complaints. Although this game doesn't have an examine feature (or taste, touch, etc.) I do like all the different reactions from people as you use items on them. Some are fairly funny with a few adult-oriented jokes thrown in.I saved the best for last: the ending. Oh man was this cliffhanger of an ending amazing! I seriously can't say more without possibly ruining it and that would be a travesty. For me at least the ending had me continuing to think about and examine the game hours after I had beaten it and even as I was trying to go to sleep. In the context of the game it is so thought provoking, bringing with it many more questions than it answers. I can say I haven't been looking forward to the conclusion in a game with this much anticipation and desire in a long time.So is this game worth 25 bucks? Right now it only has Act 1 that is 4 incredible hours, with Act 2 to come in the future for all current and future owners. If you want the most bang for your buck right now then you should probably wait for a sale or Act 2 to arrive. If you know you want this game but are thinking you'd rather wait until it's all done, don't! Part of the impact and effectiveness of the Act 1 ending is the fact you can't immediately proceed in the story to see the conclusion. Instead you are forced to think and mull it over, analyzing what it means and could mean. Conclusion: buy this game now or soon if you can and know you want it, otherwise be sure to get it later.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												Once upon a time, there was a man named Tim Schafer who made some of the best video games to ever exist. They were fun to play, hilarious, and quickly became timeless classics. Nowadays Tim Scahafer is scamming people with early access, siding with social justice warriors and con artists posing as feminist video game critics(and guess who is a recommended curator for this game!), making fun of minorities using sock puppets, and most of all, mismanaging Kickstarter funds IE this game.This game was suppose to require 400k bucks to fund, but after a Kickstarter campaign that raised 3.3m, backers were given HALF of a game. They spent 3.3m on half a game, and had to use the profits to finish the game. All of this attributed to big name voice actors, big hand drawn backgrounds, and lavish parties thrown by the developers.When you actually play the game, it just plain sucks. In act 1, the puzzles are♥♥♥♥♥♥easy which is made so by the shortness of the game, where as soon as you get an item ingame, you'll be using it real soon. The story for act 1 was actually really good, but act 2 is what ruined the whole story.There's just so much wrong with act 2. The game just feels rushed here. There's only a small number of new characters introduce and they really don't do a lot. The story is an absolute mess, like the plot twist about Shay's parents is just plain unbelievable which ruins the whole story of act 1. The villain's motive is easily skippable dialog, which is a huge story no-no, and not even that but the whole villain thing was never really fleshed out. It was like they had just plans for the villain but cut them at the end. Not to mention that the whole ordeal with one of the elderly female characters in act 2 is completely glossed over and ignored after it's revealed.Also the puzzles are act 2 are a mess. Schafer said before production of act 1 that he wanted to stay away from puzzles that had no basis in reality, yet act 2 is full of them. The biggest culprit of this is the snake puzzle and all the wiring. In act 1 you could play through each character's story fully without having to switch between them. If you go into act 2 with this mindset, you'll run into a brick wall sooner or later, and the game doesn't even warn you of this. Doesn't make since that to solve a puzzle you have to find a book as 1 character and solve the puzzle as another. Let's not forget the snake where you have to let the snake strangle you for about 2-3 real life minutes while your character mentions how they're dieing in order to proceed ahead.The ending really felt rushed. It's over so quick, and ignores the fact that everyone's standing around a giant wall that was just shooting cannons at them, it fades to credits where you get pictures of what happened to the characters next, which unlike Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel, doesn't feel fulfilling.Also there's so many social justice warrior undertones in the game it's just plain ridiculous. You can tell these people got their claws rooted in Schafer. There's girl power tones everywhere with 1 of the main characters being a strong beautiful black women who don't need no man. Also the villain is of a white race that the characters ingame describe as "privileged" ughhh.Honestly don't buy this game. Schafer lost his touch years ago, and after all the underhanded and discriminatory stuff he's done lately, you shouldn't be giving your money to him, and because of the lack of love with act 2, you're not really missing much by skipping this game.

												Since "Broken Age" will come along in two Acts, ……… I as well will take the liberty ofsplitting my Opinion for the time being until ……… I had the fair chance to experience both parts.First and foremost, there is a *huge* amount ……… of charme – established by the visuals, character design, voice acting and camera ……… work. number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												The good: Fantastic art direction, amazing voice talent, engaging story, simple gameplay.The bad: Frustrating 'use object with everything you can think of' gameplay, overly obtuse puzzles, breaks off before delivering on story.It may be that I'm getting old and no longer have the patience for puzzle games, but I can't help but feel that Broken Age's strengths are the fantastic story, art and characterization, and that the puzzle mechanics actually get in the way and detract from that experience (I had to resort to a walkthrough a couple of times, which broke the immersion somewhat) and there are a few sections of the game that feel a bit rushed or, rather, too hastily progressed through.The cliffhanger ending will hopefully be resolved in part 2, but as it stands it can feel a little unsatisfying as there's no real resolution provided for the situations the characters have created.Those points aside, it's still an interesting experience and one I'm glad I had.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2016
												As much as I really wanted to like this game ... well ... it doesn't keep up with the promises it took in any way.Let me tell you why:The whole storyline evolves around two main protagonists and thus for is splitted in half by the game design itself. Too bad they didn't use this opportunity to implement some nice coop style riddles and things. There is not one single point in the game where one player does something and the the other has to work at least with the outcomings of these actions.But it does get even worse: I won't spoil you, but in fact there is one (or two) moment just before the end of the game (a point where there have been so many obvious opportunities to do coops or at least interesting crossovers in the story - sadly noone of them do happen - and so you as the player are quite disappointed because the game was hyped by tellling to do so), where you can see information in the story part of one of the player, that must be used by the other player. And now listen closely: The two never exchange this information. The only one that knows this is the viewer / player. How illogical can game design become?Apart from that this leads to a "riddle" where you have to repair droids by making connections in their electronic brains. Here you connect two pins with cables multiple times for both droids. But noone tells you that it makes a difference what end of the cable is connected first ... :O ...  A behaviour one most likely would excpect like for e.g. on his or her everday Computer / HIFI / Telephone system in real life ... OR NOT ?!? ... :/I even mentioned this behavior one or two times while doing the adventure game typical "use everything with everything actions" using items in the inventory, where the action only takes place when the objects are selected in the proper chronological order ... GOSH ... Do you have any idea how far I have to go back to remind myself when (back in time) I was happy because this behaviour of adventure game systems seemed to hopefully never happen again in commercial games? Let's be fair and say it where the 90s ...So far for some of the technical limitations of the game's design and engine.But the TOP MOST ANNOYING thing about this game and THE MAIN REASON why i just can't like it is the overall theme of the game: it is made for depressive, psychotic, self-murdering, apathic, social-incompetent players with no friends during their whole lifes whatsoever ... reminds me of people like my neibhbours here, that where happily giving comments during the strangest psycho sequences this game has to feature, thus being possible because the walls here are too thin - and that's is the only bad thing I encountered while playing this game, that's not the game's fault ...To come to a finish: You may have fun with this game if you enjoyed games like "Edna", "Deponia" or "The whispered World". Strange depressive games made for psychotic people.You will not have fun with this game if you had the luck to enjoy real adventure games that don't want you to start hurting yourself like "Monkey Island", "Flight of the Amazon Queen" or "Beneath a Steel Sky" ... my oh my ... you can get the latter two ones for free to play on Scumm legally. And you should do it now (The last one being a perfect example on how to handle sarcarsm or bad themes in a game) and forget about this very game here.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												I changed my mind. After mulling it over I can't really recommend this game. I loved Psychonauts and all things DoubleFine, but to make me wait a yeat for this ending... it was asking a lot and failed to deliver. Don't get me wrong, I still enjoyed it and I can even manage to gloss over a lot of odd and unexplained story to that end. The puzzles, however, are suprisingly annoying and aren't really interesting or mentally challenging (like Myst or Talos) but are more about guessing and hunting hown every object until you've found it or cheated or killed yourself. One 'puzzle' is just randomly knowing to wait in one spot an arbitrary amount of time! Plus they make it so that characters solve puzzle they couldn't possibly solve without somehow knowing what the other character was doing even when that isn't possible... I dunno. Like I said, it was fun: just don't pay full price (or even anything ove $10) or expect anything too too deep. I did enjoy the art and the music and the voice acting... just not the story or the puzzles or the actual content. Besides that I played through the game one and a half times with no intention of ever playing again and it just isn't worth buying so little entertainment.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												After completing Act 1.This game is good. Nothing groundbreaking, nothing incredibly innovative (except for the fact that it started out a kickstarter gaming boom, but that's another story).This game is a very solid experience for adventure-type-game lovers all over. You follow two separate storylines of a yound girl and a boy set in completely different environments trying to find solutions for the problems that arise. The gameplay part of it seems incredibly basic, you won't be wondering around much trying to figure out what to do. Most of the time spent in the game is listening to well written dialogue and experiencing neatly animated cut-scenes.Characters, story and dialogue is a strong part of the game. You will most definitely enjoy witty humour of wordplay and voice-acting. The animation style is quite unique and was very much to my liking, easy on eyes, weird enough, pretty enough.Though I think the game is a bit on a short side (even considering it is supposed to come out in 2 parts). 4-5 hours for 1half - that's ~10 for the whole game. Also I don't like it being episodic and having to wait to leard what happens next. The game is completely playable as it is though and does have an ending.Overall I am very glad that I've kickstarted this and I am waiting for act2 soon! =)

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												When I backed Doublefine's first Kickstarter I believed they'd make a good game, maybe a great one. But what they delivered is absolutely stellar. Starting from the heartwarming story of two people on their path to freedom, the gorgeous storybook art style, the catchy music to the voice acting, this game didn't let me go from the beginning. I am on my second playthrough and I still discover new things.The downside is that only the first act is available at the moment which will give you roughly 4 - 5 hours of gameplay. But I'd rather play a short and lovingly designed game than 90 hours of shooting random mobs in the face or punching orcs in the balls in some dungeon that looks like all the other fifty ones you have already visited.If you like story-driven point'n'click adventures look no further. Do yourself a favor and grab this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												Breathtakingly gorgeous, and with a hilarious flair that Tim Schafer is known all too well for, Broken Age is a love letter to the classic point-and-click genre that is so rarely ever acted upon in this age of gaming. Growing up playing games like this such as ToonStruck and Grim Fandango, I find a heartwarming and euphoric sense of wonder washing over me with every click of the mouse. The dialogue and story is reminiscent of the days where well-written plots and stellar (not to mention gut-bustingly hilarious) character interaction was a keystone in gaming, which seems to find less and less of a foothole in many modern blockbuster games. Double Fine has always excelled at creating games that have a personality, and Broken Age is no exception. With a terrific ensemble cast of voice actors, a beautifully executed art style, and a charm that only the folks at Double Fine and the creative genius of Tim Schafer could produce, you're looking at one of the best games of the year. Don't pass this one up folks.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												This game is absolutely beautiful. Just look at those hand painted graphics. The orchestral score will melt your ears with how good it is. The puzzles are excellent and streamlined in such a way that you don't need to rub every single item together to find the solution. If you get into the right mindset, you'll be able to follow the game's own twisted logic easily. But as with all adventure games, story is king. It may start off slow but trust me, the story is incredible and will twist and turn in ways you could never expect. The humour is spot-on (as with all Double Fine games) and often had me grinning like a lunatic.There's only one minor caveat and that is that the game only offers 4-5 hours of gameplay. Of course it's only the first act of 2 so I imagine you'll get another 5 hours when Act 2 releases later in the year. It's up to you if you think playing 2 halves of a game months apart is feasible. Personally, I think I'm going to have to invade the Double Fine offices and hide amongst Tim Schafer's Rubiks Cubes because I HAVE TO KNOW WHAT HAPPENS NEXT AND I CAN'T WAIT THAT LONG.4.5/5 - Highly recommended to long time adventure fans and newcomers alike.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												This is Tim Schafer at his best. Focusing on imaginative worlds and characters. Both managing to right off the bat hook my curiosity, and through at least Act 1 maintaining that interest. Though Tim doesn't work alone of course. Double Fine is this rare company that can produce these games that makes me genuinly laugh. Partly thanks to the solid delivering of the dialogue by a quite renowned cast. I personally appreciate this atmosphere being literally painted in Broken Age. A style along with the music and surprising sound production making it all very cozy and welcoming, but occasionally tainted with a hint of darkness. Along that line of contrasts, the sun has its spots. A Double Fine game is not complete without its issues, though thankfully seldom of a game breaking level. Broken Age has quite a bunch of frame drops, and sometimes the layer sorting of the beautifully rendered art goes awry. Worst part of this all? The wait for Act 2.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												If you are looking for a beautiful experience, read no further - this is something you HAVE to play.  If you are driven by challenging puzzles and game mechanics, read on.Broken Age is a escape into nostalgiaI in more ways than one.  I took my time with this, which is how I feel it should be experienced.  I am sure I would have been disappointed if I raced through.  However, taken in spaces of 30 minutes to 1 hour at a time (which is often all I have), it provided an escape into another world and another time.  The beauty of the story and the world is transformative, it was a joy to experience this first half.I have rarely experienced a game that has had such an authentic impact on me.  Usually the experiences are much more superficial (though enjoyable).On a purely objective level, there is room for criticism with the "game" mechanics so far.  As an inquisitive/exploring player I stumbled upon most of the solutions with little effort.  I am keeping an open mind, however, as there is still more to come. For me, the experience more than outweighed the lack of challenge.  I believe this will be the case for most people, and I encourage anyone even leaning towards purchasing Broken Age to give it a try.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												Act 1 of Broken Age has lived up to everything that I could have hoped for. Voice acting, music, story, everything about this game I simply loved. For someone who has been craving and jonsing for a great point and click adventure game this game properly filled all my needs and desires. My only complaint is that it is only half a game right now. I need the other half. I want to flail around on the ground like a horrible child because life is just too horrible without it. Sure it'll be out "later this year," but I have no idea when that is. I also purchased the soundtrack, and have listened to it a couple times. I would recommend if you like Peter McConnell's other game scores.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												Put simply, the game has a great art style, interesting narrative (albeit, somewhat derivative of recent works) and doesn't often play the humour just for silliness sake. That is to say, the humour is present, but not in your face or overly slapstick. The issue appears with the puzzles. Unfortunately, whilst the point and click puzzler is a cult favourite, the actual style of puzzle is very important. My experience of Broken Age is to unfortunately use puzzles that aren't so much requiring of intelligence, but knowing a specific set of steps, one mistep of which puts you back to square one. Those are the most laborious, because it doesn't require the player to "reason it out", it requires them to know a precise sequence, or learn it by trial and error. Not great fun, and has frustrated me a few times in a playthrough.Still, overall positive impression, but I'd only recommend it to fans of the genre.

And try every choice of the dialogue, it won't affect the storyline.physical engine: I found it fluent and easy to haddle.Looking forward to the next chapter. A little expensive for only one chapter even at discount.

												I was really quite disappointed with the level of gameplay to be honest - as some of the other reviews have said, there is quite a lot of 'filler', i.e. cut scenes and the level of player interaction was rather boring, stayed and dull.  I do think however this would have come over better on the iPad and this review is for the PC version only of course.I think tbh I have been a bit spoilt playing The Cave which is an excellent game by the same company.

												What a horrible adventure game. I've been playing adventure games since the early 80's and this is surely one of the worst.The first act is okay. The puzzles are almost non existent, which judging by the quality of the puzzles in the second act is probably a good thing.It's obvious that Tim Schafer couldn't design a good puzzle if he was paid a million dollars per puzzle. The puzzles in the Cave were horrible and Act 2 of Broken Age is more of the same. Time to retire Tim, you're a  washed up game designer. In fact your latest games are so terrible I suspect that you have claimed credit for past classics that you weren't entitled to.
